editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: BACVLVM GEODAETICVM, SIVE VIATICVM. OR The Geodeticall Staffe, Containing eight Bookes: The Contents whereof followe after the Epistles.
Newly deuised, practised, and published by Arthur Hopton Gentleman.
AT LONDON, Printed by Nicholas Okes for Simon Waterson, dwelling at the signe of the Crowne in S. Pauls Church-yard. 1610.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE, ROBERT EARLE OF SALISBVRY, KNIGHT OF THE MOST HONORABLE ORDER OF THE GARTER, VIScount Cranborne, Lord Cecill of Esingdon, Lord high Treasurer of England, &c. Maister of his Maiesties court of Wards and Liueries, Chancellor of the Vniuersity of Cambridge, and one of his Maiesties most Honorable priuy Councell.
div.p:
NO man right Honorable, findeth a precious stone, bearing the splendor of any rich margarite, but straight hasteth vnto the best lapidiste, whose happy allowance thereof begetteth a rare affectation, and inestimable valew of the gem: so standeth it with your Honour, the curious Lapidiste of our most excellent wits, to whose touch euery refined tong offereth the quintessence of his best inuentions. And therefore some, whose industries haue laboured in the treasury of Diuinity, some in the necessity of humanity, some in the delectation of
the Politicks, some in the affectation of the Oeconomicks, some in Philosophy, others in Poetry, haue all brought the depth of their golden studies, to bide the touch of your noble allowance: so that after-ages may rightly admire what noble Mecoenas it was that so inchayned the aspiring wits of this vnderstanding age to his only censure, which will not a little magnoperate the splendor of your well knowne Honour, to these succeeding times. Which seeing, & hauing found this sparke of the Mathematicks, neuer yet seene before, am bold to craue your noble approbation, that it may goe (though vnworthy) amongst the rest of those worthy Iewels, that already haue past the proofe of your singular iudgmet: So shall we haue great hope, that the radiant beames of your resplendent wisdome, fauorably shining a little hereon, in short time wil reuiue the Mathematicks (the Phoenix of Arts) from the ashes of obliuion, that they may sit in this kingdome amongst the sweet inuentions of the age, and in our owne language sing forth the eternall glory of learning, as well as in other nations it doth. Euery Muse (noble patron of vertue) hath long since found a double-topped Pernassus in England to solace vpon, saue onely Vrania; euery Muse hath her delicious Helicon to sport in, saue only Vrania; euery muse hath sipt of the sweet Nectar, saue onely Vrania. Erato hath wonne a
crowne, Vrania wants a garland: then let me humbly implore your Honour, graciously to protect the fruits of this estranged Muse vnder the shadow of the sweete branches of your neuer decaying glory, which is all-sufficient to infatuate and annihilate each viperous malediction of the enuious Pierides. I know there be bookes extant treating of the art of measuring ground of, which a part of this booke also consisteth; but they be lame and defectiue, euen as a number of our surueyors be, that thrust themselues into businesses without ability to performe: wherefore I haue endeauored (my good Lord) as well to redresse wants in the one, as replenish art in the other, not doubting (seeing it becomes so requisite & necessary a faculty) but to make the serious student able hereby to benefite his country and common wealth very much.

Lastly (to cease troubling your Honour) if the dedication of bookes in any part may giue acknowledgement to great men for peculiar fauors and many singular graces shewen, then doth duty bind me obsequiously to remunerate your honorable fathers respect of our name and poore family, to whom my ancestors were, (and of a necessary consequence, my selfe to your Honour am) euer obliged. And vpon that foundation I builded the hopes of this presumption, which if it proue firme, shall animate me hereafter, to
aime to reach in some higher straine the Diatessaron of your memorable vertues. Thus in seruice at command, in duty bound, and in prayer continuall to the Almighty for your good Honour, I end, resting

closer.signed: In all humble duty at your Honours commaund, ARTHVR HOPTON.

div.head: To the beneuolent Reader.
div.p: THe opinions be manifold, and the instruments multitudes, gentill Reader, that the diuersity of pregnant wits haue brought forth in this age, and euery of those instruments serue for some singular conclusions; but I happely finding the contriuing of an instrument not bound to any particulars, but free, apt and generall, so that he is most fit to worke, most facill in working, and most easy to cary; out of my loue to those that long after these arts, I could doe no lesse then commit it vnto their reading, hoping as my intent was to benefite them with my labours, so likewise they will graint a fauorable vouchsafe to requite my paines, and that is all I seeke; which finding, I will answere then that this booke shall teach them to seeke dimensions, both Astronomicall and Geometricall, to platte and measure grounds, both Arithmeticall and Mechanicall, in such a compendious method, that the vnlearned neuer trained in the studies of these artes before, may with admiration accomplish those things that learned men haue passed ouer the moety of their liues to find out. And if this instrument please you not, you may turne further, and looke vpon the Topographical glasse, an instrument no lesse singular and commendable then the former, and for your practise whereon I haue set downe many Topographicall and Geodeticall conclusions, which because I aime to sute you with varieteis, behold the vse of the Theodelitus, the circumferent • r, with a reformation of the plaine Table, comprehended all vnder the title of the Topographicall glasse.

And since euery one that writeth a booke of any materiall consequence, disputeth first, and shewes what necessary commodity may accrew to the reader, lest other wise it be held impertinent and nothing commodious for the common wealth, (the aduancement whereof, all men are bound in Christianity to tender;) it shall therefore nothing distaste, briefly to remember the same. First then enqure of the Souldier, a chiefe defendant of his country, if he be not taught hereby to dispose of plats, castles, forts, citties, and such like, to appoint places conuenient for the campe, & to proportion euery part according to the number of men and horse: let the Politician speake of proportions, and allowances, let Architectors speake of plattes and symmetries, let the the pioners speake of conducting mines and vaults vnder the earth, for the blowing vp of citties, forts and castles; let the Nauagators speake of true directions in the vnknowen path of the seas, yea let all men speake of what vocation soeuer, and they shall find diuersity of matter, as well to exercise the head, as recreate the wit. Amongst many, I will shut vp this argument with the Geodetor or measurer of land, whose antiquity is great, as we may perceiue by Zachary, Chap. 2, questioning with a man that was meating Ierusalem; and whose commodity is no lesse great then ancient, as may appeare by the exundation of Nilus in Aegipt: for when al the bounds and limits of euery seuerall mans particular was drowned and buried in the slime and mudde remaining after the recourse of the floud, by the true direction of this science, euery man was allotted his proper quantity of ground in the same proportion it was before. Then let none grudge if we teach them the mystery and hid secrets of so necessary and rare an art, so beneficiall for man and so requisite in a common wealth, so conuenient to be knowen of some, and expedient to be credited of al, teaching nothing but truth and certainties, approued by inuincible grounds of infallable Geometricall demonstrations; and therefore we will not stagger to inserte it, as an associate to iustice, one of the foure cardinall vertues, whose office, as Ambrose saith, 1 de Officiis: Quae nihil alienum vendicat, quae cuilibet
dat, quod suum est, quae negligit propriam vtilitatem, vt seruet communem aequitatem; Et secundum ipsum, prima iusticia in Deum, secunda in patriam, tertia in parentes, quarta in omnes. For what else doth this art of Geodetia but teach directly cuilibet dare quod suum est, to giue euery man his owne? as well the Lord as the tenant, as well the buyer as the seller, as well one man as another: it brookes no deceit in exchange, no oppression of the poore, no wrong to the Lord, but aimes in all points to giue euery man his own: & therfore the office of a iust & skilful Ge • de • or, is a perfect glasse, wherein as a true mirrour we may behold a number of other vertues although some will say, they be bad members grant (in this as all other faculties) some be, shall a particular subuert the generall? A particulari ad generale, non est tenenda ratio: for we meane none of those that in base bils like players, paisted vpon postes, impudently affirme, they will suruey any Manour, and find it more then formerly it was sur
• eyed to be, such paltry bils I saw my selfe in London some three or foure yeares since, much disgracing the arte: for either they must affirme they may lye by arte, or else can enlarge the true bounds of the Manour by art. But the first platte beeing truly taken, this assertion must needs be false • but I can no more blame them to auouch this in their bils, then they are to be condemned for the paisting of them vpon euery post: shall we now turne the M • thematicks a begging? where is Alphonsus, Aristarchu • , Archimides, or some of the noble pr • fessors? if this bold, it is time to make the painters correct their Tables, and take the Globe out of the king Ptolomies band and there place a poore
• iquis, such as forlorne foreci • ers vse to haue in Pauls Church. We call the Mathematick the liberall sciences, because they should be freely taught, or for that they be most fit to be studied by great men, that haue large purses & riot wits for indeed these kind of artes he both chargeable, and difficult. But now for soath, he that can but get an old plaine Table, and measure a meadow (how vn • rue soeuer) is a Geometritian, though by profession a homely Carpenter or rude
Mason, and he that can but find the ordinary place of a planet in an Ephemerides, is an Astronomer, though otherwise a poore tradesman, of wit scarce enough to get his owne living; thus is art troden downe with presumption, and the world possest with errours. I haue heard diuers assertions and childish assumptions of such artlesse fellowes, though my selfe being vnknowen to them; some will produce you a pretty small brazen instrument forth of their pocket, and will affirme with that to goe into the middest of any field, and presently tell how many acres be in the same before he stirr • , neither will he vse the helpe of any cheine: which is nothing but meere foolish surmises and rude presumption, as farre out of their ability to performe, as they are from the vnderstanding of the art, possessing the world with impossibilities and boasting affirmations. I confesse by Art such a thing may be performed, so the medowe be plaine, and of a small quantity, but is not to be spoken in a generality, or as a necessary or speedy conclusion.

Now some there are that will abruptly say, this surueying maketh the poore Tenants haue hard bargaines, whereby all things grow scarce and deare. I answer, no: In what part of iustice is it that the Lord should be ignorant of his owne? doth his knowledge abridge his conscience? how then is ignorance the mother of transgression? is it not seene that many men of good conscience by ouer estimating their lands, let their Tenants more then hard peniworths? the randon is no scantell • can the tradesman set his friend a reasonable price of his merchandize, when he is both ignorant of the quantity and quality of the commodity he selleth, whenas! knoweth both? the vsing of his friend relleth in the goodnesse of his conscience, so is it with the Lord and Tenant, and that the measuring of grounds should bring dearth, is as false as the former. For if the tenant will couenant with the Lord, that he shall haue all commodities at the price they were in yeares past, the Lord will likewise promise the Tenant the like rate of his lands; but if all things grow to a farre higher rate then formerly they were, shall onely land be bound to rest at the old stint? shall euery
tradesman inhaunce the prizes of their wares, and onely the reuenews of gentlemen be rated? must euery one haue free liberty to make the best of his owne, and onely Landlords apportioned? It is a peeuish obseruation and foolish lenity so to doe, & is a principall cause wherfore so many tradesmen creepe into the ancient possessions of Gentlemen; yet notwithstanding it is most requisite that the Lord vse a fauorable improuement, for so to doe is acceptable before God and man: and therefore the Geodetor ought to yeeld a conscionable & true information to the Lord. But gentill Reader to conclude, let sparing reproofe assure me of kind acceptance, and then haply I shall be induced the rather to publish the flowers of the Mathematicks, not yet finished, with another instrument called Clauis Mathematica or the key of the Mathematicks; for that it vnlocketh as it were all Mathematicall questions, laying them in a plaine method open vnto thy view; the meane time I rest ready to doe thee any fauour I may,

div.head: Ioannes Passy in Artibus Magister, in laudes huius operis.
div.l: STemmata quid prosunt, seriem referentia longam?
Quid genus antiquum nobilitate potens?
Si non quae scriptis ornet stirpem generosam,
Verturesque virum, dextera doctaforet?
Est domus Hoptoni (fateor) per saecula durans,
Virtute exultans, & sine tabe virens:
Quae nunc Arthuri vigili decorata labore
Emicat, & florens tollit ad astra caput.
Agricolae, Mercatores, Nautae, Medicique,
Et genes omne hominum sedulitate tua
Debebunt Arthure tibi, dum voluitur axis
Aethereus dum Sol splender, & astra micant.
Desine liuor edax benefacta reprendere dictis,
Et bene promeritis gloria digna sonet.
Ingenium Phoebus, Pallasmi contulit artes,
Iuno decus, laudes vita polita dedit.
Arthure ô foelix viuas ter Nestoris annos,
Accedat laudi viuida fama tuae.

div.head: I. P. Mag. artium, in laudem huius operis Arthuri Hoptoni Generosi
div.l: OVi legis Hoptoni perscriptum nomine librum,
Perlege sincere, consulito que boni,
Multa fauente Deo, permulta volumina posthac,
Confecturus erit, dummodo vita sinat.

div.head: In Laudem M. Arthuri Hoptoni Mathematici.
div.l: VVAke gentle Muse and giue me leaue a space,
Inspire my wit with thy all-quickning grace:
Direct my pen to paint forth Hoptons name,
whose merits doe deserue immortall fame.
Immortall fame and honor of our time,
Whose kinde endeauours doe our art refine:
Teaching proportion Mistris of each art,
Vpon the stage to act an vnknowne part.
An vnknowne part, for neuer did I heare,
That Stagerite in arts high Theatere,
Breathing darke grounds from aphorismes strange,
Could acte a scene, so frought with pleasing change.
Thou rarest man, and more then Englands pride,
Hast brought to passe what art before denide:
Hold on thy course, for euer shalt thou liue:
Thy bodies death, life to thy vertues giue.

div.head: Rogerus Stedinanus Capellanus reuerendi in Christo patris, Roberti permissione diuina Hereford.
Episcopi, & publicus praedicator, in laudem authoris & singularis industriae suae.
div.l: QVod domus Hoptoni, multis durauerit annis;
longaeui recolunt tempora long a senes.
Cognita praeclaram referunt insignia laudem:
antiquam resonant inclyta facta Domum.
Hoptoni de Hopton vigeat celeberrima fama,
Arthuri ac feriat sydera clara poli.
Laus sua iustitia celebratur digna fideli,
digna quidem meritis, dignaque fama fide.
Est inuenis vultu: diuino Pallas ab ore
profluit, & meritis inclyta fama venit.
Sydera describit notis distincta figuris:
dumliquidis lymphis aurea luna nitet,
Arthurus numeris numerabit tempora certis:
ordine cantabit sydera celsa suo.
Splendida perlustrat supremae sydera sphaerae,
somnigenis tribuens lumina magna viris.
Denique sancte Pater, specialem mitte fauorem.
vt faueat coeptis candida musa suis.
Coelestique libro scribatur vita beata.
inter & electos numina sancta choros
Prospera cuncta precor, sibi sint foelicibus annis,
postque suam mortem non peritura salus.

div.head: To Maister Arthur Hopton.
div.l: PYthagoras in teaching did maintaine,
When bodies di • de, their soules returnd againe,
And kept the minds that they were vs'de to doe,
Within those bodies they did run into:
And now I see his maxim true and iust,
Hath ben too long abused by the most:
For who shall with Iudicial eye ore-looke
The curious art composed in this Booke,
Cannot deny in Hopton to arise,
The soule of great Archimedes the wise.
Sweete Arthur, well deserust that princely name,
Which from the regall constellation came,
Arcturus bright, which in himselfe containes,
The very nature that in thee remaines.
And doubtlesse at thy blessed birth so shone,
That all the starres were dimd by him alone,
Whilst he about the Northen pole did glide,
As Lord comander of the heauens wide,
Distilling downe vpon thee without spare,
Ioues diuine nature and the God of warre:
As thou by wisdome mighst thy fame maintaine,
So well as with the honour of thy name,
Which hath ben long and ancient without doubt:
Witnesse the house from whence thou camest out,
And from whence each best Hopton of old time
By law of armes ought to deriue their line.
Then what apt ornament is't I might chuse
To feed the height of thy aspiring muse?
A crowne of bayes for Poets, not for thee,
Thy Temples scorne to beare Apollos tree:
A weath of starres, robes of immortall fame,
shall girte thy browes, shall clothe thy loued name.

div.head: The contents of each seuerall Booke.
div.p: 1 The first declares the composition, construction & definition of the Staffe, with certaine necessary Tables and propositions to be foreknowne.

2 The second containes the quantity of all measures both English and other, with Tables of the Iame, to seeke all kind of angles and their sides, & thereby to find all dimensions, as longitudes, latitudes, altitudes, and profundities with the ground thereof, also to worke as M. D. Hoods sector &c.

3 In the third Booke is set downe the vse of the hypsometricall scale, according to the doctrine of the best writers in that behalfe, to which is added many other propositions performed by glasses, &c.
4 In the fourth, is the large vse of the Geometricall Quadrant.

5 In the fifth, the vse of the Iacobs staffe with the making of a new kind of scale, and thereby to worke the rule of proportion, called the golden rule or rule of three, and to worke the same rule inuersed.

6 The sixt containes the art of Geodetia, or measuring of grounds, which is deuided into two parts, in the first you be taught to seeke the true proportion and symmetry of grounds, according as it lieth without the dores, with rules to know if you haue wrought true or false; also to reduce the hypothenusall lines to lines Horizontall, and to protract after a new order, reforming many errours formerly practised in platting grounds.

The second part doth teach you how to know the contents of any peece of ground how irregular soeuer, with Tables diligently calculated to auoid Arithmetick, as well to know the exact contents as to deuide or separate land, with rules to performe the same instrumentally; also to measure solids as stone, timber, &c. or superficies, as boords, glasse, &c. with M. Digges his Tables for that purpose; to seeke all kind of dimensions by protracting, the rare metamorphosing of all kind of figures, and finding of their proportions one to the other, with the theoricall ground of all these; also to make a Lord of a Mannour to expresse each seuerall Tenure, &c. newly & compendiously, with certaine notes requisite for all Geodetors to know, &c.
7 The seauenth containes Trigonometria or the doctrine of right lined tryangles, by Sines, Tangents, and Secants, with new Tables.
8 The eight, containes the vse of the spheare in plano, with the making of many kind of Dials onely by the staffe.

There is an other Booke called the Topographicall glafle yet to come forth, containing the large vse of the Theodelitus, Topographicall instrument, circumferentor, and plaine Table; teaching you also to describe countries, and to find the howre of the day and night, to know the altitude of the Sunne or any starre after a new order also to make a new kind of platte, and to take a suruey after another order, all which you may better see in the generall Table.

div.head: The Printer to the Reader.
div.l: For errours past, or faults that scaped be,
Let this collection giue content to thee:
A worke of art, the grounds to vs vnknowne,
May cause vs erre, though all our skill be showne.
When points and letters, doe containe the sence.
The wise may halt, yet doe no great offence:
Then pardon here, such faults that do befall;
The next edition makes amends for all.

GI, p. 239 l. 6 for to taker take, p. 252 l, 27 for omit ear. committed, p. 257 l. 22 for taking r. laking, p. 258 l. 16 for chargeth r. chensheth, p. 260 l. 2 for the side r. the site, p. 263 l. 25 for but tooke r. but take, p. 276 l. 21 for lines r. sines, p. 281 l 31 for F N r. F M, p. 285 l. 6 for B E be equall, r. D E be pa • alled, Ibid. l. 7 for P 29 r. P 30, p. 297 l. I for Regromiontanus, p. 298 l. 11 for G F r. G F, p. 299 l. 39 for finding r. flud, p. 335 l. 1 for F K r. Scheames or figures misplaced or omitted.

Fel. 55 l. 17 scheame in the 22 Chap. fol. 93 chap 17 scheame in the chap. 7 l. 4 fol. 151 pro 2 place the figure in the 3 pro. fol. 151 pro. 3 place the scheame in the 2, pro. fol. 165 scheame in the 24 chap. fol. 347 chap, 21 the figure in the chap 17 fol 360 scheame in the 357 fol.
Faults by the cetter.

These fault is be something generall and not well to be reformed by the Printer, as in the second broke their is many pictures of Castles, Treas, &c. printed in diuers scheames and there and else where, some letters omitted and others mistaken, which the discreete reader will best correct.

div.head: THE FIRST BOOKE OF THE GEODETICAL STAFFE, SHEWING THE COMposition and making, with the diffinition and explication thereof, and euery thing therein contained, with their vocables: also certaine Tables and propositions, necessary to be first knowne.
CHAP. I.
Of the framing, composing, and quantity of mettall or wood required to make the Geodeticall staffe.
div.p: TO set a part all circumstances in speech whatsoeuer, you shall therefore first prepare two rulers or neate peeces of siluer,What stuffe the staffes is of. bone, brasse or wood, which you please: Being wood, let it be such yt is firme, solid, and of a close graine, wel plained and truly tryed to 3. quarters of an inch broad, & a quarter and halfe quarter thicke, in each of these rulers must be two hollow chanels, Rabboth, or Transumes, as Carpēters call thē, they must be under hollowed douetaile wise, so that the two hollowed sides beeing turned together, there may be a concauity or hollownesse of a quarter of an inch square, representing this figure.

2 Then must you prouide a Ruler of like wood or stuffe,The graduator. made feite and equall to runne into the foresaid hollow chanell, so that the two hollow sides being turned together, and the Ruler put thereinto, the legs cannot bee opened by reason of the doue taile chanels.

3 Next must you ioyne these two rulers (which beare the hellow chanels) together, as you doe the Sector or Circular Scale or such kinde of Instruments,The center pin▪ and the Center pin that ioynes them
must be hollowe,The Center pin, sufficient to containe a strong screw pin, neither is it materiall whether these two rulers so ioyned together be left square, or made round.

4. This so contriued, there must be a Courser prepared, as B, which is a hollow socket of brasse made fit and plyant to moue along one of the rulers lately toyned together,The Courser. vpon the top of which Courser answering to the fidutiall edge of the Ruler must strongly be fixt a screw pin better then an inch long, as B A, so that this pin is allwaies moued iust ouer the fidutiall edge of the Ruler.

If this Courser bee made halfe round for the round legs, or square, for square legs: yet must it be cut ful of holes, to the end to sée the figures vpon ye legs through ye same, as you may perceiue by the figure. In the lower side, this courser must be placed a screw pin,The Comfer for square legges. as C to fasten ye courser at any place assigned, wt a thin plate of brasse (as ye order is) within ye said socket, for ye said screw pin to force against ye ruler.

5. Next must you haue a little square péece of brasse, the thicknesse of which must be equall to the thicknes of the third Rule or graduator: through the prece must be bored a hole,The square peces of brasse. as E equall vnto the bignesse of the screw pin A, so that the said péece may slip downe vnto the foote of the pin B, then through the fore side of this péece of brasse must bee bored another great hole, on the bignes of a large wheaten straw, as E, the centers of which holes F and E must be so farre sidewise one off the other, as halfe the thicknes of the Graduator E, standing equall be twixt the vpper & lower side of the péece of brasse, as in this figure: When these holes be bored, you may file much of the superfluous brasse away, prouided that it retaine the foresaid thicknesse.

6. Next vnto this must be fastened at the end of the third rule, a pin of brasse,The pin at the graduators end. equally to moue in the hole E, in the last figure. This pin at the one end must haue a screw for the péece of brasse A, in the 7. figure to screw on the back side, beeing put thorough the hole E in the 5. figure, to the end he may not slip out of the foresaid hole, but be fastened by helpe of the screw, the pin is L O, and to the and C must be firmely fastened or filed two lippets or cheekes of Brasse, K & M, to riuet the said pin fast vnto the graduator or third ruler, which being artificially made, it
will represent this figure.

7. Next must you prouide two neat péeces of brasse, with screw holes therein, iustly to fit the screw pin A B in the 2. figure, and L O before described,The screw peece of brasse. so that the hole F in the 5. figure being put on the pin A, and downe to the foote thereof at B, this said screw peece B beeing turned downe hard, and wrested thereunto, may stay ye peece of brasse, that he cannot mooue any way: they would be made in maner of the screw peece in ye deuiding compasse, representing these figures.

8 The sixt figure must be so contriued, that whether you turne the side K or M, they may either answere to the middest of the pin A B, so that which side the graduator foeuer be turned thereunto, the fidutiall edge thereof may alwaiss agree with the center of the said pin, the hole F béeing put on the pin A B, and the pin L O béeing put through E in the 5. figure.

9. Next must you prepars a staffe 4. foote in length, he must be bored hollow 2. foote and a halfe déepe, that the foresaid 3. rules béeing put together,The hollow staffe. they may be all thrée likewise put into the said hollow staffe, and then you must haue a sine top to goe on with a screw in maner of an Aqua vitae bottell, so the staffe béeing made round raper wise, and small to carry with ease, the ioyners worke thereof is finished. Then procéede vnto the graduator thereof: but because you shall be acquainted with the names and parts of the staffe thus set together, I will first shew you the destinition and vocation thereof.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the Definition, vocation or nomination of the Geodeticall staffe, and his principall parts.
div.p:
BEfore wee procéede vnto the diuisions & proiecting of circles and such like vpon the Geodeticall staffe, we will first lay open the seuerall parts thereof: if any man therefore deinaund what this Instrument is it may be answered, that it is an Isosceles Tryangle of two equall containing sides, coupled together in maner of a Sector, which doe open & close as an ordinary paire of compa • ses, euery degrée or part therin contained or imagined,
is so proportionally, congruently and artificially proiected thereon, that it performeth and containeth in dimention, the whole vse of any Geometrical or Topographical Instrument whatsoeuer, not onely by sundry new and rare waies of himselfe: but also after the selfe same method and forme, as those instruments are wrot by their seuerall Authors, for the Appellations of this instrument, hauing shewed you that it is a Tryangle, the rest followes.

list.item: 1The legges. The two sides of this Tryangle are distinguished by the right and left leg, and each leg hath his vpper and lower side, and each side hath his inward and outward side.

2The vpper side of the legges. The vpper sides of these two legs, inward & outward, beare equall diuisions, & are numbred by 5. 10. 15. 20. &c. from the Center towards each end, on the outer side onely.
3The sites. In each leg is placed an equicurrall sight, and to the sight in the left leg is fixed the end of the graduator, these sights serue to direct the legs vnto any marke assigned.

4. In each leg is a line drawne round about the same, & where this line and the fidutialedge of the legs intersect, there is a point called the point Respectiue:Point respectiue. because without respect vnto this point, the quantity of no angle can be expressed: therefore you must haue a speciall regard thereunto.

5Lower side of the legs. Upon the lower side inward of this instrument are set vnequall deuisions, onely vpon the right leg (as in the 4. pro. they be numbred) from the point respectiue towards the center by 5. as 95.100.105.110. &c. and serue to expresse the quantity of an Angle obous 90. degrées, see more Pro. 7.

6 To this Instrument also there belougeth a rule 4. square hollow on two of his sides,The Graduator. as in ye 1. propostriō. This rule is called the graduator, because of the manifold diuisions proiected thereupon, he is so fastened vnto the sight in the left leg, that by helpe of a screw, & screw pin he may be fixed at any angle giuen, and yet will moue, so that you may turne any side downewards you please,Pro. 4. so that he admitteth a triple motion: Uppon this graduator are proiected 4. maner of Diuisions.

7Degrees of a Circle. First are placed the degrees of a circle to 90 numbred from the end where the brasse pin is, towards the other end by 5, as 5. 10. 15. &c. and serue to expresse the quantity of any angle vnder 90. degrées.

8Equall parts of the Graduator. Secondly, are placed equall deuisions numbred as the Degrées of a circle, and serue to expresse the side of any Tryangle giuen,
and are placed in the hollow side of the graduator, the equall parts are such as be placed vpon the vpper side of either legs.

9 Thirdly, are placed the part of the Geometricall quadrant,Parts of the Geometricall Quadrant. proiected on the graduator, and are numbred from either end thereof towards the middest by 5, as 5. 10. &c. ending in the middest at 60. they stand opposite vnto the degrées of a Circle.

10Part of the Hypsometrical Scale. Fourthly, are placed the parts of the Hypsometricall Scale, in the hollow side opposite vnto the equall deuisions, numbred vpon the Graduator from either end towards the middest by 3, as 3.6.9. ending at 〈◊〉 in the middest.The center of the Instrumēr. Through the center of ye 2. legs, there is a hole called the Center of the Instrument, thorough which hole is a brasse pin to be thrust, called the Center pin, three inches long, as in the 5. pro. at this latter W.

div.p: The center of the graduator The screw pin that fastens the graduator vnto the left leg, is called the Center of the graduator.
In the right leg of this instrument, must be a little moueable sight to run in the hollow chanell which I call the right Equicurrall sight, so haue you the vocables.

The name of the Staffe, As for the name of this staffe, bee is called the Geodeticall Staffe, of the word Geodetia, which signifies a science concerning sensible greatnesse and figure, as hereafter I might rather haue called him the Mathematicall Staffe, in respect of this generality of worke but I gaue him this name in respect of his aptnesse to measure and plat ground, he hath the addition of Viaticum in respect of his portability or aptnesse to trauell with.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the Diuisions of the vpper and lower sides of both the legs, together with the Graduating of the two sides of the Graduator, and of the Triple motion he admitteth.
div.p: HAuing finished the instrument, as before, you shall deuide the opper side inward of both the legs in two equall parts.Diuision of the legges. thus: The legs beeing 2. foote and a halfe long, deuide each foote into 12. inches, and then subdeuide each inch into 8. parts (or more if you will) then draw parralell lines, and there place figures, as you be wont in such workes, numbring the said parts by 5. fromwards the Center, as 5. 10. 15. &c. (as before) the equal parts must be placed vpon the inward side of the legs, and vpon the outer side, numbred onely on the outer, as in the end of the 7. pro.

The equall Diuision vpon the Graduator. Such diuisions as these are placed vpon the Graduator, as in the 2. Pro. Du • tie. You must haue a care that ye parts be truely deuided, so is this kinde of Graduating finished, considering well the end of the 7. Prop.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
To proiect the degrees of a circle vnto 90. vppon the Graduator, and of the triple motion he admitteth.
div.p: The diuision of the Graduator for degrees of a Circle to 90. First take the length of one of the legs, which heere let B C represent, then making B C the side subtending a right angie, thereupon frame anSee the 6. Pro. Orthogonium Isosceles, that is, a right angled Tryangle of two equall containing sides, A B, A C, here represents then making A. the Center, with the length of A B or A C deseribe a Semycircle, then draw C A infinitly beyond A, vntill he intersect with the said semicircle at D so is C D the Diameter thereof, then deuide the said semycircle into 180. equall degrées, so shall each Quadrant containe 90. degrées: Now to proiect these degrées, vpon the graduator, take with your cōpasse the length of euery cord in the quadrant C B, and place them in the line C B, representing the Graduator, still keeping the one foote of your compasse in the point C.

I take the length of O N, C O, C P, C Q, C R, C S, C T, C V, which is 80. 70. 60. 50. 40. 30. 20. & 10. degrees, & then I put the figures vpon the graduator C B, as they bée here placed, so is the degrée of a circle to 90. proiected vpon the Graduator: here note that you must take euery degrée in the circle, though I haue put them downe in the demonstration by 10.20. &c.

Now to proiect the degrées from 90. vnto 180. do thus. Make C ye Center, and with the length of C B describe the arch B F: then kéeping the one end of a Ruler vpon the Center A, moone the other end from degrée to degrée, in the quadrant B D, noting at euery degrée where the ruler cuts the arch B. F: hauing • o done, you must new vnderstand that these degrées are to be proiected vpon the right leg of the instrument, and vpon the lower side inward thereof, represented by A Z: therefore first take the length of A B, Of proiecting the degrees to 180. vpon the leg. and place that from the Center of your Instrument towards the end of the right leg, and where it ends; make an apparant score or race round about the said right and left leg, noting the same with some marke 〈◊〉 vpon the outer side of both the legs, and where this line so drawne doth intersect with the
Ad • tiall edge of each leg, there is a point called the point respectiue, as in the second Proposition, Definition 4. hauing thus done, take the length, of A A, Point respectiue. and place the same in the right leg from the Center towards the point respectiue, as A S in the line A B: do so to A R, A Q, A L L, A P P, & place the same in the right leg A Z from A toward B, so shall A R be equall to A T, A Q equall to A Y, A L L to A D, and so of all the rest vntill you haue finished each degrée vnto 180, you may put ye figures thereunto where you sée best occasion. I hold the fittest place to be the hollow chanell in the right leg, because they may there bee séene best, so haue you finished all the graduations belonging vnto the legs, sauing those in the 7. Proposition: the graduator deuided as before, and placed vpon the leftleg,The triple motion of the Graduator. he admitteth a triple motion: the first is along the left leg from one diuision to the other, made by mouing his center: secondly, to make any angle with the least leg proposed, as in the second Booke, Chap. 26.

3. To turne any diuision on any of the 4. sides, you please, the Graduator towards the legs: all which are performed simply of themsel • es without the lette or helpe the one of the other, as you may •• due the Graduator along the left leg, and not alter ye Angle he maketh with the said leg, as in the 27. Chapter, Booke 2. or turne any side of the Graduator downeward, and not moue him vpon the left leg, or alter the Angle, &c.

div.head: CHAP. V.
The order of Proiecting the Geometricall quadrant, and Hypsometricall Scall vpon the Graduator, with the figuring of the hollow staffe.
div.p: The proiecting of the Geometricall Quadrant. DEscribe a Semycircle of the iust bignes of the former in the 4 Proposition, then place the quadrant therein thus, deuide the arch B into two equall parts at D, and from D let fall 2. perpendiculars, the one vpon the line A B at E, the other on the line A C at F, then deuide the line D E and D F into 60. equall parts a péece.

Now it rests at your pleasure, whether you will place these parts of the quadrant vpon the legs, or vpon the Graduator, but in my conceit the Graduator is farre the better, by reason the diuisions be there more large.

Hauing therefore deuided the quadrants, as before, into 60. equall parts, lay a ruler vpon each part in the line E D and D F, and where it cuts the limbe make notes, and put figures thereunto, as in the figure, thē as in the 4. Proposition making C the center, where you still place the one foote of your compasse, take with the other the length of each cord or degrée noted in the limbe C B, which place vpon the Graduator C B, so shall you finde C F equall to C H, C I to C K, C L to C M, C N to C O, C P to C Q, C R, to C S, you may better perce • ue the placing of the figures by the demonstration then with many words, place these diuisions according vnto the second Pro. and 9. Deff.

Then for the proiecting of the Hypsometricall Scale vpon ye graduator,The Proiecting of the Hypsomericall Scall. the order obserued therein is nothing different from this of the Geometricall quadrant, onely where the sides of the quadrant were deuided into 60. parts, here the sides of the scale must be deuided but into 12. equall parts, and then proiect vnto the limbe, and from thence vnto the graduator, as before, as is plaine by the Seale.

In the Quadrant B D, so is B D the Graduator, deuide into twise 12. parts; the figure being, placed thereunto; as in the 2. Proposition, 10. Definition, the Graduator is finished together with the whole graduating of the Iustrument.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Now followeth the Staffe and his parts, with their application.
div.p: A B is the left leg, A C the right leg, G is the courser, and must run, and A B the hole: R in the figute F must go on the pin B in the figure G.

D E is the Graduator, the pin at the end thereof marked 〈◊〉 this figure 4. must be put through the hole P. in the figure F, & then the screw péece marked with 4. must be put on the end of ye said pin or courser, and then you may blunt the end of the pin so that the screw shall not come off, nor the pin come forth of ye hole P, letting the péece F alwaies hang at the end of the Graduator with the screw 4. H. is to screw on the pin B in the figure G. vnder which screw K the bellow pin is to be put vpon the said pin B, so that they may the better force downe F. W is the site for the center of the legs; A R is the right equicurall sight.
Q M and Q N are the points respectiue, which you shall finde to be •• st of like distance from A, as the length of A B is in the figures of the 4. and 5. Propo.

Z is a pin to place the new quadrant, or in the 6. booke on the saffe with, else not materiall. The péeces marked with these figures, 3. are two screw péeces of brasse to be buried in the top of the staffe, I L O is the hollow haffe, I is the top to go on and of l like an Aqua vitae stopple.

P P is a right angle made with a foote méete for the chanel in •• e of the legs and is to place the right or left leg to lie parrall • ll vpon any occasion, by hely of the plum or perpendiculer in the courser G. M is a screw pin.

In the figure W. the lower end N N should be hollowed some
small quantity as you may perceiue by the shadowed lines, to ye end when the pin is wrested hard, it may force the ioynt of the legs together, and so stay them at any angle: for if it were not hollow, it would stay vpon the riuetting put of the leg, which the lower end marked with B goes through.
F Is the legs closed with the Graduator therein, which beeing thrust home should be put all into the hollow staffe.

figure.p: Simulacrum Baculi Geodaetitii siue viatici: Astronomis, Astrologis, Geometris Medicis, Politicis, Oeconomicis, Cosmographis, Nauigantibus, & Mensoribus commodissimum, Tyronibusque facillimum: Per Arthurum Hopton de hospity Sancts Clementis societate conditum & editum. 1610.

div.p: A A Is the Graduation of the equall diuisions, which must be put 5. times vpon this instrument, one vpon the one side of the Graduator, and twise on each leg, as in the 3. and 8. Proposition.

B B Are chorde deuisions, and are placed 3. times vpon this Instrument, viz. once on the Graduator, as in the 3. Proposition, and once on each leg vpon the lower side outwards, as in the 8. Proposition, and as they be placed in the figure F.
C C Are degrees of a circle from 90. to 180. proiected vpon the right leg A C from M towards A.
D D Are parts of the Geometricall quadrant placed one by one, on one of the sides of the Graduator, as in the 5. Proposition.
E E Are parts of the Hypsometricall Scale, placed also on the one of the sides of the graduator, as in the 5. Pro.

These things so ordered, you must place of thrée Tables insuing vpon the outer side of the hollow staffe, which will serue you for many pleasant and necessarie vses; and if your Staffe be too small to hold the Table of the Sunnes altitude, as he may if you make the legges very small (as the vse is being in brasse or siluer) then may you omitte to stamp the minutes on the right hand, each row putting one degrée more vnto the degrées, if the minutes answering thereunto much excéede 30. and so may you place the Table on the smallest Staffe that is.

figure.p: The deriuation of all the lines in the Staffe.
The description of the Geodeticall Staffe and the parts thereof, which you may haue ready made by M. Reade and Iohn Tomson in Hosier lane, neare Smithfield in London.

table.head: The Table for Bord and glasse measure &c. called the Table of Planimetria.

div.p: A Table to be placed vpon the hollow staffe, seruing for the number of Timber measure, and therefore I aptly call him

table.head: The Table of Solidmerria.This Table was calculated by M. DIGS, and also the former, which are best to be placed vpon the backeside the legs, as ordinarily they be set vpon the Carpenters Rule, as is taught in M. DIGS his Tectonicon.

div.p: In the foote of this staffe, there must be a steele picke, and in the top, two péeces of Brasse, with a screw hole therein for the center pin, W to fasten A the center of the instrument therunto, yt on of these screw péeces, must stand in ye top of the staffe, ye other in the side, as neare to the top as you can, the first serueth to take angles of latitude, that which is in the side serueth to place the legges to take Angles of altitude, as will appeare in the second Booke. Propo.

div.head: PRO. VII.
A needfull Geometricall Proposition to bee vnderstood for the performing of the 4. Pro.
To make an Isosceles Tryangle where the line subtending the right angle is giuen.
div.p:
LEt B C bee the line giuen, representing the base of an Isosceles, then open your compasse vnto any reasonable distant (as somewhat more then halfe the length of B C, making then B the center, strike the arch O P, doe so to C, and make the arch M N, now these two arches shall intersect one the other twise, as at I. and K. laying a rule on those two points I K draw the line I A infitite beyond K, so is C B deuided into two equall parts at R, then place the length of R C or R B in the perpendiculer R A, placing the one foote of the compasse in R, and when
the other falles, make a point as at A. Lastly draw the line A C and A B, so is your Isosceles Tryangle made, A beeing a right angle in the Tryangle B A C. This Proposition I placed here for those that be but meanly read in Geometry, because yt should not be scaled in any thing necessary for the performing of this Instrument. Here I should proceede in opening further the termes of Geometry, which I will omit because it is growne something common, and also for that I haue collected them into one volume in my Epitome of Geometry, namely in the first part called Euthymetria.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

These former Tables orderly placed vpon the outer side of the Staffe, yet there remaineth other of diuisions, which are to be placed vpon the lower and outer sides of the legs, and vpon the vpper and outer side of the said legs, that is the chords of a circle to 60. and the equall parts, which shall serue for many pleasant vses▪ as hereafter.
The order of placing the Chords of a circle and equall diuisions, vpon the vtter side of the legges of the Geodeticall Staffe.
div.p:
The Chorde Diuisions. VVE will take the figure in the 4. Prop. but first prepare the staffe so that he may be apt for those diuisions: you shall first therefore at the point respectiue, make a marke in each legge on the lower side, halfe a quarter of an ynch, or thereabouts, from the fidutiall edge of the legges. Which done, draw a strait line from the Centre, direct to the two former points,
made at the points respectiue, then draw parrallelled lines therunto, to place the figures at, as the common order is.

Now for graduating the chords of a circle, on each legge, the worke is nothing different from the proiecting of the degrees of a circle vnto 90 vpon the Graduator, as in the 4. Prop. therefore the center of the Graduator, being placed at the Center of the leges, & the degrée of a circle being turned towards the legs, you might truly thereby marke out the chords vpon each legge, vnto 90. so will ye 60. degrées vpon ye Graduator, iust touch the point respectiue. Otherwise you may fetch the said degrée from the circle, with your compasse, placing them vpon the one of the legs from the center. The one legge thus deuided, you shall then deuide the other leg in the same order, putting figures thereunto, and numbring the degrées by 10. as 5. 10. 15. 20. &c. as you did vpon the Graduator vnto 90. You shall finde that these degrées will help you to performe many singular Propositions, as will plainly appeare in the 6. Booke.

Of the equall Diuisions. To place the chords of a circle vpon the lower and outer side of the legs, I bade you draw a line in each leg that should be produced from the Center, so that the said right lines might runne sloping wise a certaine distance from the fidutiall edge of each leg: I said halfe the quarter of an inch at the points respectiue, would suffice, and so it will; and here I let you to wit that the like sloping lines as these must be placed vpon the vpper and outer side of each leg, with parrallell lines drawne for the deuisions and figures, as you did for the chords; these sloping lines must be deuided according vnto 8. in the inch, and numbred by 5. as 5. 10. 15. 20. &c. they be the same diuisions that are placed vpon the vpper inward side of each leg, and are called equall diuisions, as in the 3. Proposition: and note if you please, you neede not set any figures vnto the equall diuisions on the inward side of the leg, because those on the outer will serue for both: onely draw parrallell lines producing the diuision at euery 5. and 10. notwithstanding if the roome will admit figures, stamp them there.

table.head: A Table containing the degrees and minutes of the Sunnes altitude for euery howre in the yeare, exactly calculated for the latitude of London.

div.head: THE SECOND BOOKE OF the Geodeticall Staffe, shewing the searching and speedie finding out of all Longitudes, Latitudes, Altitudes and Profundities, together with the Angles and sides of Tryangles (without the help of Arithmeticke, Protractor, Scale & Compasse, or any other cumbersome appendant whatsoeuer) as well Astronomicall, as Geometricall, and that after two maner of waies; both pleasant, speedie and necessary: also you are taught with facilitie to worke the Golden rule on the said Staffe.
CHAP. I.
Of the Art of Geodaesia, together with the maner of vsing of the Geodeticall Staffe, with the things therein to be considered.
div.p:
AS the Elements of Geometry serue to expresse the magnitudes in determined species or figures, and their diuerse affections by definitions & proposed theormes, wherby we haue the theoricall or contemplatiue part; so this art of Geodaesia doth explicate or adumbrate the vse of those propositions and theormes, certainly & by infallible grounds, in any materiall subiect, whereby wee haue the actiue and practicall part.Geodaesia quid. Therefore may we define Geodaesia to be all art, which doth search out the quantity of any materiall magnitude proposed to be measured, expressing the same to vs in a knowne measure; so that it is written, Geodaesia est ars, D. Ryff. quae propositae magnitudinis quantitatem nota quadam mensura inuenit. But the very emphasis of the word it selfe doth imply a proper application, in respect of our intended measuring of ground; for the word signifieth Terrae distributio, or Terrarum partitio: In Geodaesia du • consideranda • eniunt. and therefore we may aptly call the art of measuring ground, the art of Geodaesia. So now in this art of measuring two things happē to be considered, that is, the materiall subiect, proposed to be measured, and the instrumentall cause, by which it is measured. This
materiall subiect is considered as well according vnto his kinde and forme,De subiecto Geo. daesiae. as according vnto his adiuncts.

Genera magnitudinis quid, By the kindes of magnitude is vnderstood, whether or not ye thing proposed to be measured, be liniall or limamentall, and thereby whether an Angle or a figure? and if a figure, whether plaine or Solide? if plaine, whether a right line or a curued line? if right lined, whether a Tryangle or Tryangulated? and so forth, for it is a Geodeticall ground: Axioma Geodaeti. Omnis maguitudo cognomine mensurae genere mensuratur. So lines are measured by lines: for the purpose, it is required to know the length of London bridge, that is laid open by a right line, which doth equall the longitude of the bridge: but superfices are measured by superficies, as an aker is so many féete square &c. so likewise solids are measured by solids, as hereafter.

Now in the knowledge of these kinds of magnitude, the affection whereof doth offer it selfe to be considered, that is to say, whether or no the lines to be measured be right or oblique,Affectio magnitudinis. and in those liniaments whether the proposed figure be ordinary or inordinary &c. as whether the giuen tryangle doe answere vnto an Orthogonium, Amblygonium, or an Oxigonium &c. for you must note yt you may measure right lines by this geodetical Instrument after 2. Mensuratio. lineae duplex. waies, that is, either naturally or artificially.

The measuring of right lines naturally by this Instrument, is perfected by the cōgruency of the thing measured with ye measure it selfe;Naturalis mensislin. so a longitude 4. foote long (as the Staffe) is absolued by the appellation in measure of foure foote; so a yard being measured, is called thrée foote, or 36. inches, or 180. barly cornes, &c.

Artificiaelis Mens • lin. In vsu Baeculi Geodaetici duo consideraenda. But the artificiall measuring of things being most commodious, is performed by my Geodeticall Staffe otherwhere; wherein two things be occurrant or séeme fit to be preconsidered, that is, the aptnesse of the measurer, and the diuersitie or anomality of Tryangles, as in the 12. Chapter: but for the aptnesse of the measurer,Aptitudo menso ris. first he must haue a care that the sight be not infinite, that is, if the thing whose distance from you is sought, be not so farre off,Visus infinitus. that the eie cannot beare the visuall beames thereunto forcibly.

2 That you alwaies winke on the one eie; in so doing, the sight is made more strong and forcible for a long distance. vis nāque optica e duobus oculis in vnum cōducta, firmius collimat. Here we shall not néede manus quietae, Obductus oculus. as the Iacob, and such other staues require.

3 That your stationary line, or line that you measure,Linea Data. be not too short; for the longer your line is, the truer you worke; one 8. part of the distance is a good length: and note if the distance be a mile or 2, or 3. &c. neuer expresse your stationary line by feete or yards, but by pearches or scores, or such great measures, because there be not so many diuisions vpon the leg haply as there be féet or yards in the distance &c. though there may be as many score or pearches,M. Blagraue. yet you may make shift to help that by imagining euery diuision in each leg, to be subdeuided into 2. 3. 4. or 5. parts, and so procéed.

4 Let the angle betwixt the 2. stat. and the marke whose distance is required, be as neere vnto a right angle as you may, rather a little lesse then more: and as in the 3. note I shewed you how to increase the diuisions for long distance, so for short distāces you may reckon euer 10. for one, so in leuying one cypher from each number, your staffe is readily deuided.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of English measures, both old and such as be allowed by our statutes, and of the comparing of them together, with the difference that riseth betwixt any of them, in an aker of ground.
div.p:
I go about here to speake of English measures, because through the want of knowledge thereof many absurdities by the vnskillfull practitioners be daily committed: for some count the Italian miles and ours to agrée; some seeming to be more wise giue a little difference betwixt the same, which they say is not apparant or sensible, all which is a most palpable absurdity. For the true Italian mile containes 5000 féete,Milli. Italicum. and the true English mile containes 5280. feete:Milli. Anglicū. so that our English miles be longer then the Italiā miles by 280 féete: which I thinke is a difference sensible inough for any man of iudgement to perceiue. If some of our more then curious heads were no better perswaded of thēselues, they would neuer go about to affirme they can fetch you a true distance to the inch (nay I haue heard some vouch the barly corue) vpon their scale wt the plaine table Theodilitus &c, whē I haue smiled at their simplicities, seeing them maintaine such impossibilities: for how can they expresse the inch vppon their scale, when the 16. or 17. perhaps the 30. part of an Inch stands for apearch or mile? I will maintaine against such,Vnlesse they vse the scale in the 5. Booke, or lib. 6. Chap. 42. that vpon a scale of aboue
• 0. parts in the inch, they can hardly expresse a
distance vnto the yard, but for feare of digression, let v • ouerpasse such ouer-curious conceited Artists.

As many vse a false mile for our english mile, so diuerse vse false pearches,False pearches. when we haue one onely pearch allowed by Statute: for in some places in this kingdome, notwithstanding the * Statute prouided for the contrarie,Anno. 33. Ed. 1 they vse twelue foote in a pearch, vnto the great losse of the buyer, wherewith they bee accustomed to meate medowes,Tenant-right measure. calling it Tenant-right measure; of no word of art, but onely implying (as I take it) to be a right and proper measure belonging vnto Tenants: for so the word it selfe imports. Others more proper and agreeing vnto the nature of the said measure,Curt measure. call it Curt measure; likewise before ye said Statute (which many vnto this day vse) a pearch of 18. 20. and 24. féete,Wood-land measure. called VVoodland measure: all which differ from the true and allowed measure, in such sort as ensueth.

row.cell: One aker of 12. féete in the pearch, containes of Statute measure
One aker of 18. foote in the pearch, containes of Statute measure

cell.hi: Vsed in most places for wood-land measure yet.

row.cell: One aker of 20. foote in the pearch, containes in Statute measure
One aker of 24. foote in the pearch, containes of Statute measure

div.p: By this that is said, you may gather the diuersities of measures vsed by many, together with the great losse or gaine to the buyer or seller, according as the lesse or greater measure is vsed: but for the true measure which should bee measured through England, take it thus.

Thée barly cornes dryed,Compositio vlnarum perdicarum &c. Pearch. Day-worke. and taken out of the middest of the eare, make one inch of assizet 12. such inches make one foote; one foote and a halfe make a cubi • e: two cubits or thrée féete make one yard: two yards a fadome: 5. yards and a halfe, a pearch: one pearch in bredth, and foure in length make a day-worke: ten day-workes make a Roode (of some called Farthendell:) but more plaine the quarter of an aker,Rood, containing 4. pearches in breadth, &
ten in length, or 5. in breadth, and 8. in length, all is one: one pearch in breadth, an 160. in length, make anaker: or foure pearches in breadth, and forty in length, make a true aker;Aker. so that an aker by Statute ought to cōtain 6272640. square inches, which is 43560. square féet, 4840. square yards, or 160. square perches.
Againe for measures in longitude, 4. féet is an ell, 16. elles or 20. yards a score, 40. pearches a furlong, 8. furlongs a mile, as in the ensuing Table.

Fabian a Chronogapher writing of the Conquerour, sets downe in the history thereof another kinde of measure, very necessary for all men to vnderstand; foure akers (saith he) make a yard of land, fiue yards of land contain a hide,Yard of land. Hide of land. A Knights see. and 8. hides make a Knights fee, which by his coniecture is so much as one plough can well till in a yeare; in Yorkeshire and other countries they call a hide an Oxe skinne.

table.head: A new and true Table of English measures, according vnto the Statute.

div.p:
NOw I haue giuen you a perfect Table of our English measures, I will procéede vnto such measures as be vsed by the Geometritians, and men of other countries, to the end you
may both sée the difference thereof, and also apply your Statte thereunto, being occasioned by any meanes whatsoeuer.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the parts of Geometricall mensurations.
div.p: A Pian in his Cosmography saith, that measure is a finite or determinated longitude,Mensura quid. whereby is measured the vnknowne distance of places: but a late Germane Doctor, calleth all those measures that do not excéede the height of a perfect mā, P. Ryff. Francefur. mensurae minores, wherewith saith he, wee measure things naturally, setting aside arte: but those as exceede the ordinary stature of a man, he calleth mensurae maiores, which are composed of the lesse measures. And heere you shall note that the parts wherewith Geometricians vse to measure with, are called:
1 Granum hordeaceum, Paries mensura. a graine or corne of barly.
2 Digitus, Digitus. a finger containing 4. graines.
3 Vncia seu pollex, Vincia. an iuch containing 1. ½ fingers, but after Apian 3. fingers.
4 Palmus minor, Palmus. of Apian called palmus onely, containing 4. fingers.

5 Spithama,
P. R. Spithama. alii dicunt, palmus maior, aspanne, the distance betwixt the little finger and the thumb stretched out, which cōtaines 3. hand-breadths, or 12. fingers. Apian puts a measure called Dichas, after palmus, which containes 8. fingers.
6 Pes, Dichas. Pes. Sesquipes. a foote containing foure palms, or 12. inches.
7 Cubitus seu sesquipes, which is a measure of one foote and a halfe, or 6 palmes.
8 Gradus siue gressus, Gradus. a Gréese, a step, containing two féete, but with Apian 2 feete: otherwise it were all one with his passus simplex.

9 Passus, a pace,Passus Geodaeticus. two grades containing 5. geodeticall feete: but 〈◊〉
Apian this measure is called Passus Geometricus, Passus Geometricus. which he saith is used in Cosmometra.
10 Orgya, Orgya. a fathom, containing 4. cubits or 6. féete: here some make a diuision,Mensurae maiores. calling the measures henceforth, mensurae maiores.

11 Pertica siue virga, Pertica. a rod, a pearch, a pole, which among the Romanes was 10. foote, and so doth Apian take it: but with the Germanes now it is commonly taken for 16. feete, agreeing neare with our pearch.

12 Stadium, a measure of ground, containing 125. paces,Stadium. or 625. feete. There be three sorts of this measure,Ital •• ura. the first is that of Italie or Germany, as we haue spoked of alteadie: the secand Olympicum, of 600. féete,Olympicum. which is 120. paces: and the third is Pythicum, of 100. féete, that is 200. paces: of these Stadia, Pythicum. 8. make an Italian mile, containing 1000. paces,Milliare Italicum. euery pace béeing 5. féete.
I haue read of a difference betwixt Plinie and Diodorus, Plinie, & Diderus. Siculus, in the discerning of Sicile, which haply may grow by occasion of the diuersitie of these stadia.
Apian henceforth procéeding calles first,
13 Leuca, Leuca. a league, with some containing 1500. paces.
14 Miliare Italicum: the Italian mile hath 1000. paces,Miliare Italicū. or 8. stadia.
15 Miliare Germanicum, Germanleum. the Germane mile hath 4000. paces.
16 Miliare Germanicūmagnum, Germanicum magnum. hath 5000 paces, which they hold a sufficient iourney for a reasonable hodeper or traueller to go in two houres.
17 Miliare Germanicum commune, Miliare commune. the common Germane mile hath a 32. stadia.

And you must vnderstand that the Italians (which Apian called the Latines) and wée of great Brittaine, doe measure our great distances vpon the earth by miles, the Grecians by stadia, or furlongs, the French and Spanish by leucas or leagues; and yet they all differ in the length of their leagues:Leuca Gall. for the French league containes two Italian miles,Leuca Hispa and the Spanish league 3. Italian: Mag. Gorma. leu. Leuca Germa. yea in some places of high Germany their league is so long as a man can scarce ride three of them in a whole day, as in Sueuia, for the great league of Germany containes fiue Italian miles, which is nothing in comparison of the leagues neare Sueuia. Now the Egyptians measure the great space of the earth, by signes, the Persians by Parasangus,Parasange quid. which as I coniecture is a measure of ground containing 30. furlongs, but as some write, 50. furlongs.

Thus you fée the dinersitie of measures according vnto the custome of the country, but I maruaile how our yards &c. and the French & Spanish, so differ, séeing the originall of them both is all one: for as well they, as wée, haue 3. barly cornes allowed vnto one inch, and so forth, as in the second Chapter; and yet it is found that a French foote at Paris, is more then ours by one
inch, and the Italian foote to be longer then ours by 2. inches and neare a quarter; and yet their miles be shorter then ours, as in the second Chapter.Stophilerus. Some write that the Germane foode is lesse then ours by two inches and a halfe, so that the Italian foote by this account, should be longer then the Germane by 4. inches and neare thrée quarters: but I would with thée to apply thy staffe onely vnto our English measures before, vnlesse thou wouldest make any mappe or such like for other countries, or conferre former workes with thy owne, to the which end I haue wrote this Chapter, and set downe the ensuing Table.

table.head: A Table of the lesser sort of Geodeticall measures.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
Of Geodeticall Angles, and how to vse the Staffe in taking them.
div.p: THese angles which I call Geodeficall, be such as haue relation vnto things scituate vpon the earth, containing in them sensible greatnesse, and figure, in the vsing whereof,Angul. Geodael. wee attaine vnto the practicall part of Geometry: they be 4. in number, that is, Angles of Longitude, Latitude, Altitude, and Prosunditie, which indéed is but a reuersed Altitude.

div.head: PRO. I. Angles of Longitude.Angul. longitudinis.
div.p: ANgles of Longitude be such as be taken vpon plaine or hilly ground, lying before you in a right line, and be thus performed: place the legs vpon the side of the Staffe, & then bring the left leg euen with the hollow staffe, placing the said staffe perpendicular, by the 5. Chap. then moue the right legge vp and downe, vntill by the center pin, and the sight in the fidutiall edge thereof, you espy the marke whose distance from you is required: so is the Angle taken, which if you will expresse in degrées, repaire vnto the 5. Chapter.

div.head: PRO. 2. Geodeticall Angles of Latitude.Anguli geodaetisiae latitudinis.
div.p:
ANgles of Latitude, be such as bee taken in séeking the distance betwixt two Towres, Trées, Stéeples, or such like, wherein there is no regard to be taken of the perpendicularity, or the parallitie of the legs, or the staffe: but alwaies are placed at the pleasure of the Geodetor, or Mensor; you may choose whether you will place the legs vpon the top of the staffe, or hold thē in your hand only: the staffe is Manus quietae, the maner of their taking is thus: Turne the left legge towards the marke vpon your left hand, vntill by the top of the center pin, and the sight in the left leg, you sée the said marke vpon your left hand; that leg resting, remoue the right, vntil (likewise) by the ceter pin & right sight, you sée the marke vpon the right hand: the legges resting, you haue the quantity of the Angle, which if you will expresse in degrées or parts of the quadrant, resort vnto the 5. Chapter.
No otherwise areAugul. Astrono. latitudinis. Angles Astronomicall taken.

div.head: PRO. 3. Geodeticall Angles of Altitude.
div.p: ANgles of Altitude, be such as bee made in the taking the height of Turrets,Angul. Geodae. altitudinis. houses, trées, &c. Wherein it is conuenient that the left leg lie alwaies parallell vnto the Horizon, as in the 5. Chapter: then turning the right leg vnto the summite or top of the Altitude, looking by the sights, as before the Angle is taken.

Altitudinem stellarum inuenire. And no otherwise are Astronomicall Angles of Altitude takē: for there it is most requisite that the left leg lie alwaies parallell vnto the Horizon, and the right leg point vnto the Sunne or starre: but because you cannot looke vpon the sun it his beames be forcible, take either of these ensuing waies.

Hauing place the left legge parallell to the Horizon, the end thereof pointing towards the sunne,Solis altitudinē extrahere. heaue vp or put downe the right legge, vntill the shadow that the sight in the right legge yeeldeth, agrée with the fidutiall edge of the said right legge: so is the Angle taken; which to expresse in degrées, resort as before vnto the 5. Chapter.

Or if you had a square péece of red glasse placed at the end of the right leg, as Sea-men doe vpon the crosse staffe, then might you take the Altitude of the sunne, as you would of a starre, or such other thing: because his beames could not annoy you, be they neuer so forcible.

div.head: PRO. 4. Geodeticall Angles of Profunditie.
div.p: ANgles of depth, are such as be taken in measuring of vallies, welles,Profunditas. or any such other depth; they be but plaine reuersed Altitudes, as will better appeare when we come to treat thereof. In the taking of them, the left legge should ly parallell, and let him stand perpendicular, the end pointing downewards. What should I say further?Vide lib. 4. cap. 9. & 10. you sée they be but Visaversa, to Altitudes, as I haue said.

div.head: CHAP. V.
The legge of the Geodeticall Staffe, being opened vnto any angle to finde the quantity thereof in degrees.
div.p: A degrée in latine called Gradus, is the 360. part of a circle: into which portions, all circles Astronomicall, or Geometricall,Gradus. Circulus. are imagined to be deuided; and they make choice of that number, because of any so little a number, it will be deuided by most numbers.
Now for to finde the quantitie of an angle, you shall first vnderstand what the quantitie of any Angle is.

The quantity of an Angle is the portion of a circle included betwixt the two markes,Quantitas A •• gulor. whose distance is required: the center of which circle, is imagined to be at your eie, the proportion & semitry of which Angle is represented by the legges of the staffe: so that to finde the quantity of any Angle, is no more but to find the portion of the circle that is included betwixt the two points respectiue in each legge, which is thus had.

Place the center of the graduator vpon the Equicurrall sight in the left legge: then bring the same center vnto the point respectiue,Angulorum quantitatem, calculare. by the 4. Definition, in the 2. Prop. of the first Booke: and by the 7. Definition, turne the degrées of a circle towards the legges, the center of the Graduator so resting, bring the other end of the Graduator vnto the right point respectiue: then the degrées cut vpon the Graduator by the said point respectiue, is the true quantity of the Angle.

But it may so fall out, the Angle being greater then 90. that the Graduator wil not reach vnto ye point respectiue in the right legge: then must you note among the degrées, or vnequall diuisions, in the lower side the said right legge, where the very end of the Graduator cuts (the other end resting at the left point respectiue,) which by the 5. Definition, in the 2, Prop. 1. Booke, is the quantitie of the Angle.

LET C A B bee an Angle, whose quantitie is required, heere placing the Graduator in the left legge A C, at the point respectiue D, then mouing the other end of the graduator F, vntill the fidutiall edge cut the point respectiue E, in the right leg A B: so shall you sée the quantitie of the Angle C A B, numbred vpon the graduator, to be included betwixt the two points respectiue D E, videl. 57. degrées, which the right point respectiue E. cuts.

But if the féete be opened to the Angle C A M, then the end of the graduator F will not reach to L the point respectiue in the right legge A M, therefore mooue that end lower towards A, vntill the very aper, or end of the graduator touch among the vnequall diuisions in the lower side of the right legge, as at P, so shal you sóe the said end of the graduator, among those vnequall diuisions, point out the iust quantity of the Angle C A M, 104. degrées.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
To open the legges vnto any Angle proposed.
div.p:
BRing the graduator vnto the point respectiue, in the left leg: then if your Angle be vnder 90. degrées, bring the point respectiue in the right legge, vnto the quantitie of the said Angle in the graduator, so is the Angle made: but if the Angle proposed he aboue 90, degrées by the 3. Defi. in the 2. Prop. Booke 1. séeke
the said Angle, and thereunto bring the moueable end of the graduator, so is the angle made. I will make short of this Chap. because he is but visa versa vnto the former.
Before wée procéede any further in dimensions, wee will lay downe some fewe Astronomicall propositions, because they be desired by most, and make the Staffe more detectable to many.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
To take the height of the Sun, Starres, Comer, or any other thing aboue the Horizon in the heauens.
div.p: BY the Altitude of the Sunne or starres, is meant (not as the vulgar imagine, that is to say, how farre they are distant frō the center of the earth,De altitudine so • lis, & stellarum.) but how many degrées the said Sunne or starre is eleuated aboue the Horizon towards our Zenith, which is easily had thus.

Place the legges vpon the side of the staffe, so that the left leg lie parallell to the Horizon: then turne the right legge towards the sunne or starre, as in the 3. Prop. of the 4. Chapter is plainely set downe, so haue you the angle.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
The Altitude of the Sunne being giuen, to finde the howre of the day easily.
div.p:
HAuing taken the Altitude of the sunne, repaire vnto the Table vpon the outer side of the staffe,Horae inuentio interdius. which Table is also set downe in the 5. Chap. Booke 1. and there in one of the ten rowes, vpon the left hand amongst the moneths, find ye moneth, and day of the moneth (or the nearest thereunto,) and you shall vnderstand that all the moneths from the beginning of June to the end of Nouember, haue their daies set vnder them from 10. to 10. and all the other moneths from the beginning of December, to the end of May, haue their daies put aboue the moneth, counted from 10. to 10. or there abouts. Hauing found the day of the moneth, note the rowe wherein it stands, in which rowe procéede rightwards, going about the staffe, vntill in the Table answering thereunto, you finde the degrées & minutes, if there be any of the Sinnes true altitude before taken: and you must note, that the letter D in the top of the staffe, and the letter M placed in each Columne, stands for degrées and minutes, seruing
for all the rowes in each Table, as they stand vnder the said letters. Now the Sunnes altitude béeing found in the Table agréeing vnto the moneth, and then in the said Table answering to the day of the moneth, to finde the howre of the day, looke in the head of the said Table, inst ouer the degrées of the sunnes altitude, if your demaund were before noone, or in the foote of the Table, iust vnder the degrées of the sunnes altitude, if your obseruation were after noone, so will the howre of the day appeare: and héere note, if you cannot finde the iust altitude of the sunne in the Table, take the nearest by proportion, which by the 28. Chapter, you may worke as neare as you will.

Also note in some moneths, there be placed the 33.35.34. day of the moneth, as in June, July, August &c. which shew the 3.4. &c. day of the ensuing moneth: as in August there is placed, the 35. day, August hath but 31. daies, therefore it stands for the 4. day of the ensuing moneth, which is September.

The 12. of June I find the Sunne to be 53. degrées high, and 45. minutes: then resorting vnto my Table vpon the high outerside of the Staffe, I finde the said 12. day of June; and then procéeding rightwards in the same rowe, I find 53. degrées, 45. minutes, answering to which, in the top of the Table is 10. of the clocke, and in the foote, two of the clocke: but forasmuch as my obseruations were in the forenoone, I conclude it therefore to be 10. of the clocke before noone.

The 16. day of August, 1606. I finde the Sunne to be 40. degrées high, the nearest day to the 16. that I can finde, in the 13. day, answering to which, in the rowerightwards, I séeke 40. degrées, the height of the Sunne: but forasmuch as I cannot finde 40. degrées in that rowe, I take therefore the nearest thereunto, which is 43. degrées, and 11. minutes: then for as much as my obseruation was after noone, I séeke the howre in the foote of the Table, right vnder the degrées of altitude, as before, answearing whereunto is two of the clocke after noone.

Now if you desire to haue the iust and precise howre of the day, when the iust day of the moneth, nor the true degrée of the sunnes altitude cannot be found in the Table, worke by the 28. Chapter, making proportion according to the difference.
