Note, you may make a Cylinder by the foresaid Table, and place the same vpon the backe of your Staffe in steed of the said
Table, and so saue the stamping of so many figures,Gruntȳ Finei Delph, horologio rum, lib. 3. pro. 3 as you be instructed.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
To take the distance of any two starres vnknowne.
div.p: PLace the legges vpon the top of the staffe,To take the distāce of starres. and then resort vnto the 2. Prop. 4. Chap. of the Geodeticall Angles of Latitude, where this Chap. is performed in all respects.

I desire the distance betwixt Oculus Tauri, and Canis Maior; working according vnto the 4. Chapter, and 2. Prop. you shall finde they be distant 46. ¼ degrees: so and in like maner may you take the length of the taile of any Comet, or such other like impression séene in the airs; you shall alwaies finde the Comet and the sunne to be in one great circle,Cometa. he beeing opposite vnto the sunne, towards whom the taile of the said Comet is extended: from which reason, Cornelius Gemma drawes the foundation of his argument, when hee affirmes that there is no fiery Region, and that Comets, &c. are set on fire by the onely heate of the sunne: but the ancient Philosophers, affirme that a Comet is ingendred in the highest Region of the aire, being of a viscosious, or grosse, warme, and slimie substance,Cometa quid. apt to nourish fire, there kindled by the fiery Region, &c. But I runne heere from my owne intention into a new discourse, therefore I refer those inquisitiue hereof, vnto Aristotle. I haue drawne a Booke of Meteors my selfe,Liber. 1. cap. 4. Meteorologicorū;. not yet Printed.

div.head: CHAP. X.
To finde the howre of Sunne rising and setting, the length of the day and night by the Geodeticall Staffe.
div.p: HAuing found the day of the moneth as before, procéeding in that rowe, go round about the staffe rightwards, vntill you come vnto the last degrées and minutes of the sunnes altitude,Ortum & occasum solis, nec non arcum eius diurnum & nocturnum, siue quantitatem diel & noctis obseruare. that is placed there: then sée what howre is iust ouer the head thereof in the howres of forenoone, and that obserue for the howre of sunne rising. The howres in the foote of the Table, iust vnder the said degrees, is the howre of sunne setting, or a little after, according to the quantitie of the degrees.

Then if you double the howres of Sunne-set, thereof commeth the length of the day, which if you take from 24. you haue
the length of the night, as if the Sunne sette at 8 of clocke, that doubled is 16. the length of ye day, which taken from 24 leaueth 8. the length of the night.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
To find the Altitude of the north Pole by the starres, as neuerset, a necessarie Proposition for Sea-men.
div.p: Altitudinem poli ngnoscere diuersis modis sub nocte. TAke the Meridian Altitude of the said starre when he is iust aboue the Pole, and againe when he is iust vnder the pole, right in the Meridian, then adde these two Altitudes together, the halfe whereof is the Elevation of the Pole. In this working there must be alwaies iust 12. howres betwixt ye taking of the two altitudes: for so long will the starre be descending from the Meridian aboue the Pole, vnto the part of the Meridian vnder the Pole: Now if you take the Eleuation of the Pole from 90. Altitudinem Equinoct. supputare. there remaines the Equinoctiall height.

div.head: CAP. XII.
To doe the last Chapter another way, by the starres sette, or by the Sunne.
div.p: FIrst take the Meridian altitude of the starre, then learne the starres declination: if it be North, you must subduct the said declination out of his Meridian altitude, so haue you the Equinoctials height: but if the declination were South, adde the same vnto the Meridian altitude, so likewise haue you the Equinoctials height, which if you take from 90, you haue the Poles eleuation: for the latitude and the Equinoctiall height are alwaies one, the complement vnto the other, both making 90.

Altitudinem poli in die perscrutari. As in the night you take the Eleuation by the starres, in the selfe same manner may you finde the Eleuation in the day by the Sunne: for there is no difference at all, therefore I will make short hereof.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
The Latitude of any place beeing found, how to get the declination of the Sunne, or any Planet, Starre, or Comet out of the heauens, by obseruation.
div.p:
TAke the Altitude of the Starre or Planet, by the 7. Chap. then note whether the said altitude be more or lesse then the
Equinoctials height: if it be more then the Equinoctials height,Declinationem solis stellarū, & planetarum elicer • . then take the height of the Equinoctiall from the said Meridian altitude, the remainder is the declination of the said starre, which you may conclude to be north, because the altitude was greater then the Equinoctiall height.

If the altitude had beene lesse then the Equinoctiall height, you must haue taken it out of the greater: so should you haue had the declination which you must haue called south, because the Meridian altitude was lesse then the height of the Equinoctiall: but you shall finde some starres as neuer come into the south, for that they alwaies kéepe vpon the north side of the Zenith. The Meridian altitude of such starres may be twice takē, as in the 11. Chapter: for the declination of these, take the latitude out of the greater Meridian altitude, and the remainder frō 90. so haue you the declination: but if you will worke by the lesse Meridian altitude, take then the said altitude out of the eleuation, and that which remaines out of 90, so haue you the declination.

Or if you take the lesser Meridian altitude from the greater, and halfe the remainder thereof from 90. the declination also appeares: and take this generall to make vp the end of Astronomicall matters, that all those starres, whose declination is equal to the latitude, being both north or south, once in 24. howres, touch our Zenith, and those starres declining fromwards the Pole eleuated,Quae stellae orlantur, & o cidant, aut per ver ticem aut infrae horizontem semper m • uentur, manif • stare. whose declination is greater (neuer so little) thē the Equinoctials height (or complement of the Eleuation) are neuer séene in that country; and in like maner those starres whose declination towards the Pole Eleuated, excéedeth the height of the Equinoctiall, doe neuer sette, as Casiopaeia, Vrsa maior, and minor, with vs doe.

Such as neuer appeare vnto vs, be Ara, pars equina Centauri. the bottome of the ship, and Canopus, with the Crosse and Triangle to Constellations newly found out, the béeing whereof is doubted of many.

Let this suffice for matters Astronomicall at this time, hereafter it may be, I shall be occasioned to speake further: now we will onely haste to the Geodeticall vse of the staffe, for to finde the pralax of Comets, Planets, &c. and the distance from the center of the earth, is easie.

div.head: CAAP. XIIII.
Of the diuersitie of Geometricall Triangles.
div.p: BY the diuersitie of Triangles,Diuersitie of Tryangles. is not meant in respect of their quantitie, according as they be greater or lesser: but in respect of the sides or Angles that be giuen or required: for in all Geodeticall mensurations, you shall haue but two lines, and one Angle, or two Angles, & one line giuen; the other vnknowne lines and Angles be sought for, and may happen diuerse waies.
1 You may haue two knowne angles to stand at the end of a line knowne,Situs angulorum & linearum rectarum. as A B C, and B C A, at the ends of the line C B, knowne, as in the 15. Chap. or 30.

2 Or one of the Angles knowne, may be scituate at ye end of a line knowne, as C A B, at the end of A B the line knowne, and the other angle may stand at the end of a line vnknowne, as A C B at the end of A C an vnknowne line, as in the 18. and 19. Chapter, or 32.

3 For the second difference, where you haue two lines and one angle giuen, thus may they be scituate, either both ye lines knowne may containe the angle knowne, as C B and C A, doe the angle A C B, as in the 32. Chapter.

Or else the one line knowne,Vide chap. 34. may be the side of the angle knowne, as A C is to the angle A C B, & the other line knowne, may subtend the angle knowne, as A B doth the angle A C B, & this is the greatest diuersitie that may happen in any dimension vpon the staffe, as in the 33. Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
If a Castle, Fort, or armie of men, &c. be seene farre before you, how to fetch the distance of them from you with great speed, and facilitie, without Arithmeticke,

p.hi: being scituate at the ends of a line knowne, to find the quantitie of the 3. Angle, and the other two sides vnknowne.

div.p:
IT is a common receiued ground amongst all Geometricians, En. 32. p. 1. Ra. 9. cl. 6. that in all Triangular figures, the third angle is taken together,
are equall vnto two right angles, and two right angles make 180. degrées of a circle; therefore subtract the two knowne angles from 180. the remainder is the quantity of the 3. angle.Longitude. Now for the distance of sides of Triangles, worke thus: hauing a place assigned, whose distance is required, appoint two stations, in a knowne distance from you, then go vnto the first station, and tourning the left leg towards the second station, take ye quantity of the angle betwixt the said 2. stations, & marke whose distance is required, by the 4. Chap. Prop. 2. Wrest the center pin there hard, so that the angle made by the legs be not altered: next take vp your staffe; but first remoue the center of the graduator vpon the left leg, so many parts from the center of the Instrument, as the distance betwixt the first and second station is found to be: now go vnto the second station, and there place the center of the Graduator, inst ouer the said station, in such sorte, that the sidutiall edge of the left leg may lie in a right line with the stationary line (the angle before made looking frōwards the first station,) which you may eastly doe, by mouing the staffe, you standing at the end of the left legge, vntill by the center of the graduator, and the center pin of the Instrument, you sée the first station: but you must haue a speciall care not to alter the angle made vpon the legges at the first station: this done, turne the moueable end of the graduator which lyeth vpon the right legge (but not stirring the center from his place) vntill the fidutiall edge thereof, point iust vnto ye marke, whose distance is required, this being done, you haue your desire: for the equall parts betwixt the center of the graduator, and the instrument, is the distance betwixt your two stations, and the parts cut by the fidutiall edge of the graduator vpon the right legge, is the distance of the marke from the second station, and the equall parts of the graduator cut by the right legge, or so many parts of the graduator, as be included betwixt the right & left legge (for all is one) is the iust distance of the 2. station from the marke desired, in such parts of measure as you expressed your stationary line by, so haue you the two vnknowne sides of the Tryangle.

Let A B be a distance, A a Tree, B your station from whence you desire the true distance of the tree, appoint C for the second station on the left hand, and there set vp a visible marke: now take the quantitie of the angle A B C by the 4. Chapter, Prop. 2.
which let be 75. degrées, then count the length of B C vpon the left legge from the center, which let be 40. pearches, whereunto bring the center of the graduator, then take vp the staffe, and go vnto the second station C, ouer which place the center of the graduator, then turne the left leg K M, vntill the center of the graduator C, and the center of the instrument K point iust to B the instru: so resting, remoue the end of the graduator O, vntill the fidutiall edge thereof C & O point iust to A; so is there 55. pearches betwixt C and A: for that there be so many equallparts included betwixt ye left foote K M, and ye right foote K R vpon the graduator, then the graduator cuts the right foote at R, which is 49. parts, and so many pearches is B from A. So you sée wée haue made a Tryangle vpon the legges, as K C R equall and proportionall vnto B C A, whereunto we might inferre proportionall termes, with the Geometricall demonstration, which we will reserue for another place.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
To take the height of any Castle, Tower, Tree, &c.
div.p: FOrasmuch as all altitudes stand perpendicular,Altitude. and therefore make right angles with the line of leuell, by occasion wherof, you shall néede to séeke but one angle and one line, for that the second angle is before hand knowne to be right.

Take therefore the distance from your standing, vnto the base of the thing whose altitude is required, this done, open the legs vnto a right angle, & then place them vpon the side of the staffe, so that the left legge lie parallell to the Horizon, next remoue ye center of the graduator, to so many parts of the left legge, as the base of the foresaid altitude is distant from you, then heaue vp, or put downe the other end of the graduator, vntill the fidutiall
edge thereof agrée with the summite or toppe of the altitude; the parts then betwixt the graduator and the center, counted vpon the right legge, is the altitude of the thing required, and the parts of the graduator included betwixt the two legs, is the distance of the toppe of the altitude to your foote, whereby you may finde the length of any scaling ladder.

Let N A B be a height, B C the distance, 27.½ yards, therefore I remoue the center of the graduator C, 26.⅕ equall parts frōwards N, videl. to C, then I open the right legge N M to a right angle on M, then I heaue vp the other end of the graduator F, vntill the point iust to A, so will he cut 29. parts at Z vpon the right legge M N. I conclude therefore briefly, that A B is 29-yards high: and forasmuch as there be 39. equall parts counted on the graduator C F, betwixt the two legges M N, and N O: I therefore affiune the length of the Hipothemsall line C A to be 39. yards, and so long must the scaling ladder haus beene.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
You standing vpon a Cleffe, Tower, or Rocke, & to tell how farre any thing seene before you, is distant from you.
div.p:
OPen the legges to a right angle,Longitudoc and then place the right legge to lie parallell, so shall the left leg point iust to the Zenith, now measure how high the Tower wheron you stand is, according to which height, place the center of the graduator in distance from the center of the instrument; the legs standing as before, and the right angle not altered, moue the other end of the
graduator, vntill by the fidutiall edge thereof, you see the marke whose distance is required. The parts then vpon the right leg, intercepted betwixt the graduator, and the center of the Instrument, is the true distance of the marke whose longitude was sought.

Here A B is the distance sought, C B the Tower, 32. foote high; then working as in the last Chapter you shall finde the distance A B 57. foote: for the working is all one, if the termes of arte doe but interchange, as distance for altitude, &c. as you may easily perceiue by the letters in each demonstration, or figure. Note that in the former, and also in this Chapter, you might haue taken away the graduator, and onely worked by the left sight, vnlesse you had required the hypothenusall line, as in the next Chapter will appeare.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
The height of a Fort, Castle, Tower, or such like giuen, to fetch his distance from you by onely taking his angle of altitude.

p.hi: Two knowne angles of a Tryangle, being scituate, the one at the end of a line knowne, and the other opposite to the said line, to finde the other angle and two lines vnknowne.

div.p: YOu be taught in the 15. Longitudo. Chapter, to finde the quantitie of ye third angle, and for the lines worke thus.

Open the legges vnto a right angle, and then turning the center of the instrument towards the height, place the left leg to lie parallell, and the right to point iust vnto the Zenith: now remoue the sight in the right legge, so farre from the center as the
height of the thing instructs you, the right sight resting there, draw backe the sight in the left legge, vntill he be in a right line with the summite of the altitude, and sight in the right leg: then so farre as he is from the center, that is, so many equall parts as be included betwixt him and the center, so many pearches, scores &c. is the thing from you.

Suppose you lay encamped in a field by a riuer side, on the further side whereof there were a Castle, against which you would lay batterie, and would be resolued whether your Drdinance that throwes a bullet point blanke 50. yards, would reach thereunto, or whether it were requisite to mount the said Péece to any degrées of random: now suppose likewise you durst not (by reason of shotte) stirre abroad to performe it by the 15. Chap. but onely by some friend in the aduerse Camp, you had notice that the Castle were 30. yards high aboue the leuell of vs. Well then procéede thus.

Place the left legge C D to lye parallell, and then remoue P C the right legge to a right angle: now for that B R is 30. yards high, I place the sight A in the right legge C P, 30. equall parts from C, thē I draw backe F ye sight in the left legge C D, vntill by F and the site A, I sée the top of the Tower R: so that F A R lye all thrée in a right line, then I count the equall parts betwixt F and C, and find them to be 50: so then I may conclude, that it is iust 50. yards to the Castle, and that the péece of Ordinance will beare a bullet therunto point planke.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
The last Chapter performed by the Author another way.
div.p:
OK thus, you may apply the last Chapter, Suppose you had a Péece of Ordinance that would carrie point blanke; 50,
yards, and that you were vpon a present occasion to place him to endanger the aduersarie, heere remoue the sight in the right leg to 30. the height of the Tower (as before) and then draw backe the sight in the left leggs to 50. the length that the Péece will carrie: now cause the Peece to be drawne after you, you going direct towards the Tower, and bearing the left legge (as before parallell, vntill by the sites in both the legges, you sée the very top, and there may you surely plant your Péece, so that hee shall throw the bullet full point blanke vpon the Castle.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
You seeing two shippes vpon the seas, or two Castles, Towers, Trees, or such like vpon the land, to seeke the distance thereof without Arithmeticall calculation.

p.hi: One angle, and two sides of a Tryangle beeing knowne, which containe the angle knowne, to finde the other two angles, and third side vnknowne.

div.p: AS for the finding of the angles, they bee taught in the 33. Chapter hereafter, onely thus you shall find the third side.

By the 15. Chapter, take the distance of the two Towres from you then by the 4. Chapter, 2. Prop. take the quantitie of the angle betwixt the 2. markes, whose distance is required: then count the distance of the marke vpon the left hand, on the left legge, and thereunto bring the center of the graduator; then count the distance of the marke vpon your right hand from you, vpon the right legge, and thereunto bring the fidutiall edge of the Graduator: the equall part then included betwixt both the legges vpon the graduator, is the true distance sought.

Let C A in the figure of the 15. Chapter, be to marke whose distance is required, let B be your sta. first I take the distance of C B, and finde it to be 40. pearches, then of A B, and finde it to be 49. pearches, which noted, I take the angle A B C, then I count 40. vpon the left legge, and thereunto bring the center of the graduator, then I count 49. on the right legge, where I lay the fidutiall edge of the graduator: so then there are 55. equall parts vpon the graduator cut by the right legge, which I pronounce for the true distance of C A.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.

A Castle, Fort, Towre, or such like seene before you, so that by reason of diuerse impediments, you cannot take his distance from you by the 15. Chapter, how to performe it heere by the helpe of two stations, though you cannot discerne the base or any part thereof, but some pinnacle or such like; nor go sidewise, but straight forwards or backwards.

p.hi: Si Triangula sunt aequiangula seu similia, cruribus homologis propertionalia,

div.p: OPen the legges vnto a right angle, and then take away the graduator, placing both the sites in the left leg, this done, go as neare vnto the Towre as you will, or place the lower sight in the left legge at soms euen number vpon the legge, going to and fro, or stirring the said site vntill the extremes of the end of the right legge, and the foresaid sight agrée with the very summite of the altituds, kéeping the right legge parallell, the site resting so, remoue the other site some euen number from the first placed site, going fromwards or towards the marke, as occasion serueth, vntill you sée the summite of the altitude: againe by the end of the right legge and the last placed site, the sites so resting, measure the distance betwixt your two stations, and note how many euen parts be contained betwixt your two sites vppon the left legge: for so many times as those euen parts be contained betwixt the vppermost site, and the center of the Instrument, so many times may you safely conclude the distance betwixt your two stations, to be contained betwixt the Towre, & the station furthest off the said Towre.

Suppose the distance of A B is required, now by reason of woods and hilles you can see nothing but the top thereof C; well then, I open the legges of my instrument vnto a right angle, and appoint my first station at D: the right legge lying parallell, I place my eie at the end there of E, remouing the site in the left legge D F, vntill he be in a right line with C E, which falleth out to be in the toppe of the legge at F: so if you could measure the distance of B E, you had the altitude B E (as it falleth out here) but for that I cannot, I go backe to G, and there I appoint my 2. stations, kéeping the legs at a right angle (as before) and the right legge G A, parallell pointing iust to B: then I place againe my eie at A, remouing the other site vntill he be in a right line wt C A, as at I, then I note how farre I the second site is off H my first sire, and I finde it 96. equall parts (the séete being 2. foote long) then I note how often that is to be found betwixt H G, which hath 192. equall parts, I finde it is twice there, therefore measure the stationary line E A, and it shall be twice so farre frō A to B A as 35. pearches, therefore A B is 70. pearches, which is twice so much as 35.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.

To take the altitude of a Castle, Steeple, Towre, Tree, or such like, where you dare not by reason of shotte, or cannot by occasion of waters, &c. come neare vnto the base thereof, according to the 16. Chapter, without Arithmeticall calculation.
div.p:
OPen the legges vnto a right angle, then go towards the base of the altitude (so it be not ouer neare) there plant your Instrument,Altitudo. so that one of the legges lie parallell, and the other stand perpendicular, as they did in the former Chapter: Now place the site in the perpendicular legge, about the middest of the legge, or as occasion leades you, so that your eie being placed at the extremes of the parallell leg, you may thence, and by the site in the perpendicular legge, see the summite or toppe of the Altitude required; this done, bring the site in the le • ell legge, from the end towards the center, a certain e distance, as 3. quarters, halfe a quarter, or iust so much as the site in the perpendicular leg is from the center: let the sites and right angles all stand fixed, then choose you a second station (going towards the wall) vntill you see againe the toppe of the Towre by both these last fixed sites (still kéeping the foresaid legges, the one parallell, the
other perpendiculer.) Lastly measure the distance betwixt your two stations, that is betwixt the places where your seete did stand at time of obseruation, and the same distance shal be either the third part, the halfe the quarter, or iust the height you sought, according as you did place the site in the leuell legge, the third part, halfe the quarter, or whole length of the site in the perpendicular legge from the center. Example.

I place the left legge to lie parallell, and the right perpendicular at E, making E my first station, E D the left legge, E F the right: then I draw G the site downe from F towards E, vntill he be in a right line with D A. viz. at G, which falleth out in the middest of the right legge E F. then I make a marke vnder the end of the left legge D, viz. at O, next I remoue ye staffe, bringing the site in the left legge so farre from the end M, as G was from E, that is to K, so is K the left site so farre from M, as I is from L: then I go toward the altitude, vntill K I be in a right line with A, as D G was before, then I make a marke iust vnder K at S, then I measure the distance betwixt S O, & finde it 6. pearches. I conclude, because K M is iust as much as H I, or F G, that S O is iust so much as the height A C, S O is 6. pearthes, therefore A C is 6. pearches high,Vide Chap. 36. so that such proportion as K M hath to H I, the same hath S O to the altitude C A, so may you worke by the 29. Chapter.

Note, in all these dimensions you fetch so much of any height as is aboue the leuell of your eie: for if you would know B A, you
must adde K S or D O thereunto.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
To measure any vallie of such like prosunditie.
div.p: VVEe will make short of this Chapter, because of the facilitie thereof.

Suppose you were to measure the vallie A B C, first get ye length of A B, then of A C by some proposition in this Booke, which had, the line C B cannot be hid, if you worke by the 20. Chapter, for it is all one therewith.

Take the quantitie of the angle C A B, then count ye length of A B 46. pearches vpon the left legge, and thereunto bring ye center of the graduator: then count C A 40. pearches vpon the right legge, to which bring the fidutiall edge of the graduator; the parts then intercepted betwixt both the legges, is ye length of C B 43. pearches.

div.head: CHAP. XXIIII.

A Church or such like, scituate vpon the top of a high hill, and you standing vpon a lower hill, and a great vallie betwixt, so that you cannot place the left legge to make right angles with any part of the Altitude, yet to finde the height of the said Towre, Church, &c.
div.p:
FIrst get the length of the line A C in the last figure, then by the. Chapter, get the quantity of the angle A C B, then take the said quantitie from 180. so haue you the quantitie of the angle E C A;
En. 13.14. p. 1. Ra. 1, cons. 8. E. 5. then open the legges vnto the quantitie of the said angle C by the 6. Chapter, next count the line C A vpon the left legge from the center, and thereunto bring the site or center of the graduator, then make the fidutiall edge of the said left leg so lie in a right line with A C: then placing your eie at the site in the left leg, heaue vp or put downe the other end of the graduator, or the fite in the right legge, if the graduator bée away, vntill the two sites be in aright line with the summite; the part then betwixt the site in the right legge and the center, is the altitude required: so may you doe by a Castle standing vpon a high rocke by the sea fide, and you in a shippe sarre below.
A C is 40. pearches, and so working as before, you shall finde C E 24. pearches, as is plaine by the figure, without the multiplicitie of words.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
To take the profunditie of any Well, or such like.
div.p: IN this worke, Profundities. See the 4. Book Chap. 10.11. & 12. you may take away the graduator, then open the legges to a right angle, making B F the left leg lie parallell to ye toppe of the Well B C, thē shall the right leg B G stand perpendicular; then moue the two sights in each leg, as A & D, vntill your sight passing in a right line by both those sights concurre iust with the point E ye bottom of the Well, then shall you note the equall parts on each legge, where both the sites stand, let D stand at 11. and A at 30. lastly measure B C, which let bee 60. now to séeke the profundity or length of C E, work thus.
Multiply B A in B C, and diuide by D B, the quotient is your desire; I encrease B A 30. by B C 60. so haue I 1800. which parted by D B 11. yéelds 135. the profunditie.

p.hi: A note for another working by the staffe then before.

div.p: In all the Chapters before, I aduertised you to open the leg vnto a right angle, and here I let you to wit, that you may doe it as well if you place the graduator all at right angles with the left legge, therefore you may worke by either, according as you shall be occasioned.

And note further, that as you wrought any of the former propositions instrumentally, so likewise may they be performed on the staffe Arithmetically, which will nothing differ from the nature of the 5. Booke, and therefore I haue heere let it passe: for consider what part of your staffe doth correspond with the thing measured, which encrease by those parts of the legges answering to the thing required, and the product part by the line measured; so haue you your desire.

The question is to know the distance of B F, the altitude B R being giuen 30. féete, open the legges to a right angle, as P C D, then put the sight A in the left leg at any number of equall parts, as at 15. which represents the line giuen: then draw backe the other sight, vntill hee bee in a right line with A and R, as R A F: note the parts, cut them by F on ye right legge C D, which let be 25; so doth C D correspond to B F the distance sought, therefore as A C / 15 is to C F / 25, so is R B / 30 to B F / 50, or as A C / 15 is to R B / 30, so is C F / 25 to B F / 50 féete. Worke therefore by the cōmon golden rule, or by the 28. Chapter.

p.hi: To worke in maner of the Sector by the Geodeticall staffe.

div.p: Before wee can come to worke by the Geodeticall staffe after the maner of a Sector, it is most requisite to vnderstand the Chapter ensuing, without which, things hereafter cannot so well be attained vnto.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
Of the Equation of angles in the Geodeticall staffe.
div.p: BY the Equation of angles, is meant to make an angle at the center of the graduator equall vnto the angle proposed at ye center of the Instrument, or contrariwise to make an angle at the center of the Instrument, equall to the angle at the center of the Graduator, both which are performed after one and the selfe same maner; therefore when henceforth I bid you make Equation, remember that thereby is meant the making or coequating of an angle at the center of the graduator, equall to the angle at the center of the Instrumēt, or cōtrary, as before.

Let the legges of the Instrument be opened vnto an angle of what quantitie you wil, as C A B. Now to make one at the center of the graduator equall thereunto, bring the center of ye graduator vnto what point you will in the left leg, viz. to P, then moue the other end of the graduator K to and fro, vntill A N and P N be equicurrall, or make an Isosceles, that is to say, vntil the parts of the graduator cut by the right legge A B, be equall vnto the parts of ye right leg cut by the graduator, and so will there bee as much distance betwixt ye center of the graduator P, & the place where he falles on the right legge, as there is betwixt the center of the legges and the graduator, counted on the right leg,Ra. lib. 6.10. Pr • . viz. to N; and so haue you made the angle N P A equall to P A N, as may be proued.

And so must you worke if the angle made at the center of the Instrument be required to be made equall to the angle at ye center of the graduator, onely you must kéepe the graduator at one
stay, as you did the right legge, and moue the right legge as you did the graduator.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
Two numbers being giuen, or two lines assigned, to find the third in proportion.
div.p: OPen the legges to any angle what you will, then on ye left leg count the lesser of the numbers or shorter of the lines,Duobus numeris datis, innenire tertium proportionalem. whereto bring the center of the graduator; then count the greater number on the right legge, and thereunto bring the fidutiall edge of the graduator, he resting at that angle, wrest the screwe at the center of the graduator strait, so that the said angle be not altered: then count the greater number vpon the left legge, and thereto draw the socket and center of the graduator, not altering the angle; so shall the parts cut by the graduator vpon the right legge, be the third number or line in proportion.

Let the proposition be to finde a number to beare such proportion to 30. as 30. beareth to 20. count 20. from A towards B, as to C, there set the center of the graduator, remoue the other end E, vntill the fidutiall edge cut 30. in the right legge A G, as at F, then wrest the screw at C hard, so that you doe not alter ye angle A C F, next count 30. vpon the left legge A B, and thereto draw the center of the graduator, as to H: so shall the fidutiall edge of the graduator cut the right legge at O, & the parts there cut shall be in such proportion to 30. as 30. is to 20. which you shall finde to be 45, as may be prouedEu. 2. pro. 6▪ & 17. Prop. 11. in ciuill affaires.
And thus may you apply this Chapter: if 20. horses eate 30. bushels of oates in a day, what shall 30. eate in a day? and you shall finde 45.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII.
To performe the Golden number, called the Rule of 3. or rule of Proportion, where you haue three numbers giuen, and be required to finde the fourth in proportion.
div.p: THis rule of 3. is so called, for that as much as by 3. proportionall numbers knowne, it alwaies findeth out ye fourth,De potestate 4. numerorum proportionalium. and is of such force, that well-nie, all as well ciuill as Mathematicall negotiations depend thereupon: but wée will onely open it for the bréefe Mathematicall vse thereof. The worke.

Count the first number giuen vpon the left legge, and thereunto bring the center of the graduator: then (the legges beeing opened to any angle, as in the last Chap.) count the third number giuen vpon the right legge, whereto bring the edge of the graduator, and so wrest the screw at the center of the graduator hard, that the angle made be not altered: next count the second line vpon the left legge, and thereunto draw the center of the graduator, not altering the angle:Eu. lib. 6. Pro. 10. note the parts then cut by ye fidutiall edge thereof in the right legge, for that shall be the 4. number in proportion.
Let the proposition be, if 48. giue 96. what shall 40. giue?

First count 48. in the left legge A B, and where that number ends, bring thereto the center of the graduator, as to C: then
count the third number giuen (which must alwaies be of the same denomination as the first) vpon the right leg A G, which is 40. whereunto bring the edge of the graduator C D, as to D: next count the second number giuen, that is 96. vpon the leg A B, and where it ends make the point E, whereunto bring the cēter of the graduator, not altering his angle: so shall the fidutiall edge thereof, cut the right leg A G at the fourth number in proportion, viz. at F, which is 80, bearing such proportion to D, as E doth to C.
If 48. inches, giue 96, what shall 40. inches giue? and you shall finde 80. as before, the height sought for.
If 48. yards of veluet cost me 96. pounds, what then shall I pay for 40. yards? E. 19. Pro. lib. 7. you (as before) shall finde 80. pound, as is demonstrated.

As I haue noted before, so must you take héede in the placing of the numbers vpon the legges of the staffe: for the 1. and 3. must be of one denomination,Conditio regulae animaduertēda. so must the second and fourth, and the first and second must alwaies be counted vpon one legge, and the third and fourth on the other, as vpon the eight, so as the placing of these numbers differeth not from the working Arithmetically, as it is written:
div.q: Debent nihilominus ipsi numeri, in vsum practicum eo modo reuocari, vt ignotus & optatus numerus quartum possideat ordinem:Orontius lib. 3. cap. 4. De Arith. Parct. ac ipse primus, ré & nomine conueniat cum ipso tertio, secundus autem cum acquisito quarto.
div.p: You may vse the third note in the first Chapter, if néede be.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX.
If a Tower, Castle, or armie of men be seene farre before you, how to fetch the distance thereof from you.

p.hi: Two Angles knowne, and scituate at the ends of a line knowne, to finde the quantitie of the third angle, & the other two sides vnknowne, in any Tryangle.

div.p:
AS in the former working by the staffe,Longitude. of necessitie you performed euerie Proposition before you could remoue the staffe, so in this kind of working may you doe; notwithstanding it rests at your pleasure so to doe, or onely take the angles, and
performe the rest at your best leasure. I will make short hereof, let A be a trée whose distance is required, B your first station, and C your second; first, by the 4. Chapter, Prop. 2. take the angle C B A, which is 79. degrées, note that done, then take ye angle B C A, which is 60. degrées, note that done: lastly measure the line C B (which I call your stationary line, because it is included betwixt your two stations) and you shall finde it 40. pearches, and note that done; so haue you two angles and one line: now to finde the third angle, and the other two lines, worke thus.

Adde the two angles together, that is 79. & 60. which makes 136, which take from 180, so haue you the quantitie of the third angle 44. degrées, as is proued: then for the two sides, B A, Chap. 15. and C A, worke thus.

By the 6. Chapter, open the legs to the quantitie of the angle C B A, which is 79. degrees, then make equation by the 26. Chapter, which done, wrest the screw at the center of the graduator hard, so that ye angle made at the center of the graduator be not altered then open the right leg to theVide lib. 6. Cap. 13. angle of 60. degrées, and there let him rest, lastly draw the cēter of the graduator, so farre from the center of the Instrument as the line C B instructs you, that is 40. pearches; then the parts cut vpon the right legge by the graduator, is the distance of B A, which will be 49. pearches, and the equall parts of the graduator included betwixt both the legges, is the length of C A, 55. pearches, and so of any other.
So haue you the third angle, and the two sides of the vnknowne Tryangle, knowne, which was required.

div.head: CHAP. XXX.
To take the height of any accessible thing, standing perpendicular.
div.p: TAke by the 4. Chapter,Altitude. 3. Proposition, the angle of altitude, viz. A C B, then measure the line C B, which is 27.½ yards. Now you néede not to seeke ye angle C B A, because he is knowne to be right, therefore you néede to doe no more but remone the graduator 27.½ equall parts from the center, and there place him at a right angle, then the legges resting at the angle A C B, the parts of the graduator cut by the right legge shewes the altitude, which will be 29. yards.

Or if you cannot place the graduator at a right angle, then make equation by the 26. Chapter: which done, wrest the screw at the center of the graduator hard, so remouing the right legge from the former angle vnto a right angle, the parts then cut by the graduator vpon the right legge is the foresaid altitude, which will fall out to be 29. yards. And here you must note that you may not remoue the center of the graduator from the place hee was fixed first, as at 27.½.
If you vnderstand this Chapter, the working of the 17. Chapter after this maner cannot be hid, onely the angle A C B is taken as an angle of longitude, see therefore the 4. Chapter, Prop.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI.
The height of a Tower, &c. giuen to fetch his distance from you, and the length of a scaling ladder, without measuring to the base.

p.hi: Two angles of a Tryangle beeing knowne, whereof the one is scituate at the end of a line knowne, and the other opposite to the said line knowne, to finde the third angle, and other two lines vnknowne.

div.p: SUppose I were standing at F, and that I were desirous to know the distance of F B and F R: Longitude. first I take the angle of altitude by the 4. Chapter, Prop. 3. viz. R F B, and now the other angle R B F is already knowne: wherefore the third angle F R B is found by the 30. Chapter: but forasmuch as R B F is knowne to be right, I neede therefore but to take R F B out of 90. and the remainder is the angle F R B: R F B is found to bee 30. or there abouts, take 30. from 90. there remaineth 60. the angle F R B, then for the sides, worke thus.

Open ye legs to the angle F R B,
viz. 60. then remoue the refer of the graduator so farre from the center of the legs as ye line B R instructs you, that is 30. yards, hee resting there, make equatiō by the 26. Chapter, not stirring the right legge: which done, fasten the graduator at the angle: lastly remoue the right leg vnto a right angle, so is the parts of ye right leg cut by the Graduator the length of B F, viz. 50. yards: and the equall parts of the graduator which are included betwixt ye two legges, the length of F R, the hipothenusall or scaling ladder.
And so might you haue fetcht the length of R B standing at B, by knowing the line B F.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII.
Two ships seene vpon the seas, or two Towrets vpon the land, to fetch the distance betwixt them both.

p.hi: An angle knowne, and two lines knowne, containing the said knowne angle, to finde the other two angles vnknowne, and the third line.

div.p: LEt C A be two markes,Latitude. whose distance is required, first by the 30. Chapter take the distance of B C, and you shall finde if 40. pearches, then by the same Chapter, take the distance of B A, which you shall finde 49. pearches, then take the angle C B A y the 2. Prop. Chap. 4. this done, stay the legges at that angle, and count the length of C B vpon the left leg, therto bring the center of the graduator, then count the line B A vpon ye right legge, and thereto bring the edge of the graduator: the equall parts then vpon the graduator included betwixt both the legs, is the distance of C A, viz. 55. pearches. Now to find the quantitie of the other two angles, wrest the screw at the center of ye graduator hard, so that the angle made before be not altered; the graduator so resting, make equation by the end of the 26. Chap.

This so done, the right legge resting at that angle, remoue the graduator to the point respectiue, and so find the quantitie of the angle made by the said legs, which is 60. degrées: so now haue you 2. angles, viz. C B A first taken, which is 79. degrées, and B C A now taken, which is 60. degrées; so is the third angle easily found to bee 44. degrées, by the 15. or 30. Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII.
To finde the distance of any 2. places, though you cannot come to take the angle of latitude, as in the last chapter.

p.hi: Two lines and one angle being giuen, so that the one line is the side of the angle knowne, and the other doth subtend the said angle, yet to finde the third line, and the other two angle vnknowne.

div.p:
SUppose you knew how farre B were off C, and also how farre C were off A: but you desired to know how farre A were off B, now suppose you durst not go to C to take the angle of latitude
but were compelled to stand at B.

First therefore take the angle C B A, the féete resting at the angle 79. degrées, remoue the center of the graduator vpon the left leg to the length of B C, viz. 40. pearches; this done, count the line C A vpon the graduator, viz. 55. stirring the moueable end of the graduator, vntill the number of 55. agrée iust with the fidutiall edge of the right legge: the parts then cut by ye graduator vpon the said right legge, is the true length of A B, 49. pearches.

Now to finde the other two angles, the center of the graduator fastned at his former angle, by the end of the 26. Chapter, make Equation, not stirring the graduator; which done, bring the graduator to the point respectiue, and so by the 5. Chapter, finde the quantitie of the angle made at the center of the legges, which you shall finde to be 60. so haue you two angles, A B C, 79. degrées, and B C A 60: then by the 15. or 30. Chapter, the other is found easie to be 44. degrées,* or otherwise,Lib. 6. chap. 13. as is said.

I haue worked in this Chapter something from the nature of the Prop. though nothing from the truth: for the words of the proposition be, that the one of the sides should subtēd the angle knowne, which you shall ice me briefly worke, because you may sée the diuersities.

Hauing, taken the angle C B A to bee 79. degrées, as before, count the fide C A vpon the left legge of the instrument, whereto bring the center of the graduator, (hither vnto the worke is all one.) Now must you make Equation by the 26. Chapter, not stirring the right legge: so that now by transposition, the cēter of the graduator containes the angle knowne, which angle must be kept truely; then count the line C B 40. pearches vpon the right legge, this done, open the right legge or close him, as occasion serueth, vntill the fidutiall edge and the point where the 40. pearches before counted, did end iust cut the edge of the graduator: the equall parts then vpon the graduator, included betwixt the two legs, is the length of the line B A, 49. pearches, as before.

Now to finde the two vnknowne angles, you must measure the quantitie of the angle which is made at the center of the legs by the 5. Chapter,Vide. lib. 6. chap. 13. which you shall finde to be 60. degrées, so haue you the first angle 79. degrees, this 60. degrées; the third therefore cannot be vnknowne, as before.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIIII.
Any Tower of such like seene before you, to fetch the altitude & hipothenusall distance thereof at two stations.
div.p: IN this kinde of dimension, I am to forewarne you of one thing,Conditio reguloe • nimaduertēda. which ought to be obserued in all propositions before, where the angle of altitude is twice taken; that is, that the leg of the instrument which lyeth parallell, be placed direct in ye same line of leuell at the second station, as he was at the first, so that it is not lawfull at the first station to plant the instrument high, and at the second lowe, although at both stations you haue respect to the parallitie of the legge; therefore looke what part of the altitude is leuell with your eie at the first station, & that make againe leuell with your eie at the second station: ordering your staffe thus, you may proceede;ede without the producement of any errour at all.

Let the Proposition be to fetch the altitude of A C: Altitudo. first I take the angle of altitude A K C, which I finde 45. degrées; next I take (going backwards some reasonable distance) I take the angle of altitude A D C, 23. degrées: then I measure the distāce of K D, which is 6. pearches: these thrée had, I note them downe, and procéede thus.

Open the legge byLib. 6. Cap. 13. the 6. Chapter to 45. degrées, the angle taken at my first station K: then make equation by the 26. chap. but first draw the center of the graduator to some point in the
left legge, as to Z in the ensuing figure, so by transposition is ye angle at the center of the graduator D Z P, equall vnto the angle at the center of the instrument F P Z: the graduator so resting, remoue the right legge vnto a right angle, then diligently obserue where the fidutiall edge of the graduator cutteth the right legge, which will fall out at the point D; this done, make a note where the center of the graduator was as at Z, then by the 6. ChapterLib. 6. chap. 13. open the legges vnto the angle made at the secōd station D, 23. degrées; which done, make equation, thē wrest the screw hard, that the angle at the center of the graduator bée not altered: now remoue the right legge vnto a right angle, and draw backe the center of the graduator, vntill the fidutiall edge thereof fall againe vpon the point D before noted in the right legge Y P: then note the parts included betwixt D P on the right legge,The legs with the Geometricall ground of the worke. and N Z vpon the left legge.

Now thus may you inferre the proportionall termes, as D P is to N P, so is C D in the 22. Chapter to A C: but you see part of C D is vnknowne, therefore argue it thus from the parts knowne, saying, as N Z, the parts included vpon the left legge N P, is to D P the sigment of the right legge, so is D K in the 22. Chapter, the distance betwixt the two stations, to C A the altitude: N Z containes 144. parts, and D P 144. parts also; the distance betwixt the 2. stations is 6. pearches: therefore works by the 29. Chap. and you shall find the altitude A C to be 6. pearches, equall wt the length of the two stations, and so of any other, length or depth, thus farre the sector.

p.hi: Si Triangula sunt aequiangula seu similia,

div.p:
The Tryangle A C D and D P N are alike, and the angle A C D and D P N are equall, therefore D P is also parallell to A C, as may be proued Eu. 31. P. 1. Ra. 5. confi. 3. pro. 12.: therefore by the same reason Eu. 2. Pro. 6. & 17, p. 11., ye thighs of both the Tryangles bee proportionall among themselues, so
that as A C is to C D, Fundamentum est. 4.5.6.7.8.9.10.11. & 12. p. 6 R. lib. 5. P. 13. lib. 6. p. 8. so is D P to P N: and as N P is to N D, so is C D to A C: in like maner as N P is to P D, so is D C to C A, and as N P is to D C, so is P D to C A.
And againe for our purpose, as N Z is to P D, so is D K to C A, as before: or as N Z is to D K, so is P D to C A.
As the first of these two last demonstrations serue for this last Chapter, so also doth it hold in the 22. Chapter, and therefore may the said 22. Chapter be wrought by the 29. Chapter,

p.hi: The end of the second Booke of the Geodeticall Staffe.

div.p: Note generally, that the equall parts inserted vpon the vpper side of the legs outwards, are alwaies to worke by ye helpe of a paire of compasses, and the equall diuisions inwards to worke by the graduator: therefore if I bid you sée what number of equall parts the graduator cuts, you must séeke it amongst the equall parts vpon the inward side of the legs.

div.head: THE THIRD BOOKE OF the Geodeticall Staffe, concerning the vse of the Hypsometricall Scale.
CHAP. I.
To place your staffe vpon plaine ground, so that he may stand iust perpendicular on the line of leuell, or vpon slopy or hilly ground to make right angles with the ground line.
div.p: I Place this Chapter first,To place the staffe at right angles with the ground line. because of the great vse thereof in euery Proposition ensuing; for in the taking of many kindes of dimensions, I was often driuē to carrie a plumb liue with me for the placing of the staffe perpendicular, and in other dimensions, a squier for the placing of the said staffe at right angles with the ground line, vntill at last the staffe yéelded a better and more easie way vnto me himselfe, which is thus.

From the place where you will plant your staffe towards the marke, whose distance is desired, measure ye iust length of your staffe, and there make an apparent marke: your staffe then being placed in the extremes of the last measured line, and in the end furthest distant from the marke whose distance is required, open the legges vnto an angle of 45. degrees, by the 6. Chapter, lib. 2. then bring the fidutiall edge of the left legge to agrée with the edge of the hollow staffe beeing there fixed: and the angle before made not altered, moue the top of the staffe towards or fromwards the marke, vntill by the fidutiall edge of the right legge you see the marke before noted vpon the ground to agrée therewith, so is the staffe ready planted.

div.head: CHAP II.
To measure the distance of any marke seene before you in a right line.
div.p: TAke the legges out of the staffe, and place them vpon the side of the staffe, placing the hollow staffe so; that hee may not leane towards or fromwards the marke whose distance is required,Qualiter linea recta in plano metiatur. as in the last Chapter: then by the 4. Chapter, Prop. 1. Booke 2. take the angle of longitude, and wrest the screw pin hard, so that the angle be not altered: next bring the center of the graduator vnto the left point respectiue, and then turne the parts of the scale towards the legge *;Lib. 1. Pro. 2. Desi. 10. ; and note what parts are there cut by the right point respectiue: for such proportion as ye parts cutte haue to 12. the same hath the hollow staffe to the length required.

Let G the point respectiue cut D B the graduator at 3. parts, and for because 3. is to 12. in a Quadruplate proportion, I conclude E F the line required, to containe the length of the staffe 4. times, whereupon the staffe being foure foote, I may interre the line to be 16. foote.
Hopt. Or worke thus by the Lib, 2, 29. Chapter, saying, it 3. giue 12. what shall 4. giue? and you shall finde 16. and here it were fit to vse the fourth note of the first Chapter, Booke 2.

div.head: CHAP. III.
To performe the former Proposi. where a distance is required, by the onely helpe of a vulgar gnome, or Carpenters squire, represented on the staffe.
div.p:
•• a operandi vulgati Gnomo
• i • . IT hath pleased some to adioine a maner of measuring without the hypsometricall scale, whereby the length of the foresaid
lines lying vpon plaine ground, are obtained as it were at an instant by a gnomon or right angled figure, such as Mechanicks vulgarly vse, called a squire. I would not let passe thus kinde of measuring (saith my Author) aswell for that it is facill and easie, as also because it seldome happens that such measures haue alwaies a scale at hand; let therefore the right line be giuen whose longitude thou dost desire, and let it be A B: then by the first Chapter erect your staffe A C, then take the graduator of ye legs, and open them vnto a right angle, as D C E, then place the center C vpon the side of the staffe, not altering the angle, lift vp or depresse downe both the legges vntill by the fidutiall edge of C D, the visuall beame concurre iust with the further terms or end of the line whose length is sought, as to B: the legges so resting and the right angle not altered, wrest the center pin hard, and there let the instrument remaine, then looke by the fidutiall edge of the other legge C E, and note where the visuall beames touth the ground, as at F, which noted, say thus:
Such proportion as the erected staffe A C hath to the parts A F, the same shall the line A B haue to A C, the length of the staffe.

As if A C be 6. foote, and A F 2. foote, because 6. to 2. hath a triple proportion, therefore the proposed longitude A B shall thrée times containe six féete the length of the staffe, which is 18. féete.

Hopt. But my staffe is but 4. féete, and A F falleth out to be 1. foote and foure inches, which is also in a triple proportion to 48. inches, which is foure foote: work by the twenty eight Chappter, Booke 2. Deductio praedioctorum geometricae, Eu. lib, 1, pro, 32

In the Tryangle B C F, the 3. angles bee equall vnto a right angle, as may be proued *: but B C F is a right angle, therefore the other two, C B F, and B F C together are equall vnto a right angle: also by the same reason the two angles A C F, and C F A in the tryangle A C F, are together equall to one right angle: for
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
the third C A F is right, therefore the two angles C B F and B F C, are in like maner equall to the two right angles A C F and C F A, because they be coequated by a like angle, that is to say, with a right angle: but if you doe take the angle B F C, common to both, from those equall angles, the remainder C B A by common sentence will be equall to the other A C F, and the angle B C A is equall to the angle C A F: for they be both right, and therefore ye other angle A C B shall in like maner be equall to C F A: therefore the two tryangles A B C and A C F, are equangle (saith my Author,Orontius. 4. Eu. lib. 6. ) quare & quae circum aequales angulos laterae proportionalia: therefore as A C the staffe is to A F the measured line, so is the proposed longitude A B to the erected staffe A C, which was required to be done.

Hopt. As you haue fetcht lengths, so by the same reason may you fetch heights, as in the demonstration: for C D will hold alwaies the same proportion to D E, that B F doth to A B; so by measuring of F B, and working by the 29. Chopter the altitude cannot be hid.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
To take the height of Altitudes perpendicular, eleuated by the meanes of shadowes, with the Geodeticall staffe.
div.p:
ALthough (saith Orontius) we haue determined to set down the difference of shadowes to the thing ensuing shadowe, in their place, that is in our fourth Booke of Cosmography, howbeit
we shall not bring it out of season, hereto deliuer a pregustation in briefe, how things directed Orthogonaliter vpon the plaine of the earth, doe séeme to excéede their altitudes. Therefore of shadowes we must vnderstand which be called right,Vmbrarū recta. rum Definitio. that is to say, which are extended in length and direct on the plaine of the earth, and doe make right angles with the thing causing shadowe; such are the shadowes of Turrets or any other thing perpendicular, eleuated vpon plaine ground: but all right shadows are protended infinite when the Sunne is in the east or west,De vmbrarum rectarum cremento atque decremento. & by how much the more the Sunne ascends vpwards, by so much the more the longitude of the said shadowe doth decrease, and so continue proportionally vntill such time as the Sun shall come vnto the Meridian, and then all right shadowes be at their shortest. Furthermore, the Sunne declining from the Meridian into the west, the foresaid shadowes be augmented in right order, and are made so much the greater by how much the more the Sunne shall be nearer vnto setting: but on this condition, that the Sunne béeing in points distant alike from the Meridian, the longitude of the shadowe shall fall out alike.

1 Now to fetch the altitude of any thing by the shadow thereof,Operandi modus quand • vmbra maior • st vmbr • si longitudine per B • c. Geod. first by the 4. Chapter, Prop. 3. Booke 2. take the height of the Sunne, and fasten the legs at that angle; then bring the graduator vnto the point respectiue in the left legge, and note the parts of the scale cut by the right point respectiueLib. 1. Pro. 2. Defi. 10. : if it fall out in the contraris shadow, you may safely conclude the length of ye shadowe to be longer then the altitude sought; and the same proportion as 12. hath to the parts cut, the like hath the length of the shadowe to the height required.

Wée will take Orontius his example, let 6. bee the parts cut on the graduator by the right point respectiue, & let the altitude causing shadow be F G, and the shadow it yeeldeth G I, ye beames of the Sun H I: now zbecause 12. is to 6. in a duplatiue proportion, I conclude, the altitude F G to be twice contained in G I the shadowe; therefore because I G is 20. paces, G F of consequence must néeds be 10. paces.
Or multiply the length of G I by the parts cut, and make diuision by 12. so haue you the altitude, as may bee proued by the demonstration of Orontius in this Chapter.

Multiply 20. by 6. there riseth 120. which diuide by 12. & there
comes 10. so many pearches or paces high is F G, according • a you did measure G I by pearches or pearches.
Hopt. But with more ease then any of these, worke by the 29. Chapter, Booke 2, thus:if 12. giue 6. what shall 20. giue? so shall the graduator cut 10, as before.

2 If you take the altitude of the Sun,Dum vmbra suo aequatur vmbroso. as before, and the right point respectiue, cut 12. parts iust, then the altitude is equall vnto the length of the shadowe, therefore measure the shadow, & the desired altitude cannot be hid.
Let F G be the altitude required, the Sun béeing in K, whose beames A K L, and the shadowe G L, which shall bee equall to G F.

De vmbrae altitudine velvmbros • minore. If you take the altitude of the Sunne by the 2. Booke, Chap. 4. Prop. 3. as before, bringing the graduator vnto the points respectiue, and see the parts cut to be in the right shadow or parts next to the moueable end of the graduator, then is the shadowe of the bodie causing shadowe shorter then the bodie it selfe.
Therefore such proportion as the parts cut haue to 12. the same hath the length of the shadowe to the height.

Let the right point respectiue cut the graduator in 6. parts of the right shadowe, let the shadowe be G N, the Sunne beames
M N, let the length of the shadowe G N be 5. paces: then for asmuch as 6. is to 12. in a subduplatiue proportion, therefore G N is halfe the height of G F: which doubled, maketh the iust altitude, viz. 10. paces.
Generally multiply the length of the shadow by 12. and denide by the parts cut: the quotient is the altitude.
Multiply 5. by 12. there riseth 60. which diuide by 6. the parts cut, there remaines 10. and so many paces high I conclude the altitude S G as before, and so for all the parts of the right shadowe.
Hopt. But without Arithmeticke, workeLib, 2, cap, 39. as before, saying, if 6. giue 12. what shall 5.? and in so doing by the foresaid doctrine, the graduator will cut 10. the height, as before.

And take this generall in all your obseruations, if 〈◊〉 altitude of the Sunne be vnder 45. degrées, then is the length of the shadowe greater then the bodie causing shadowe, and the point respectiue shall cut the graduator in the contrary shadow: which in our latitude falleth out from the 24. of August to the beginning of Aprill, because in all that time the Sunne commeth not at the nearest within 45. degrées of our Zenith.

But if the altitude fall out to be aboue 45. degrées, then is the shadow shorter thē the perpendicular boy causing shadowe: & the parts cut by the point respectiue on the graduator, shall be in ye right shadow, which falleth out in the Sommer time, from the beginning of Aprill vntill the 24. of August, because the Sunne at that time towards the middest of the day moues nearer vnto the Zenith then to the Horizon, because his meridian altitude is greater then the equinoctials height: which happen to regions on the north side the equinoctiall, when the Sunne is included betwixt the equinoctiall and the vernall Solstitiall parallell or tropicke of Cancer, and with vs in England being 7. degrées north from the equator: and further, at halfe an howre after thrée of the clocke after noone, or so much after 8. in the forenoone, you shall neuer finde the point respectiue to cut in the right shadowe, (especially towards the middest of England) tho you make obseruation euen on the solstitiall day: so that after 3. a clocke in the after noone, and after 8. before noone, you shall neuer vse the parts of the right shadow for the cause abouesaid: but these differences I will referre vnto a larger volume, where it shall bee handled more artificially, onely here I giue a taste
thereof for the better vnderstanding of the Staffe.

And you shall note that the first side of this scale whereof the one is called Vmbra recta, Note. the other Vmbra versa, be no other thē the Tangents of a lesser marke in a semiquadrant, as you may perceiue in the appendix of the 7. Booke.

div.head: CHAP. V.
To performe the last chapter with more ease.
div.p: HAuing taken the angle of altitude, note the part cut in the right or contrarie shadow, as before you did in the last Chapter: if the parts cut be in the right shadow, thence sort vnto the two towes of figures placed vpon the backe side of the right legge neare the moueable end,Tabula vmbrarum. and in the aguies vpon the left hand, find the parts cut, answering to which is the figures set to expresse how often the length of the shadow must bee taken to finde the length of the thing causing shadowe, as in the Table in the margent appeares, which Table must bee placed vpon the right legge, as hee is here.

I find, hauing taken the Sunnes angle of altitude, that the point respectiue cuts 4. parts of the right shadowe, which 4. I finde in the towe vpon ye left hand, answering to which is 3. placed, signifying vnto you, that you must take the length of the shadowe 3. times to make the altitude causing the shadowe.

2 If the point respectiue cut the graduator in the contrarie shadowe, resort also vnto the said Table as before, & the parts answering to the parts cut, sheweth thee how often the height is contained in the shadow, that is, how often the length of the shadowe doth containe the height of the thing causing shadowe.

Hauing taken the angle of altitude as before, I find the point respectiue to cut 8. parts of the contrary shadowe, answering to which in the Table of shadowes is set 1 ½, which shewes ye shadowe containes the altitude causing shadow, once and a halfe; therefore if the shadowe were 12. foote, the height was but 9. foote.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
To finde the altitude of any body perpendicularly eleuated by the visual beames, without the helpe of the Sunne.
div.p: IT often falleth out when we would measure altitudes after the foresaid maner,Generalis operands via. that by reason of the interposition of some darke cloud, the beames of the Sunne are made so weake, that there can no shadow happen: therefore wee must vse the visuall beames of the eie thus.

Take the angle of altitudeCap. 4. Pro. 3. lib. 2. , as before, then as you be accustomed bring the center of the graduator vnto the left point respectiue, & note the partacutPro. 2, Desi. 10. lib. 1. by the right point respectiue, which done, procéede therein according to the 8. Chapter: for there it is performed in all respects, in which for the better opening of ye vse of the staffe, I will procéede more at large, taking the demōstration in the said 8. Chapter.

1 Let the Towre proposed to be measured be F G, let the angle of altitude be F N G, Vide cap. 4. apud. 3. and let the right legge cut the graduator at 6. parts of the right shadowe: therefore such proportion as the parts cut haue to 〈◊〉 ,Quando altitud • propositae mato • est intercaped • ne plani. the same hath the distance of N G to the altitude F G: N G is 5. paces, the parts cut be 6. therefore F G must néeds be 10. paces.

2 De plani longitudine, proposita altitudine aquali, If the parts cut (when the angle of altitude is taken) be 12, then is the altitude equall with the length betwixt your staffe & the base, adding (as you must before also) the distance of your eie from the ground thereunto: sée the 4. Chap, at the figure 2.

If the parts cut by the point respectiue fall in the contrarie shadow, then must you worke contrary vnto the operations in the right shadowe,Dum altitudo ab intercapedine plani supercttur. after this maner: such proportion as 12 hath to the parts cut, the same hath the length from your staffe vnto the base to the desired height, alwaies adding the height of your eie aboue the base thereunto. Example.

Let the parts cut be 6. in the contrary shadow, which is to 12 in a duplatiue proportion: therefore the distance of your eie from the base as G I; is twice so much as the altitude F G: G I is, 20. paces, therefore G F is but 10. paces: worke therefore by Arithmeticke or without, as in the 8. Chapter at the figure 1. You shall also finde this Chapter to agrée with the 9. Chapter: therefore the Table of shadowes set there may also be vsed heere in the same maner.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
To search out inaccessible height, with no lesse case then before.
div.p: Canon generalis • perationis. IT often falleth out that you cannot haue accesse to the base of the perpendicular, whose altitude is required, and yet you are desirous of ye height therof, which you may easily perform thus.

Appoint thy first station, and there place thy staffe, and take the angle of altitude by the second Booke, Chap. 4. Prop. 3. and note the parts of the scale cut as before: then go towards or frōwards the altitude as occasion serueth, and there make thy 2. station in a knowne distance from thy first: which done, take againe the angle of altitude (as before at the first station) & likewise note the parts cut at this station: then sée senerally what proportion the parts cut at either station haue to 12. and subtract consequently • he lesser out of the greater (for they will bee alwaies vnequall) and the residue reserue for the number of the altitude then measure the distance betwixt the falling of the first visuall became and the second, (or betwixt the two places where your staffe was, if after you adde the distance of your eie from the base to the altitude) the occurrant or former number is to be deuided by this number of measures betwixt your two stations: the quotient ingendred by the diuision of this number, sheweth the altitude, in those parts or measures, as before you measured the distance of the two stations by.

It sometime happeneth that the distance intercepted betwéen both the stations is to be taken for the altitude,Corolarium. which comes to passe so often as after subtraction of the former numbers there remaineth but one, because it is frustrate to deuide a number by one.

Let the altitude difficult to haue accesse vnto, be F G, and let your first station be where you placed your staffe, at the point H, and let the visuall beames fall at I, and let the right legge B A cut twelue parts on the graduator at C; here the parts cut are equall to 12. therefore you shall keepe but one for the denominator in the first number.

Afterwards go backe to the second station, as at K, and there againe take the angle of altitude, and note the parts cut as before, viz. 4. by D O, the right legge at F: then because 12, to 4. is in a triple proportion, kéepe therefore 3. and in like maner th • visuall beames vpon that plaine do concurre to the point L: the • subtract 1. from 3. the remainder is 2. which kéepe for the height then measure the interuall or distance of I L, which let be 20 cu • bits, which deuide by 2. there is made 10. for the quotient, ther • fore let vs conclude F G so many cubits high.

Alius ad idem operandi modus. Hopt. Here note, if you measure the distance betwixt H K, the places where your staffe was, and omitte the reuersed visuall sights D L and B I; then working as before, the altitude taken is so much of the Tower as was aboue the leuell of your eie at either statiō, viz. Z: to which if you adde the length of your staffe B H, or B K, the whole altitude from the base to the top appeares as before: and note further that the left legge D Y and B R must ly parallell, and at both stations point to one marke, as to Z; as is in the 36. Chapter, Booke, 2.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
To performe the last Proposition with more ease, after Gemma Frisius.

p.hi: Gemma Frisius in his Booke called Vsus Annuli Astronomici, teacheth this way for such that be ignorant in Arithmeticke.

div.p: SEeke two stations in going towards or departing from the marke whose altitude is required, so that in the one station ye point respectiue cut 12. the other 6. of the right shadowe; then double the distance betweene both the stations, and the altitude appeares: or if in the one station 12. be cut at the other 8 of the right shadowe, then triple the distance or in the one at 12, the other at 9. Vmbrae rectae quadruplate the distance.

In like maner if at the one station the point respectiue cut 12. in the other 8. of the contrary shadowe: then double the distance of both the stations, or one in 12. the other in 6. of the same shadowe; then the space betwixt both the stations is equall to the height.

Also if the point respectiue cut 6. parts, vmbrae rectae, and at the other station 8. vmbrae versae, or 6. vmbrae versae, and foure of the same shadowe at the other station, or 4. and 3. vmbrae versae; in all these the distance betwixt both the stations is equall to the height: remembring to adde the height of your eie aboue the base thereunto, as in the end of the last Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
To take any perpendicular height by the onely helpe of the hollowe staffe, without the aide of the legges.
div.p:
LEt your staffe be deuided into 12. equall parts, then erect him orthogonaliter vpon the giuen plaine,Modus metiendi resum altitude
• s per Baculum G • adaetum ab sque crurum be nesicio. so that hee lie parallell to the perpendicular altitude: then placing your eie at the ground, go backwards or forwards, as occasion serueth, vntill such time as thou dost behold the summite or highest part of the thing to be measured by the head of the staffe: which done measure the distance betwixt thy eie and the foote of the staffe by the same parts of measure as the staffe is deuided into: for such proportion as the staffe hath vnto the said distance, the same hath ye
proposed altitude vnto the longitude intercepted betwixt thy eie and the base of the said altitude.

1 Whereupon if the staffe and the foresaid distance be equall, so maist thou conclude the proposed altitude to be so much as it is betwixt thy eie and the base thereof, as in the figure with this example is apparent.

C D is the staffe equall to the distance A C, Prima exempli differentia. included betwixt your eie A, and the foote of your staffe C; whereupon it may be inferred, that the proposed altitude B F is equall to the plaine A H, included betwixt the points A and B, whereof both contain iust 6. staues length.

2 But if it so happen that the foresaid interuall be lesse then the height of the staffe,Secunda exempli differentia. then the proposed altitude is greater then the intercapedicall plaine, which is comprehended betwixt thy eie and the base of the altitude required; and the altitude hath ye same proportion vnto the longitude of the plaine, as the staffe hath vnto the interuall, betwixt thy eie and the foote of the staffe as is not difficult to perceiue by the staffe E G, and the interuall A E: for euen as the staffe E G doth containe the interuall A E once and a halfe, after the same maner the altitude B H doth comprehend A B the longitude once and a halfe; A B the longitude doth containe 6 such parts, therefore B H shall be 9. so that the halfe of A B is to be added the whole longitude, that the foresaid altitude may appeare.

3 Furthermore if the foresaid interuall be greater then the length of the said staffe,Tertia exempli differentia. then the foresaid longitude shall also be greater then the altitude proposed, and in such proportion the length shall excéede the height, as the interuall doth the staffe.

As for the purpose, such proportion as I K hath to the internall A I, the like hath the height L B to A B: I K is to A I in a sesquialiter proportion, whereupon it commeth to passe that A B ye measured longitude, cōtaineth B L the altitude once and a halfe: therefore it A B be 6. cubits, B L the altitude is 4: so that a third part of the said A B is to be taken away, that the proposed altitude B L may appeare.

The reason of this and all other such examples whatsoeuer,Praedictorum confirmatio Geometrica. do hang on the equal proportion of angles & sides of Tryangles: and that we may summarily,Eu. l. 4.5 & 7. p. 6. or compendiously comprehend all things before recited, behold A C D, and A B H together
with A C K,
Ra. 7. p. 9.10, 12 and A B L, are alike equianguled: therefore as the side A C is to the side C D in the Tryangle A C D, so is the right line A B to B E: and also as A E is to E G, so is A B to B H: and as A I is to I K, so is A B to B L,

div.head: CHAP. X.
To setch altitudes by the visuall beames reflected into a glasse pleasantly and with great facilitie.
div.p: TAke a plaine glasse, and throw the saine vpon the ground,Altitude by a glasse. then depart from or draw neare thereunto, vntill such time as you see the top of the Tower in the glasse to answer with the top of your hollow staffe held perpendicular: then measure the distance betwixt the foote of your staffe, and the marke in the glasse where you fixed your eie, for such proportion as the said internall or distance hath to the staffe, the like hath the length from the glasse vnto the base of the perpendicular, vnto the height desired.

Let A B be a Turret whose altitude is required, let the glasse be C, the center of the eie E, the staffe erected perpendicular D E: therefore it commeth to passe, as C D is to D E, so is C B to B A: the altitude C D is 6. foote, and so is D E: therefore C B is equal to B A, C B is 6. yards, therefore C A is 6. yards; worke by the
29. Chapter of the second Booke.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
To fetch the altitude of a Tower or such like, after a new way not spoken of heretofore, and that with great ease.
div.p: SUppose that you were vpon the top of the Towre F, Altitude by a glasse. where you might behold another Towre, as A: now suppose there were a man standing at C in the open field betwixt the two Towres A F, who defired the altitude of the Towre A B, from the place where he stāds, he could tell you no more but how farre the Towre was from him, how farre from you he or the Towre was he could not tell, and yet he required the altitude: now imagine also you might not stirre frō F to fetch ye altitude of F G, or the longitude of G C, nor G B to performe it by any proposition heretofore, so then must you worke it in this maner.

Cause the man in the field to throw the glasse on the ground, iust where his féete were: then cause him to moue it vp or downe (kéeping it parallell) vntill you sée the top of the Towre A B reflected therein, so will the visuall beames be A C F: then with the legges of your instrument by the 4. Chapter, Prop. 4. Booke 2. take the quantitie of the angle C F G, which note downe, viz. 4 • . deg • ées: so this is all the obseruations that you shall make, and yet we will fetch the quantitie of euery angle in the 2. tryangles, which is more then was proposed.

First take the angle C F G from 90. (for C G F is knowne to be a right angle) so haue you the quantity of the third angle F C G Ra. lib. 6. Pro. 9. , which is equall to the angles A C B, as may be proued Per sextam secundae partis perspectiuae communis, at que decimam 12 & 13.
Eu. 32. p. 1.
perspectiuae Vitellionis.

Hauing taken the angle C F G, as before, viz. 45. take that from 90. so haue you the angle A C B, viz. 45. degrées: this had, count the line B C vpon the left legge of the instrument, viz. 6. cubits, where make a marke: then open the legges vnto an angle of 45. degrées by the second Booke, Chapter 6, and bring the center of the graduator vnto the point before noted, viz. 6. cubits ye length of C B from the center of the instrument: the graduator resting there,Lib. 2. Cap. 26. and the angle before made vpon the féete not altered, make equation,* and then remoue the right legge vnto a right angle: the parts then included betwixt the graduator and the center of the instrument is the iust altitude, viz. 6. cubits.
Now if you require the quātitie of the other two angles, take 45. from 90, so haue you the angle B A C, because the angle A B is knowne to be right.
In like maner, if the man had giuen you the altitude of the Tower, and required the distance thereof from him, it must haue béene performed as before, as you may perceiue, Lib. 2. Chap. 14. deft. 2.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
To fetch heights after another way (by their shadowe) then was spoken of before.
