div.p: ERect your hollow staffe perpendicular, and note the length of the shadow,Altitudes by their shadowe. then sée what proportion it beareth vnto the said staffe: next measure the length of the shadowe of the thing, whose altitude is required: for such proportion as the length of the shadowe had to the hollow staffe, the same shall the shadowe of the altitude haue to the altitude it selfe.

The staffe is D E, his shadowe D C, the shadowe of the altitude is B C: therefore such proportion as C D hath to D E, the like hath B C to B A: D E is equall to D C, therfore A B is equall to B C: worke as before.Lib. 2. Chap. 29.

Many things more might bee said of the Hypsometricall Scale: but it were tedious to write all. Here is all set downe that Orontius speakes of, whose limits I intend not here to excéede in that behalfe, because I haue chosen him for my Author: onely profundities and lengths in heights are wanting, which he hath wrote of, the which I here omit, because I will shew their vse in the Geometricall quadrant ensuing now next: and as I haue applyed the staffe vnto Orontius, so likewise haue I aswell made choise of diuerse other Authors, as you may perceiue by the Title of the Chapter, as also added many new conclusions: & for that you shall the better vnderstand the diuisions, proportions and subdiuisions herein contained, I haue inserted a compēdious Table, which may much enlighten a weake vnderstanding.
div.trailer: The end of the third Booke.

div.head: A Generall Table of Number, declaring not onely all their kindes of number, and in what diuision or subdiuision, any number whatsoeuer is comprehended: but also sundry varieties of proportion arising by the comparison of numbers together, aswell in quantitie as in qualitie.
The branch most necessary for this third and fourth Booke.

div.p: which is so much as ½ 3/1 4/1 5/1 1 ½ 1 ⅓ 1 ¼ 1 ⅕ 1 ⅔ 1 ¾ 1 ⅘ 1 ⅚ 2 ½ 2 ⅓ 2 ⅕ 3 ⅙ 3 1/7 3 ⅛ 4 1/9 4 1/10 4 ¼ 2 ⅔ 2 ¾ 2 ⅘ 3 ⅔ 3 ¾ 3 ⅘ 4 ⅔ 4 ¾ 4 ⅘ This proportion of the lesser inequalitie is when the antccedent exceeds the consequent, as 2 to 3, as 5 to 7, if you deuide 2 by 3, the quot ent is 2 thirds, if 5 by 7, the • u ••• 5 7 parts, so that this d ••• ereth not from the former, onely to euery name this word sub is ioyned.

div.head: THE FOVRTH BOOKE of the Geodeticall Staffe, concerning the vse of the Geometricall quadrant:

According as it is set downe by Orontius: so that in practising by this staffe, you may worke by the quadrant it selfe at first inspection; set downe both Arithmeticall, according to the said Orontius doctrine, and mechanicall, agreeing to the vulgar capacitie.
CHAP. I.
To take the Horizontall distance of any marke from you, with or without the helpe of Arithmeticall calculation, and that at one station.
div.p: De metienda linea super idenplanum. BEcause we will saue a labour in the cutting of new figures, we will take the demonstration in the third Booke, Chap. 2.

Let therefore the marke whose distance is required be F, the place where you stand E: where erect your staffe at right angles with the ground line, by the third Booke, Chap. 1. then take the angle of longitude F A E by the 2. Booke, Chap. 4. Prop. 1. next sée what parts of thevide lib. 1. Pro. 2. Defi. 9. geometricall quadr • nt are cut by the right point respectiue: for such proportion as 60. hath to the parts cut, the like hath the length of the staffe vnto the altitude.

Let the right point respectiue cut 15. parts at G, then such proportion as 60. hath to 15, the like hath A E the staffe to E F the longitude: 60 is to 15 in a quadruplate proportion: therefore A E must néeds containe E F 4. times, A E is soure foote, therefore
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
E F is 16 foote: beare this Prop. in minde, for he commeth often in vse hereafter.

Hopt. And here we may worke better then Orontius, because the staffe in these operations represents ye one of the sides of the quadrant, which by how much it is larger, by so much it workes truer then the quadrant.
And to put by Arithmeticke, workeLib. 2. Chap. 29. thus, saying: if 60. giue 15. what shall 4. giue?

div.head: CHAP. II.
You standing vpon the toppe of a Turret, to measure the distance of any marke seene before you on the ground.
div.p: Qualiter ex alto linea recta in plano metiatur. IF thou standing on the toppe of a Turret or any such like, & doest sée any marke vpon ye ground, whose distance thou wouldest measure, the ground being plaine, and making right angles with the said Turret, do thus.
Let the Turret be B E, the line proposed E F, or E H, or E K, whose longitude from the foote of the Towre B is required by the geometricall quadrant.

Take therefore the angle of longitude by the first Booke, placing the left legge of your staffe by the side of the Turret, and heauing vp the right legge vntill by the fidutiall edge thereof, you sée the marke, whose distance is required: then bring the graduator vnto the points respectiue, and note the parts cut in the geometricall quadrant: for either the section will be at C, which is the middest of the graduator, or betwixt B and C, or betwixt C and D, of necessitie.

1 Quando linea data aequalis est alti ab oculo. First let the parts cut be in C, and let the proposed line to be measured be E F; I say the line E F to be equall with A E ye the perpendicular, because the graduator is cut in 60. parts at C therefore measure A E, so haue you E F; which happens so often as the point respectiue cuts the graduator at 60. parts.

2 But if the segment by the right point respectiue be made betwixt B and C, as in G, De linea cadem altitu, ab oculo minore. then the proposed line to bee measured E H, is shorter then the perpendicular A E, and hath such proportion to the longitude E H, as 60 hath to the parts cut: therefore if B G be 40. parts, because 60 is to 40 in a sesquialiter proportion, in the same maner A E shall containe E H once and a halfe: therefore measure A E by a thread, and take thence a third part of the length thereof, that is of A E; so haue you E H.
As if A E were 24. cubits, then E H the desired line should be 16 cubits
Hopt. Or say, if 60 giue 40, what shall 24. giue?Vide lib. 2, cap. 29.

3 But if the segment bee made betwixt C and D, as in I, and the line to be measured be E K, Cum cadem linea altitu. ab oculo superat. then the said E K shall be longer then A E the perpendicular; and such proportion as ye parts cut haue to 60, the like hath the-altitude A E to E K, the proposed longitude.
Let D I be 40 parts, 40 is to 60 in a sesquialiter proportion, whereupon the foresaid E K containes A E once and a halfe: so as if A L be 24 cubits, E K is 36 such cubits.
Hopt. Worke by the legges as before, saying: if 40 giue 60, what shall 24 giue? you finde 36 cut.

div.head: CHAP. III.
You standing vpon the ground, how to measure the perpendicular altitude of any thing standing orthogonaliter vpon plaine ground.

p.hi: Because the working of this Chapter is but vice versa to the former, we will therefore turne the figure thereof vpside downe, and so make him serue our purpose.

div.p: FOr the auoiding of proffers, let the altitude be A K, A F, or A H, Generalis operāds modus. erected perpendiculary vpon the plaine A E: then placing your staffe at A, take the angle of altitudeVide lib. 2. cap. • . Pro. 3. : which done, consider the section made in the parts of the geometricall quadrant by the right point respectiue, that is, whether it be made in the point C, which is at 60 in the middest of the graduator, or betwixt B C, or else betwixt C D: for because it cannot bee made in any other manner.

1 Quando linea data maior est intercapedine plani. First therefore let the section be made betwixt C D, as in I, and let the altitude to be measured be A K: then the altitude shall be greater then the space intercepted betwixt thy staffe and the base: and such proportion as the parts cut haue to 60, the like hath the line A E to E K, the altitude.
As if D I were 40 parts, because 60 to 40 is in a sesquialiter proportion, so likewise A E shall containe E K once and a halfe: therefore if A E were 18 cubits, E G must containe 27 such cubits.

2 De linea aequalidistantiae ab ocuio ad basim. But let the parts cut be 60 in the point C, and let the altitude be E F: then such proportion as the said parts cut haue to 60, the like hath A E to E F.
A E is 18 cubits, therefore it may be inferred that the said line E F proposed to be measured, is also 18 such cubits: therfore measure A E, so haue you E F.

3 Quando plani longitudo datam superat altitud. When the foresaid section is made betwixt C and B, as in G: then the proposed altitude shall be lesse then the line A E, intercepted betwixt thy eie and the base of the said altitude E H: so that such proportion as 60 hath to the parts cut, the like hath A E to the altitude E H.

Let B G be 40 parts, then because 60 is to 40 in a sesquialiter proportion, therefore E A shall containe E F once & a halfe, so that if you measure A E, and take away a third part thereof, you haue E F: as if A E were 18 cubits, you may conclude E F to be 12 such cubits, and so of any other of those parts. Therefore if 60 giue 40, what shall 18 giue? you shall finde 12, and so worke as before.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
To measure inaccessible heights by the geometricall quadrant.
div.p: THere be many altitudes whose base we cannot come vnto, by reason of waters or ditches in the earth, or such other prohibiting impediments: when such altitudes happen whose height be required, in this maner shalt thou worke.

Choose some conuenient place, and there plant thy staffe,Operandi regula. and take the angle of altitude by the 2. Booke, 4 Chapter, as heretofore: then note the parts of the geometricall quadrant cut by the right point respectiue, obseruing what proportion they haue to 60, and those kéepe in minde: then go direct backwards, or drawe neare vnto the altitude, euen as the aptnes • e of the place requires, and there againe plant thy staffe, taking the angle of altitude: and then note the parts of the quadrant cut, and what proportion they haue to 60. Now consider whether the parts kept at this station of the first be greater, and then subtract the lesser from the greater, & that which remaineth kéepe in mind: then measure the interuall or stationary line, which diuide by ye former or occurrent number, which after subtraction was the denominator, and then the quotient thereof ingendred declareth the altitude.

Whereupon if there were a vnite left, the interuall comprehended betwixt the two stations,Corolarium. is to be taken for the altitude: for because a vnite neither in deuiding or multiplying, doth alter the number, as is said before.

By example what we haue said, it may be, it will be the better vnderstoode; let therefore the proposed Turret be E F compassed about with water, whose altitude is required: let the first angle of altitude be at G, and the parts cut vpon the graduator be D H, 20 at the point H: 20 to 60, is in a triple proportiō, therefore keepe 3 for the denominator. This so done, go to the second station, viz. to I, and there againe take the angle of altitude, noting the parts cut, and then see what proportion they haus to 60: the parts cut here are 12, betwixt D K, at the point K: 60 to 12, is in a quintuplate proportion: therefore kéepe 5 for the second denominator: next take 3 from 5, there remaineth 2, which kéepe for the vpright, next measure the distance G I, and let it be 24 cubits: which diuide by 2, so is the quotient 12: so many cubits high is E F the altitude.

div.head: CHAP. V.
You being vpon the toppe of a high Turret or such like, how to measure the altitude of any other Turret, though he be farre lower.
div.p:
Ex altiori breuicrem altitudinem met • ri. LEt the greater altitude be A E, from the toppe whereof you are put to measure the lower altitude G F: therefore place the left legge to point iust to F, and open the right leg to the angle F A G: the right and left legge so resting, and pointing to the former markes, place a thread with a plumb at the end, in some part of the right leg, and to cut the left legge A D at what parts you will, as H I: then consider what proportion A I hath to the part of the thread, intercepted betwixt the two legges of the instrument: for the same proportion shall the visuall beame
A F haue to the proposed and lesse altitude F G.

For there be two tryangles, A H I, and A F G, alike equall: & because the angle at A is common to both the tryangles,Probatio Geoemtrica. and the angle A H I intrinsicall, and of the same parts is equall to the angle A G F, and also the angle A I H is equall to the intrinsicall angle A F G, as may be prouedEu. 1. Pro. 29. Eu. lib. 4. p. 5.6. Ra lib. 7 pro. 9. : therefore such proportion as A I hath to A H, that keepe: for A F shall haue the like, to F G the altitude, as may be proued.

Therefore it shall be necessarie to teach you how to finde the quantitie of the line F A, which thou shall do after this maner: take the longitude of A E by some plumb line, then measure E F by the second Chapter, or any other in this Booke:Inuentio. Diagonalis. afterwards multiply A E and E F in themselues quadrately, and reduce the product thereof into one number, and then extract the quadrant roote from the foresaid aggregated number: for that shall be the side A F of the right angled tryangle A E F. For example, let A
E be 8 pearches, and E F 6: therefore 8 multiplied in 8, makes 64, afterwards 6 times 6 is 36: put 64 and 36 together, so will there result 100, the roote quadrature whereof is 10: therefore 〈◊〉 many pearches A F: the thread H I in the middest of A D, the
left legge, and A I, is double to I H: therefore A F is double to F G: so of consequence F G is 5 pearches, such as A F was 10.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
To worke the last Chapter versavice.
div.p: IF you would worke the former Chapter contrarie, as to stād at O the lesse altitude, and fetch R E the greater, do thus: place the left legge O Z to ly parallell, then hsaue vp the right legge O P, vntill you haue taken the angle R O L: so O L E F is a parallelogram, whose opposite sides are equall, as may bee proued *:Eu. lib. 3.4. p. 1. Ra. 10. p. 6. cons, 2 therefore measure O F by a thread, so haue you L E: then take the length of E F by the 2 Chapter, so haue you O L by the former alledged reason: * then take the altitude L R by the third Chapter, which added to L E, the altitude appeares: for such proportion as 60 hath to the parts cut, the like hath O L to L R, by the third Chapter, Defi. 3.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
How to measure the longitude of any mountaine, whose toppe stands not perpendicular ouer the base, but hangs sidewise.
div.p:
To seeke the height or length of mo •
taines. THe longitude of any mountaine whose toppe bends from, or hangs not oner the base perpendicular, is had no otherwise then you found the length of lines lying vpon plain ground by the first Chapter: therefore you must obserue that maner of working: and here you shall sée the necessary vse of ye first Chapter, Booke 3.

Summarius operandi modus. Let E F be the mountaine proposed to be measured, F the top thereof, hanging like the reoffe of a house from E: place therefore your staffe by ye preallegated Chapter, so that he may make right angles with the ground line E F: then take the angle of longitudeVide lib. 2. Chap 4. pro. 1,
A F E, and note the parts of the geometricall quadrant cut by the right point respectiue.
For such proportion as the parts cut haue to 60, the like hath the length of the staffe to the longitude E F.

Let the right legge A B cut the graduator at 10 parts, viz. at G: then because 60 to 10 is in a sextuplate proportion, in like
maner E F the longitude containes A E 6 times; whereupon if the staffe were 4 foots, the longitude is 24 foots.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
To take the altitude of a Tower &c. placed vpon the toppe of a hill, or such like.
div.p:
Quomodo altit •
do linearum disquiratur. LEt the Turret be P R, placed vpon the top of the mountain S R: then by the last Chapter, take the longitude of ye mountaine S R betwixt the foote thereof, and the base of the Towre, which let be 18: then turne the left legge S H to point iust to the base of the Towre R, heauing vp the right legge S G, vntill he
point iust to P, the top of the Towre: the legs resting in this maner, let fall a thread with a plumb from the right legge to cut the left legge S H in what part you will, as G H the thred, deu •
ding the legge S G into two equall parts at the point H: then measure the part of the thread G H intercepted betwixt both the legges, and also the part of the legge S H intercepted betwixt S H: for such proportion as the part S H hath to the part of the thread G H, the like hath S R, the length of the mountaine, to R P.

Geometrica probatio. For the two tryangles S G H, and S P R be alike equall, as may be proued Eu. 29.1. Ra. 7. P. 9. Eu. 4 & 5.6. P. : and for because the angle S H G intrinsicall, is equall to the like parts of the angle S R F, it is proued, that as S H is to H G, so is S R to R P, the proposed altitude.

Let for example S H cut halfe the left legge, and H G bee a quarter, that is 15 parts, because the leg is imagined to be 60, so as S H will bee 30: then because 30 is to 15, in a duplatine proportion, therefore S R the longitude shall containe R P the altitude of the Turret twice: and we haue supposed S R the longitude to containe 18 cubits, therefore R P the altitude must bee but 9 cubits; which you may worke by the golden rule, saying:

First multiply 18 by 15, there is 270, which deuide by 30, so haue you 9 for your quotientingendred, the altitude; or worke as I haue often aduertised you by the 2 Booke, 29. Chapter without Arithmeticke.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
How lengths in heights are found out.
div.p: Length: in height are found. VVE will make short of this Chapter, because of his facilitie in working. Suppose that you were standing at F, and desired the length of A L in the altitude A E, first take the altitude of E L, then of E A; lastly take the lesser out of the greater, the remainder is your desire.

p.hi: To performe the same by the staffe other waies.

div.p:
First take the height of L E as before, then open the legges vnto a right angle, turning the right legge towards the height, & holding the left parallell, then remoue the left sight so farre from the center as you be from the base of the Tower; next remoue ye right site to the height of L E vpon the right legge: so you placing
your eis at the left site, you may sée the right site, and the said left to be in a right line with the said latitude L: the legs so resting, heaue vp the moueable end of the graduator not stirring the center thereof, vntill the fidutiall edge thereof point iust in a right line, to A: the parts then intercepted betwixt the right site and the edge of the graduator vpon the right legge, is the height of L A: so of any other.

div.head: CHAP. X.
To take the depth or profunditie of any Well or such like.
div.p: I Haue often told you that profundities bee but reuersed altitudes, therefore we will make short of Orontius, and onely proceede to the matter.

Let therfore the oblated pit be quadrangular B E F G, Profunditie. whose depth B G, or E F is proposed to be measured: place therefore ye left legge to lie in a right line with B G: he resting so, remous the right legge vntill by the center A C, the site therein, you see the further side of the pit F, which is opposite to you at B: then
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
sée what parts of the geometrical quadrant be cut, as you be wont: for such proportion as the parts cut haue to 60, the like hath the diameter E B to the profunditie B G, or E F; so measuring E B, you haue your desire.

For example, B H is 20 parts cut, Eu. lib. 34. P. 1. Ra. li. 10. P. 6. c. 2 B E measured is 6 cubits, and so many cubits is F G, as is proued: therefore multiply 6 by sixtie, there is made 360; which deuide by 20, the quotient is 18, and so many cubits is A G; from which if you take A B, the length of the left foote, you haue B G.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
To performe the last Chapter by the equall parts of the legs.
div.p:
FIrst take the angle F B E
Lib. 2, cap. 4. P. 4. as you are often instructed, next measure the line B E; this done, count the line E B vpon the left legge, whereunto bring the center of the graduator, and then make equation,Lib, 2, cap, 26. * not stirring the legges: which done, wrest the screw at the center of the graduator hard, so that the angle be not altered: lastly remaue the right legge vnto a right angle; ye parts then intercepted betwixt the graduator and the center of the initrument, is the length of B G.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
To performe the foresaid Chapter otherwise.
div.p:
Open the legge vnto a right angle, and there fasten them, remoue then the center of the graduator so farre from the center of the instrument as the line B E shall instruct you; then place the said left legge to lie parallell to the line B E, so will the right legge be in a right line with G B: the legs so resting, moue the moueable end of the graduator vp and downe, vntill you sée by the fidutiall edge thereof, the bottome of the pitte opposite to you, as to E: the equall parts then that the fidutiall edge of the graduator cut vpon the right legge, is the depth of the pit, as may be proued * Eu. 4 & 5. P. 6
R. 7. P. 9..

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
To measure prosundities by the hypsometricall Scale.
div.p: LEt the pit or Well whose depth is sought, be E B G F: Profundities by the Hypsometricall seale. place the left legge of your instrument A B to stand perpendicular vpon the line B G: then remoue the right legge vntill he point iust to the opposite and profundest part of the pit, as to F: which done, bring the graduator vnto the points respectiue, and note the parts of the hypsometricall scale cut:Lab. 1. pro. 2. next measure the line or diameter E B: Desi, 10. for such proportion as the parts cut haue to 12, the like hath E B the diameter to B G, the profunditie.

E B is 6 foote, the parts cut be 4: multiply 6 by 12, there commeth 72, which deuide by 4; there is 18 foote the depth of B G or E F: or worke as I haue often instructed you, by the legges, saying, if 4 giue 12, what shall 6?

div.head: CHAP. XIIII.
To fetchaswell the length of the sides, as also the perpendicular depth of any value or such like.
div.p:
IT is auaileable oftentimes to know the depth and latitude of vallies, or such like, which you shall doe in this maner. Let the vallie be F, EE, FF, such as they be wont to dig about
the walles of Citties, whose greatest latitude F, FF is required, and also his greatest profunditie GG De Vallis aut fossae latitudine. EE: take therefore the longitude of D F by the second Chapter, which let be 18 cubits: then by the doctrine of the said second Chapter, take the dorsine longitude, or the length of F, EE, which let be 15 cubits.

Multiply then 15 in it selfe, and there is made 225, afterward multiply the halfe of F, FF in it selfe, that is F, GG, 9 cubits; and there arifeth 81: take then 81 from 225, there remaineth 144, ye quadrant roote whereof is 12: so many cubits may you conclude the profunditie GG, EE to be; so of any such like.

And here we will conclude this fourth Booke, together with the first Booke of Orontius, presuming that there can no right line happen howsoeuer scituate, but he may be measured by the doctrine beforesaid.

div.trailer: The end of the fourth Booke.

div.head: THE FIFTH BOOKE OF the Geodeticall Staffe, containing the vse of the Iacobs staffe, together with the working of the Golden rule by scale and compasse • without Arithmeticke.

Also you are taught to worke the rule of proportion after another way then in the second Booke, that is, with scale and compasse, with such speede as hath not beene seene or heretofore published by any; also it teacheth you the golden rule inuersed, and the double golden rule without Arith-meticke, with the construction of a new scale.
CHAP. I.
Of the Iacobs staffe, of the comparing him with the Geodetical staffe, together with the things requisite for to be obserued in the vse thereof.
div.p: THe Iacobs Staffe is an instrument consisting of two rules made 4 square,Descriptie Baculi Iac. and truely tride: the longer of the two rules is called the Index or yard: the shorter is called the Transum, or Transuersarium, that is the transuerse or ouerthwart rule: for because he must alwaies lie crosse on ye yard, making right angles. The yard with some is deuided into 2100 equall parts, & the Transuerse into 1000 such like parts, with other lesse, according as the vse thereof occasions them: the Transuerse & the yard are coupled together, so that the one may moue along the other at right angles.

This instrument by some is said to take his name of Iacob, Nominatio Eaculi Iac. grounding their reasons vpon these words in the Bible, For
with my staffe came I ouer this Iorden: Gen, Cap. 32. and the name might be well taken, the nee vpon diuerse reasons, though the staffe hee vsed there, be interpreted to no Mathematicall vse: others say he taketh his name of Iacob, for because he was inuented of that Patriarch himselfe, or his vse was most in request about the time of Iacob: and there is no one of these prealiegated reasons, but there may be sufficient causes vrged to induce some credit to the foundation of their opinions that so called the said staffe: but howsoeuer, it is written of the better sort, this instrument Esse omnium reliquorum geodaeticorum instrumentorum commodissimum, which also is well demonstruted by P. Ramus
Lib. 9. Pro. 1.2 3.4.5.6.7. &c. . Now for the affinitie that this staffe hath to the Geodeticall staffe, I say, the equall deuisions are alike vpon both, but those of the legs of my staffe be not so many:Lib. 2. cap. 1 no. 3 notwithstanding you be * instructed to make them as many as you will, they also agree because they be both right angles: now the diffecence of these two staues is this, the Iacobs staffe hath a transuerse to moue along towards or fromwards the end of the yard: which my staffe hath not, but is aswell supplied by the site in the left legge, which doth represent the yard: for you may mo • ue him towards or fromwards the right legge at pleasure, aswell as you could the transuerse vpon the yard. The Iacobs staffe hath also a yard to moue vp and downe vpon the transuerse, so that he may be neare vnto ye one end, & further off the other end, or contrary, as occasion requires. My staffe cannot doe so, howheit you may moue the equicurrall site in the right leg in such forte, so that the right legge may supply the vse of the transuerse in as good and easte sort as the transuerse it selfe.

The things requisite to bee obserued herein, and in thè vse hereof, are no other then such as be remembred in the 1 Chapter and second Booke, in the end thereof: whereunto for breuities sake I referre you, onely here the legges must still be kept at a right angle by helpe of a pin put thorough the hole neare the center, for so much I entend in euery proposition.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the making of a new Scale, and to worke the golden rule thereby.
div.p:
In my second Booke I spake of the deliuering the 400 part of an inch, which I held no instrument could doe: howbeit I wil
affirme, that by this scale you may giue the smallest part as can be required, and possibly laid downe: and indéede this kinde of scale aboue all others for exactnesse and trueth is best, as you shall finde by practising thereon.

Prepare therefore a fine péece of wood, or rather brasse well smoothed & polished of 6 inches long, as M O, or thereabouts; and an inch or inch and quarter broad, as M N: now you must consider according vnto how many parts in the inch you would make your scale, I make this according vnto 40, deuide your ruler first into inches, as R.S.T.V.VV.O: then deuide euery inch into 4 equall parts, aswell on the side N B, as on M O; thē draw the Isosceles tryangles, according as in the figure, still skipping one deuision, so shall you make N 10 and 20: the first Isosceles; then 10 20 and 30, the next Isosceles, and so procéed. Lastly deuide the side M N into 10 equall parts (for because 4 times 10 maketh 40) and from each deuision draw parallell lines to M O, according as you sée: then put figures at euery angle of the Isosceles, according as in the demonstration: and if you would haue made your scale according vnto 20, or 16, &c. in the inch, you must then haue deuided M N but into 5 or 4 equall parts, because 4 in 5 is 20, or 4 times 4 is 16, &c.

The numbersincreasing by 10, are set downe vpon the side M O and N B, which you may take thence with your compasse: but if any of those numbers haue an vnite annexed, as 7 to 10 making it 17, or 5 to 20 making 25 &c. then must you place the foote of your compasse in the line M N, extending the other along one of the parallell lines according vnto the number proposed: and you must note that the figures increasing to 9 at the toppe of the rule M N, serue for the side N B, and the figures belowe for the side M O. I would expresse a line 45 parts long: according vnto the prescript, place one foote of your compasse in the line M N, at the end of the parrallell marker with 5, extending the other foote along that parallell, vntill it cut the side of the I sosceles running from 40 to 50; which will fall at Z your desire.

I would haue aline 98 parts long, according vnto the prescript, I place the one foote of my compasse in the line M N, at the end of the parallell answering to 8 in the lower end O B, extending the other foote of my compasse to the intersection of that eight parallell, with the side of the Isosceles extended betwixt
90 and 100, which will fall out at the point marked with 98; which is your desire, and so of all the rest.
Now if you would apply this scale vnto 20 in the inch, you must omit euery other parallell, &c.
And note, the broader you make your scale, the truer shall your worke be.

p.hi: The ruler made, you shall worke the golden rule thereby thus.

div.p: Draw two lines, which let intersect, making what angle you will at all aduentures, that is, it forceth not how big or little a quantitie so euer the angle be, as for the purpose B A C; thess two lines so drawne vpon a faire shéete of paper, of some smooth boord or slate &c. procéede thus,
Let the proposition be, if 36 giue 72, what shall 40 giue?

First with your compasse take the length of 36 degrées, and place that in the line A C (being one of the sides of the foresaid angle) by putting the one foote of your compasse in A, and extending the other towards C, and where he falles, make the point D: next take the third number giuen, that is 40, which taken with your compasse from your scale as before, place it in the line A B, the one foote of your compasse resting at A, the other extended towards B, as to F: next draw a straite line frō D to F, and so beyond F at your pleasure, then with your compasse take from your scale the length of your second number giuen, 72, which place in the line A C, from A towards C, as at E: this done, from the point E drawe a line E G parallell to the line D F, (which you be after taught how to do,) but to finde the fourth number in proportion, I say it is already found: for note where the line E G intersects with the line A B, as at G: then take the length of A G, and apply it vnto the scale among the diuisions, as you worked before: and so many equall parts as be contained betwixt the two féete of your cō, passe, so much is the fourth number in proportion, which you shall finde to be 80.

You shall draw the line G D parallell to D F thus: take ye length of D E with your compasse, the same widenesse remaining, place the one foote in the line F D at all aduentures, as at H: with the other describe the portion of a circle, as K I: then lay a rule vpon E, and the very edge of the I K, as at L: now by the fidutiall edge of your scale or rule, Ra. lib. 2. P. 11. & Ra. 5. Pr. 11. Eu. 2. P. 6. & 17. l. line as long as you will, viz, E G, which shall be parallell to F. D. as may be prouedEu. lib. 1. defi. 35.

The ground of this working may be gathered from in fallible Geometricall demonstrations *. Ra. 5. P. 13. con. 1 2 & 3.
Eu. 2 P, lib 6. R. 8. P. lib. 6.

div.head: CHAP. III.
To worke the golden rule reuersed, called in latine, Regula euersa.
div.p: Regula euersa. THis rule is termed reuersed or inuersed, when the question is so propounded, that according vnto the course of numbers, the fourth should surmount the third, and yet in reason it must needs be lesse; or contrary according vnto course of numbers diminishing, when it should increase: as for the purpose, if 12 Masons can be able to make a certaine wall in 20 daies, how many shall make the same in fine daies?

Here it is apparent that by course of numbers, as 12 is lesse then 20, so the fourth sought should be lesse then the third, and therefore consequently much more then 12 daies: but reason teacheth that if 12 men be 20 daies about a peece of worke, if you would haue the same dispatched in lesse time, it is requisite to haue more then 12 men; the course of numbers therefore, & the truth in reason being repugnant, you must worke by the rule of proportion inuersed.

This reciprocall or conuersed proportionalitie is such a proportion, which beginneth with the first number, comparing it forwards directly, but not to the next terme, but vnto the third and then with the fourth or last terme, comparing it vnto the second conuersely, as it were backwards: as for the purpose, comparing these 4 tearmes before remembred, 12, 20, 5, 48, I say thus, as 12 exceedeth 5, so doth 48, 20, whereby you see there is a true proportion; otherwise if the proportionall 80 termes had beene inferred as they stand, there had béene an vtter disproportionality: therefore to worke this rule, we must reduce the numbers giuen into a direct proportion thus, not euersed, put the third terme first, the first second, and the second last, so will they stand thus: if 5 giue 12, what shall 20: and so working by the doctrine of the second Chapter, you shall finde 48 your demand: for as 5 is to 12, so is 20 to 48, or as 5 is to 20, so is 12 to 48; but conuersed in direct proportion thus, they should stand 12, 5, 48, 20, so as 12 is to 5, so is 48 to 20: so that by the prescript you sée, there is 48 men required to finish that wall in 5 daies, which 12 men were about 20 daies.
And this rule may be easily wrought vpon the legges of the staffe, euen as it is here.
Another example.
If 20 men can vndermine a Towne in 30 daies, how many will doe it in 8 daies.

And here I could easily teach you to worke the double ruls,Re • ul •• diplex. but for because we shall haue small vse thereof in these intended workes, and also for that the former operations well vnderstood, the working thereof is very facill, we will here omit the same vntil I we be further occasioned that way by some fit incitation.

And here you must note that this kinde of working medleth not with fractions or irrationalities, for because it is the office of geometry to proceed no further then to proue that there are irrationals medling onely with rationall and whole numbers. Infinite waies could I teach you to apply the vse of this scale, as to finde out the proportion of lines one vnto another, to draw figures, mays, sea-cards &c. proportional in a lesse or greater figure, &c. all which wee will put ouer vntill I haue accomplisht my present intendements.

div.head: CAAP. IIII.
How many vvaies the Iacobs staffe will performe Dimensions; whereupon he dependeth, and what he requireth.
div.p:
The Iacobs staffe finds out the height and length of any thing three seuerall waies, and breadths two waies; the two first waies require you to make obseruations but once, ye third way must be performed at two obseruations, that is at two stations: and you must vnderstand that all the measures performed vpon the Iacobs staffe depend vpon three numbers giuen to finde out the fourth, whereby you may perceius how apt the second Chapter is to bee coupled to the vse of this said staffe. Two of these giuen numbers are alwaies found vpon the staffe of the one, vpon the Inder or yard, the other vpon the Transuerse: but in our working the one is vpon the right leg, the other vpon the left legge; the third number assigned in proportion is some thing which is measured: for in the measuring of lengths, heights, &c. you must haue some thing or other measured,
sured, which must be the third number in proportion; which 3 numbers had, and all things considered, fall to worke thus.

div.head: CHAP. V.
By some knowne altitude to find out the vnknowne longitude at one station.

p.hi: Si visus sit ab indicis recti in metam longitudinis:
p.note: Rae. lib, 9 P. 7. ex 21, P. optic. Eucl.
p.hi: vt tunc erit segmētum indicis ad segmentum Transuersais, sic mensoris altitudo ad quaesitam longitudinem.

div.p: IF the sight passe from the beginning of the inder, being right to the thing measured, vnto the end of the length; as the segment of the inder shall be vnto the segment of the Transuersarie, so is the height of the measure vnto the length.

And here you must vnderstand that by the height of the measurer, is not meant the height of the man that measureth simply, but the height or distance of his eie from the ground, be he vpon the ground or on a Towre, &c.

p.hi: As the equall parts included on the left legge, betwixt the site and the center, are to the parts on the right leg included betwixt the file and the center, so is the length to the height, and contrarie.

div.p: E statione vnica, longitudinem ignotam inuenire, ex alto. OPen therefore the legges of your staffe vnto a right angle, and there stay them by putting a pin through ye hole neare to the center, as you may perceiue in the figure in the first Booke; this done, take away the graduator, for here wee haue no vse thereof, and then procéede thus: place your staffs with the legges, so that the left legge may lie parallell, and the right perpendicular: as you be wontvide lib. 2. cap. 17. remoue the sites in the right and left legge vntill they both agree in one right line frō your eie to the marke whose longitude is required; which done, note the equall parts included betwixt the two sites, and the center vpon each leg: for such proportion as the parts cut haue one to the other, the like hath the height to the length or length to the height.

Suppose the parts included betwixt the site and the center vpon the right legge were 60, and the parts cut vpon the left legge by the site were 180, let the height of your eie from the ground be 4 pards: then worke with ease by the second Chapter, saying, if 60 the parts included vpon the right legge, giue 180, the parts included vpon the left legge, what shall 4 yards giue? so shall you finde 12, & so many yards may you conclude the height.
In the same maner may you measure heights standing below.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
To measure lengths standing vpon the ground at one station.
div.p: PLace your staffe to make right angles with the ground line asLib. 3. cap. 1 you be taught; the legs resting at right angles (as they alwaies must) place the left legge to lie parallell,Qualiter ex alto line 〈◊〉 in plane metiatur. then remone the sites in both the legges, vntill they agrée in a right line with the thing whose distance is required: then note the parts included betwixt the sites and the center vpon the right and left legge; for such proportion as the part cut vpon the right legge hath to the parts cut vpon the left legge, the like hath the height of your eie from the ground to the longitude.

Let the parts cut vpon the right legge be 20, and the parts of the le • t legge be 60, let the altitude of your eie be 4 foote: then say by the second Chap. if 20 giue 60, what shall 4 giue? so shall you finde 12 foote, the longitude desired.

Neither is it any matter whether the longitude be on plain ground or vpon hilly, so as you place your staffe at right angles with the ground line, as you haue * done before, Lib. 4. cap. 6. as it is written.

p.hi: Nec quidquaminterest, siue longitudo sit in subiecto plano, siue in ascensu descenuve montis, sursum deorsumve collimando: dummo do index in lineam longitudinis sit rectus.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
By the knowne altitude to finde the vnknowne longitude at one station, the left legge lying parallell, and the right standing perpendicular.

p.hi: Sivisus sit ab initio Indicis paralleli in metam longitudinis: vt erit segmentum transuresarii ad segmētum Indicis,
fic data sen cognita altitudo ad longitudinem.

div.p: If the fight passe from the end of the Inder, lying p •• allell vnto the thing measured, as the segment of the transnerss •• shall be vnto the segment of the Inder, so is the giuen height to the length.

p.hi: As the included parts vpon the right leg are to the parts included vpon the left legge, so is the giuen altitude to the longitude desired.

div.p: PLace, the left legge to lie parallell, and the right perpend cular, as before, and let the right legge he towards the perpendicular altitude, as in the second Booke, Chap. 16; then moue the fites vp and downe, vntill they he both in a right time with the altitude required: then note what equall parts be included betwixt the sites in each legge, and the center for such proportion as the parts included vpon the right legge haue to the parts included vpon the left legge, the like hath the altitude to the longitude desired.

Suppose you had the height of a Castle giuen you, and you being in the field farre off, were required to tell the diffance of the said Castle, let the parts included vpon the right legge be 120, or 60, let the altitude of the Towore giuen be 400, or 20 féete, let the parts included vpon the left legge vs 210, or 10 • : then if you worke by the second Chapter, you shall finde the longitude or distance of the said Towre from you to be 700, or 350 féete, and so of any other such like.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
By the knowne altitude to seeke any longitude at two stations, when you can worke by neither of the former waies.

p.hi: Si visus sit ab initio transuer sarii par alleli, in met am longitudinis, per terminum Indicis recti ad metam in alto propositam: vt erit in Indice differentia maioris segmenti ad minus,
sic differentia inter priman & secundam stationem ad longitudinem quaesitam

div.p:
If the sight passe from the end of the Transuersarie beeing
parallell, &c. as in the inder the difference of the greater segment is vnto the lesser, so is the difference of the second distāce vnto the length.

AS the difference of the greater parts included vpon the right legge, is vnto the lesser, the sight passing from the end of the left legge, or any part thereof, so shall the length betweene both the stations be to the distance required.

In the Iacobs staffe, here the yard standeth perpendicular, & the Trans. parallell, notwithstanding though wée haue appointed the left legge of our instrument to represent the yard, &c. yet let him lie parallell: as he was wont, for all is one.

Choose thée out therefore one station as neare vnto the altitude as thou wilt, and there plant thy staffe, so that the left leg lie parallell, and the right stand perpendicular, looking towards the altitude: then place thy eye at the end of the left legge, or in any place thereof, as you will, and looke by the very end of the left legge, or by the site therein placed any where, remouing the site in the right legge, vntill by the end of the left legge or site therein placed and the said right site, you sée the altitude or summite thereof: make a note in the right legge what parts the site cut, then the legges resting at a right angle, and the sites not stirred, go backwards in a right line from your first station the further the better, and there againe plant your instrument as beforevide lib. 2. cap. 36. ; then place your eie againe at the end of the left legge or the site therein, as you did before, drawing downe the site in the right legge vntill he be in a right line with your eie and the summite of the foresaid altitude: note againe the parts of the said right site then stands at: for such proportion as the former parts where the site was at ye first station, haue thereunto, the like hath the distance betwixt both the stations to the longitude required.

Suppose you make your first station, placing your eie at the and of the left legge, and remoue the site in the right legge, vntill he be in a right line with the altitude; let the parts the sites then stands at, be 72: then go backwards in a right line, which let be 40. féete, and there againe make collimation, drawing downe the site in the right legge, vntill he bee in a right line with your eie (placed at the end of the left legge) and the summite of the altitude, as before, let the parts the site then stands
at, be 36: then must I take the lesser out of the greater, vi • . 36 from 72, there remaineth 36: therefore I conclude thus, if 36 the difference of the segments on the right leg, giue 40 féete, then 72 must néeds giue 8 feete, because the proposition saith, as the difference of the greater parts included, be to the lesser, so is the distance betwixt my two stations to the length propounded, therefore worke by the second Chapter.
You may performe the last Proposition, and neuer remoue the site in the right legge, as you be there required.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
By the knowne longitude to finde out the vnknowne altitude at one station, the right legge being perpendicular, and the left parallell.

p.hi: Si visus sit ab initio Transuersarii rectiterminum altitudinis,
per terminum indicis paralleli in metam altitudinis: vt erit segmentum Transuersarii ad segmentum indicis, sic longitudo data ad altitudinem.

div.p: If the sight passe from the end of the Transuersarie beeing right, &c. as the segment of the Transuersarie shall be vnto the segment of the Inder, so is the length giuen vnto the heights,

IF the sight passe from the extremes or end of the left legge being parallell, or from any part thereof, as the parts included vpon the left legge are to the parts included vpon the right legge, so is the longitude giuen vnto the proposed altitude.

Place the left legge to lie parallell, then place your eie at the end thereof, or in any part of the left legge, as at 60: then moue the site in the right legge, till he be in a right line with the left site: and the summite of the altitude: then note the parts cut, which let be 36: let the distance of the Towre from you be 20 féete, worke then by the golden rule, or the rule 2 Chap. so shal you finde the altitude 12 féete.

But if your féete were leuell with the base, you must adde hereunto the length of your hollowe staffe, which is 4 foote, so the altitude would be 16 foote: for by this kinde of working you alwaies tell how much higher the summite is then the leuell of your eie, I meane that part of the altitude which is leuell with your eie.

div.head: CHAP. X.
By knowing of the breadth of any Pit, Well, Turret, &c. to fetch the vnknowne profunditie thereof.

p.hi: Sivisus sit ab initio indicis paralleli in metam profunditatis:
vt erit segmentum Transuersarii ad segmentum indicis, sic data longitude ad profunditatem.

div.p: If the sight passe from the end of the Inder being parallell vnto the thing measured, as the segment of the Transuersarie shall be vnto the segment of the Inder, so is the length giuen vnto the profunditie.

If the sight passe from the end of the right legge, beeing perpendicular, or from any part thereof, as the parts included vpon the left legge, are to those parts included vpon the right legge, so is the breadth to the depth.

Place therefore the left legge to lie parallell, and the right to stand perpendicular in a right line with the profunditie: let the parts included vpon the right legge be 13, and let the parts included vpon the left be 5: let the breadth of the Well be 10 feete: then if; the parts of the left legge giue 13, what shall 10 giue? worke therefore by the golden rule, or according to the doctrine of the second Chap. so haue you the depth from your eie to the bottome of the Well, which will be 26 feete: from which you must take the height of your eie aboue the mouth of the Well, which let be one foote, 6 inches: which taken from 26, there remaineth 24, 2/4 féete.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
By the giuen longitude to finde the vnknowne Altitude of any thing.

p.hi: Si visus sit ab initio indicis recti in terminum altitudinis:
vt erit segmentum indicis ad segmentum Transuersarri, sic data longitudo ad altitudinem.

div.p: If the sight passe from the beginning of the Inder beeing right as the Transuersarie, so is the assigned longitude vnto the height.

IF the sight passe from the extremes of the legges, or by any parts equally included on each legge, as they be equall one to the other, so is the longitude to the height, and contrarie; therfore the legges being opened to a right angle, as you be accustomed, if you draw neare or depart from the altitude (kéeping ye left legge parallell) vntill you sée the top of the altitude by the two ends of the legges, then may you safely conclude the distance from you to the base of the altitude, to be equall to the altitude it selfe; alwaies adding the length of your eie aboue the base thereunto, and so would it come to passe, the sight passing from any parts equally on each legge included.

Let the parts on the right and left legge included betwixt ye sites and the center of the Instrument, be 60, and let the distāce of the Towre be 250 féete; and so working by the golden rule, or the second Chapter, the altitude will also appeare to be 250 féete; to which adde 4 féete the length of my staffe, so there is 254 féete the true altitude.

div.head: CAAP. XII.
By the knowne part of some altitude, to finde our the whole altitude it selfe.

p.hi: per pinnas seudioptras Transuersarii & cursoris, in terminos notae partis: vt erit interuallum pinnaerum ad reliquum supereminentis Transuersarii, sic notae desuper altitudinis pars adreliquam.

div.p: If the sight passe from the beginning of the Index, béeing right by the vanes of the Transuersarie to the termes, as of some knowne parts; as the distance of the vanes is vnto ye rest of the Transuersarie aboue the Index, so is the part knowne vnto the remainder.

IF the sight passe from the beginning of the left legge, by both the sites in the right, to the termes of some knowne parts, as the parts included betwixt the two sites are to the parts included betwixt the site nearest to the center, and the center, so is ye
knowne part of the altitude to the part vnknowne.

Place therefore both the sites in the right legge standing perpendicular: then set your eie at the end of the left leg, moning the sites in the right, vntill they agrée with the extremes of the knowne parts of the altitude: note then the equal parts contained betwixt both the sites, for as they are to the parts betwixt the lower site and the center, so is the altitude known to the rest vnknowne.

Let the parts included betwixt the sites be 20, and the parts betwixt the site and the center 30: let the knowne part of the altitude be 15 foote: I conclude by the former doctrine, that the part vnknowne is 22, ½ féete.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
To finde the altitude of any thing by helpe of two stations.

p.hi: Sivisus sit ab initio Indicis recti in terminum altitudinis, vt erit in In dice differentia segmenti ad differentiam distantiae(primae videl. ac secundae stationis) sic segmentum Transuersarit ad altitudinem.

div.p: If the sight passe from the beginning of the Index beeing right, as in the Index the difference of the segment shall be to ye difference of the distance, (that is, of the first and second station) so is the segment of the Transuersarie vnto the height of the thing measured.

If the sight at two seuerall stations passe by two points in ye left legge, and by some one point in the right; as the difference of the parts vpon the left legge be to the distance of the two stations, so are the parts included vpon the right to the altitude desired.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII.
To finde out latitudes by 2 stations, that is, the distance betwixt two Townes, Turrets, &c.

p.hi: Si visus sit ab initio Indicis recti, per pinnas Transuersarii, in terminos latitudinis:
vt erit Indice differentia segmentorum (per duplicē distantiam facta) ad differentiam ipsam stationum seu distantiarum, sic interuallum primarum Trausuersarii ad latitudinem quaesitam.

div.p: If the sight passe from the beginning of the Inder, beeing right by the daines of the Transuersarie to the termes of the breadth: as in the Inder the difference of the segment (made by the double station) is to the difference of the distance, so is the distance of the vaines to the breadth.

IT would be something troublesome to teach, you to seeke out breadths after this Proposition, therefore without any more trouble, performe them as you would an altitude: for which purpose the 9 Chapter shall at this time serue, because I will haste to that which is more fingular, and performed with greate ease, that is, the art of measuring ground, and fetching of longitudes, latitudes, &c. by protracting: and you shall note that you may performe the proposition ioyned with perspectiue in the former Bookes after great ease, by vsing this staffe as a Iacobs staffe: all which and farre more the ingenious practiser will finde out with ease, whose studies that way, I could wish my selfe present to further, to the vttermost of my abillitie: because aiming at facilitie, I doubt I haue writē so rude, as it wil séeme difficult to a iudiciall eie, not for that the matter is hard, but because the method is harth, in wanting of conuenient phrases to explicate the same: but my excuse is, that my penne was applyed to the vnderstanding of the ignorant, and not for the ripe wits of the learned.

div.trailer: The end of the fift Boooke.

div.head: To the equall Reader.
div.p:
FRiendly Reader, after I had finished my former Bookes, I was drawn on, as well by diuerse my friends, as also with a certaine affectation which I beare thereunto, for to set forth a Booke of the art of measuring grounds by this my new deuised instrument: for that I see daily errours continually practised, euen by those which be in most practise: whereby it giues the ignorant occasion, and not without cause, to bring in question the truth of that infallible and noble science of Geometrie, the mistresse of all Arts. Let no one be offended though I affirm that all ascending, or descending grounds heretofore laide downe in plano by the plaine Table, Theodelitus, &c. are falsly laid downe. If they followe the doctrine of anie one writer now extant, I know the rules they publish to cast vp the contents, be true, but the rules they teach instrumentally to fetch the contents is false, as may appeare in the ninth Chapter of this Booke. Some it may be will say, we haue instruments sufficient already, and then what needeth this? which I affirme also conditionally, that they adioine the vse of the II Chapter of this Booke thereunto: but
this let such vnderstand, that they haue not extant a better for portabilitie, and true rendring of the quantitie of an angle; for the whole instrument is to be carried in a small walking staffe, of one inch diameter in the biggest place. And as thereby thou art taught to platte and measure grounds, both Arithmeticall, & Mechanicall, so also haste thou rules to know whether thou haue wrought true of false; which heretofore was neuer published, but thou left in that point, as it were to worke at random, so that thou mightest hope to haue wel done, though thou hadst no certaintie thereof. Then if this Book giue thee full satisfaction, and bring the art of measuring grounds vnto a perfect head in one entire volume, which neuer heretofore hath beene; accept him kindly, & giue the Author good words for his paines: & so I end, wishing my selfe present when any doubt happens to arise by meanes of hasty writing, or ill phrased tearmes,

div.head: THE SIXT BOOKE OF THE Geodeticall staffe, containing the Arte of Geodesia, or mesuring ground, deuided into two parts; the first most rarely and after sundry new waies, teaching you to take the true platte of any peece of ground, according to the true proportion & symmetrie, without the help of needle, protractor or any other combersome appendant, with the correcting of diuerse errors heretofore practised.
CHAP. I.
Of measuring of ground, and what instrument is most fit for the same.
div.p:
MEasuring or plotting of ground, is an Art of well measuring,Ars metiendi. and therefore it might be called Geometry, which properly signifies, ars bene metiendi. But we vndersiād in the learning of Geometrie, we obtaine a theoricall knowledge, by the contemplating with demonstations and figures; and in this arte of measuring ground, we haue as it were the actiue part by practise and vse thereof: for which practise & vse, there haue diuerse men studied to finde fit instruments for the true, easie and spéedy working thereof; amongst whom I seem with the best to compare this Geodeticall staffe, not doubting, hauing reason my iudge, but to show sufficient cause why this instrument should be preferred. Let vs therefore enter into consideration what is required of that instrument that should take place, and that I hold to be, which can truest expresse the quantity of an angle, and render it againe: for so to doe is the drift of all instruments: then it refteth to proue what instrument is best able to expresse the quantitie of an angle. First for instruments guided with the néedle, I say they be vncertaine, because
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
the sides which represents the one side of the angle vpon the instrument, be so short, that the losse of a degree is neuer perceiued; so that when they come to protract with a large protractor, they produce most absurd errors: for in a Theodelitus of 18 inches diameter, I say, the worke is with as much error as if he were but halfe a foote diameter: my reason is, because that which representeth the one side of the angle is so short, that he hath no congruencie with the other, which is the Inder. To what purpose falles it, to seeke the degrées of the one side in a large circle, and of the other in a small circle? haply some will say, the néedle is but to fixe some part of the instrument iust vnder the Meridian, and then the Inder serues in a large circle to expresse the angle of position, which I grant: but yet I say, the vncertaintie of a short néedle produceth an error as before: as for the purpose, take an angle of position, and note it down, then let another, nay, come you your selfe and take the said angle; agains I say, you shall hardly find him to agrée with the former: and what is the reason? first the vncertaintie of the néedle, whereby you are not able to place that part of the instrument vnder the Meridian as was before, then the disparallelitie of the planting of your instrument &c.

But being made large, are as good. This granted, to descend then vnto other instruments without néedles: let the smallnesse of their diuisions be a sufficient argument of their vncertaintie without vrging further. Lastly, to procéede vnto the Geodeticall staffe, our now intended labour, whose sufficiency it rests to proue, which I had rather referre vnto the censure of the wise, then seeme to heape many words together in the praise thereof: but this I will say, that he shall with more spéede and truth fetch the quantitie of an angle, then instruments with néedles can. First for spéede, while you be waiting for the motion of your néedle to ceasse, I will haue finished, nay, before you haue planted your instrument parallell, for my instrument respect no parallelity at all: then for the yéelding vp of any true angle, I hope this instrument is best able to doe the same, because his sides be longest, and consequently his degrées largest: but let these things passe, onely returne we to the briefe vse thereof in measuring ground.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of protracting of Angles, and finding out of the quantitie of angles protracted.
div.p: Protracting without a circle deuided. FIrst therefore to protract an angle, is to downe vpon ye paper an angle, iust to containe the number of degrées giuen: all angles in this instrument are protracted by the chords of a circle graduated vpon the backe side of the legs, in this maner.

Describe a circle or a portion thereof, place then the semidiameter of the said circle betwixt the two points respectiue, in ye points there made, as in the first Booke, Pro. 7: then take ouer in each legge the quantitie of the angle giuen, that is, place the one foote in the number of the angle giuen, vpon the one leg, and extend the other foote to the like number in the other leg, which place in the portion of the circle: so haue you the quantity of the angle, by drawing lines from the center to these 2 points made in the circle.

I would protract an angle of 30 degrées, first describe a portion of a circle, as BD, vpon A the center: then I place the length of A B the semidiameter ouer in the points respectiue; next among the chord diuisions, I take the distance ouer from 30 to 30, in each legge, which I place in the foresaid circle, the one foofe in B, the other in C: and then draw the line A B, and
〈2 pages missing〉 the right of B, and there take the quantitie of the said angle A I B, as you be taught *, which I finde to be 39 degrées: next I direct the left legge towards B, Lib. 2. Cap 9, Prop. • . and the right to C, & then take the quantitie of that angle as before, which I finde to be 67 degrées, B I C: then I direct the left foote to C, and the right to D, and take the quantitie of the angle C I D, which I find 56 dedegrées; so I procéede to all the rest, and take their seuerall quātities, as of D I K, which I finde 16 degrées, of K I E, 30 degrées; of E I F, 20 degrees, of F I G, 9 degrées, of G I H 72 degrées: and last, of H I A, 51 degrées. Of these I make a Table, and set the same downe thus, with figures to shew which was the first, second, third angle, &c.

p.hi: The quantitie of the angles of position or station.

div.p: Then I fall to measuring the seuerall distance of each angle from my staffe, and note the same orderly downe by my angles of position: first I measure with a line from I to A, and finde it 27 pearches, then I measure from I to B, and finde it 9 pearches and ¾ parts; then I measure I C, and finde it 7 ¾ pearches, then I D, 19 pearches, I K, 12 ½ pearches, I E 28 pearches, I F 25 pearches, I G 14 pearches: and lastly I H, which I finde to be 21 pearches, and these I ioyne to the former Table, thus.
The quantitie of each angle of station. Sides of each angle.
This table taken, and in this order noted downe, you shall lay downe the plotte vpon paper when you come home, or in ye field. if you please, so the weather be faire, thus.

Draw a line at all aduentures, as A B: then taking from the legs of your staffe, as is said, or from your scale, the length of 27 pearches, which lay vpon the said line, A B; then protract by the second Chapter an angle of degrees, as M A N: then protract an angle of 67 degrées, as N A O; then of 56 degrées, as o A P, then of 16 degrees, P A Q, and so round to all the rest: then draw lines from each marke to the center A, M A, N A, O A, P A, Q A, R A, S A, T A, V A: next from your scale, take 9 ¼ & place that in the line A N, from A to D; then count 7 ¾ pearches in the line A O, placing the one foofe at A, alwaies, as from
A to E: then from A to P, count 19 pearches, as to F, there make a marke: then from A to Q, count 12 ½ pearches, as to G: doe so to all the rest, so will A H be 28 pearches, A I, 25, A K 14, A L 21 pearches: then from B to D draw a line, then from D to E draw another line; doe so from E to F, from F to G, from
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
G to H, from H to I, from I to K, from K to L, and lattly from L to B, where you began: so haue you a platte agréeing in true Symmetrie to the former, the contents whereof, you may easily cast vp in akers.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
To know if your platte will close, and whether you haue done true or not.
div.p: VVHen you haue set downe all your angles of station, adde the said quantitie together, according to the common order of addition, and if the totall surmount, or be vnder 360, you haue falsly done, and your platte shall neuer close: as for the purpose, I adde the former angles together, and after addition, I finde the totall to be 360: which giues me warrātise, I haue wrought truely, for if it had béene more or lesse, my worke had béeene false.

div.head: CHAP. V.

To take the platte of a field at two stations, and to lay downe the true proportion thereof, according vnto the scituation of the angles in the said field, so that you may make a faire carde, as before, in maner of a mappe.
div.p: YOu shall repaire into the field, or to some corner thereof, from whence you may sée all the angles in the said field,A platte taken at two stations. as before; there plant your instrument, and take the quantitie of euery angle, according as you did in the third Chapter, whereof make you a Table, and call that the Table of your first station: but in this sort must you begin to take the first angle: when you haue planted the staffe where you intend to make the first station, espy out the place where you will make the second station, then go vnto the end of the left legge, mouing the same, vntill by the site and center pin you sée the place where your second station shall be; the left legge so resting, go then vnto the center, and remoue the right legge to point to the next corner of the right hand, and take the angle, and then procéede as you be wont.

When you haue thus taken all the angles, and made a Table thereof, as I haue said, take vp your staffe, leauing some
apparant marke, or some body to stand in the place where your staffe was: then go you vnto the place that you appointed before, for your second station, and there againe plant your staffe, directing the end of the left legge to the first station, or place where you left the foresaid marke, and turne the right legge vnto the angle or corner vpon the right hand, taking the quantitie thereof: then procéede round about, taking the quantitie of euery angle as you be accustomed, and note them all downe, making a Table thereof, which call the Table of your second station this done, measure, or by some proposition take the distance betwixt the two places where you made your obseruations, and note that line downe, which you shall call your stationarte line: this done, you shall take a faire shéere of paper, on the middest whereof, drawe a straste line crosse ouer the paper. then towards the one end, make a point, which call your first station, whereupon by the second Chapter, protract all the angles noted in your first Table of station, beginning at the line that you drew crosse the paper, and procéeding rightwards round about: then take from your scale with your compasse ye length of your stationarie line, and apply the one foote of your compasse to the former point in the line, whereupon you protracted the angles before, and extend the other towards the other end of the line, and where he falleth, make a marke, which call the second station, whereupon as before, describe all the angles noted in the Table of your second station: draw out the sides of all these angles at both stations infinitely. Finallie, you shall note diligently the concourse or crossing of euery line like line with his match, according as you noted them downe in their proper Tables, with figures of purpose, from which crossing, if you draw lines, that is to • ay, from one crossing vnto to the other, you haue the true platte of the field: the length of euery hedge, or part therein, may you measure by the scale, which before you laid out the stationarie line by.

Suppose there were a field to bee measured, whose corners were DEFGHIK, the platte and length of euery hedge is here required: I cannot Trauerse from my staffe to euery angle in the field, by reason of some quabdes or martsh, or some such like.

Therefore go I into the field, and choose me a place, from whence I may sée all the corners in the said field: which let bee
at A: there I plant my instrument, and take notice of some other marke, whence also I may see all the corners in the said field, which let be at B: now I open the legges and go vnto the end of the left legge, moning the same about vntill by the said end and the center I sée to B: then I 〈◊〉 vnto the center: so wil the end of the left legge point iust to C: then I direct the other legge to the first angle on my right hand, and so take the quantitie of the angle C A D: which I note downe in my Table of ye first station, viz. 57 degrées: then I take the angle D A E, directing the left foote to D. and the right to E, which I find 62 degrées: this I note downe in my table for the second angle, as in the table, and so I doe to all the other angles, and note them downe, viz. to the third, 4.5, 6, 7, and 8: as E A F: F A G, G A H, H A I, I A K, and K A G: so shall you collect as Table in such maner as I haue here sette downe.

A Table of my first station.
Degrees.
1 57
2 62
3 33
4
• 4
5 37
6 32
7 100
8 36
Totall 360 Proofe.
Proue this Table by the 4. Chapter.

I hauing thus done, I go vnto my second station B, where turning the left egge to A my first station, I take the angle A B D, 33 degrees, and note it downe in my Table of the second station; and so I procce • e right wards to the second, third, fourth &c. angles, taking their seuerall quantities, and noting it downe as before as of D B E E B F, F B G, G B H, H B I, I B K, K B A, so shall I haue made such: a Table as the former.

A Table of my second station.
Degrees.
1 33
2 35
3 30
4 39
5 69
6 77
7 58
8 19
Totall Profe.
360 Chap. 4
Then with these Tables I resort to some plaine & smooth superficies, as paper or such like, whereupon I protract all the former angles in maner as is said before.

First I draw the line A B at all aduentures, then towards the end A, make a point for your first station C, whereon describe a circle A F G I K: then protract the angles of the first table therein beginning at A, as A C E, E C F, F C G, G C H, H C I, I C K, and K C A, and draw lines from euery of those letters to C, as from E to C, from F to C, &c. and put the figures thereunto for to note the first second third, &c. angle as you sée: then from C rightwards in the line A B, set out ye length of your stationary line 15 pearches, as C D, and vpon D describe another circle, L O Q R, and beginning at L, protract ye angles of the second table, as L D M, M D N, N D O, O D P, P D Q, Q D R, R D S, and S D L, and then draw lines from each letter to D, as M D, N D, O D, P D, &c. then put figures thereunto as before, to giue thée notice which was ye first, 2, 3, 4, &c. Now note the concourse of the semblable lines, that is to say, where the second line E issuing from C, doth méete with ye second line M, issuing from D; and thus I proceede to all the rest, still noting the concourse of the correspondent lines, which I note with these letters, T, V, W, X, Y, Z, L, as in the figure you may sée.

Then draw lines from T to V, from V to W, from W to X, from X to Y, from Y to Z, from Z to L, and from L to F, so haue you made the true platte of the former figure in Symmetrie & proportion, which you may measure by the scale you laid out the line C D by; so shall you finde T V 21 pearches, V W nine pearches, and so go round about.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
To take the platte of a peece of ground, by measuring round about the same.
div.p:
A platte taken nt one station otherwise then before. THere may a péece of ground so happē, that you can neither measure the distance from euery corner to your staffe, as is required in the third Chapter, by reason of marishes, fennes and such like, nor yet finde two places anie thing distant one from the other: from whence you may behold perfectly all the corners in the said péece of ground: for your helpe therin, worke after this maner, you shall go vnto some such place in the field, whence you may behold all the angles, and there plant your stasfe, and take the quantitie of euery angle seuerally, and note them downe as you be accustomed: then let one measure the
length of euerie line which doe subtend those angles, that is, let euery hedge particularly be measured, that is included betwixt each corner in the field, which note downe against his proper angle; this done, measure the distance of the first corner from your staffe, which also set downe: these things had, protract the foresaid angles vpon a faire boorde or cleane shéets of paper; then on the line which points vnto ye first angle, which you measured and noted downe before, lay downe with your scale and compasse, the length thereof: then take from your scale the length of the first line which you measured on the outer side the file, and put the one foote in the point made in the former line, and turne the other about, vntill he intersect with the second line; then take the length of the second line measured, and doe so to the third line protracted, and so go round about, as will better appeare in the ensample.

Suppose A B C D E F G H, a péece of ground to be measured, I place my staffe at I, and there begin and take the angle A I B, 39 degrées, then B G C, 67 degrées; and so I go round, taking euery angle, and noting the same downe as you sée.

p.hi: The quantitie of each angle of station.

div.p: Then I measure the distance of A, the angle, from my staffe I, viz. 27 pearches: then I measure the length of A B, B C, C D, D E, E F, F G, G H, and H A; which is found, as in the Table.
The quantitie of each angle of station, with sides subtending the said angles. A, I, 27 pearches.

Then in the middest of some shéete of paper, I describe a large circle, and there I begin to draw the line M A, at all aduentures from A the center, infinite beyond the circumference: then I take the length of A I, and place it from A in the line A M in this figure, and there make the point B: then I protract an angle of 39 degrées, as M A N, then of 67 degrées, as N A O, and so round as beforevide 3. Cap.: and then I draw lines from A to each point in the circumference, as from A to M, from A to N, &c. next I take from my scale the length of A B, 20¼ pearches, & place the one foote of my compasse in the point B in this figure, and moue the other about, vntill he cut the next line A M, and there make the point D: then take the length, 9¾ pearches vpon your scale, placing the one foote of your compasse in the point D, with the other strike an arch or portion of a circle, & where it intersects with the line A O, make the point E: next take ye
length of 16 pearches, placing the one foote of your compasse E, and with the other strike some small portion of a circle, & where it cuts the line A P, make the point F: doe so with all the rest, as with 7½, from F to G in the line A G, with 18½ pearches, from G to H in the line R A, with 10¾ pearches, from H to I in the line A S, with 11 pearches, from I to K, in the line A T, with 22 pearches, from K to L, in the line A V, and with 27 pearches from L to B in the first line M A: then draw lines from B to D, from D to E, from E to F, from F to G, from G to H, from H to I, from I to K, from K to L, and from L to B: so haue you made the true platte of your ground, which you may measure or know the contents, according as you bee hereafteer instructed.

Infinite be the waies that I could teach you here to fetch the platies of ground: but I will here ceasse, lest that I confound the memorie of some with multiplicities, and only giue them acatalogue of the diuersities of platting by this staffe.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Diuerse waies of taking plattes of ground, by this Geodeticall staffe.

list.item: Diuersities of platting. vide cap, 3, 1 AT one station, where all the angles in the field may be séene, as before.
2 At two stations, Cap. 5. where the angles may be all séene, as before.
3 At one station by measuring round about the field. Cap, 6,
4 At many stations by measuring round about the field.
5 At many stations by measuring from euery angle to your staffe, where all the angles cannot be séene from any one station.
6 At diuers stations, yet measuring but one line in ye whole field.
7 At diuerse stations by going round about the field, as with the geometricall Table, or circumferencer, after a new maner neuer yet practised vpon any instrument.
8 At diuerse stations by taking the angles in the middest of the field, and also going round about the field as before, yet measuring but one line in the whole platte.

div.p: Any of all which waies are easily performed, if you vnderstand but what is said before: therefore it would be to too tedious and superfluous to demonstrate them all.

div.head: CAAP. VIII.
To measure wood-land ground, or such other rough grounds, where you cannot run vp and downe with your chaine within, by reason of bushes, or cannot see the corners because of Trees.
div.p: To measure wood-land. Conferre this Chapter with the end of the 48. I Had well neare forgotten to set downe this Chapter, which is more requisite then the former, for because it often commeth to passe, that you be put to measure woods and such like, whose platte must be fetcht by going round about the same, because through the impediment of trees and such like you cannot make obseruations as before, and here I must shew you to worke after such a way as hath not béene yet published, in the Theodelitus circumferēror, and all other instruments, you are now onely guided by the néedle and backe site, but here we will hold the néedle as néedlesse, and to no purpose: let there be a péece of ground full of wood, assigned to be measured, as A B C D E, &c. here you sée by reason of woods and such like, I cannot worke according vnto any of the former Chapters.

In the taking of this platte for your more ease in working, you be to consider 4 things, that is, whether the angle proposed doe incline into the field, as D, or F, or decline from ye field, as A, B, or C, &c. thē whether he be more then 90 degrées, or lesse: this considered, you shall take their quantitie thus.

1 It the angle be more then 90 degrées, as B, and decline, thē place the left legge B H, to lie parallell to the side of the hedge A B, and moue the right legge I, vntill the fidutiall edge thereof direct your sight to C: then take the quantitie of the angle as the legges be opened vnto, which let be 35, I B H. But you will aske me how I will come by the angle A B C, which is all our drift in this place? you shall double the angle I B H, made vpon the legges, which was 35, which being doubled there is 70: take that from 360, there remaineth 290: halfe that is the quantitie of the angle required, viz. 145: ye reason of this work is grounded vpon this proposition.

p.hi: Si duae rectae inter secantur, aequant angulos verticales inter se,
p.note: Eu. lib. 1. Pro. 15 Ra, l, 5, P. 8, co, 2

div.p:
But forasmuch as I B H and his verticall angle are known to be equall, and A B C and his verticall angle also knowne to be equall: therefore you shall not néede to double them, and so make subtraction, but onely take the angle found vpon your staffe, viz. 35 from 180: so haue you 145, as before, which is ye
