true quantitie of A B C, and this worke is grounded vpon this proposition.

p.note: Eu lib. 1 Pro. 13 & 14, Ra, l, 5, P 8, con, l,
p.hi: anguli deinceps positi duobus rectis aequentur, & contra.

div.p: 2 If the angle decline and be lesse then 90, as E, then shall you make the left legge H E ly parallell to the hedge E F, and the right I C to the hedge E D, so haue you the true quantitie of the angle.

3 If the angle incline and be more then 90 as F, you must go into the field, and there make the left legge E H lie parallell to F G: then moue the right leg E l, you so standing at l, vntil the fidutiall edge thereof con •• y your sight parallel by ye hedge side to E; then sée what quantitie the angle
• H made vpon the legge containes, which let be H, which take from 180, so haue you 143, the true quantitie of the angle E F G.

4 If the angle incline and bee lesse then
• 0, then worke as in the second difference of declining angles.

If you aske me why I put you thus to so many differences, and to vse subtraction, Argumentum. since I might take the quantitie of each seuerall angle with the legge, for that they will expresse ye quantitie of any angle to 180 degrées, and no angle can be bigger. I say that is true: yet my reason is two sold, first in respect of the smallnesse of the degrées beyond 140 degrées; secondly, & most especially, because of the • n aptu • sse of the p •• ting o • the legges at so great an angle, aswell in • espect of your standing, as the due ordering of the legges: is for the purpose, you would take the angle G F E, you must then thrust your • elfe betwixt the instrument and the hedge, otherwise you could not come vnto the center, and when you were there; the further discomoditie you may easily perceiue in searching the degrées cut, and such like: yet he that liketh this may better then the former, may vse it at his pleasure, for it will well serue for any angle. You hauing thus learned to take the quantity of the seueral angles, you shall fetch the platt thus.

Plant your staffe at any angle, as at A, and take that angle, then let one with a chaine measure so farre as your fight by the fidu • iall edge of the right legge passed in a right line, as to B, then note the angle G A B, and the line A B downe, then plant your staffe at B, and take that angle, causing one to measure from that angle you be at, vnto the next, viz. C; then note the angle A B C, and the line B C downe, next remoue your
staffe to C, and there take that angle, causing one to measure from your staffe, vnto the next angle, as to D, then go vnto D, but you must go ouer into the field, and there take that inclining angle, causing one to measure from D to the next corner, as E, then note downe the angle C D E, and the length of the line D E, then go to the declining angle E, and take his quātitie, causing oue to measure to F, both which note downe as before then go vnto F, the inclining angle and take his quantitie, causing one to measure to G which line and angle note downe: now if you worke truely, you néede not to take the angle G, or measure the line G A, becau • e in protracting, they will be expressed of necessitie, therefore I would counsell you for the sauing o • labour so to begin that you might haue the largest side or hedge to doe last, because you may • uo • d the labour of measuring him.

Now all the angles and side had, and noted downe in a Table, as you bee • ont, beg •• ne then and protract the quantiti • of the angle G, B, drawing the two sides A G and A B at length then take the length of A B from your scale: and place it in the said line, as at B from A, and on that point making A B one side, protract the angle A B C, and so go round as your table directs you: and when you come to protract the angle F, you shall see that you need not to measure the line G A or take the angle G; because the intersection of A G and F G,
• quates the line A G, and the angle G nay that which is more you need not measure the line F G but onely take the angle G F E, for that the intersection of the side F G and A G, limits asw • ll the length of these two lines, as it doth the quantitie of the angle G; let this ensuing rule therefore be inserted to this kind of mesuring generall.

If the figure or platte proposed to be measured,Regula obseruanda. be a triangle of what sides soeuer, as an I sopleur • n, I so •• eles, or Salenum, or of what angles soeuer, as an orthogon • um, ambligoni •• n, or origonium you shall measure but one side and two angles in quadrangles of what kinde soeuer, as right angled parallel • grams and oblonges, or oblique angled paralle lograms as Rōbes and • omboide: measure but 2 lines and 3 angles, and so of a Trapezia, which is quadrangulate, but more briefe, take it thus.
In all figures, be they multanguled or oth • rwise, you may omitte the measuring of any one angle and his two sides.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of errours daily practised in platting ground, and of the reformation thereof.
div.p: Of errours before practised, reformed. IN taking and platting of vneuen grounds, ourlan • measurers continually practise and commit great errours, because when they are put to measure a hill, or an ascending ground, when they go round about the said field, as is said before, and so measure from corner to corner, I say, the ground lines they measure with their chaine, be hypothenusall, and the right lines they protract be horizontall: so that it is not possible that their platte should close. I haue seens diuerse vsing the Geometrical Table, called of some the plaine Table, impute the not closing of their platte to the ill ordering of the needle & the backe sight when it was nothing else but the want of skill to reduce ye Hypothenusall lines vnto lines Horizontall, though indeed there may be great errors vnawares committed by meanes of the néedle and backe sight: but to returne vnto our purpose, the onely meanes to helpe these forepractised errours, is to reduce the lines hypothenusall vnto lines Horizontall.

It is certaine that in this kinde of working the hypothenusall line A B, Eu, lib, 1, P, 18 & 19. is a line subtending a right angle; and therefore is, the longest line that may be made in any orthogonium, as may be proued *: Ra, lib, 6, p, 11 Lu, lib, 1, p, 47 & 48, R, lib, 12, P, 5 for that a right angle is the greatest angle, that can be made in any or thogonium try angle: this granted, then of consequence must the line A C called here the horizontal line being the base of the said triangle, needes be lesse then the line C B: for that the hypothenusall C B, is in power equall to the horizontall A C, and the perpendicular B C *, and so of necessitie more then the line A C, be the perpendicular or Cathetum B C neuer so short: then let them confesse how farre they haue erred heretofore, which haue laid downe the hypothenusall line in stead of the horizontall, since here it is apparant that if they measure ascending or descending grounds, it is not possible for them to make their platte close, vnlesse the lines hypothenusall be reduced into lines horizontal: so then it resteth for vs, hauing the length of the line A B giuen, by measure or otherwise, to finde the length of the line A C, and him protract vpon our paper, which is thus performed.

Let there be a marke placed before you in the angle, whereunto
you would direct your sight, iust so high from the ground as your eie is placed, viz. 4 foote: now are you to consider if the ground ascend, as A B, or descend, as B E.

If the ground ascend, as A B, open the legges of your instrument vnto a right angle, turning the right legge towards the marke, and causing the left legge to lie parallell: then bring the center of the graduator vnto any number of diuisions where you will, as to 30, heauing vp the other end, vntill the fidutiall edge thereof conuey your sight direct vnto the toppe of ye staffe before planted in the angle at B: then shall you note the equal parts cut by the right legge vpon the graduator,Here note if the ground both ascend & descend, as A B and B D, you need but take the angle D B A, then measuring the two sides containing the angle, viz. A B, & D B then worke as in the 2. Bocke, Chap. 20. imagining D A a distance, or Booke 7, cap 3, Axioma 4, de. 2 Vide lib, 7, axi • m 3, sub, 3, which let bee 34 and better: lastly measure the hypothenusall line A B, which let be 40¼ pearches: then multiply the equall parts cut by the center of the graduator vpon the left legge, viz. 30 in 40¼, the length of A B: and the product deuide by the parts cut vpon the graduator by the right legge, viz. 34, and better: so haue you 35 the length of the line A C, whereby you may inferre that y• line A B, which was measured 40 pearches, must bee laid downe in protraction: but 35 pearches & this proposition may you worke by the 5 Booke, Cap. 2.

This Proposition may also be wrought Synnically by the table of Sines: for if you take the angle A, which here is 30 from 90, so haue you 60 the angle C B A, as may be proued, Eu, lib, 1, P, 32 Ra, lib, 6, to 9 because one of the angles is knowne to be right: hauing the angles, then finde the Synes, and proportion them accordingly.

And as you worked for grounds that did ascend, so must you worke for grounds that doe descend: onely it were best that the left legge should stand perpendicular, and the right parallel, which before was placed perpendicular.

But forasmuch as some will hold this way tedious to stand calculating in the field, and for that Arithmeticke is not common vnto euery one, nor the briefe vse thereof knowne vnto al men, you shall haue a way ensuing to auoid all arithmeticall calculations.

div.head: CHAP. X.
To finde the difference betwixt the hypothenusall and the horizontall lines without calculation.
div.p: IT is our onely intent in this staffe to auoid all kind of arithmeticall calculations,The difference of the horizontall and hypothenusall line, as hitherunto we haue done, and therfore I should doe the staffe wrong, if in this I should leaue him destitute of such an necessarie conclusion, being offered vpon his owne accord.

You shall therefore plant the legges vpon the side of the staffe, so that the left leg ly parallell vnto the Horizon: then heaue vp the right legge, vntill by the center pin and the site in the said left legge, you spy the top of the staffe placed in the angle, as in the last Chapter: Next, place the graduator at a right angle, and there fasten him by helpe of ye screw: then measure the length of the hypothenusall line A B, which let be 40 pearches, and count that vpon the right legge making a marke there: next shall you draw the center of the graduator along ye left legge, not altering him from his right angle, vntill the fidutiall edge thereof iust cut the point before noted, at 40 in the right legge: the equall parts then vpon the left legge, included betwixt the center of the graduator, and the center of the instrument, is the length of the said horizontall line, which you shall finde to be 35 pearches as in the last Chapter.
If the ground descend, as B D, then must you make the left legge hang perpendicular, pointing towards the ground, and the graduator to lie parallell at right angles, with the said left legge.

And here let if be noted, that your best way is onely in the field to take the angles of altitude, and measure the hypothenusall line, noting whether the line did ascend, or descend: and then may you reduce the same at home when you protract, as is faught.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of the making of a new quadrant to be vsed with the geodeticall staffe, for the finding out of the horizontall lines in the platting of grounds.
div.p: SOme it may be will seeme curious,A new Quadrant to finde the horizontall and hypothenusall lines. that they will hold it much labour to take off the legges from the toppe of the staffe, and place them vpon the side when they measure vneuen grounds, which I am perswaded can be no labour at all: howbeit, because I would set my staffe so neare as I might vnto the disposition of each seuerall minde, they shall here haue a quadrant most ap • for to performe the same.

You shall therefore prepare a quadrant of brasse, or some fine grained woods, whose two sides let be 6 inches, or there abouts: them must you deuide the limbe thereof into 90 degrees (if you please) as the common order is then shall you deuide the two sides thereof in to 90 equall parts, drawing parallell lines by euery of those 90 diuisions in each side, so will there be in the quadrant a number of iust 4 square holes, according as you may plainly perceiue by the ensuing figures.

Next must you make an handle or such like deuice of brasse or wood, with a s • lit through the same for the quadrant to moue in: the center of which quadrant must be placed in the toppe of the handle, according as you see at A and then must there be a fidutiall line for to answere vnto the center of the quadrant, as A B, which must be deuided into 90 such equall parts as the one of the sides of the quadrant was: vpon this handle there must be struck a line C D parallell to the edge A B, whereon must hang a line with a plumb: lastly in the foote of this handle there must be a hole, as at R, through which must go a scrue pin of braffe into the hole in the side of the staffe, to the end yt by the helpe thereof, you may fasten the handle firme vpon the side of the staffe, as occasion requireth, all which you may plainly perceiue in viewing well the ensuing figure.
The quadrant thus ordered, you shall fall to worke therewith in this maner.

p.hi: To worke by the new quadrant.

div.p:
Place the hole R vpon the side of your staffe, by helpe of a screw pin, causing the handle D C to stand perpendicular by
help of the plumb: then hauing prepared your staffe to be carried before you, as it is said before, and duely placed in the angle, heaue vp or put downe the side of the quadrant, vntill through the two sights F and G, you sée the top of the staffe before planted in the angle: then count the hypothenusall line vpon the handle A B, towards B: the line which then passeth by that number vnto the side A K, is he that limits the length of the horizontall line, which you must protract, being numbred in the side A K.

As for the purpose, let the quadrant stand as he doth: I count the line measured beeing 55 pearches vpon the handle from A towards B, and there doe I sée a line passe by at Z, which following to the side A K, I finde him numbred, 30: whereby I may conclude that the line measured 55 pearches, must in protraction be laid downe but 30 pearches and so of any other. Or you may take the angles of ascension in the field, and mesure the hypothenusall line, and then reduce them by the quadrant
when you come home, onely noting in the field the angle of ascension, and the length of the hypothenusall line: for which purpose I haue appointed the limbe of the quadrant to be deuided into 90 degrées, as the common order is, and so worke in angles of descension.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
To take an altitude onely by the Quadrant.
div.p: HAuing placed the handle is stand perpendicular as before,Altitudes by the new quadrant. heaue vp or put downe the sides of the said quadrant, vntill through the sights F G, you sée the summite of the altitude: the quadrant so resting, count the distance of the Towre from you in the side A K, and where that number ends, note there what line passeth thence vnto the handle: for the line crossing there, and passing to the side F G, limits the desired altitude.

Let the Quadrant rest at the angle he doth, and let the distance of the Towre from you be 40 féete: I count 40 vpon the side A K, and there doe I sée a line passe thence to the handle intersecting at P, whence doe I sée a crosse line passe to the side F G, which is numbred 60: and so many féete high may I conclude the Towre to be: then shall I sée 70 féete counted vpon the handle from A to the intersection of the foresaid lines at P, which is the length of a scaling ladder, and so of any other.
So may you finde out depths: many rare conclusions might be performed by this quadrant, which at this time for want of oportunitie I am forced to omit.

So then by that which is said before, you may be answered, that it is not possible for any man vpon one scale to lay downe the true platte, and by the same scale expresse the true contents of ascending or descending grounds: for because if he make the platte true, and then by the same scale cast vp the cōtents thereof, it will be lesse then the ground if selfe is: and again if you lay down the true contents of such vneuē grounds, then the may you make will neuer close, nor you be able to set forth the true proportion and Symmetry of the said grounds.

The best way therefore is, for him that will measure vneuen grounds, to prouide two scales, one to expresse the true hypothenusall line, and the other to lay downe the true horizontall line: and so by taking notice thereof, you may worke with more truth then I haue seene any hitherto practise.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

The legges being opened vnto any angle, to finde the quantitie thereof without the helpe of the graduator in a most excellent maner, so that you may take expresly the quantitie of any angle, and put aside the graduator or protractor.
div.p: YOu must turne the backe side of the legges vpwards,To finde the quantitie of any angle vpon the legges without the graduator. and then with a paire of compasses take the distance ouer from one legge vnto the other, in the two points respectiue: the compasse resting at that extent, apply the one foote to the center of the instrument, and turne the other towards the point respectiue in one of the legs, and where that foote of the compasse falleth amongst the diuisions, the degrée there set, is the quantitie of the angle: but if the angle excéede 90, then hauing taken the distance ouer betwixt the two points respectiue, halfe that distance, and apply it vnto the legs, as before, so shall you finde halfe the quantitie of the angle, which double, so haue you the whole: and by this meanes may you take the height and distance of starres, measure grounds, &c. without the helpe of the graduator.

As for to make proofe of this Chapter by helpe of the graduator, open the legges vnto an angle of 30 degrées, then with your compasse take the distance ouer in each legge betwixt the points respectiue: which applying to one of the legs, as before, you shall finde the foote of your compasse fall iust in 30 degrées, which is the angle the legges then make; allowing some small difference for the stoping of the chard diuisions from the • idutiall edge of each legge.

p.hi: To open the legges vnto any angle assigned.

div.p: Place the one foote of your compasse in the center of the leggs,To open the legges vnto any angle assigned. and extend the other vnto the angle required, in one of the legges amongst the deuisions vpon the lower side: which widenesse of your compasse still remaining, set the same ouer in the two points respectiue, opening the legges vntill 60 degrées, or each point respectiue agrée with the said widenesse of the foote of your compasse, and so is the angle made: and so must you worke in any other such demand: this proposition is most excellent for to finde angles in the 2 Booke, Cap. 29, &c. whereby you may performe it with great ease and spéede.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII.
Hauing taken the quantitie of each angle, and measured the lines truely, in going round about wood grounds, as Lordships or such like, to know if you haue wrought truly or not.
div.p: HAuing gone round about the wood or Lordship proposed to be measured,To know if you haue wrought truely or not. adde all the quantities of each seuerall angle together, and note the totall: then multiply 180 by a number, which shall be lesse by 2, then the number of angles or corners in the said field, and note the product; for if it agrée with the former totall, you haue wrought truely, otherwise not, and your platte shall not close.

The totall of all the angles being added together, is 540, ye number of angles is 5, from which I take 2, the remainder is 3: 180 multiplied by 3, produceth 540, agréeing with the former totall: which argues my platte wil close, & that I haue wrought truely, and so of any other.
The geometricall ground hereof is grounded vpon these Propositions ensuing.

p.hi: 1 In omni triangulo tres anguli simul sumpti, sunt duobus rectis aquales. Euc. lib. 1. P. 32. Ram. lib. 6. P. 9.

div.p: The 3 angles in any tryangle are equall vnto two right angles, therefore 180 is multiplied.

p.hi: 2 Cuiuscunque triangulaeti latera sunt binario pluratriangulis, è quibus constat. Ram. lib. 10. Pr • . 1. cons. 1.

div.p: The sides of a tryāgulate are more by 2, then the tryangles whereof he is made.
Therefore multiply by two lesse then the number of sides or angles, in the multangled figure.

p.hi: The end of the first part of the art of Geodetia.

div.head: THE SECOND PART OF Geodetia, containing the measuring of the superficiall content or Area of any platte, peece of ground, mappe or such like, howsoeuer formed: and that two kinde of waies, as Arithmeticall, or vulgarly without calculation, with diuerse new tables, as well for the casting vp or deuiding of grounds, as also to extract the square roote, or finde the true square of any number, with the measuring of all kinde of superficies, as boords, glasse, &c. or solids, as tymber, stone, &c. after diuerse waies, both old & new, together with the ground of the worke: also to seeke dimensions of heights, bredths, &c. by protracting after my new kinde of working, to separate or inclose grounds, or make any figure according vnto any proportion assigned onely by the staffe, to metamorphize or transforme any figure from one shape vnto any other, for the more speede in measuring to finde what proportion peeces of ground, glasse, boords, or any superficies one hath to the other: the making of a compendious Table to containe the legall part of measuring ground, with many Apophthegmes, requisite for all Geodetors to vnderstand.
CHAP. XV.
Of such things that are to be considered in the casting vp of grounds, as also to extract the square roote, or finde the true square of any number by a Table.
div.p:
I Haue before giuen you rules how to fetch the true platte of grounds out of the field as they lye:Of things which are to be preconsidered. it resteth now to declare by what meanes wee shall finde the superficiall content thereof: but before we speake thereof, hauing a platte of a péece of ground giuen, you must consider whether it be a tryangle, a quadrangle or a multanguled figure: and if it be a tryangle,
how he is distributed, as well in respect of his •• des, as in respect of his angles: in respect of his • ides, whether it be an Isopleu • o • . Isosceles, or a Scalenum: in respect of his angles, whether an Orth • gonium, Ambligonium or Origonium.

If the platte be a quadrangle or figure of 4 angles, then must you consider whether it be a parallelogram, or a Trapezia: if a parallelogram, whether a quadrāt, an oblonge, or an obliquangle: if obliquangled, whether a Rombus, or a Romboides.

If your platte be a figure multangled, then must he be reduced into some regular figure, and so measured as hereafter, and you shall note that it is best to reduce any multangled figure into tryangles, because they be soonest done, and easiest measured: but first behold briefly what is said before, for Ignorant in the termes, and ignorant also in the Art.

list.head: Geometriae Radix.

div.p: To extract the Quadrant roote, or to finde the square of any number with great speede, by helpe of a new Table.

IF you séeke the quadrate roote of any number, enter the table following, séeking the said number whose radix is desired, in one of the colums descēding, vnder the Title of square nūbers: the which if you finde precisely written there then the number answering in order on the left hand, vnder the title of Radix, is the iust square roote of the number proposed: as if you would séeke the square roote of 1600, enter the Table following, séeking therein orderly vnder the title of square number, the said number 1600: so shall you finde in the row on the left hand vnder the title of Radix, 40 answering thereunto, which is the square roote of the said number 1600: and so contrariwise hauing the radix giuen, to finde the square number thereof.

But if the number whose square roote you seeke be not precisely to be found in the table, then must you worke with a double entring in this maner: take two square numbers expressed in the Table, wherof let the one be the next, that is lesse then the number proposed, & the other the immediate greater then take the lesser of those two out of the greater & that which remaineth call the first number, which indeede is the portion or fraction of the integer number, and is called the difference, and shall be the deuisor; afterwards subtract the foresaid lesser number, out of the number proposed, whose radix you séeke, and the residue kéepe for a second number, then the third number shall alwaies be 60: therefore augment the second number reserued, in the third, and the product deuide by the first: and that which shall be gathered by this deuision, shall be added to the square roote of the lesser of the numbers found in the table: so shall you haue the true square roote of the number proposed.

Let the number proposed be 829, I cannot finde this number precisely in the table, wherefore I take in the table that number which is next lesse then it, which is 784, and the next greater, which is 841: the difference of these numbers is 57, as you
may perceiue in the rowe on the right hand vnder the title Difference, and this difference is the first number, and the deuisor: to conclude, the lesser number being subtracted from the number proposed, viz. 784, from 829, there remaineth 45, that is to say, the second number: the third number (as is said) is alwaies 60, therefore augment the second in the third, and there is produced 2700 parts of fractions, which deuide by the first number that is 57 parts or fractions, so is the quotient 47 ferè, which are fractions to bee added vnto the square roote, that is 28: so will there rise 28 integers; and 47 fractions, the radicall square of the number proposed, viz. 829.

table.head: A perfect Table for the extraction of square rootes, or finding the true square of any number, from 2 to 14290, faithfully supputated.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Of an Orthogonium, or right angled Tryangles, & to measure the area or superficiall content thereof, with the ground and reason of the worke.
div.p: AN Orthogonium Isosceles is such a figure,De Triangule recsangulo Isosceles. • uc. 1. Defi. 25. that hath one right angle and two equall* sides, as B A C, and may be measured after two manner of waies, thus.
1 Multiply the one equall side in himselfe, that is, square ye one side halfe, which is the superficiall content, which is eastly found by the 27 Chapter.
A C is 20 pearches, the square whereof by the Chapter is 400, the area of A B D C: halfe which is 200, the content of B A C, for A B C is equall to B C D.
2 Or thus, you must multiply A C one of the equall sides in A F the halfe of A C, so shall the product yéeld the area.

A F 10 pearches, multiplied in A B 20, produceth 200, the contents of A B E F, which is equall vnto A B C, for B E G, the triangle without the figure is equall to F C G, the tryangle within the figure: therefore the one doth decrease what the other hath in excesse.

THis figure is such an one that hath but one right angle,De triangulo rectangulo, Scaleno Eu • . l. 1. Defi. 26. E. 1. defi. 27. Ra. 8. Pro▪ 2 as A: * and all his sides be vnequall: and as the measuring of ye right angled Isosceles depended on the measuring of a right angled equilater parallelogram, or square, so doth this orthogonium Scalenum rely vpon an oblonge: for the two sides
containing the right angle, as A B, and A C are but the 2 sides of an oblonge, as you may perceiue by the pricked lines, & may be measured after two maner of waies, thus.

1 Take with your compasse the length of two of the sides containing the right angle, and thē multiply one of those sides in the other halfe the product, whereof is the superficiall content or area of the right angled Scalenum.
A B is 20 pearches, and A C 40: 20 multiplied in 40, produceth 800, halfe which is 400, the true area of the said péece of ground.

Whereby you sée that A B augmented in A C, yéelds the content of A B B C, the oblonge: but for that we desire but ye area of A B C, which is but the halfe thereof, therefore I take but halfe of the product, and it sufficeth.
2 Or you may multiply the one side in halfe the other, and the product is the true area.
As H I, 10, multiplied in A C 400, produceth 400, as before.
Or E H 20, halfe A C multiplied in A B 20, produceth as before.
Wherein you sée you worke alwaies but as it were an oblonge, or a square, and may easily perceiue the ground by applying the pricked lines vnto the préescript of this proposition.
And thus farre of right angled Tryangles, called Oxigonium.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
Of Acute angled Tryangles called Oxigonium.
div.p: Of acute angled tryangles, there be three sorts, and euery one hath his proper measuring:Oxygonia Trianguia tripheis, the first hath all his sides equall, and is called an orthogonium Isopleuron: the second an oxigonium Isosceles, and the third a Scalenum oxigonium, the difference alwaies rising in the sides.

p.hi: To measure an oxigonium Isopleuron. Proposition. 1.

div.p: An Oxigonium Isopleuron is such a figure whose 3 sides be all equall,De Triangulo onigonion aquilatro Euc. 1 Defi. 24. Ra. 8. Pro 8 Euc. 1. Defi. 29. and whose angles be all acute, and may be measured after 4 seuerall waies.

First, square the square of one of the sides by the Chapter: then multiply the off-come in 3, and the product deuide by 16: the roote quadrate is the area: this way depends rather vpon proportion, then otherwise.

Admit A B one of the equall sides by your scale & compasse, found to be 6 pearches, the squared square whereof, is 1296: which augmented by 3, produceth 3888: that deuided by 16, yéeldeth in the quotient 243, the roote quadrate béeing 15 and better as betwixt ⅗, and ⅓ 8/1, yéelding the true area.
2 Or you may multiply the cube of halfe one of the equall sides in the semiperimeter of the tryangle: the roote quadrature is the superficiall content.
The cube of AE, 3, being halfe A C, is 27, which if you multiply by the Semiperimetry B A E, 9, yeeldeth 243, whose roote quadrature is the true contents, as before, viz. 15, &c.
3 Square one of the knowne sides, which multiply in 13, then the number resulting, deuide by 30, so haue you the contents.

The square of A B is 36, which multiplied in 13, produceth
468, which deuided by 30, leneth 15, &c. as before.

4 But Arithmeticall with most ease, take it thus. Take the length of the perpendicular let fall from any angle vnto his opposite side subtēding the said angle, as you bee taught: Chap. 21. & 25. which multiply in halfe the length of the base, the product whereof is the area: for the perpendicular and half one of the sides represent the two sides of an oblonge, equall to the Tryangle.

The perpendicular B E is 5 pearches, and something better, and E C halfe A C, 3 pearches: 3 multiplyed in 5, &c. produceth 15, &c. as before, the area of the oblonge B D C E, which is equall vnto the oxygonium Isopleuron A B C.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
Of an oxygonium Isosceles, and to measure the area thereof.
div.p: De Trianguio Oxygenio Isosceles.THis tryangle is such a figure that hath all his angles acute, as before, only hauing but two sides equall,Euc. l. 1. Defi. 25 wherein the difference consisteth: and hath two measurings proper to himselfe.

1 First from the square of one of the equall sides, subtract the square of halfe the base or side which is vnequall: the quadrate roote of the remainder multiplyed in halfe the base, produceth the superficiall content.

Let A B one of the equall sides be 6 pearches, let B C the base be 4, the halfe whereof is 2: then take 4 the square of 2, from 36 the square of 6, there resteth 32: the roote quadrate whereof multiplyed in 2, produceth 11 7/21 pearches, the area very neare.

2 Or with more ease as before, you may reduce this figure into ablongs thus: take the length of the perpendicular as you be * taught,Chap •• . Pre. 2. & Chap. 25. and multiply that length in baise the base, and note the product for the true area.
Multiply D C in D A, so haue you the contents of A E C D the oblonge, which is equall vnto A B C the tryangle.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
Of an oxigonium scalenum, and to measure the superficial content thereof.
div.p: De Onigenie See, l • n • .THis tryangle is such a figure that hath all his angles acute as before, the difference from the former rising in ye sides, for that the other tryangles had fides equall,Eu. l. 1. Desi. 16 in this there is no side * equall one vnto another, but all vnequall, & is measured after one way.
Multiply the perpendicular in halfe the length of the base, the product there of is the area.

L O, the perpendicular, augmented in M P, or P N, produceth the oblonge, L Q, N O, which is equall to the tryangle L, M, Corolarium. N: whereby you see the measuring of tryangles for ye most part, differ not from oblongs, as hereafter.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
To measure all kinde of superficiall Tryangles generally, and of obtused Angles in perticular.
div.p: I Thinke it not amisse in the conclusion of tryangles to adds a rule, not onely to measure the Area of amblygoniums, but generally of any other kinde of tryangle, without the séeking of the perpendicular: and the rule is thus.

Adds together the length of euery side of the tryangle,Regula generalis ad omnetriaugulorum. Oron. whose superficiall capacitie is sought, and of the totall take halfe: out of this halfe by deduction, noting the difference, that is, how euery side differeth from the reserued halfe: then multiply that halfe by any one of the differences which you will, (but most fitly by the greater) & the product thereof augment by any of the other differences: which off come increase by the last and third difference, and of the totall take the square roote, which note for the area.
Neither is it materiall in this kinde of worke, which of the three differences you make the first, second, or third.

Let the tryangle be A B C, whose left side A B is 6 pearches, the right side A C 8, and the base B C 10: ioyne therefore 10 and 8, and 6 together, and there will rise 24, whose halfe is 12, from which detract 6; so the remainder is 6: and 8, there resteth 4: and 10, so 2 remaines: therefore augment 12 in 6, so haue you 72, and 72 in 4, the off-come is 288: this number againe multiply by 2, so shall there result 576, the square roote whereof is 24 the area.

The same number 576 should be ingendred if you had augmented 12 in 4, and the product in 6, and that product in 2; or if you had multiplyed the said 12 by 2, and the off-come by 4, and the product thereof by 6: or the same 12 in 2, the product in 6: and lastly, the number ingendred in 4: so is there alwaies
made 576, as you may perceiue by the demonstration follow
• ng.

row.cell: Demonstration.The forme of, finding the square roote:

p.hi: To performe the same Proposition otherwise.

div.p: Take the former example; if you multiply 6 in 4, Alia via qua omnis pariter Trianguli ared vestagatur. and that product in 2, and againe that product in 12, or if you augment 6 in 2, and the product in 4, and that last product in 12, or 4 in 2, and the product in 6, and the resulting number thereof in 12; there will alwaies arise one and the selfe same number, as 48: which multiply by 12, so is there produced 576, according vnto the subscript following.

The summe of this rule is but adding the thrée sides of any tryangle together,Summaria huius Regula declaratio. and of the resulting number to take halfe, and then to take the difference that euery side seuerally doth differ from that; compose halfe (according to the premonition,) afterwards to multiply one of the differences in the other, and the product in the third difference: and againe, ye product in the halfe of the number aggregated of the composition of the sides, the roote quadrature whereof is your desire.

p.hi: Of an Ambly gonium, and to measure the Area thereof. Proposition 2.

div.p: OF Amblygonium or Obtus-anguled tryangles, they be found onely to consist of two differences, that is, an Amblygonia Isosceles, and an Amblygonium Scalenum.
An Amblygonium Isosceles is a figure consisting of two equall sides,Eu. 1. def. 28. Ra. l. 8. p. 7. hauing an obtuse angle. Measure him according vnto the 18 Chap. Def. 2.
This Tryangle is such a figure which hath an obtuse angle as before, differing from the former because all * his sides be vnequall.
This figure agrées with the measuring of the figure in the 19 Chapter: and therefore I will let it passe in this place. Eu. 1. def. 16.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
To find the length of the perpendicular in all kind of Triangles.
div.p: AS for all right angled triangles, the one side containing the right angle is the perpendicular, and the other the base: and therefore there needeth no other rule for that purpose then what is sayd before; for the rest both Acute and Obtuse, take these insuing rules.

p.hi: To find the perpendicular of an Isophiron oxigonium.

div.p: If you will worke Arithmetically without the helpe of the 25 Chapter,Oxigonium aequilatrum. you must multiply one of the equall sides by 13, and part the offcome by 15: the quotient is your desire.
Multiply 6 in 13, there is 78, which deuide by 15; so haue you B E 5 pearches and 3/15 your desire.

p.hi: To finde the perpendicular in an Isosceles Oxigonium.

div.p: Square B D halfe the base B C, and then square one of the equall sides, A B or A C, Oxigonium Isosceles. from which square subtract the former square of B D; the roote quadrat of the remainder is your desire.
4. The square of B D taken from 36 the square of A B, leaueth 32, whose square roote is 5 pearches, and 94 fractions and better, the length of A D your desire.

p.hi: To finde the perpendicular of any Oxigonium Scalenium.

div.p: First square euery side,Oxigonium Scalenum, noting the products; this done, adde the square of the base vnto the square of the shorter side of the triangle, and from the offcome detract the third square, noted before: halfe the remainder deuide by the base, the quotient where of square againe, which deduct from the square that you added to the square of the base, and note the square roote for the perpendicular.

Let the Oxigonium Scalenum be L M N, whose side
L M let be 6 ½ pearches, L N 7 ½ pearches, and M N the base 7 pearches, the square of L M: 6 ½ is 42, of L N 7 ½ 56: and of 7 is 49: then the square of 7 added to the square of L M 6 ½, produceth 91: from which if you abate the square of L N 7 ½ there remaineth 35: the halfe whereof is 17 ½, which deuide by 7 the base, the quotient is 2 and ½: so many pearches is the left section M O, whose square is 6, which take from 42 (the square added to the square of the base) so there remaineth 36: the roote quadrate whereof is the length of the perpendicular, viz. 6.

Adde 56 the square of L M to 49 the square of the base, so haue you 105, from which take 42, the square of L M the other side, and there remaineth 63, the halfe of which is 31 and ½, which part by 7 the base, the quotient is 4 ½; so many pearches is the right section N O: therefore square 4 ½, so haue you 20, which if you take from 56 the square of L N, the remainder is 36, the roote quadrate whereof is 6 pearches, as before.

p.hi: To finde the perpendicular in any Ambligonium Isosceles.

div.p:
Let the figure be A B C, let the two equall sides A B and A C conteine 10 pearches,Amblygonium Isosceles. let the base be 16; therefore square 10,
so haue you 100: then multiply halfe the base in it selfe, that is B D 8: so haue you 64, which if you deduct from 100, the remainder will be 36, whose square roote is the perpendicular.

p.hi: To find the perpendicular in any Amblygonium Scalenum.

div.p: You must square euery side, then adde the square of the base or sides subtending the obtuse angle vnto one of the other squares, deducting the third square from the product,Ambl • gonium. Scalenum. and then of that which remaineth: halfe which deuide by the base, whose quotient you shall square, and deduct the same from the square which before you added vnto the square of the base, the square roote of the remainder is your desire.

In the triangle L M N, L M is 20, L N 34, M N 42, the square of L M 400, of L N 1156, of M N 1764:—1764, put to 400, raiseth 2164, from whence detracting 1156, the remainder is 1008, whose halfe is 504, which deuided by 42 the base, yeeldeth 12, the length of the left section M O, which square maketh 144, and subtracted from 400 leaueth 256, the quadrate roote thereof yeeldeth the perpendicular L O, 16: this differeth not from the 3 Propop.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
Of quadrangles or peeces of ground, hauing 4 sides and 4 Angles.
div.p: A Quadrangle is such a figure that is comprehended vnder * 4 right lines,Quadrangulum quid. and that may happen two manner of mayes,Eu. l. 1. def. 22. Ra. 10. pro. 4. as a Parallelogram, and a Trapezia; and the parallelogram may be right angled, and then a quadrat or an oblonge, or oblique-anguled, and then a Rombus or Romboydes, as followeth.

p.hi: Proposition 1. Of a quadrate or square.

div.p: A square is a right angled aequilater parallelogram, Quadratum quid. Eu l. 1. def. 30. * whose sides be all equall, as you may perceine by the figure, and is measured thus. Ra. 12. p. 2.
Multiply the knowne side of the square in it selfe,Ra. 2. cons. 1. De quadrati area. the product whereof is the Area.
Multiply A C 20 pearches, one of the knowne sides, so haue you 400, the Area of A B C D, the square.
Inuentio Diagonalis quadratorum. And if you desire to finde the diagonall B C, multiply A C in it selfe, and the offcome double; the Radix quadrature is your desire.
An oblonge is a rect-angled parallelogram, Oblongum quid. Eu. l. 1. def. 31. Ra. 13. p. 1. not aequilater, * with some, called a long square, whose measuring followeth.

De mensione quadranguli altera parte longioris. Take with your scale and compasse the length of one of the shorter sides, and also of one of the longer, which augment one in the other; the off-come is your demaund.
Multiply A B 20 in A C 40, the product is 800 your demaund, viz. the area of the oblonge A B C D.
If you desire to finde the Diagonall B C, square A C 40, Vt Diagonalis oblong inuenitur. and B A 20, which adde together; the square roote whereof is your desire.
A Rombus is an oblique-angled Parallelogram, aequilater, Rombus quid. Eu. l. 1. def. 32. Ra. 14. p. 8. * formed like a diamond, and hath foure kinde of measurings proper.

1. Let there fall a perpendicular from one of the obtusest angles,Rombus qualiter metiatur. to one of the sides, then multiply the same side in the length of the perpendicular, the product is the Area.
A B C D is the Rombus, augmented by A F, the perpendicular falling on B C, in B C; so haue you 96 pearches.

2. Or you may measure a Rombus by multiplying the whole distance betwixt two opposite angles in halfe the distance
betwixt the other two opposite angles, whereby it may appeare that this kind of worke differeth not from an Origonium Isosceles.
Multiply A C 12, in D E 8, halfe of D E; so haue you 96 the Area.

So that you sée A C D is an Isosceles Origonium, as in the 18 Chapter: now for because A B C is equall to A D C, therefore take all the line A C, and the whole perpendicular E D, and so get the capacity of the oblonge A C H G, which is equall to the Rombus A B C D; as is plaine, if you consider well the pricked lines.

3. Or you may measure him as an Ambligonium Isosceles, as in the 20 Chapter Propo. 2. for if you multiply B D the base of the Ambligonium Isosceles in A E the perpendicular, you haue the oblonge B D G I, which by the prescript is equall to A B C D the Rombus.

4. Or you may measure him as an Orthogonium Scalenum, as in the 16 Chapter Prop. 2: for A E and E D the two sides containing the right angle, augmented one in the other, produce 48, the contents of the oblonge A E D G, which is equall to halfe the Rombus: therefore double 48, so haue you 96, as before.
A Romboides is an oblique-angled parallelogram, not * aequilater. Romboides. Eu. l. 1. def. 33. Ra. 14. p. 9.

Let fall a perpendicular from one of the longer sides vnto the other, which perpendicular increase by one of those longer
sides, so haue you your desire:De Romboides Area. this differeth not from the 4 Prop. Def. 1.
A B C D is the Romboydes, B F the perpendicular, which multiplied in B C, produceth the oblonge B C G F, equall to A B C D.

2. Or you may reduce the Romboydes into two triangles by the line A C, and so measure them as an Ambligonium Scalenum: for D E the perpendicular in the Ambligonium Scalenum A C D, multiplied in A C the Diagonall, produceth the contents of the Romboides.

p.hi: Proposition 5. To measure a Trapezium Isosceles.

div.p: A Trapezium is defined * to be a Quadrilater Triangular, Trapezium. Eu. 1. def. 23. Ra. 14. p. 10. Trapezium diuersitat. not Parallelogram: therefore we do call that figure a Trapezium, which is neither a parallelogram, neither aequilater, nor aequi-angled. And of Trapezias there be diuerse sorts, as well in respect of the diuersity of the sides, as angles among themselues:Isosceles Traperium. Some doe séeme to beare the forme of a perfect Isosceles, hauing two equall sides with two other vnequall, yet parallel with two angles accute, and so many likewise obtuse, whereupon he is not vnaptly called an Isosceles; and many although they haue two sides alike equall, or parallel, yet they do admit •• nd right angles and therefore I will presume (and not vnworthily) to call such a figure an Orthogonium Trapezium, the rest of the Trapezias, Orthogonium Trapezium. which admit neither like angles or sides, I will call an Ambligonium Trapezium. And first I will speake of the Isosceles Trapezium, and then of the rest.

You shall measure the length of the other perpendicular included betwixt the two parallel sides, which you may find by the 7 Prop. then multiply the perpendicular in halfe of the two parallel sides added together; the product is your desire.

The perpendicular by the 7 Prop. Def. 1. is found to be 8 in the Trapezia A B C D, the equall sides are A B and C D, the parallel sides B C and A D: B C and A D added together, make
20, halfe which is 10, 10 multiplyed in 8 produce 80, the contents of the oblonge 4 F E 16, which is equall to A B C D the Trapezia: or you may resolue the Trapezia into two tryangles, and so measure him by the Doctrine of tryangles before.

And if it shall any thing auaile thee to finde the Area of a right angled Trapezia, Vt rectangulum metiatur. Traperium. do thus. Adde together the two parallel sides (whereof the one conteines the right angle,) halfe which increase by the perpendicular or other containing side, the product is your demaund.

Let the Orthogonium Trapezium be F G H E, adde halfe F G 6 pearches to halfe E H 18, so haue you E K 12, which augment by F E 5; so haue you 60 pearches the Area of the oblonge F I K E, which is equall to F G H E, for that the tryangle G I L exclusiue, is equall to the tryangle inclusiue L K H.
Or you may resolue this figure into a tryangle as, before.
This figure may happen after diuerse manner of wayes: but for all I will set downe onely thrée differences, whose measuring are all one kind of way.
You must resolue each figure into two tryangles by the shortest diagonall you can, then measure those two tryangles by the former instruction of tryangles.
These thrée Trapeziums A D C D are resolued into two tryangles by the Diagonall A D, and then measured by the prescript of triangles; and A D is the shortest Diagonall that can be found.

p.hi: Proposition 8. To find the perpendicular in an Isosceles Trapezium:

div.p: You shall multiply one of the equal or dis-parallel sides in it selfe, and reserue the product; then square halfe the difference of the two parallel sides, and subtract the product from the first reserued number: the square side or roote whereof is the perpendicular.

Let the Isosceles Trapezia be A B C D, whose vnequall side is A B 10 pearches, A C 4, and the base A D 16; the square of wc is 100, the difference of A C and A D is 12, whose halfe is 6, whose square is 36, which take from 100, the remainder is 64, whose radix is 8 your demaund. And thus farre of Quadrangles.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
Of a Polygonium, and to find the center and superficiall content thereof, as also to measure irregular figures.
div.p: A Multangle figure is that which is conteined vnder more then foure right lines * and is called a Poligonim, Multangula. Eu. l. 1. def. 23. Ra. 14. p. 11. Oron. and of some a Multilater, for because it doth containe more then foure sides and foure angles: and of Multilaters, some be regular, others irregular:Regulares multilatrae figurae. those be called regular Multilaters, when one may inscribe or circumscribe a circle, whose center shall be the common cēnter both of the equall sides and angles. Those be called irregular which haue sides,Irregulares. and consequently angles vnéquall.

p.hi: Proposition 1. To measure a Regular Poligonium.

div.p: When you would find the Area of any regular Poligonium or Multilater, obserue then this generall rule.
div.q: Si fiat planus è perpendiculari à centro in latus, & dimidio p • ri • etri, factus est area multanguli or dinati: Oron cap. 8. lib. 2. De R • & prac. Geomet. Ra. l. 19. P. 1.
div.p: Which is Englished thus: The plaine number made of the perpendicular, drawne from the center vnto the side, and of halfe the perimeter, is the content of a multangled ordinate figure.

Therefore by-the-second Proposition find the center of the Poligonium, and produce a line from their perpendicular vnto one of the equall sides, afterwards augment the s • yd perpendicular in halfe the peripher, and the product is the Area of the Poligonium.

Let the poligonium A B C D, be a Pentagon, E • empium de Pentagono. whose equall sides let be 12 pearches, let the center be A, from whence draw •• ine perpendicul • r to B C, which let be 8 pearches: then for because 5 times 1 •
make 60, the halfe thereof is 30 pearches, • s D E: therefore if you multiply 30 by 8, you haue the content of the oblonge D E F A, equall by the prescript vnto the polygonium pentagon, or figure of 5 sides.

p.hi: Proposition 2. To find the center of a polygonium hauing an odde side.

div.p: If the figure haue an odde side, as the pentagon in the last Prop. find his center thus.

Let fall a perpendicular from one of the angles vnto his opposite side, as from D on the line B C; do so to some other angle, as you may perceiue by the figure. I then conclude that the intersection of those two perpendiculars is the center of the figure as A; vpon which you may inscribe or circumscribe a circle, and the inscription shall answer vnto the middest of each side, and the circumscription to the angles.

p.hi: To finde the center of any polygonium containing equall sides.

div.p: Exemplum De Hexagon. You must draw two lines betweene any opposite angles, the intersection is the center, so shall you finde D to be the center of the hexagon D E F H G M K; then the perpendicular is 5 ⅖, which augment in 30 halfe the peripher, so haue you 93 ⅗ pearches, the content of the Hexagon Poligonium.
And thus farre of regular poligoniums, presuming I haue sayd sufficient for the perfect vnderstanding thereof.

p.hi: Proposition 4. Of irregular Polygoniums, called irregular figures.

div.p: There can be no other rule be prescribed then to resolue such irregular figures into some regular forme: for which purpose the 44 Chapter and 8 Metamorphis shall stand you in a singular vse: therefore I will cease here to speake further thereof: and indéed by that chapter you may measure all kind of ordinate or inordinate figures without any of the precedent Propositions.

And here I might take occasion for to amplifie this worke with the dimensions of circles and their parts: but it were vaine so to do, since they are performed in more easie manner by my Staffe in the prealle gated 44 Chapter: But howsoeuer I hold a circle nothing necessary to treate of in the measuring of ground: for that of all figures is the perfects, so that I thinke it scarce possible to find a péece of ground simply round as a circle: yet for those which be perswaded to the contrary, let them take the ground of finding the Area of circles thus: Planus siue quadratus è radio & peripheriae dimidio, dabit aream circuli. Ramus lib. 19. Prop. 2. Cons. 1.
which is: The plaine number made of the radius and halfe the circumference, is the content of a circle.

div.head: CHAP. XXIIII.
To reduce pearches vnto acres, and such like Statute measure.
div.p:
VVHen you haue multiplied your figures, as before, and found the true quantity of pearches therein,
you shall reduce them vnto acres,To reduce perches vnto acres and Statute measure. roods, &c. according vnto the second Chapter of the second booke, thus. If the number of pearches excéed 160, deuide the sayd number by 160, the quotient she weth the number of acres, then if there be any thing remaining, if it excéed 40, make particion thereof by 40, so shall the quotient shew the number of roodes; then if there be any thing remaining deuide it by 4, the quotient is the number of day workes, and the remainder the number of pearches; and if after partition by 160, 40, • 24, the number remaining be lesse then 4, it is pearches.

By the doctrine of the 20 Chapter, Prop, 3. I find the perpendicular L O 16 pearches,By this doctrine you may augment the Tables of land measure as far as you please. and the base M N 42, then by the foresayd doctrine of tryangles I augment halfe M N 21 in L O 16, so haue I 336 pearches, which by the prescript of this Chapter I first deuide by 160, so haue I 2 for my quotient, and 16 remaining: then because 16 will not suffer partition by 40, I part it by 4, so haue I 4 for my quotient, and nought remaining: whereby I may conclude that the tryangle L M N, doth containe 2 acres, 0 roodes, 4 day-workes and 0 pearches.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
To measure all manner of land without Arithmeticke, or to render the contents of the plat taken.
div.p: To measure ground without Arithmeticke. I Am not ignorant that diuerse neuer yet studied in the Art of Arithmeticke or Geometry will notwithstanding be very desirous to haue a sight in this Art of Geodetia or measuring grounds; which to performe let such worke thus.

If the figure be irregular, resolue him into tryangles (because
experience teacheth me, and Geometry confirmes the same, that there is no figure how irregular soeuer, but he may be resolued into tryangles:) but if the figure be a tryangle if selfe, you shall séeke out the greatest angle:To find the perpendicular in tryangles without Arithmeticke. wherein place the firme foote of your Compasse, extending the other so that you may take the shortest extension betwixt the sayd angle, and the base line that doth subtend the angle: this widenesse of your Compasse you shall apply vnto your Scale, and see how many pearches it containes: for so many equall parts as be included betwixt the two féete of your Cōmpasse, so many pearches long is the perpendicular: then take the length of the base, and note the halfe thereof, and so by the 27 Chapter enter the table with those two numbers, and you haue your desire.

Let L O M be a tryangular peece of ground, whose base M N is 7 pearches, and whose perpendicular L O is 6 pearches, which is the shortest extension betwixt the angle L, and the line M N: then I enter my table according to the 27 Chapter, with 6 and 3 ½, which is halfe 7. But first because there be fractions annexed, I enter with 6 and 3, so do I find 2 day-work and 1 pearch: then for the ½ or halfe the pearch anexed to 3, I enter the table according vnto the 28 Chapter: so do I find 3 pearches more, which added vnto the former, viz. to 2 day-worke, and one pearch make 2 day-worke, and 4 pearch: which by the last Chapter is iust 5 day-worke, or halfe a roode, the content of L M N.
Which is as if you had multiplied 6 by 3 ½, and proceeded as in the 19 Chapter.

And heare let it be noted generally, when you reduce your plat into tryangles, make them as bigge as you may,Notae. and so consequently as few as you can: for looke how many angles the plat containes, if you worke truly, there will be two lesse tryangles therein; as if the plat consist of 6 angles, the tryangles
angles therein will be but 4; if of 4, the tryangles will be 2, as you sée in the ensuing figures by the line A D.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
Of the measuring of a Trapezia, Rombus, Romboides, &c. without Arithmeticke, or an oblonge, &c. also to measure all lands without plaining.
div.p: YOu may resolue any of all these figures into two tryangles by the 7 Proposition of the 22 Chapter, and so measure them as in the last Chapter; or otherwise worke thus,

Let A B C D be a square:A Square. by my scale and compasse I and
A B to conteine 20 pearches, with which entring the table by the 27, with 20 and 20 I haue my desire, viz. 2 acres and 2 roodes.

Let A B D C be a long square: as before, I find A B 20 pearches, and A C 40, with which entring the ensuing table according to the 27 Chapter, I find 45 acres the content of A B D C; and you might haue resolued the figure into 2 tryangles by the line B C, and measured him, as in the last chapter.

Let a figure be giuen A B C D, like vnto a Diamond:A Rombus. by my Scale and Compasse I find B D 16 pearches, and the line A C 12: enter the table with 8, halfe B D, and 12, the whole of A C: so haue I 2 acres, and 4 day-workes, the contents of A B C D: or you might haue resolued it into tryangles, according as you sée the pricked lines, and so wrought by the 25 chapter.

For a Romboides, A Romboides, Vide prop. 4. cap. 22. looke what numbers I bid you multiply one in the other, the same find by the last Chapter, and enter the table therewith; so haue you your desire. Or you may resolue the figure into 2 tryangles by the line A C, and so worke as in the last Chapter.
In briefe looke what numbers I bid you multiply one in the other, the same find by your Scale and Compasse, and so enter the ensuing table, and you shall haue your desire.

We will take this Poligonium Pentagon, or figure of fiue sides A D G B C H: first by the 23 Chapter Prop. 2, I finde his center A, then I find the perpendicular by taking the shortest
extension betwixt A and one of the equall sides, as B C: let the perpendicular be 8 pearches, then I search the length of the 5 equall sides with my Scale and compasse, which let be 12 apeece, the whole peripher D B C H making 60, the halfe whereof is 30: so I enter the table with 8 the perpendicular, and 30 halfe the peripher, and find one acre and two roodes, which is the contents as truly as if I had increased 30 by 8, and founde 240 pearches, which by the 24 chapter agrées with the former.

p.hi: Proposition 6. To measure all kind of land without taking the plot.

div.p: But many times you shall not be put to plot ground in such order as the first part of this booke directeth you,To measure land without platting. but onely to yeeld the contents of the peece of land in the field according to the dimension there taken by your chaine, and so to ingrosse the particulars, as you be taught in the Appendix; which when it so fortunes, you must diligently obserue the formes and diuerse fashions of the sayd grounds, and so reduce it into some one regular figure or other, as into a square, a tryangle, or tryangles, a Trapezia or such like, and then measure it as before. But in so much ye many, or rather most peeces of land beare no regular figure, there be diuerse wayes that I haue vsed for the measurement of the same.

First, you may take your instrument and square the fielde,To square a peece of land. and then measure the odde peeces by it selfe, according to the figure they represent: and this squaring of a peece of ground is either performed by ye staffe or some other instrument without an needle or with an instrument with a needle.

To performe it by the staffe, open the legges vnto a, right angle, and then planting the same in foure seuerall places the one legge at the second station, respecting the first station, and so the third, the second; the irregular superficies is reduced into a true square, the fragments being measured according vnto such figures as they represent: as in the figure A B F E D, opening the legs vnto a right angle, I place them first at A, so doth ye one leg point to B, ye other to D: then placing him at D, the one leg points to A, ye other to C. Lastly placing at C, ye one leg points to D, ye other to B, so haue you made a perfect long square parallelogram. As for the fragments and corners omitted,
you must measure them as I sayd, according to the figure that they represent, as you may plainely perceiue by the figure before, and by the pricked lines inscribed therein.
If you conceiue this forme, you may also performe the same by the Theodelitus or Topographicall Glasse, &c.

p.hi: Proposition 7. To find where the perpendicular in any tryangle fals vpon the base, without Arithmeticke, in the open field.

div.p: Now in platting of grounds,To finde where the perpendicular in any Tryangle fals vpon the base. when there happen tryangles, you must of necessity find the perpendicular; and for that it is troublesome to performe it Arithmetically, you shall therefore performe the same by any of these ensuing wayes.

1. Open the legges to a right angle, and then place the one legge iust ouer the line subtending the greatest angle, mouing the Instrument from place to place (keeping the sayd one leg still ouer the sayd line) vntill the other poynt iust in to the angle opposite to that line: so then doth the instrument stand in the place where the perpendicular should fall: therefore measure from thence in to the sayd angle, so haue you your desire.

2. Or obserue the angle at one of the ends of the subtending line, and then (the legges refting at that angle) measure the other side conteining the sayd angle, which count vpon the right legge: now placing the graduator at a right angle, draw him along the left legge, vntill the fiduciall edge thereof cut the parts before numbred vpon the right legge; so doth the center of the graduator vpon the left legge cut the number of pearches; that the perpendicular falleth vpon the base line, being counted from that end you obserued the angle at.

3. You may performe the same by any of the other instruments, according to the first direction. Further more the figure opposite may happen to be most easily measured, by reducing the same vnto a Trapezia, and certaine figures, the which performe thus.

A B C D is a figure or fielde proposed to be measured. Here you see that this field may be well and easily reduced into a perfect Trapezia, which it doth of it selfe much represent: but is not perfect: for that C D and A B be not parallel: therefore to make a true Trapezia thereof, or to proue if the two opposite ends lye parallel, do thus.

Plant your Topographicall Glasse at A, making the needle stand iust in his true place, then moue the Index or Alhiada, vntill through the sight you see B: note the degree cut, which let be 200, then plant him in the lesser of the angles at the end of the line C D, as at C; making againe the needle to stand ouer his right place, bringing also the Index vnto the degree cut before, viz. 200: so do the sights poynt to E, whereby you haue made a true Trapezia A B C E, which measure accordingly; then for the tryangle D E C, measure the same according to the doctrine of tryangles.

By this meanes may you draws parallels in any kind of figure conceiued in the fields, and so reduce the same into what figure seeming most fit and requisite, as a Quadrate, an Oblonge, a Rombus or Romboides, which are all figures consisting of parallel sides.

Likewise may you draw any lines stoping out one as much as another, as from the poynt B, to draw the line B E to slope out as much as the line A C doth at the poynt A: hereby also haue you made the angle C A B. equall to A B D.

In this order must you worke when you be put to measure lands without platting, still by your instrument reducing the proposed field or pasture into certaine exact and regular figures:Many measure grounds falsly. for it is most absurd and direct contrary to the grounds of Art, to giue credit vnto the measuring that many countrie fellowes vse. For you shall see a Mason, Carpenter, or some
such Mechanicall fellow vndertake to measure and truly denide his neighbors grounds, when as his rules be most false and vncertaine. For some vse to measure round about the ground without regard of any regular or irregular figure it represents: others vse to measure all kind of lands as we do a Trapezia: others take halfe the sides and ends, all which to be vsed in a generallity, is false and absurde.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
The vse of the Table for land measuring.
div.p: VVHen you haue two numbers assigned, thē resort vnto the Tables, and in the vpper end or head thereof séeke the greater number assigned, going forwards from Table to Table, as you be there directed, vntill you haue found the sayd number: then descend that colume vntill you come so low that you are iust against the lesser assigned number in ye descending row vpon the left hand: so in the common angle or square where the concourse of both lines meete, you shall find placed in the sayd square the number of acres, roodes, day-workes or pearches, as the plat containes.

I find by the doctrine before, that the length of some perpendicular is 15 pearches, and the halfe of some base 20 pearches: I find 15 in the side of the table, and so proceeding vntill I come right vnder 20, in the vppermost colume: thers then in the common angle do I find 1 acre, 3 roodes, and 5 day-worke, and so of any other number.

And if the numbers exceed your table,To worke when the numbers exceede the rables. make partition thers of taking the halfe 3 degrée, part or quarter; and so enter the Table, and then proportien what you find according vnto the parts you tooke.

My one number is 100, the other 8; I can find 8, but not 100 in my table: therefore I take the fourth part of 100, which is 25, The one number exceeding the Table. entring my table with 8 and 25, so do I find one acre, and one roode; which take 4 times, because I tooke the fourth part, so haue I iust 5 acres: or you might haue taken halfe and so entred with 50 and 8, so should you haue found two acres and two roodes; which doubled amounts, as before.

Now it may happen that both the numbers shall excéede the Table, let the two numbers be 100 and 100; suppose I cannot find them in the Table, take therefore what parts you will thereof, I take halfe of the one, and the fourth part of the other, halfe 100 is 50, the fourth part is 25: I enter my table with 50 and 25, and find 7 acres, 3 roodes, 2 day-workes, and 2 pearches: then because I tooke 2 parts of the one number, and the fourth of the other, I increase 4 by 2, so haue I 8, which argueth that I haue found but the eighth part: therefore must I take the foresayd number eight times, so shall I haue 62 acres, and 2 roodes; so of any other. And note that each square hath foure numbers therein contained, fignifying as followeth:

Of the foure numbers, the
vpper
leftwards
rightwards
lower
leftwards
rightwards
conteines
acres.
roodes.
day workes
pearches.

This row proceedes in the 2 Table.

div.p: This Table doth extend from 1 perch to 10, in breadth and length; the left row proceeding in the 2 Table, at 11.
You moste note that these words belowe euery Table, (In Table) doe note in what Table both the sides of that Table are continued together.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII.
div.p: How to worke when there be parts of Pearches adioyned to

table.head: A perfect Table of the Fractions, or parts of Integer Pearches: newly calculated, with easie denominations for the exact measuring of all Land, according to the Statute made by Ed. 1. Anno. 33. entituled Compositio vlnarum & perdicarum.

row.cell: Here the denominatiōs change to those in the foot of the table.

div.p: Vnder the title of Inch, one pricke standes for a quarter, & two pricks for halfe an Inch.

For partes wanting in
length
breadth enter this Table with the
breadth
length
of your peece
of ground
Parts wanting in breadth and length worke first as it were the length. then as it were the leagth, then as it were the breadrn of the ground. & that as refulteth of both adde together.
3. Barley cornes i • an Inch. 12. Inches a Foote. 3. Foote a Yard. 5. Yards and a halfe a Pearch. 4. Pearch a day-worke. to day worke a Roode. 4 Roode an Acker.
Place this Table betwéene folio 194. and 195.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX.

A Tryangle peece of ground giuen, in the one side whereof is a Well placed, this peece of ground is to be equally deuided betwixt two men, in such sort that both parties may haue benefite thereof: my question is, how it shall be performed.
div.p: LEt the Péece of ground like a Tryangle be A B C: To deuide a peece of groūd from any poynt assigned. let the Well be at D, then I deuide that side C B into 2 equall partes at E, next I place my Staffe at the Well D, and take the angle C D A, kéeping that angle vnatred I place again my staffe at E, the midst of the side the Well standeth in, making the left legge as it was before ly Paralell vnto the side C B, then I note vnto what place of the side A B the fidutiall edge of the right legge pointeth as to F. and there I make a marke: for a Hedge made from D to F, deuides the Tryangle as it was proposed.

div.head: CHAP. XXX.
A Triangular peece of ground assigned, to cut off any number of Acres, rootes, &c. as shall be required, and that by a Hedge drawne from any angle assigned.
div.p:
YOu shall first consider from what Angle the Hedge shall be drawne,To cut off any number of acres in any square peece of groūd. and then what side subtendeth the said angle, which side you shal measure, and then measure the whole Area of the Tryangle: then shall you consider how many Acres, Roodes. &c. you would cut off, which multiply by the length of the Base or Line subtending the former Angle, the Product whereof deuide by the whole Area of the Triangle: the Quotient ingendred thereof declares vnto you how many perches
you shall measure in the Base from any one of the Angles to cut off the number of Roodes desired.

LEt the 3 sides of the Tryangle be 30, 40, 50, Perches my desire is with a right line from the angle subtended by
• 0 the greatest side to cut of one acre off ground: to performe this first I seeke the Area of the triangle, as is taught before, which is 600 Roodes, now because I would cut off from the Figure one Acre, which is 160 Roodes, I multiply 160 by 50, the whole side subtending the said Angle; the product being. 8000, I deuide by the Area of the Tryangle. 600, the Quotient is 13⅓, so many Perches I reckon in the Base from some of the corners, and then from the assigned Angle to the ende of your measure, in the Base draw a line which cuts off one exact Acre.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI.
In a rectangled or oblongd Paralellogram to cut off any quan-assigned by a parallell line.
div.p:
ADmit you haue a parallelogram which conteins. 65 acres, 16 perches, & that with a parallele to one of the endes, I would cut off 5 •
acres first therfore by some Rules before published, find ye length of one of ye longer parallele sides which let be 308 roode; thē I multiply 308 by 800, for so many roods are there in
•
Acres the whole Area, which yeldeth. 246400, which deuide by. 10416. the number of perches cōteined in the whole area, which yeeldeth in ye Quotient 23. perches 11. foote, and so much must you measure frō the end in both ye longer parallele sides, & where that number ends, in each side make two markes direct frō one of which vnto ye other draw a line which shal cut of iust
•
acres: & this rule is general for al quadrangle péeces of ground whose sides & ends be parallell be the figure a Rombus, an oblong &c. other wayes you may find (which I omit) to separat other regulare figures, & the rather because there shal a Table of purpose insue, and may be perfourmed Instrumentally also.

And heere note when you haue any péece of ground how irregular soeuer or of what regular fashion soeuer, as circle, &c. you may reduce ye same in to a square or such like figure as is * taught, & so spéedely measure the same, or deuide it into what kinde or how many partes you wil, as you be taught in the Cap. 30, 31, 32, 33, of this Booke.

table.head: The Table whereby to separate or inclose one Statute acre of land by it selfe.
The Table for one Acre of ground.

div.p: The end of the first Table calculated for one acre of ground.

table.head: The table for three acres of ground.
A Table to lay out two Acres of ground.

div.p: The end of the second Table calculated for two acres of ground.

table.head: The table for three acres of ground.
The Table to lay out three acres of ground.
The table for three acres of ground.
A Table to lay out three Acres of ground.

div.p: The end of the third table for three acres of Statute measure.

div.head: Chap. XXXII.
The vse of the former Tables.
div.p: THE vse of the thrée former Tables is,The vse of the former Tables. to lay out one acre of ground, two acres of ground, or thrée acres of ground, in any kind of parallelogram, which you shall thus performe.

Consider how many pearches you will haue the one side of the Acre to conteine, and that measure out with your Chayne, and there make a marke: note then how many Pearches you measured in that side, which call the first side: Now, to lay out one, two or thrée acres of land, finde the number of those perches you haue measured in the former Tables in the Rowe of the left hand vnder the title of the first side: then looke in the table right-mards vnder this title, the second side, where you shall sée the l • gth of the second side of the acre, in perches, parts of perches, &c. This founde, measure from one of the ends of the first side Orthogonaliter or Squyre-wise, the number of pearches, &c. last found, and let that be the length of the second side, so haue you gotten two sides of the acre; then measure so many perches from the ende of this last measured line (& that Squyrewise) as the length of the first side was: then from the ende of that line measure so many perches as the length of the second side was, which you shal meat with the first side, so haue you finished.

I Haue allotted vnto mée 13 pearches one way, for to make ye one side of an acre which I am allowed: I wold know how long the second side should bée? Repayre vnto the first table, and there in the first Colume vpon the left hand finde 13 perthes, vnder ye title of first side rightwards, answering to which vnder the title of second side, shall you find 12 pearches & ¼ of a perch, 11 inches and better, and so long must the second side be; hauing these two sides, the two other are like therunto, therefore procéed as you be taught before: The like order is to be obserued in laying out of 2 or 3 acres: And if you would lay out. 4. acres, looke in. 2. acres, and that you finde in the second side double; or adde that you find for one and 3 together: and if you would lay out 6 Acres, double that you finde for the second side in thrée Acres: and if you would lay out 9 Acres, treble it. &c.

Note in euery Table vnder the title of inch, one prick standeth for halfe an inch, & •
2. prickes for lesse then halfe an inch.
Now (for a time) we will digresse to shewe you other Nouelties, so shal you be more apt when we returne to our former intendments of measuring ground,

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII.
To know if Water will be brought vnto any place.
div.p: TAke the distance betwixt the Spring-head and the place wherto you would bring the water,If water will be brought vnto any place. which multiply in it selfe; adde the product therof to the Square of the earthes Semidiameter; viz. to the square of 3436 and 4/11 talian miles, then out of the product therof extract the square roote, and then from that square root, take 3436 & 4/21 miles, ye remainder is the difference betwixt the line of leuel & the water or circular leuel.
But this you may doe with more ease and that without Arithmetick by your Staffe, if you note but the Chapter of the difference of the Horizontal and hipothenusall lines.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIIII.
The Description and vse of the Table set downe in the ende of the first Booke, to be placed vpon the hollow Staffe called the Table of Planimetria.
div.p: THis Table is denided into 6 Columes,To measure boords. and one litle row vpon the left hand, then euery of those Columes is subdeuided into two rowes: in the first Colume is placed ye parts of an inch, which happen in the taking of the breadth of your Boords, Glasse, &c. set downe thus ¼ ½ ¾, signifying one quarter, one halfe, and thrée quarters of an inch: then the Table is deuided crosse into 6 great columes, wherin is placed Capitall letters frō? to 36, which stand for inches: wherein the bredth of any glasse, &c. is to be sought in whole inches, as the parts of inches were before: all other pendant Columes expresse the length of your rule ye must be laid out to make a foote of boords, &c. as will better appeare in the example.

table.head: A Table for Boord and glasse measure, &c. called the Table of Planimetria.

div.p: I haue a peece of glasse 9 inches and ¾ broad, I would know how much in length would make a foote square. First find 9 inches in some of the crosse rowes amongst the great letters, which you shall find to be in the second great pendant row, then in the first row vpon the left hand I séeke ¾ parts, and drawing rightwards from thence, vntill I come vnder IX, there do I finde 1 foote 2 inches, and ¾ of an inch, and so much measure in length must the glasse be to make one foote square: So that I may conclude a péece of glasse 9 inches and ¾ of an inch broad, and one foote two inches, and ¾ of an inche long maketh one square foote, which is 144 square inches.

Then suppose my glasse were 3 foote 8 inches and ¼ of an inch long, I then take 1 foot 9 inches and ¾ parts, & measure the length of the glasse, noting howe often it containes the length of 1 foote 9 inches and ¾, which I find 3 times: therefore I conclude that there is 3 square féete of glasse contained in the whole, which was 9 inches, &c. long, and 1 foote, &c. broad.

I haue a péece of boord 15 inches one way, I would know how much of my rule must be layd out to make a square foote. Seeke 15 inches, as before, and then in the margent vpon the left hand find the figure 1, from which directing your eye rightwards, vntill you come vnder 15, there shall you finde 9 inches and ⅝ parts of an inch, and so much must the other side be, so that I may conclude, a boord or pauement, &c. 15 inches one way, and 9 inches ⅝ parts, the other is a iust square foote, and then if the boord be many feete long, sée how often you can finde 9 inches and ⅝ parts therein, and so many féete of boord may you safely conclude to be contained in the said peece of boord.
And if the breadth exceed the table, then deuide the breadth into parts, and so proceed.
