The ground of this working is thus.The ground of boord measure. You must vnderstand that the diuisions of the boord measure, is the breadth of the boord giuen, to find how much in length will make a foote of boord.

To do which, you must also vnderstand, that a square foote is 144 square inches. Therefore if you will knowe how long the second side must be, deuide 144 by the side giuen, and the product sheweth thy demaund.

I would know how many inches the second side should be to make a foote square, the first side which I measure being 36 inches, deuide 144 by 36, and the quotient will be 4 inches, which sheweth that the second side must be 4 inches long to make a square foote.
And so shall you find 32 to yéeld his second side to be foure inches, and ½, &c. so of all the rest, and thus take the ground hereof briefly.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV.
The vse of the Table, called the Table of Solidmetria.
div.p: THis kind of measure is to meate all kinde of peeces of timber,To measure timber. stone, pillars, or such like solide things, which sheweth how much in length will make a foote of timber, the side of the square thereof being giuen; the working whereof is thus.

First get the square thereof in equall parts of measure: for which purpose M. Digges hath well calculated a Table, notwithstanding you shall go neere inough to worke, if you do but gird the said peece of timber about, and then take the fourth part thereof for the square of such a peece of timber; the side of the square found in inches resort to your table of Solidmetria, and there in one of the rowes vnder this letter S, signifying square, finde the square of the sayd péece of timber, answering to which rightwards shall you find the féete, inches, or parts of inches, which you must measure in length, to make a foote of timber.

The square of a peece of timber is eight inches, answering to which is two feet, three inches, and so much of my rule must I lay out to make a foote square of timber: therefore if the peece of timber had beene nine foote long, there must
be 5 square féete of timber therein, because 2 foote, 3 inches is fine times conteined in 9 foote.

And so if the peece had bene longer, you must haue séene how often you could, haue found by measure 2 foote and 3 inches therein, and so many foote of timber might you conclude to be in the sayd péece, so of all the rest.

Hereof is deuided the cubicall inches in foote,The ground of timber measure. viz. 1728 by the square of the timber giuen, the quotient she weth how many inches of your rule must be layde out to make a square foote.

The square is giuen to be 36 inches, I would know how much of my rule must be layd out to make a square foote: multiply 36 by 36, which maketh 1296, by which deuids 1728, and the quotient will be 1 ⅔, and so much of your rule must be layd out to make a cubicall foote, that is, a foot to containe 12 times so much as a plaine square foote of 144 inches: by these tables may you place boord and timber measure vpon the Carpenters rule truly and precisely.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI.
Of another kind of new working in timber measure.
div.p: THis kind of working shall shew you how many foote of Timber there is conteined in euery foote of length,A new kind of timber measure. the side of the square thereof being giuen, and is knowne by extracting the square root of so many square féete as the length containes; as if you would know how many inches square that péece of timber must be as should containe 2 foote of timber in one foote of length, worke thus.

The square inches in one foote vs 144, so 2 foote 288, the square roote whereof is 16 64/65, which sheweth 16 64/65 inches square doth make 2 foote of timber in each foote of length: the like of any other.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII.
Of Shide measure.
div.p:
SHide measure sheweth how many shides of timber is contained in each foote of length:Shide measure. for you must note that a shide
of timber is halfe a foote of timber, and such a peece whose end is 18 inches ouer, and whose length is 4 foote: and is thus wrought. Multiply the number of shides that you would know by 18, and from that product extract the square roote which sheweth how many inches square that péece of timber must be that shal containe the number of shides giuen therein.

I would know what square the peece must beare that shall containe 15 shides in 4 foote of length. First multiply 15 by 18, there commeth 270, the square roote whereof is 16 ⅘ your demaund, so of all the rest.

These diuisions of shides serue for the measuring of a timber trée that standeth, thus performed. Gird the trée about 4 foote from the roote, and take ¼ of the g •• ding, then see how many shides be contained in that square, and for the next 4 foote abate 2 shides for the Trapezing of the trée, and so for all the 4 footes in the length thereof; then adde all the shides together, so haue you the contents of the trée.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII.
To fetch all manner of dimentions by helpe of the Cord diuisions placed vpon the backe of the legges, with more ease then before hath bene fet downe, and first of altitudes.
div.p: AL altitudes are perpendicular • e • leuated vpon the sure face of the earth:Altitudes by protracting. and therefore make right angles with the line of leuell, the working whereof is thus.

Go us néere, or stand as • ure aff the altitude as you please, and there take the angle of altituds as you be instructed in the second: Booke, Chapter foure, which note downe, thou measure the true distance of the say •
〈◊〉 from your standing, which also note downe, and then fall to worke thus: Draw a straite line: and on the one end thereof erect • perpendicular, call this line the perpendicular; and the first line, the line of leuell: then open your Compasse vnto so many number of pearches, yards, &c. as you noted the distance of the tower from your standing, which lay vpon the ground line from the intersection of the perpendicular therewith towards the other end, Lastly, where the foote of your Compasse falleth there make a poynt, thereon by the 12 Chapter protract the • n •• e of altitude before taken, and then •••• ing that side of th • angle
forth in •• nitly, note at last the intersection of the sayd line with the perpendicular, the distance betwixt the sayd intersection and the base, is the altitude which is found by applying the sayd distance vnto your former scale.

Let A B be an altitude, C your station, where you take the quantity of the angle A C B 60 degrées, Lib. 2. cap. 4. pro. 5. then I measure my distance from C to B 16 yards, these two I note downe, then I draw the line E upon faire paper in •• nitly, then upon E the extremes of E G I, erect the perpendicular F E; then I lay downe 16 yeards in the line E G, viz. E F, and upon G H protract an angle of 60 degrées, by the second Chapter, as I H E. Then 〈◊〉
H to T, and to infinitly I dr •••
〈◊〉 and note, where it cuts the • h ••
E F,
〈…〉
F, thou I take the •••• th of
E F, and apply the same vnto my scale, which I find to containe 29 equall parts betwixt the two féete of my Compasse; therefore, I conclude the altitude 29 féete high, in like manner must I haue found the Hypothenusall line C A for the length of any scaling ladder.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX.
To search out inaccessible heights.
div.p: SUppose the height A were required,Inaccessible heights by protracting. and that you could not approth vnto B to measure the distance from me to the base: therefore I appoint the first at C, where I take the angle of altitude, viz. 60 degrées: then I go backe some certaine space as to D, and there I take the angle of altitude againe 30 degrées, as A D B. Lastly I measure the interuall or distance betwixt C and D, which let be 33 yards: these thrée things had, viz. the two angles of altitude, and the distance betwixt the first and second station, séeke the altitude thus.

You shall draw a ground line forth so long as you may, as E G, then abont the middeth thereof, as at C towards D, layout 33 yards, as C D, and vpon D
• rotract an angle of 30 degrées, as F G M: then note the intersection of F G, and H F, and there make the point F, from which point let fall a perpendicular vpon the ground line E G, as at E. Lastly, apply the
length of F E vnto your scale, so haue you 29 yards the altitude, to which if you adde the height that your eye was aboue the base, the whole altitude appeares: and if you require the Hypothenusall or length of a scaling ladder from either of your two stations, apply the length of F H, or G F to your scale, as before; so haue you your desire.

div.head: CHAP. XL.
To seeke the distance of any place from you.
div.p: IN the 31 Chapter let, the distance of A from D be required: First therefore I appoint D for my first station,Longitudes by protracting. and then from thence some knowne distance as 33 yards: I appoint my second station C, then I take the angle A D C 30 degrées, next I go to C, & there againe take the angle A C D, which I find 120 degrées: these thrée things I note downe, viz. two angles, and one line, then I protract thus.

First as I am wont I draw a base line forth at length E G, The figures in the 40 Chapter serueth here. then vpon the extreme, as vpon G protract an angle of 30 degrées, as K G L; then from G by K I draw a line forth infinitly, next I lay downe the length of 33 yards from G towards E, and where the foote of my Compasse falleth I make the point H, whereupon I protract an angle of 120 degrées in H I (or if you will, you may take 120 from 180: so will there rest 60, the quantity of the angle F H E, Eu. lib. 1. p. 13 & 14. * which angle you may protract in stead of the other) then note the intersection of the line G F, and G H, Ra. l. 5. p. 8. cons. 1. which let be at F. Lastly by applying the length of F G to your scale, you haue the distance of D A 58 yards, and so may you measure the other line C A.
Note in taking the angle A C B, if you had made the •• dutiall edge of the lost l • gge C O point iust to D, as O C doth, then might you have taken the angle A C B, as you did in the 31 Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. XLI.
To take a distance betwixt any two markes, though you cannot aproach to either of them.
div.p: THis Chapter I will commend vnto you for ease, facility, and spéed, before any other heretofore wrot whatsoeuer. Imagine that you would take the distance of A B, standing at F or E.

First I appoint me two stations F E in a knowne distance from me, as 35 yards: then I take the quantity of the angle A F E, and note it downe, viz. 30 degrees: Next I take the angle A F B, and note that downe, viz. • 8 degrées: these two angles noted for my first station, then I repaire to the second station as to E, and there obserue the angle F E B, and A E B, which I note downe for the angles of my two stations, viz. 45 and 60 degrées, then I protract thus.

First I draw a line at all aduentures, as E F, whereon I appoint 35 yards taken with my compasse from my scale, then vpon the point I protract an angle of 30 degrées, as I F H, then from F by I. I draw a line infinitly as to A, next I protract and angle of 98 degrées as L F I, drawing a line from F by K out atlength, as to B, so haue I finished the angles obserued at my first station F, then I go to E, and there protract an angle of 45 degrées, as L E M, drawing a li •• from E by M out
at length, vntill it intersect with the line F B, as at E, next I protract an angle of 60 degrées, as N E M, laying a rule vpon E and N, and drawing forth a line vntill it intersect with the line F A, as at A, then from the intersection A, to the intersection B, I draw a straite line A B, which applied vnto the scale sheweth the distance, viz. 40 yards.
In like manner may you measure the line F B, or F A, or the line E B, or E A, by applying the length thereof vnto your scale: and thus briefly of Dimentions by protracting.

And here note that you may performe any kind of Dimention after this way, (I meane by protracting) mentioned in any of my former bookes. And this kind of worke I placed here (as it were out of order) for that you may hereby séeke the length of hedges, or any distance in any field, for the spéedy deuiding or separating of the same without chaine measure.

div.head: CHAP. XLII.
To vse the legges of the Geodeticall Staffe as any kinde of Scale, according to 10, 16, 20, 30, &c. in the inch.
div.p: IN the second Chapter of the fifth booke I taught you to make a Scale,Of the proportion of lines. and here I let you to vnderstand that you may vse the equall parts vpon the legges in as good sort as it were a Scale, by taking the equall parts set vpon the legges thence, as you would from a Si •• le: But some will say, and truly, that the divisions he so large, that apaper will not containe any number about 100, or thereabout: for remedy whereof I will teach you a most excellent way.

Suppose you haue a line now pearches long, which is a pointer to be abase line, vpon which you must 〈◊〉 are a perpendicular 160 pearches long. First open your Compasse to what small distance you please, and that widenesse fit ouer in a hundred in each legge; the legges at that angle resting, take with your Compasse the distance ouer in 160 in each legge, so haue you the length of that line as truly as he had bene taken from a small Scale. And so might you haue taken the length of any other number whatsoeuer, 10, 20, 40, &c • and by this meanes may you find the length of any part of a line:Cap. 45. pro. 6. To vse the legs of any kinde of Scale. and thereby also may you vse the legges as any kind of Scale, according to 8, 10, 16, 20, 30, &c. in the such, as for the purpose.

I haue obserued the angles, and measured the lines in a field, according to the doctrine of the first part of this Booke, and am required to protract the plat according vnto a Scale of 16 in the inch, which I easily perforine, as thus.

Fit the length of an inch (which you may take from the equall diuisions on the legges, for 8 make an inch) ouer in 16 equall parts on each legge; the legge so resting, take the distance ouer in each legge from number to number, so may you expresse any line assigned: as if you would expresse a line of 20 pearches by a scale according vnto 16 in the inch, the legge resting as before, take the distance ouer from 20 to 20, which is your desire; and so of any other number.

Now if you would apply them vnto a scale of 20 or 30 in the inch, ye labour is no more but to fit the inch ouer in the assigned number, into which it is deuided, as in 20 or 30, and then worke as before: whereby you may note the singular vse of this Chapter, by helpe whereof you may cast vp any assigned plat according vnto any Scale, reduce maps and plats from greater formes to lesse, or from lesse to greater, performe the Art of Little foote in proportioning images, pictures, houses, &c. and still auoide the cost and multitude of Seales.

div.head: CHAP. XLIII.
To deuide a peece of ground as shall be assigned.
div.p: FIue men haue all alike title vnto one tryangular peece of ground,To deuide ground instrumentally. the fourth man compoandeth with three of them for their titles: so then there is but two haue title to the sayd peece, and they agrée to inclose it, the purchasor must haue foure of the fiue parts, and the other man but one of the stue parts vnto his share: I demand how I shall performe this?

To performs this you must note this generall, that if the
base of a tryangle be cut according vnto a proportion assigned, a right line drawne from the angle subtended by the base to any poynt therein, shall deuide the tryangle according vnto the proportion assigned; let the tryangle A B C be a peece of ground to be deuided, as is sayd.

I deuide C B in such proportion as 4 is to 3, by the 3 Prop. 45 Chapter, so that C B the base is so cut in the poynt E, that C E is to E B, as 4 to 5: therefore a line drawns from A to E deuideth the tryangle, as was proposed. In like manner could I teach you to deuide a parallelogram: but for because there be tables for the purpose set downe before, I will onely shewe you the proposition and no more.

If the base of a parallelogram be deuided according vnto a proportion assigned, a perpendicular reared vpon that poynt in the base where the diuision was made, shall deuide the parallelogram giuen, according to the proportion assigned.

div.head: CHAP. XLIIII.
The rare Metamorphosing of all Geometricall figures, both regular or irregular, into any regular figure, for the speedie measuring thereof by the Geodeticall Staffe.
div.p: OF all figures a circle is the most perfect, and hitherunto hath bene most troublesome to be measured: for which causes we will begin therewith.

A circle is a round plaine, as is proued,Circulus quid. Eu. l. e. 15. Ra. l. 15. p. 1. * the measuring whereof by this instrument is grounded vpon Eucl. l. 12. p. 2. Ram. l. 15. p. 2.&l. 19. p. 2. Cons. 1.2. & 3.

p.hi: To reduce a Circle into an Oblonge.

div.p:
The easies • way possible I can find to measure a circle,Archimedes demonstrauit aream cir •• li aqualem is to find two lines, which being multiplied in themselues may
produce the Area of the Circle:esse triangulo rectangulo, cuius vn • m latus ex his qu • e rectum comprehendunt, angulum ipsius circulo sem • diametro, re iquum circumferentiae fuerit aequale. and for that in all other abseruations you be required as well to know the Circumference as the Diameter, before you can finde two such lines, I will teach you here a way by helpe of this instrument: that hauing but any part of the Peripher or Diameter giuen, how to finde out the whole peripher and Diameter both.
Therefore in this kinde of working you must either haue the Circumference or the Diameter giuen, or else some part of the one of them.

First, let the whole diameter be giuen A B, which set ouer in 7 and 7 equall parts on the outer side both legges; the legges so resting, take the distance with your compasse betwixt 5 ½ •
and 5 ½: then the diameter A B, and the length of that line last taken B C, are two lines, of which you may make an oblonge, by erecting B C perpendicular vpon one of the extremes of A B; or for the spéedy casting vp of the contents, measure with your Compasse and Scale the length of those two lines A B, and B C, and then worke as in the 22 Chap. Prop. 2, or Chapter 25.

Now if you desire the right extension of the Circumference A R B N, the legges resting at the distance they were, with your Compasse take the distance ouer in each legge betwixt 22 and 22, so shall you haue the line E I your demaund.
If you please, or if the numbers of 7 and 7, and 5 ½, and 5 ½ fall too néere the center, you may take 14 and 14, and 11 and 11, and all shall be one.

Secondly, if you haue but the Semidiameter of a circle giuen, as B E, set the length of that line ouer in 3 ½ equall parts on both legges: but because those parts fall too néere the center, set the line E B ouer in 14 equall parts in both legges, and then take the distance betwixt 44 and 44, so shall you haue the line E G: now it resteth a • your pleasure whether you will make an oblonge thereof, as E G F B, or cast it vp, as in the last Metamor.

Thirdly, you may happen to haue but the halfe Semidiameter H E giuen, which set ouer in 7 and 7 equall parts, or in 14 and 14, and then take the distance ouer in 88 and 88, or in 176 and 176, and note that line downe I E, for the other fide of the oblonge; then you may either make an oblonge E F K H, or spéedily cast it vp, as in the first Metamorp.

Fourthly, if you haue onely the Circumference E I giuen,
set that distance ouer in 88, and then take with your compasse the distance betwixt 7 and 7, and note that line downe E H; then with these two lines worke as before.

Fiftly, if you haue onely the Semicircumference giuen, and be required to find the true Area of the circle, set that line as E G ouer in 22 and 22 equall parts in each legge, taking the distance ouer betwixt 7 and 7, so shall you haue the line E B; then worke as before: for hereby haue you the ende and side of an oblonge.

Sixtly, if you haue but the quarter of the Peripher, as E P giuen, set it over in 11 and 11 equall parts, and then take the distance ouer betwixt 14 and 14, so shall you haue the line A B, then worke as in the first Metamor.

p.hi: Metamorphosis 2. To reduce the Sector of any circle into an Oblonge.

div.p: The Sector of a Circle is a segment contained inwardly vnder two right lines, making an angle in the center,Sector. Eu. l. 3. p. 9. Ra. l. 16. p. 3. the concourse being called the base, as is proued.

Then to make a right angled Parallelogram, the semidiameter, and halfe the segment are the two sides thereof; and contrary, as the segment N E B is equall vnto the oblonge L E B M, made of the semidiameter E B, and halfe the segment B O.

Or you may vse halfe the Semidiameter, and the whole segment; so is E P the whole base of the sector, and E H the halfe of the semidiametient E B, the two sides of an oblonge E P Q H, equall to the sector R E B.

p.hi: Metamorphosis 3. To reduce a Lunular into asquare.

div.p: Let the Lunular be A B C D, then draw the line A B, halfe the square whereof is the Area of the Lunular, viz. E C F B, which measure by the 22 Chapter, Prop. 1.

p.hi: Metamorphosis 4. To reduce an Oblonge into a square.

div.p: To performe this you must turne the sides of the legges vpwards, which beare Corde deuisions, and then procéed thus.
In all Oblonges you shall either haue one side or two sides giuen, and if you haue one side, it is either the longer or the shorter; and for either worke as followeth.

First, let the greater side A B vs giuen, which set oner in 60, and 60 in each legge, then take the distance betwixt 36 and 36, and note that line downe A G; I say the square made thereon is equall vnto the oblonge, viz. A E F G is equall to A B C D, Eu. l, 6. p. 17. & l. 7. p. 20. Ra l. 12. p. 4. as may be proued, * and that G B is the other side of the Oblonge B D vnknowne.

Secondly, if the shorter side B D be giuen, set that ouer in 36 and 36, and then take the distance betwixt 60 and 60, and note the length of that line downe A G, which is the side of the square equall to the oblonge, which you may measure as the third Metamorp. Then if you desire the longer side of the Oblonge vnknowne, continue B D and A G forth in a right line, so haue you A B your desire: for B D is equall to G B, and A G is the meane proportion,Ra. l. 18. p. 8. as may be * proued.

Thirdly, if both the sides of the Oblonge be giuen, as K I and K G, ioyne them both together, continuing them forth in one right line, so shall you haue the line A I; make that line the diameter of a circle, and on the poynt K, where they were both ioyned together, raise a perpendicular to the circumference, as K L; which is the side of the square K N M L, that is equall vnto the oblonge K I H G, as may be proued.Eu. l. 6. p. 23. Ra l. 16. p. 19.
And in the same manner that you found K L, so must you find out the meane proportionall of any two lines proposed: therefore note this difference well.

p.hi: Metamorphosis 5. The one side of an Oblonge, and the side of a square being giuen, to find the other side of the Oblonge, that is, to reduce a square into an Oblonge, to containe the iust height of the Oblonge proposed.

div.p: LEt A B be the shorter side of the Oblonge proposed,To reduce a square into an Oblonge, which continue forth at pleasure, as to E; then on the poynt B raise the perpendicular B D equall in height to the side of the giuen square; then from D to A draw the line D A, in the middest whereof as at G, raise a perpendicular, and note where it intersects with the line AE, as at F, then making F a center, with the length of A F describe a circle, which shall cut the point A and D, and also the line A E; as at E; so is D E the other side of the oblonge: note this proposition, for it will be in singular vse hereafter.

p.hi: Metamorphosis 6. To reduce a square into an Oblonge, not regarding the height of the Oblonge.

div.p: SEt the side of the square giuen A G ouer in 60, and 60 Chords of each legge: then take the distance betwixt 36 and 36, so shall you haue the line G B, which ioyne in a right with A G: so haue you the line A B, the longer side of the oblonge: now to find the other, I say it is already found: for B G is your demaund, to which B D is made equall: so haue you A B D C an oblonge equall to A E F G, the square which was required.

p.hi: Metamorphosis 7. To reduce a tryangle into a square, and to find the meane proportion betwixt the perpendicular and the base of any tryangle.

div.p:
I Would make a square equall vnto the tryangle A B C: To reduce a tryangle into a square. First I continue forth ye side B C infinite, as to D, and from A the top of the tryangle, I let fall the perpendicular A D on the line D C: then thus I first find the meane proportion, to A D I adde halfe B C, as B E, which I continue forth in a right line, so that the continuation D F be equall to B E, then making A F the diameter of a circle vpon K the center thereof, I describe a halfe peripher, F H I A: Eu. l. 6 p. 13. Ra. l. 16. p. 19. so is D H the meane proportion, as may be proued: * which if you make the side of a
square, it shall be equall vnto the tryaugle proposed, as the square D H I G, is equall vnto the tryangle, A B C?

p.hi: Metamorphosis 8. To reduce any irregular or multanguled figure into one square.

div.p: THis is also performed by finding the meane proportion or square of each tryangle,To square any irregular Polygonon. and of all other is most necessary: for because you shall hardly find any figure but he may be resolued into tryangles, and so consequently all those for their spéedy measuring, may bee reduced into one entire square.

Let the figure be an Hexagon, as A B C D E F, which must be resolued into foure tryangles, as in the end of the 8 Chapter, and as you sée; then by the 7 Metamorphosis finde the square or meane proportion of each tryangle, so shall you find the line G to be the square of A E F H, the square of A D E, I of A C D, and K of A B C: then reare G perpendicular vppon the extremes of H, as L M on L N; the Hipothenusall M N, is the side of a square equall to the two first tryangles F and E: so as if your figure had bene a Trapeza, it had bene finished; for the square made vpon M N, is equall to the square of M L, and L N, as the pricked lines shew, and as may be proued, Euc. lib. 1. Prop. 47.48. & 6. Prop. 31. Ra. l. 12. Prop. 5.

But to procéede, lest haply I séeme to obscure that which is easie, next you shall reare the line I perpendicular on the extreme of M N, as M N O: then the hypothenusall O M is the side of a square equall vnto the three Tryangles F E and D, as you may perceiue by helpe of the pricked lines. Lastly, on the extreme of O M, raise K perpendicular, as M P, I conclude, the square made vpon the hypothenusall P O, is equall vnto the whole Hexagon, as P O R G, is equall vnto A B C D E F: and thus might you haue procéeded vnto an Heptagon, an Octagon, Eneagon, Decagon, or any kind of multanguled figure: and thereby find one line, which multiplied in himselfe, should produce the superficiall content of any field, Lordship, or Countrey, as for the purpose.

If you worke according vnto the doctrine before sayd,The square or meane proportion of the County of Salop. you shall find the meane proportionall of the County of Salop, to containe 28 of our English miles, whose square is 784 miles; which augment by the square of 320, viz. by 102400,
and there is produced 80, 281, 600, The number of pearches in Salop. the number of pearches in the County of Salop; which by reduction vnto statute measure, according vnto the 24 Chapter, you shall find there amounts in the County of Salop 501760 acres,Number ofacres in SaloP if it were plaine: but it is not procise, by reason it was taken from a small Scale.

p.hi: Metamorphosis 9. To performe the last Metamorphosis in strumentally.

div.p: HAuing found out the square of each tryangle, you may performe this Metamorphosis easily by your staffe thus, drawing no figure at all.

Open the legges vnto a right angle, for which purpose there is a hole néere vnto the center, to put through a screw pin, and so stay the legges at a right angle; then shall you count the line G 10 pearches vpon the left legge, whereunto bring the center of the Graduator, and fasten him there; then vpon the right legge count the line H 14 pearches, whereunto bring the fidutiall edge of the Graduator; so shall you find 17 13/60 equall
parts and better cut vpon the Graduator by the right legge, which is the line S, being equall to M N; and so proceed forward vntill you come vnto the last line: as for the purpose, hauing found 17 13/60 equall parts cut vpon the Graduator, count that vpon the left legge, whereunto bring the center of the Graduator: then count the line I 12 pearches vpon the right legge, whereunto bring the fidutiall edge of the Graduator, noting the parts cut thereon, which you shall find 20 and something better, which is equall to M O. Lastly, count 20 and better on the left legge, and 11 on the right, so shall yon sée well néete 23 equall parts cut on the Graduator (by working as before) which is the line V equall to P O, whose square is the superficiall content, as is sayd.
In like manner may you worke with your compasse on the legges,Chap. 25. Pr. 1. setting aside the. Graduator, and all diuistons, by noting the length of each line.

p.hi: Metamorphosis 10. To performe the last Metamorphosis Arithmetically.

div.p:
Hauing found the meane proportionals, as before, viz. GH I K, worke thus. Adde the square of G. no H together, and note the Radix by the 1 •
Chapter; then add the square of that Radix to the square ofl, and note againe the Radix quadrature, the square whereof added to the square of K, produceth a number, whose square roote is the true square of the Hexagon, whose square is the contents.

The square of G is 100, and of H 196, which added together maketh 296, whose Radix is 17 13/60, the square whereof must be added to the square of I, as 289 169/600 to 144, there eiseth 433 169/3000, whose square must be added to the square of K; so haue you the contents, the radix quadrature being the sibe of the sayd square, as P O.

div.head: CHAP. XLV.
Of the proportion of lines and numbers one to another, with the deuiding of lines, without the knowledge whereof it is not possible for any to be perfect Suruey or or Geodetor.

p.hi: Proposition 1. To cut a line by extreme and meane proportion.

div.p: A Right line is sayd to be deuided by extreme and meane proportion, when,Es • . l. 6. p 3. Ra. l. 14. p. 1. as the whole shall be vnto the greater segment, so the greater segment is vnto the lesser; and is performed thus.
You must first consider whether you haue giuen the extreme or the meane: and if the extreme, whether the greater or the lesse.

1. If the greater extreme be giuen, as C D, fit that line ouer in 60 and 60 amongst the Chord diuisions on each legge; then take the distance betwixt 36 and 36; count that distance in the line C D, as C H. I conclude, the line C D is cut proportionally, C D and H D being the extremes, & C H the meane,Metamor. 4. Def. 1. as is proued.

2. If the lesser extreme be giuen, as H D, fit that line in 36 and 36 among the Chord diuisions in each legge, and then take the distance ouer in 60 and 60, and note that line downe C H, which continue sorth in a right line: so shall you haue C D the greater extreme, and C H the meane, as is proued Metamorphosis 4, Deft. 2.
3. If the meane be giuen, and both the extremes required, worke as in the 4 Metamorphosis, Def. 3.

p.hi: Proposition 2. Two numbers being giuen, to find two lines which shall haue such proportion one to the other, as the numbers giuen haue.

div.p: THis kind of working is grounded vpon this Geometricall Proposition:

q.p: Sirectam triangulo est parallela basi, secat crura proportionaliter,Ra. l. 6. p. 9. & contra, Eucl. l. 1. Prop. 32.

div.p:
In this kinde of working we shall not altogether digresse from D. Hood in his Sector, Proportión of numbers to lines. whose many labours deserue to
be eternized.

Consider if the two numbers giuen be vnder or aboue 19, if they be both vnder 19, ioyne a cypher on the right hand, and then open the legges vnto what angle you please, séeking those two numbers in the legges; and then the distance with your Compasse taken ouer from number to number, yéeldeth the proportionall lines.

Let the numbers be 13 and 6, I ioyne a cypher to 13, and make it 130, and to 6, making it 60; then I open the legges, as I sée cause, and take the distance oner betwixt 130, and 130 equall parts in each legge, and note that line C D: the legges so resting, take the distance betwixt 60 and 60, and note that line downe C E; so haue you two lines, Viz. C D and C E, in such proportion one to the other, as 6 is to 13, or as 60 is to 130.
2. If either of the two proportionall numbers be aboue 19, ioyne no cypher, but séeke the numbers out in the legges, as before.

p.hi: Proposition 3. A line being giuen, and a proportion assigned, to lay downe a line, which shall be to the line giuen in suchproportion as was assigned.

div.p: I haue a line giuen C E, Proportion of lines. and am required to lay downe a line that shall beare such proportion vnto C E, as 13 doth to 6; by the doctrine of the last Proposition I ioyne a cypher vnto the two numbers giuen, so be they 130 and 60: fit the line giuen C E ouer in 60 equall parts of each legge, and then take the distance ouer from 130 to 130; so shall you haue the line C D, which is the line that is vnto C E, as 13 to 6.

In this kind of working you must call the first number the antecedent,Note. and the latter the consequence, and you must sée whether the antecedent or consequent be greater: If the antecedent be the greater, you may conclude that the line sought for is greater then the line giuen, and that the line giuen must
be applied to the lesser number: because I seeke for a great ex line, as 13 is to 6: here 13 the antecedent is greater then 6 the consequence: therefore the line sought for is greater then the line giuen, and must be fitted in 6 and 6, and the line sought taken from 13 to 13.

If the consequence excéede the antecedent, then the line sought for is lesser then the line giuen, and the line giuen must be applied to the greater number, because I séeke for a lesser line. Or thus briefly according to the prescript.

The
Antecedent
Consequent being Maior, apply the giuen line to the
lesser number.
greater number.

p.hi: Proposition 4. Two lines being giuen, to find what proportion the one hath to the other.

div.p: In this Art of Goedetia you shall find this proposition to be no lesse requisite then the rest,What proportion lines haue among themselues. as hereafter appeares, which made me the rather deuise to performe it by my staffe: for there shall no supersicies that is plaine, as boords, glasse, pauements, pastures, &c. happen, but by this Proposition you shall spéedily find what proportion the one hath vnto the other: but setting aside amplifications, let vs returne vnto the purpose.

Fit the longer of the two lines giuen ouer in any number of equall diuisions what you will: the legges so resting, with your Compasse take the length of the shorter line, and bring that along the graduation of the equall diuisions, vntill you haue fit it ouer in like parts on both legges; which done, you may conclude that the parts wherein the feete of your Compasse then stand, and the parts wherein you placed the longer line, be in proportion one to the other, as the lines proposed be.
I haue two lines C D and C E giuen, and am required to thew what proportion the one beareth vnto the other.

First I fit C D ouer in 130 equall parts on both legges, then I bring the length of C E along the graduation of equall diuisions, vntill the feete of my Compasses cut equall parts in
both legges, which will fall out at 60: I conclude C D is in such proportion to C E, as 130 is to 60.

p.hi: Proposition 5. To denide a line into any number of equall parts proposed.

div.p: Fit the line giuen ouer in the number of parts,To deuide a line into any number of equall parts. into which you would deuide the same, and then take the distance ouer from diuision vnto diuision, so haue you your desire.

I would deuide an inch into 20 equall parts. Let B E be the inch, which fit ouer in 20 and 20 of each legge; then take the distance from 19 to 19, which apply to the line B E, as to C from E: so haue you B C, which set 20 times, denideth B E into 20 equall parts: or else procéede downewards along the graduation, taking the distance from number to number, and applying it to the line, as from 18 to 18, so haue you the line F E, &c.

p.hi: Proposition 6. A line being giuen to deliuer any part thereof.

div.p: I haue a line A E giuen, and am required to deliuer a third part thereof:To deliuer any part of a line. to auoide Arithmeticke, chuse some number which you may deuide into thrée equall parts, as 60: therefore fit A E ouer in 60 and 60 equall parts on both legges. Then because 20 is the third part of 60, I take the distance betwixt 20 and 20, so applying that distance to A E I haue A B, a third part of A E: if you would haue found ⅔, you must haue taken the distance ouer from 40 to 40, so should you haue found the line A D, your desire.

Fit the length of the line giuen, as A E ouer in any number of equall parts, as in 60 and 60, which deuide by the parts of the line required, which let be the sixt part: 60 deuided by 6, yeeldeth 10: therefore I take the distance betwixt 10 and 10 in both legges: so haue I the line A G, which is contained 6 times in A E, and so often is 10 in 60.

div.head: CHAP. XLVI.

Of finding of the proportion that one figure or peece of ground, &c. hath to another, to finde out the Diameter of a circle, or any chorde or side of any regular figure, the circumference being vnknowne, to deuide a circle, and finde the proportion of any chorde vnto the circumference.

p.hi: Proposition 1. Two figures or two peeces of ground being giuen, to finde what proportion the one hath to the other.

div.p: EIther the figures proposed be all squares or oblonges,What proportion any two figures one hath to the other. &c. or one a square, the other an oblonge or a multangled, &c. and for either worke thus. Reduce the two figures into two parallelograms of equall height, then by the 45 Chapter, Pro. 4, find what proportion their bases haue one to the other: for such haue the figures, as is proued *.Eu. l, 6. p. 1. Ra. l. 10. p. 13.

Let the one figure be a circle, and the other a multangle, by the first Metamorp. I reduce the circle into an oblonge, then by the 7 Metamorp. I reduce the multangle into a square. Lastly, by the 5 Metamorp. I reduce the square into an oblonge, equall in height to the oblonge made of the circle. I conclude by the 45 Chapter Prop. 4, that such proportion as their bases haue the one to the other, the like hath the figures, viz. the circle and the multangle one to the other.
In the same manex may you deale with pauements, floores, boords, glasse, &c.

p.hi: Proposition 2. Any chord of a circle being giuen, to find the diameter of a circle, to which the inscription of the chorde shall answer.

div.p: To performe this proposition,To find the diameter of any circle. you must turne the chorde diuisions vpon the legges vpwards, and then fit the length of the chord in the parts of each legge answering thereunto; the distance then taken betwixt the two poynts respectiue, or from 60 to 60, yéeldeth the iust length of the semidiameter, which doubled is the diameter.
Or fit the chorde giuen ouer in the number answering to the halfe thereof, the distance then betwixt 60 and 60 is the diameter.

I haue B C the side of a pentagon giuen, and am required to deliuer the diameter of the circle wherein the pentagon or figure of fiue sides may be inscribed: fit therefore the side of the pentagon B C ouer in 72 and 72 parts of each legge, which are marked with this letter P to signifie a pentagon, and then take the distance from 60 to 60, which double; so haue you your desire G H.
And by this meanes the chorde of a circle being giuen, you may find out the center.

Also the diameter being giuen, you may inscribe an equilater tryangle, a square, a pentagon, an heragon, &c. by fitting the semidiameter ouer in 60 in each legge amongst the chorde diuisions, and then take the distance ouer from number to number in each legge marked with the letter K answering thereunto.

I would find the side of an heragon, that might be inscribed within the circle E G F, the semidiameter E D being giuen, fit E D ouer in 60 and 60, then because 60 and 60 on the legges is marked with an H, signifying an hexagon, you haue your demaund, which fit 6 times in the circumference, so will E F one of the equilaters be equall to D E the semidiameter.

2 But if you would inscribe a square, hauing fitted D E in 60 and 60, take the distance from 90 to 90, marked with S Q,
to signifie a square, so shall you haue D I, which may be set foure times in the circumference, as E I G L.
Or hauing fitted the semidiameter in 60 and 60, worke thus in numbers.

For the side of
a square
a pentagon
an hexagon
an heptagon
an octagon
an eneagon
a decagon to take ye distance ouer betwixt
90
72
60
51.20 ferè
45
40
36 degrées in each legge.

To finde the side of an equilater tryangle, you must put the side of an hexagon twice in the circumference, so shall you inscribe the tryangle E H M. Whereby vpon a necessary consequence it followeth.

that hauing ye side of
an Eq. tryangle
a Square
a Pentagon
an Hexagon
an Heptagon
an Octagon
an Eneagon
a Decagon, by deuiding and subdeuiding, we may find ye side of figures hauing 6.12.48.96. 8.16.32.64.128 10.20.40.80.160 as atryangle 14.28.56.112. as a square 18.36.72 as a square sides.

Also hauing the semidiameter of any circle, you may easily
deuide the same into 360 parts,To deuide any circle into 360 parts. by fitting the semidiameter in 60 and 60, and then taking the distance from degree vnto degrée, and applying the same vnto the circle, vntill you haue finished the one quadrant, which done, procéed to the next.

p.hi: Proposition 5. The chord of any circle being giuen, to find what proportion it beareth to the circumference.

div.p: First, by the 45 Chapter,To finde the proportion of a chorde vnto the circumference. finde a line which shall be to B A the diameter, as 7 is to 22 (which yon be taught to do also in the 44 chapter, Def. 1.) vide E I: let the chorde be R S, which by the 45 Chapter, Prop. 4, you may easily find what proportion R S hath to E I.

p.hi: Proposition 6. To find a right line equal to any assigned arke of a circle.

div.p: As 360 is to ye arke giuen,Of the right extension of any arke. so is the line of the right extension of the circumference to the line required: vnderstanding the premises, this is easie.

div.head: CHAP. XLVII.
Of the making of any figure like and proportionall to any figure assigned, with a further discourse of deuiding all maner of grounds.

p.hi: Proposition 1. A circle being giuen, and a proportion assigned, to deliuer a circle answering to the Symmetry thereof, and the proportion assigned.

div.p: AL circles be like one vnto another, and as for the proportion, worke thus.

Because there can no figure he made proportionall vnto any
assigned figure,To make a circle according to any proportion. vnlesse some line be giuen to make the same vpon: therefore in all circles take their diameter, which let be A B; then by the 45 Chapter, Prop. 3. séeks a line which shall be to the Diameter A B, according as the proportion was assigned, viz. as 4 to 3, which let be C D: ioyne those two lines together in the poynt D, and let them be continued foorth in a right line F F, which make the diameter of a circle E G F: then vpon the poynt D, where the two lines were ioyned, raise a perpendicular D G, to touch the circumference, as at G, at all aduentures: so is D G the diameter of a circle, whereon the circle must be made, as you may perceiue by the figure, where two circles be circumscribed according vnto ye proportion assigned, as may be proued. *Ra. l. 16. p. 19. Eu. l. 6. p. 13.

p.hi: Problema. 2. A greater tryangle being giuen, and a proportion assigned, to make a tryangle lesser and like the greater, according to the proportion assigned.

div.p:
Let the tryangle in the last probleme be D L F, Deuiding of tryangles. take either of the sides thereof, namely D F, which is equall to the line D C; let the proportion be as 3 is to 4, a subsesquitertia: finde therefore by the 3 prop. of the 45 Chapter, a line which shall beare such proportion vnto C D, as 3 doth to 4, as B A; continue them in one right line E F, which make the diameter of
a circle, as in the last probleme: and where they were ioyned together, raise a perpendicular, as on D, which shall cut the circumference in G; then count the line D G in the line F D, from F towards D, as F K: then from the poynt K drawe a line parallel to D L, which let be K M. I conclude the tryangle K M F is like the tryangle D L F, Ra. l. 4. p. 14. Eu. l. 6 p. 2. & l.
• . pro. 4. & 5. Ra. l. 6. p. 8. & l. 7. p. 9. as may be * proued, and hath such proportion to the other, as 3 to 4, as may be proued.

p.hi: Problema 3. A lesser tryangle being giuen, and a proportion assigned, to make a greater like and proportionall.

div.p: This probleme is but as it were visu verso vnto the last,To make a tryangle according to any proportion. sauing where you counted the meane proportion D G from F towards D, vpon the greater extreme, here you must count it from E towards F vpon the lesser extreme, as to K.

Let E I D be the tryangle proposed, and let the proportion be as 4 to 3, worke as before, and then count D G from E towards
F, as to K: then draw the line K H without the tryangle, and parallel to the sayd D I. I conclude the tryangle E H D is to the tryangle E I D, Problema. 2. as 4 to 3, and is like thereunto also, as may be proued.

p.hi: Problema 4. To performe the second prob. by drawing parallel lines about the tryangle.

div.p:
Let the tryangle be B C D, whose center you must find by Euc. l. 4. prop. 5. or Ra. l. 17. pro. 5, * or as you be taught,Cap. 23. p. 1. which let be A; whence drawe right lines to each corner,To inscribe a tryangle according to a proportion. as from A to B, to C and D: now let the proposition be as 30 to 40, here you be required to inscribe a lesser tryangle, like and proportionall vnto the greater B C D: take therefore the line A B, and by the 45 Chapter, Prop. 3, find a line which shall be to A B as 30 to 40, which let be P Q and R S: ioyne P Q and R S together at F, making one right line as G E, and let the poynt of connection be F; make E G the diameter of the circle G H E, then on the poynt F raise a perpendicular, which shall cut the circumference M H, then count F H M on the line A B, from A towards B, as to I, which line also count in the line A C and A D, as A K, and A L; then draw the line I K, K L, L I, which shall be parallel to B C, C D, Eu. l. 6. p. 2. and D B, Ra. l. 6. p. 8. as may beRa. l. 4. p. 14. & lib. 5. p. 12. Cons. 4. & l. 7. p. 9. proued. Then I conclude that the tryangle I K L is like the tryangle B C D, as may be proued, and that the tryangle I K L inscribed is to B C D, as 30 to 40, as is also proued,Eu. l. 6. p. 15.
Ra. l. 4. prop. 15. Cons. 1.

p.hi: Problema 5. To performe the third proposition, by drawing parallel lines about the figure.

div.p: THis is not much differing from the last probleme, when you haue found out the proportionall lines.

Let therefore the tryangle be I K L, Cite umscribing tryangles according to a proportion. finde the center thereof as in the last proposition, whence draw the lines A I A, K, & A L infinitly, now let the proportion be as 40 to 30: first by the preallegated 45 Chapter, proposition 3, find a line which shall be to A I, as 40 is to 30, which let be M E; to which anner A I, in the point M, so shall you haue the line B E, (so now the worke differeth not frō the last proposition:) now I make B E the dyameter of the circle B N E, raising on the point M A perpendicular, which cutteth the circumference in N, at all aduentures; then shall you count the line M N, in the line A I, A K, and A L, as from A to B, from A to C, from A to D, beyond the tryangle: lastly draw the line B C, C D, and D E, which shall be parallel to I K, K L, and L I, as is proued in the last probleme. I conclude that the tryangle B C D circumscribed, is to I K L, as 40 is to 30, or in lesser numbers, as 4 to 3 (which is a sesquitertia proportion) as is proued in the 4 probleme.

p.hi: Problema. 6. A greater tryangulate figure, or peece of ground being giuen, and a proportion assigned, to deuide the lesser, so that he shal be like vnto the greater, and keepe the proportion assigned.

div.p: IN this as in the former probleme, you be required to performe two things,To deuide a cryangulate. that is to make a lesser figure like to a figure assigned, and to retaine the proportion assigned,

Let the greater Tryangulate be A W X Y Z, &c. and let the prob. be to find a lesser tryangulat that shall be to the greater as 3 to 4: first therefore from any one corner, as from A to each corner in the tryangulat draw straight lines, as A X, A Y, A Z, then take any one side of the tryangulat containing the angle A; let it be A W, and by the 45 Chapter, proposition 3, find a line which shall be to A W, as 3 is to 4: ioyne those two lines together, as in the former probleme, making them the dyameter of a circle and so find out the meane proportional, which
count in the line A W, as A F: then draw aline from the point F parallel to W X as F E, and from the point E draw a line parallel to X Y as E D; from D draw a line D C parallel to Y Z, and from C draw C B parallel to Z &. I conclude the tryangulate A B C D E E, is like the tryangulate, A W X Y Z &, asProblema 4. is proued, and that they beare such proportion one to the other as was assigned, as also may beRa. l.
• 0. p.
• 2. be proued in the end of the second and sourth probleme.

p.hi: Problema 7. A lesser tryangulate being giuen and a proportion assigned, to deliuer a greater, like and proportionall to the lesser.

div.p:
If the lesser be giuen, and the greater required, hauing found the lines by the preallegated prob:To circumscribe a tryangulate proportionall. 45. cap. p. 3. that haue such proportion one vnto the other as the numbers giuen haue, and then made them the dyameter of a circle, and so found out the meane proportionall as before, the worke differeth not from the last probleme, sauing that the lines must be drawne vpon the vtter side the figure, as before they were on the inward: so
is A F, the line giuen, and the proportion as 4 to 3; following the doctrines before, A W is found the meane proportionall, and so is there drawne the lines, W X, X Y, Y Z, and Z, &c. parallel to F E, E D, D C, and C B, so is the greater tryangulate A W X Y Z, &c. made according to the proportion assigned.

p.hi: Problema 8. A field of tryangulates being giuen, to inscribe a tryangulate with parallel sides according vnto the proportion assigned.

div.p:
The formes generally that may rise in kinds of tryangnlates be infinite,To inscribe a tryangle. for that the seuerall kind of tryangles that may be packed together be infinite: for a tryangulat is nothing alss but the aggregating of a certaiue number of tryangles: for he is said tryangulated, because he is composed of tryangles, & may be resolued thereinto againe: but notwithstanding their different formes, yet the order of working in one is common to all, whether they be quadrangles nuiltaugles or any such kind: and so I would haue you to vndorstand that whatsoener I haue said of any one figure before in particular, ye like is to be vnderstood of all of like denomination in generall, as of tryangles
whether they be Isosceles or scalenums, &c. And to be short, this worke, the prenrisses vnderstood, differeth not from what is said, but for the vnpractized Geometritian, whose cause I tender; I will not cease to prosecute the same.

And if you please you may draw any of these forenamed tryangles or tryangulates without circumscription or inscription, according vnto any proportion assigned, onely by themselues if you doe but note the angles, and make your proportion, the ground whereof you may gather by these propositions. If parts like to the parts of a figure giuen, and in like manner situate, be placed vpon a terme giuen, there shall be placed vpon the fame terme a figure, like to the figure giuen, & in like manner situate. Ra. L. 4. P. 14. Cons. 4. Like figures be figures equianguled proportionall in the feete of the equall angles. Ra. l. & pro. as before.

p.hi: Problema 9. Any kind of figure being giuen, and a proportion assigned, to make a figure which shall haue his sides to the sides of the figure giuen, in such, proportion as was required.

div.p: Let the figure be A B C D E, and let the proportion be subsesqui • erti • , as 30 to 40, To make a figure proportionall in sides to any figure. by which proportion you may gather that the figurs sought is lesse then the figure giuen.

Take therefore some poynt in the side or Area of the figure giuen, which let be A, from either of which points produce right lines vnto each corner in the peripher of the figure, as from A to B, from A to C, from A to D, &c. then take the line A C, and by the 45 Chapter, Prop. 3, séeke a line which shall be
to A C, as 30 to 40, which let be A F; do so to A D, so shall you find the line A G; do so to A E, and A B, so shall you finde the lines A H, and A I. Lastly, if you tooke your poynt in the Area, as at A, doe as before with A A, so shall you haue A K; then draw the lines K I, or A I, I F, F G, G H and H K. If you tooke your poynt in the Area, I conclude either of the inscribed figures, as A F G H K I made on the poynt A, taken in the Area, or A I F G H taken in the corner A, in like vnto the figure A B C D E, and that their sides be in such proportion as 30 to 40.

Let the numbers be 30 and 40, multiply 30 in 180, so haue you 5200, which deuide by 40, the quotient yéeldeth 130; then worke with 180 and 130, as you did before with 40 and 30, and all will be one: and if you can no Arithmeticke, you be taught to performe it in the second Booke, or in the fist Booke by my scale. Let this conferred with the prescript of the Chapter be sufficient to teach you for to haue circumsc ••• ed, that is, to haue made a greater, or to haue made the lesser or greater by themselues, according vnto the proportion assigned. Now I procéed according to promise, vnto a further discourse of de • uiding grounds.

p.hi: Problema 10. To deuide or cut off any number of acres from any parallelogram, be it square, Rombus, &c. by aright line drawne from a corner to the opposite side.

div.p: In this worke you be to consider two things, that is,To deuide any parallelogram as shall be assigned. whether the quantity you would inclose exceede the moyety of the figure, or whether the medietie of the Area of the figure excéede the quantity to be inclosed. If the portion inclusiue be lesser then the mediety of the Area, multiply the number of pearches that you would cut off in the opposite side to that line, whence your deuiding line is produced, and the product part by halfe the area; so shall the quotient shew you how many pearches you shall meate on the foresayd opposite line, from whence a hedge insuing to the angle, shall deuide the figure as was assigned.
And this number is counted vpon the opposite side, beginning at the end next vnto the angle whence the hedge cometh.

But if the portion of separation be greater then the mediety of the figure, you shall deduct it from the whole area of the parallelogram, and with the residue worke as before: onely this difference is, that the part separated is at that end of the parallelogram opposite to that which was separated before.

p.hi: Problema 11. The King granted a peece of wast ground vnto eight men, vpon condition that fiue of them shall occupy their portions together: yet to be seuered from the parts of the other three, which also occupie their three parts together. I demaund how it shall be performed.

div.p:
The péece of ground granted is found to containe 16 acres,Deuiding of grounds. 3 day-workes, and 2 pearches, which let be A B C D: the grant
is to eight men, the proportions be 3 and 5, which make 8: by the 45 Chapter. Prop. 3, find a line which shall be to A D, as 3 to 5, which let be E D: drawe E F parallell to D C or A B. I conclude, A E F B is the iust portion that the 5 men should haue, and E F C D the part that the 3 men should haue.

But I sayd before, that the peec • of ground contained 16 acres, 3 dayes worke, 2 pearches, which is 2574 pearches, I would know how much each man hath vnto his part, and so consequently howe much each enclosure containes. Deuide 2574 pearches by 8, so haue you 32 •
pearches, 8 cubits, and 4 inches and better: then if you multiply this number by 3. you haue the content of E C F, or by 5, of A B F E, or ha • ing multiplied by 3 or 5, subtract the quotient from 2574 the area, so is the remainder your desire. I conclude by the prescript that each man hath; 32 •
pearthus, 8 cubits 4 inches and a little better, &c. and in the same order might you haue inclosed any of their parts by themselues, and this rule is generall for any parallels gram: and if you do but consider what is sayd of proportions, there shall nothing séeme so hard but your staffe will helpe you therein with ease, be the figure ordinate or inordinate.

div.head: CHAP. XLVIII.
To measure mountaines and vallies, with a further discourse of measuring groundes.
div.p: THe order of measuring mountaines,Mountaines and vallies. and not reducing them into plains as before, is, first you must measure the cirenit of the base of mountaines or compasse of the brim of vallies,But this worke of the hils be-much irrregularis not precise. which two adde together: then in mountaines measure the longest and shortest ascent from the base vnto the toppe of the said mountaine, which also adde together: then multiply or enter your table with halfe of the two ascents, and halfe of the circuite of the base and toppe, so haue you your desire so of vallies onely reckoning, or measuring the descent for the ascents.

This is the receiued opinion of measuring hils and dales, but if it so fortune that the hill or dale be much irregular and not inclining to the forme of a loafe of bread or suger loafe (for so Maister Digges in his Tectononicon intends) but confists of along side of a hill or such like, do thus.

Resolue the sides of the said banke or hill into such figures
that it will most aptly receiue, and then measure the same according to the •• gure it doth represent,To measure hils and vallies after a new way. and in so doing you shall • uoide erro • s; for if I measure the side or root • of an house as it were plaine I haue the trew contents, and therefore I wil will take a plaine ensample: imagine that the roofe of an house, from the wall plates vpwards did stand in the middest of a plaine field, now if you did measure the contents of the field not regarding the banke like the roofe of an house, it were too litle. Therefore not regarding the ground the roofe or banke standeth on, but omitting the same I resolue the said field into apt figures to measure, and then afterwards measure the two sides of the roofe or banke like vnto two long squares (for such a figure the side of the roofe of an house doth represent) which I adde to the former, and the contents appears.

But if you had taken the platte of the field, and so cast vp the contents without regard of the hill, then must you haue measured the hill as before, and added the contents thereof to the contents of the field; next must you also haue taken the plat of the ground that the b • nke did stand on by measuring about the fo • te of the said banke, and also haue given the contents of the said plat of ground that the hill did couer or stand vpon, which you must haue taken from the former totall, and then the remainder is the trew contents of the field & hill, viz. of so much ground that is to be seene, but we take no notice of smal banks or vallies.

The contents of the field is 40 acres, of the banke 10 acres, of the ground that the hill stands vpon, 4; acres; 40 and 10 added together make 50, from which I take 4; so there remaines 46 acres the trew contents, whereby the contents of the field by reason of the hill containes 46 acres, which being plaine had ben but 40. acres,

And here I would haue you note that whereas in the 8 Chapter of the first part of this booke, I shewed you how to go round aboute the field, stil taking the quantity of euery seueral augle, here I let you to wit that if the ground be full of angles you may measure such hedges as if it were one straight line, remembring at euery small angle, to measure how much he doth giue out, which note downe, & against what part of the straight like the giuing out was: and this straight line I would haue
you to call the visuall line, and the line of giuing out must be measured into the very vtter angle perpendicular from the visuall line, because you may the easier protract:and as you noted the angle of giuing out, so likewise must you note the point where it commeth into a right line againe, and by this meanes may you reduce any irregular péece of ground into a regular & easie forme of measuring.

Let the irregular field be, A B C D E F G H I, which by the visuall lines A C, C E, and A E you see I haue reduced into a tryangle, so that whereas there were fiftéene angles to be obserued, you see we néede but thrée; then for the giuing out at D in the line C E, I worke thus. I take the angle A C E, and meate the visual line C E, & in my meating I note where the giuing out begins, as at K 13 pearches: then I meate forward vntill I come against D, as at M 33 pearches: there the angle giueth out furthest: then I meate in a right line from M to D 11 pearches which I note downe (and let M D concurre with C M at right angles in M) then I procéed forwards from M in measuring, as to L, 56 pearches, where the giuing out cometh in againe; then I procéed in meating vnto E, so C E the visual line is 91 pearches: so that you may sée that the angle of deflection beganne at 13 pearches, as at L, and that the very Tropick of deflection was at M 33 pearches, containing 11 pearches as M D; and that the helical deflection came into the right line A E at; 56 pearches, as at L; & so by taking such notes as these be, all the rest performed with greter ease and spéed.

Many other thinges must be omitted to the discretion of the Geodetor or measurer, which would séeme vaine and proue tedious to be aggregated in one volume: such things that be not ordinary, I haue here set downe, and some such as I am certaine were neuer mētioned hertofore by any: We haue diners bookes extant for the Mathematical part of measuring proūds,
as first Maister Benefe, whose labours might as well haue serued as any one of his successors, if there had béene no more sit to speake thereof; but such is the acuity of our refined wits, th • t they obtaine a more daily affect action vnto the arte by euery of their new additions: First Maister Benese, he contriued tables and taught to measure ground wel & plainely; then comes Maister Digges and wittily addeth the measuring of superficies & solides, dilligently calculating tables; Maister L •• , he addeth the legall part of Suruey.Solas good as the best. And lastly comes I. N. and propounds a dialogue explaining thereby, what he thought conuenient, and for myself, what I haue added or deuise, I referre to your consideration: Amongst many things I hau • added the order of making a platte, with briefe tables to expre •• e euery seuerall cōmodity rising or acrewing therein, and if this like you not, you may sée another in the ending of the booke of the Geographical instrument.

div.head: CHAP. XLVIIII.
Of the making of a Table to declare euery seuerall tenor and commodity, rising in any Manor, &c.
div.p:
IT is not sufficient for one to take the true plat of a Manor, and so render the true contents thereof in acres &c. but you must also acquaint the Lord of the Manour what estate euery tenant houldeth by, that is,The making of a neccessary table for a suruey. whether the lands they hold be frée hold, or whether they haue a rearme therein for liues, yeares, at will, or such like: then must you see what medow ground, what errable, what pasture, and what woodland is belonging vnto euery seuerall tenement, and what quantity of such pastures belonging to each feueral tenement, that is, how many acces of woodland, how many of medow ground, &c. then is it requisite to see what rent each tenement payeth, and what their tenement were worth, if their estate for life, or yeares, were exspired: then should you take notice, what time of their estate is compleat, next should you see what seruices each tenant oweth vnto his Lord by force of the lease, or otherwise; then what number of sheepe and other great cattell they be alowde to keepe vpon the common, if there be any: then should you see what comodities rise in the Lordship, and what profit may accrew vnto the Lord thereby, and in whose ground, and what ground they stand in, to the end the Lord in his chari •
may the better consider the poore tenant, for the losse of his ground: for it may so fall out that a moyne may happen in a medow of some one of his tenants, which happely may be all the medow ground the tenant hath: and the moyne still continuing, God forbid the tenant should be so much damnified, as to léese the most commodity thereof, since he still payes his rent: these and all such other things happening it is requisit the furueior should take notice of, and acquaint the Lord, as well of the one as the other: and for the more liuely vnderstanding, I haue here drawne the epitome of a Lordship, &c, in such a compendious forme as I presume the like hath not bene published.

Upon the one side, thou séest the true proportion of the Lordship or Manour, and euery parcell of ground therein contained, then on the other thou séest a table to expound all that we haue said before, directed therein by letters alphabettically as will be plaine by an example or two.
William Ashbe is my tenant, I would sée what tenewre &c. he holdeth by.

On the left hand I sée he is tenant at wil, then procéeding rightwards vntill I come vnder the title of medow, there doe I sée that he hath but one parcell of medow ground, and that doth containe 1 acre, 2 roods, and 4 day • works of land: the letters A B telling me, that where I find those two letters in the platte, there is the péece of medow, and the name of the said péece, which you shall finde to be a closse, and so procéed vntill you come to the end of the table.

William Cocke •
is my tenant, I desire his tenewre estate, &c. on the left hand. I sée his tenewre is for yeares, and he hath in possession 2 parcels, of medow ground, containing 4 acres, 1 roode, 3 day-works, 1 pearch, and AE directs me to find how they stand in the Manour, where I find their names and seuerall contents as smal acre containing 1 acre, 2 day-works, 1 pearche. And new medow containing 3 acres, 1 rood, 1 day-worke, 1 pearch: in like manner must you find wood ground, pastures and errable, as is plaine in the table, and you must note in each row vnder the title of acres, that the vppermost figure vpon your left hand represents acres, and that on the right hand roods, the lower on the left hand day works, and

table.head: A Table to declare all the seuerall Commodities issuing out of the Mannor of Sale, &c.

p.hi: Seruises proper vnto each tenant in the Manor, and where Heriots be due, &c.

cell.hi: Two dayes with his Teeme in seednesse—
Two daies with his Teeme in Haruest to carry corne.
To appeare at his Courts one day with his Teeme in Lent seednesse.
His best beast at his death.
Money at his death for A Heriot.
16. Acres of common Woodes, wherein be 600: great Limer Trees. 100. Ashes, &c.
The Manor is charged. With one ANnuity of twenty pound for 18 yeares, Rent charge of one hundred pound.

p.hi: Note the Demesnes with the site of the Manor house, &c. being faire and in good reparations conteines 500. acres, 220 of errable, of pasture 150, of medow 130, left vnplatted.
Also the Tenants claime paughnage for foure pence a swine in the common wood.

div.p: Place this Table and May betwéene the folioes 254. and 255.
the other pearches.

But to procéede to the estate, I find that William Cocke was tenant for yeares, then if you procéed in a right line rightwards vntill you come vnder the title of estates, there shall you finde that his estate was for twenty one yeares, standing vnder time leased: next in the row vnder time expired, there shall you find eight yeares, and so much of his twenty one yeares were expired, at the time of taking the surueye. In the next row, vnder suruises there shall you finde this marke * which refers you to the little table of suruises, below the other great table: and so often as you find that starre there, so many suruices is the said Willam Cocke bound to doe to his Lord, which you shall find to be foure times, and those foure suruises be.
First, 2 daies in the haruest to carry corne, 2. to be two daies with his téeme in séednesse. 3. one day with his téeme in Lente séednesse. 4. his best beast at his death.

Lastly vnder the title of Pated for, you shall find how many shéep, and great beasts he is allowed to put into the common, where you shall find that the foresaid William Cocke is rated at 50 shéepe, and 2 beastes, as appeares vnder the seuerall titles.
Then what other commodities rise in the Manour, & what the said Manour is charged with, you may plainely perceiue in the tables vnder placed of purpose.

As there is a moyne of iron stone worth 50 pound by yeare, it is in the ground of Robert Dodde, and then the letter (HH) refers me to the vpper great table, which sheweth me that the said moyne lieth in his pasture ground, which is called the Slead, containing 3 acres, &c. and if you would sée where ye said péece of ground standeth in the Lordship, the letters (HH) will direct you.

And here note that if you haue occasion to hedge or ditch & parcel in the manor, you may meat the same with your paire of compasse and scale in the foote of the platte as trewly as if you did goe into the field, and so may you know what the doing thereof is worth &c. and so set hedgers &c. tax worke.

div.head: CHAP. L.
Certaine Apopthegmes requisite for all Geodetors or measurers of ground to vnderstand.
div.p: Geodeticall Apopthegemes. AL grounds be either naturally good of themselues, and such be knowne by the herbes, &c. as they yéeld; or artificially good, and those are made by endeuors and painefull trauels in manuell labours.

list.item: Wall worts
Soft rushes.
Mallowes.
Thrée leafed grasse.
Straight and faire trées.
Broad elmes.
Great Okes and Ash.
Slo, or Bullace trées.
Wilding, called crab-trées.
Blacke thornes.
Black herrie trees
Corne, thistles, & great thistles.
White or red honisucles.
Hony suckle leanes.
Grasse thicke at the ground.
Good wild fruits.
Good wild hearbes.
Or any one of all the foresayd.

div.p: Made by continuall heaping of doung thereupon, such are about London.
Where old Castles or buildings haue bene situate.
Where pooles haue heretofore bene, by carying the mudde forth, but then it is best to let itly vpon heapes till it be dry, and after carry the same vpon the land and spread it.
Or where land flouds & waters be brought ouer the ground.
Made by letting the grasse grow 6 or 7 yeares vneaten.
Where many sheepe are folded, which they vse in some countries, and so saue dunging their errable grounds, by burning the ground:

But grounds would be considered according to the nature thereof, viz. hot or cold, apply to
hot: mudde.
cold, slime, &c.
colde: lime stone.
marle, &c.

p.hi: Signes of fertill grounds, and such as be rich, are

div.p: Where Crowes and Pies follow the plough.
Mellow and fat grounds that will soone be dssolued best for corne.
Such which be fat and stiffe best for corne.
Where fearne doth grow. best for corne.
The colour of the earth being like new war.
The swelling of the earth, and waxing blacke and dirty after raine.
A blacke or yellowish earth, which kéepeth not raine water but drinketh it vp.
Where the face of the earth is not hard in winter.
Where the earth doth yeeld a pleasant sauor after sunne set.
Where after a shewer of raine following a great drought, you find pleasing smels.
If a péece thereof haue a good taste after it hath line foure houres in pure water.
Which being wet waxeth clammy, and cleaueth vnto your fingers like dough.
If a digged pit lie open thrée or foure dayes, and the mould earth taken thence being cast in againe, afterwards swell or rise aboue the brimme of the pit being troden downe.

p.hi: Signes of barren, leane and vnfruitfull ground.

div.p: If it rise but to the brimme of the pit, indifferent ground.
If it shrinke in vnder the brimmes of the pit, or gape or channe, barren ground.
Where the earth wet with raine doth harden & shew white.
Which be white and hare.
Which abound with grauell, sand or chalke, taking mixture of earth.
Which in a temperate sommer doth gape and open.
Which aboundeth with great grauell, stony or glittering dust.
Which abound with grauell or peble stone.
Which is so dry that it burneth the rootes of plants put therein.
Which is heated and gapeth with small heate of the sunne beames.
A rough, stiffer or tough, a fennish, marish or slime, a red dry and thicke, a leane and cold, a dry leane and stiffe ground.
Where the face of the earth is hard in winter.
Short trées or scrubs.

Alder trées, hard and pricking plants, ill relishing herbes, bitter, Juniper, thornes, briers, fyrses, heath, wormewood, lothsome and ill weedes, withered fearne and plants, arguing a cold seyle, ill coloured herbes, weedes and plants, arguing
a wet ground ouer abounding with moisture.

p.hi: The yearely growth of trees is knowne

div.p: In some by the knots and • oints, in some by their branches; but the generall way for all is▪ giue a slope streake in the rind of the trée, so that it pearce vnto the body, then see in the rind so cut, how many seames or scores be therein contained betwixt the body of the trée and the vtter side of the barke, and so many yeares growth is the said trée.

Likewise may you perceiue the same if a trée be fallen, by the seames that be within the body of the trée running about the hearte, like a number of parallel circles about one center, for so many seames or circles, so many yeares growth is the trée.
The aire according as it is situate breedeth pure and wholsome bloud, or corrupt and bad humors in the body of man, and so chargeth or infecteth the heart, the which is the most noble part.
A sound and pure aire is

lg.l: Made hote soone after sunne rising.
Made colde soone after sunne setting.
Which yéeldeth a pleasant smell after raine.
Cléere and not euaporated, open and lightsome.
Where the North wind bloweth, for it clenseth the aire,
but causeth dry colds, and hurteth plants,
Where the East winde bloweth in the morning.

div.p: A corrupt and infectious aire, is

lg.l: Made by influence of diuers starres.
Made by the vsuall blowing of the South-east and by
South-wind, which gendreth clouds and sickenesses, or by the
South-wind or west in the euening.
Where the sunne is long a making warme after sunne rising.
Where the aire is long hote after sunne set.
Where the aire is close, cloudy or thicke.
Where aboundance of carrion lieth long aboue ground.
Where waters filthy and defiled with watering hempe,
throwing of carrion, emptying of vaults &c, stand long.

div.p: Where multitudes of vncleanly people lie in small roome, many ill sauoring trades in narrow lanes wanting aire, with vnclensed cellars and such ground roomes, abounding too much in London.

Waters are often led by pipes and gutters vnto houses, and the finest leading of them in descending grounds, is in trenches, fild full of pebbell stones, and couered ouer with earth: and you must note that as there be corrupt and vnwholsome aires, so be there bad and naughty waters vnfit for the vse of man
That water is best and purest for mans vse which,

lg.l: Runneth Northwards.
Runneth out of a hill into the East, from the North, and
is the best that runneth farthest in course.
Runneth swistly through stones, rockes, &c. and from a hill.
Hath no sauor, smel or colour, but is thinne and pure.
Will take the colour of any thing cast therein.
Will be soone hot and cold.
Is warme in winter and cold in summer.

div.p: Yeeldeth no staine after a drop or two, is let dry vpon a polished stéele glasse, plate of siluer, brasse, which boyling yéeldeth least filth to be scummed off, or being poured out leaueth the vessels bottome cleanest.
Is lightest in waite.
Is taken in sommer after a clap of thunder, or after a mild shewer, but not such as falleth off houses and out of gutters.

The bad and vnholsome waters be such, which are opposite vnto the former, as such which runs into the South, which be heauy, ill sauored, and staine what they fall vpon, which run flow, which is long in heating.

div.head: CHAP. LI.
Of surueying of ground, of making a new kind of particular of apportionating lands, of ancient measure, and buying annuities.
div.p:
SUrueying of grounds consists of two parts, Mathematical and legal the Mathematicall is performed instrumentally, as in the first parte of this booke, the instrumentall operation is either to deliuer the true contents of euery particular, by plot or ingrosement; to ingrose the contents of any Manour is to measure euery particular truly and precisely, and to write the same in Latine orderly, in a faire booke with broad margent notes, easily and quickely offering the contents to the
eye, and this is performed after diuers wales, some beginne with the side of the manor place, then proceed to the common fields, &c. butting and bounding euery seuerall particular, which is not materiall, vnlesse there be free holders in the manor, or one man holding free hold, and coppy, or leass land both. Others begin with the circuit, then go to the fight, next to the Auousonage, and then to the tenants.

But the best way, in my fantasie, is first hauing giuen the title to beginne with the Maner house, noting the buildings, &c. then to procéede to the demesnes, then to the Rectory, next to the freeholders, next to the Tenants for yeares, liues, will, &c. noting downe euery seuerall particular by name, with the true quantity of acres, and what an acre is worth: For you must note that some acres be better then some, according to the place it lieth in. For medow grounds in some vpland grounds may be worth but ii • j s. the acre, in some places worth v. s, in some x. s. in some xx. s. or xxx. s. or xl. s. yea in some I know medowes let for i • j. l. the acre, and yet the Tenants haue a good bargaine. Now all this being noted, draw a right line to containe euery particular belonging to that tenement, as in the end of the Topographicall Glasse.
