Writing in the right margent in the middest of the sayd right line the yearely rent, and at the lower ende the improuement: And last by collect, how many acres of medow, how many of pasture, &c. each tenement hath belonging thereunto, and then say, Inpratis 40 acr. in pasturis 80 ac. &c. according as you may gather by this one tenement vnder written, in manner and forme aforesayd.

figure.p: Superuis. maner. de Sale ibidem capt. per ambulationem examinationem & mensurationem tam, A. H. general, superuisor. quod T.N. Domini maner. praedict. & per mandat. eiusdem, quam per sacrament. R.B, &c. tuncibid existent. 12. die Octobris, anno Domini 1606, annoque regni lacobi, Dei gratia, Angliae Franciae, & Scotiae.

table.head: Iohannes at Noke tenet per Indenturam gerent. dat. 28 Septembris, Anno regni domini Regis, &c. vnummesuag. siue tenementum cum certis terris, viz.

cell.hi: DOmum mansual. iacent. inter regiam viamibidem ex parte occidental. & oriental. inter tenementum A. D. & communem campum ex parte boreal. & le broad streete ex parte Austral. & continet 28 perticum in latitudine & 62 perticum in longitudine, & mesuagium siue tenementum praedictum sufficienter constructum ac etiam tegulatum cum vna aula, vnum caenaculum vocat. a parlor, octo cameris & coquina cum vno stabul. & vno horreo, acle oxhouse, ibid cum stramine coopertum continen. 8 bayes, ac caeteris domib. necessari is adiacent.

row.cell: Vnum clauss. prati voat. le broade medow, cont. 20 ac. quaelibet acra valens 30. s̄
Clauss. pastur. vocat. le healde, cont. 10 acr. qualibet acr. 15 s̄, & redditper ann. 7. s̄. 6. d.
Clauss. terr. ar abil. vocat. le mil field, cont. 20 ac. quaelibet acr. valens 8 s̄ & reddit peranum 1 s̄ 6 d
Clauss. prati vocat. long medow, cont. 2 acr. quaelibet acr. 18 s̄, & reddit per ann. 13 s̄. 6 d.
And so of all the rest, as you find it: then say, Valet dimittendum. 47 P 6 s̄.

div.p: Lastly say according to the true improuement.

cell.hi: Iohannes at Noke tenet in pastuis —10.

div.p:
But seldome times you shal come to a Manor, and finde all the particulars valued by themselues, as before. vnlesse in some certaine places by an ancient reseruation:To apportion linds. for commonly the tenement is taken altogether, giuing a fine and some small rent, so that it is hard to come to know what they pay for euery acre according to the present rent: therefore where the rent of euery seuerall particular is not knowne, the surneyor
must apportion the value and worth of the acres; according to his discretion. For medows lying barren and high, or low and fenny. yeelding gréene hard rushes, flagges and knotty grasse, are not worth aboue 4 s, 6 d per annum: but whether the rent be knowne of euery particular or not, the receined order of apportionating is thus. Get the value of an acre of arable land (but aime not at the best nor the worst, as hereafter) then double the value of the arable land, and to the product adde halfe the value of the sayd acre of arable, so haue you the worth of an acre of pasture: then multiply the value of the arable acre by 4, and to the product adde halfe the worth of the sayd arable acre, so haue you the value of an acre of medow. And note, if the medow & pasture consist most of a fertill soile, take the value of your arable acre in the best place, &c. But this rule is not certaine, and therefore must be amended according as the goodnesse of the ground shall apeare: neither be woods, orchards or gardens subiect vnto this apportion.

In the second Booke and second Chapter I recited a measure set downe by Iabian, but that is not certaine in all places: For there I told you,Ancient measures of groūds Hide of land. Plough land. that 8 hides make a knights fee, but in the Duchy of Lancaster they count but halfe so much, to wit, 4 hides, euery hide 4 plough land, which is so much as one téeme may till in a yeare.

And this plough land is called in the North an Oxgange, euery plough land is 4 yard land, euery yard land 30 acres, so that euery plough land containes 120 acres, euery hide 480 acres, and euery knights fee 1920 acres: but some account it more, as euery kuights fee 5 hides, euery hide foure yard land, euery yard land 24 acres, but in the second booke euery knights fee is 8 hides, &c.

Now two knights fee make a Cantred, which according to the first of the former accounts is 3840 acres;A Camred. 6 Cantreds & ½⅙ make a Barony, which is 25600 acres, whose reléefe is 100 markes;A Barony. one Barony and a halfe makes an Earledome, which is 38400 acres, whose releefe is 100 pounds: but I meane not that euery Earledome or Barony of neressity must haue so much and no more:A Earledome. onely these were the proportions at the first institution.

To purchase Annuities. And if any annuities be issuing forth of the Manor which you be desirous to purchase, by my tables published in my Almanacke
1608, séeke what 10 P. per. annum is worth for the time proposed, & then making that your radix by the rule of proportion taught often before, obtaine your destre, saying, if 10 P per annum be worth so much for so many yeares, what is 60 P. &c. worth? Concerning my Almanacke for this yeare 1610, My Alman • cke there was in my absence a most rare kind of Tables for the computation of time omitted for the priuate gaine, and at the especiall request (as I heare) of some priuate man: whereby I was much iniuried, my booke quite defaced, and the common weale restrained from the generall benefit thereof, as though they or we were tied to a particular method: but if it might haue bene a hinderer to any, more then the same might haue benefited many, I then rest well contented.

div.head: CHAP. LII.
To reduce Statute measure into customary measure, or any kind of measure vsed in any particular place: or contrary.
div.p: IN the second booke of our Geodeticall Staffe, I gaue, certaine notes concerning the diuerfitie of measures vsed in diuerse places, and in my Art of Geodetia I omitted to deliuer any proposition that might yéeld the proportion of one to the other: For indéede as the Chapters are there set downe disorderly without any commendable consequence, so was my leysure but short for the accomplishment of the same; neither could I intend to alter the first manuscript, but did onely procéede, adding (though not in their proper places) such things I saw wanting, but tooke them by whole sale, one with another: for my intent indéede was not to publish the same.

To reduce stasture measure to woodland measure. But to procéede, when you know the contents of any péece of ground according to Statute measure, and are to deliuer the contents thereof according to 18 foote in the pearch or pole, commonly called woodland measure, do thus.

You are first to consider the lowest proportionall termes of their lines: for the like proportion that the square of the one terme beareth to the square of the other, the like shall the acre of the one beare to the acre of the other, or the square pearch of the one to the square pearch ofthe other.

The lowest proportionall terines of 16½ is 11, and of 18, 12, (which you must find by the abbreuiating of thē by 1½:) now the square of 11 is 121. and the square of 12 is 144; by the
thirtéenth Chapter of the sixt booke.
So then the proportions stand thus, as 121 the square of 11, is to 144 the square of 12, so is an acre of 16½ in the pearch to an acre of 18 foote in the pearch.

Therefore for the reducing of Statute measure into woodland measure, as before, multiply the giuen number by 121, and the product deuide by 144, the quotient shall yeelde you the contents according to woodland measure.To reduce woodland measure to statute measure.

But it may be that the woodland measure of 18 féete in the pole, will be giuen, and you required to reduce it into Statute measure, which performe thus. Multiply the giuen number by 144, and make partition of the product by 121, so haue you your desire.
And here note, that if ye giuen number be expressed in acres, reduce the same into pearches for your more ease in working.

div.head: CHAP. LIII.
Of the platting or casting vp of one Manour, &c. by diuerse scales, as Statute measure, and woodland measure, &c.
div.p: I Haue séene it so fall out in platting of Manors, Lordships, &c. that there hath bene wood grounds therein to be measured, not according to statute measure as the former was, but after 18 foote in the pearch, which you may do thus. Measure it by one scale,To measure grounds by two scales. as you did the rest, then afterwards reduce it by the last Chapter. But say that some stubborne people not séene in the art of our reducement, will onely haue it measured in the field, according vnto 18 foote in the pearch, and not suffer vs about the woods to vse the Statute measure: wherefore I shall be driuen to worke by another Scale, otherwise I should thrust the plat out of proportion.

To measure and plat wood-grounds by 18 foote pole, so that it shall agree with the rest of the plat taken by statute measure. Therefore I must worke thus: take 12 of those parts of the scale I formerly platted the rest with, and that length deuide into 11 equall parts, so haue you made a new scale which you may make as lōg as you wil, according to those 11 equal parts.

Now may you safely measure according vnto 18 foote in the pearch, still platting or laying the measured lines downe by this new scale, in so much ye though you measured the Manour by a scale of 16½ foote in the pearch, and the wode by 18 foote in the pearch; yet protracting by this new scale, all the grounds will abut and bound in due and true proportion, euen as they
had bene measured by one scale of 16½ foot in the pearch.
For these causes it were not amisse to haue two scales made according to the prescript,

And take this note, that all grounds measured by a statute pearch, and platted by a scale of 12 in an inch, that you may readily find the contents according to 18 foote in a pearch, if you doe but cast vp the platte by a scale according to 11 parts in an inch: the reason is because a 11 pearches in length of this woodland measure make 12 in length of statue measure; hereby may you render the contents of any wood grounds according to either.

div.head: Chap. LIIII.
In the surueying of a Manour, how to ioyne all the parcels in one platte as they lye in the whole Manour.
div.p: VVOrking by the plaine table Theodelitus Geodetical staffe, or any other instrument, the best rule I can prescribe you is,To ioyne al the parcels in a Manour in one plat or card. first to get the perfect & direct perimeter of the Lordship, and that to lay downe by a large scale vpon faire shéets of paper glued together; then goe into euery seuerall field in the Manour taking the true platte as you be instructed in the first pare of Geodetia: and then at euery night carefully to place those parcels, within the former perimeter in their proper places; which to doe you must take notice how one lyeth by another, that you misplace not any: hauing finished, if the particulars iust fill vp the perimeter, you haue truly wrought.

But this note, if you platte by the plaine table, take as many particulars vpon one shéet as you may, and when you change your shéete, worke as you be taught in my Topographical glasse,To change the paper in the plaine table. or by helpe of your néedle at euery changing of your shéete, strike a Meridian ouer the new shéete, for your better directing your selfe in ioyning your shéetes, because the Meridians must lie parallel when you ioyne the said shéets.
Also haue a care in making a platte to place the houses, buildings, trees, and euery notable thing in your platte.

div.head: CHAP. LV.
To alter the whole platte of a Manour, and euery particular therein, easily and speedily.
div.p: VVHereas in the last chapter I instructed you to lay the perimeter of a Manour downe by a large scale for your more direct working, yet happely you shall be required to deliuer the same in a farre more lesse proportion; and tho I haue already set downe diuers rules in my arte of Geodetia for the performance thereof instrumentally, yet shall it be nothing amisse to shew you an other easy way,To alter the platte of a Manour to any proportion. for that your instrument is not alwaies at hand. By the insuing Chapter, get the true plat in a faire shéete of paper in such lines that may be rubbed forth againe, then to alter the plat to any other proportion doe thus. Prepare a rule with a renter hole, deuide this rule into as many small equall parts as you can, & number the same by 10: let the rule be of some thinne plate.

Now to worke herewith, about the middest of the platte with a small néedle through the center hole of the rule, there fasten the said rule to the paper, and the boord that the paper lyeth on: then remoue the edge of the rule to any corner in any fielde, and note the equall parts cut, and of these take what part you please according to the proportion assigned as the ½ ⅓ or any other: your rule stil resting at that angle, by the edge of the said rule make a pricke according to the proportion taken, as if the parts cut be 60, & you meane to make the plat but halfe so big that is, then must you make a pricke at 30, which is halfe 60: then turne the rule to the next angle in the said field, and doe the like to the proportional part of that number cut, and so laying the rule by euery angle make pricks at the proportionall part, and then draw a line from pricke to pricke; so is a figure made lesse and proportionall to the greater; this done rub out with crummes of bread the blacke leaded lines of the field, and then procéed to the next, doing so to euery field seuerally vntill you haue finished, still rubbing forth the blacke leaded lines as you finish the said field.

To alter plats from lesser to greater. And there you shal note, that as you may by this doctrine alter a great platte to a lesse, so may you one the contrary, alter a lesser to a greater, onely noting

In altering of plats from the
Lesser to the greater,
Greater to the lesser, You must begin at the
Perimeter of the platte.
Middest of the platte.

But in this you must not alter the center of your inder from the middest of the platte, howsoeuer you alter the platte either from greater to lesse or lesse to greater: certainely this kind of worke is most precise and excellent for the altering plattes of Manours, sea-cards or such like, tho they vse to performe it by crosse lines, or squares, which may serue for that purpose, but not so well for this: others vse to alter them by circles other waies; but take this tho something Mechanicall, yet most requisite, for many conclusions stand firme and true in demonstrations Geometricall, though otherwise in practise tedious and vnnecessary.

div.head: Chap. LVI.
To take a platte out of one peece of paper, and place the same truely in an other peece according to the same proportion and fashion it had before, and that diuers waies.
div.p: YOu must take the paper whereupon the platte is drawne, and rub the backe side with blacke lead all ouer,To take any platte out of one papar and place it in en other. then lay a faire shéete of paper (or two or thrée glued together if the plat • e large) vpon a plaine boord, and vpon that lay the leaded side of the platte or other shéete: fasten them both vpon the boord at the 4 corners, then take a sharpe pointed bodkin, and with somewhat a heauy hand trace all the lines within the said platte, & all such other things that you would expresse: lastly take away the vppermost paper, so will all the lines that you haue traced, remaine vpon the lower shéete, which you may rub out with crummes of bread.

Lay the plat it selfe vpon the Table, then prepare a paper well oyled with Lin-séede oyle, and fasten the same vpon the plat that lieth vpon the table: so shall you sée all the lines and other notes in the plat through this oyled paper, as through a cléere glasse; then with a pen & inke, or a bodkin draw or trace all the lines required: • o haue you taken the plat out of the lower paper into the oyled paper, which you may pricke and pounce, and so place vpon any other paper at your pleasure: by such oyled paper may any simple body take any worke, flower, or such like, forth of any place as he pleaseth.

You may pricke all the lines with a small néedle, as the order
is, and so accordingly with pund coles in a cloute pounce the same, and then draw the lines with a pen, or pensell made of blacke lead, or a Sally cole, according as you would haue the lines to remaine, or vpon any occasion blotted out. Many formes more art-like I could deliuer, but for the causes before remembred these shall suffice.

div.head: CHAP. LVII.
To garnish your plat.
div.p: YOur plat being finished, and all things orderly contriued, it resteth then for you to garnish and beautifie the same with such water colours as is conuenient,To garnish a platte. adding thereunto the due proportion of all houses, buildings, &c. and for your better instruction lay all arable lands in red, all pasture in a russet, or some such kind of colour, and all medows in gréene, decking all woodlands with trees, and doe not omit the port wayes or any other way worthy of note nor any brooke, well, crosse, or trée of note or other speciall marke of note: for all such are true ornaments & most requisite to be placed in your Card: for it is absurd to follow many rude painted obseruations, making trées where none be, laying gréene where no medow is, and such like; & take care that you make not your port waies, bookes, &c. broader then the proportion alloweth. I haue séens diuerse draw a brooke, being not passing one pearch broad indéed, more then 5 pearches broad, being applied to their scale; which was absurd: and many more such grosse errors concerning the rules of proportion, which I omit. And so for this time I end this Art of Geodetia, desiring my ability were such to answer to the fulnesse of thy expectation in this volume:In my Topographical glasse. hereafter it may be I shall be occasioned to speake more.

div.trailer: The end of the sixt Booke.

div.head: THE SEVENTH BOOKE OF THE GEODETICAL STAFFE, called Trigonometria:
Containing Longimetria and Altimetria, performed by Synnicall supputation, with a Canon for the dimension of tryangles: compendiously calculated for the performance thereof.
CHAP. I.
Geometricall definitions, propositions and consequences of lines, angles, and tryangles, &c.
div.p:
Trygonometria
TRigonometria is a doctrine treating of the dimension of tryangles, of which there be two kinds, right lined and sphericall; we onely at this time speaking of right lined angles.
A point. 2 A poynt is a signe in a magnitude vndiuisible. Ra. l. 1. p. 6.
A right line. 3 A line is a magnitude onely long. Ra. l. 2. p. 2. Or a line is the shortest extension betwéene two points; or a line is the motion of a point.
4 A touch is made in a poynt, Eucl. l. 13. p. 3.
Crooked lines. 5 A crooked line is a Circumference, or Helix. Ra. l. 2. p. 7.
6 A Circumference is that which is equally distinct from the middest of the space contained in it. ibid. p. 8.
7 A Circumference is therefore made by the running of a line equi-distant about the renter, the one end resting fixed; or a Circumference is made by the motion of a poynt equally about the Center.
8 An Helix is that which is vnequally distant from the middest of the space that is contained within: but we néed not this Prop.

9 Parallel lines are such that be equally distant one from the other euery where. Eu. 35. p. 11. Parallels. Therefore parallel lines
being exiended infinitly neuer intersect.
10 If one line be parallell to many, all those lye parallell one to another, or amongst themselues.
11 An angle is a liniate consisting in the common section of the Termes. Ra. l. 3. p. 3. or an angle is made by the concourse of two lines.
12 The féete of the angle are the termes comprehending the angles. Ra. ibid. p. 4.
13 Angles homogeneall, are angles alike in all respects.
14 Ifangles haue equall féete, they be also equall. R. l. 4. p. 5.
15 An angle is either right or oblique.
16 A right angle is made by a perdendicular falling vpon the base, or which doth containe the fourth part of a circle.
17 In right angled tryangles the line subtending the right angle is called the hypothenusall, either of the other termes containing the right angle, may be called the perpendicular, or the base.
18 An oblique angle is either obtuse or acute.
19 An obtuse angle is an oblique angle greater then a right angle. Eu. l. 1. def. 11.
20 An acute angle is an oblique angle, lesse then a right angle. Eu. ibid. Def. 12.
21 A figure is a lineate magnitude, limited on euery side. Ra. l. 4. p. 1.
22 A center is the middle poynt in a figure.
23 A perimeter is that which doth inclose a figure.
24 A radius is a right line extended from the Center to the perimeter.

25 A diameter is a right line inscribed in a figure, and drawne through the center. Therefor
1 In one figure there may be infinite diameters.
2 The center is alwaies in the diameter.
3 If there be many diameters the center is in the concourse thereof.
4 If two diameters intersect, the center is in ye intersection.
26 If a right line fall vpon a right line, the angles there made are equall vnto two right angles, and contrary. Euc. l. 1. p. 14. 13.
27 If two lines crosse one the other, the verticall angles be equall, and all the angles equall to fours right angles.
Tryangles. 28 A tryangle is a right lined plaine contained vnder thrée angles, and thrée right lines.
29 Any two sides of a tryangle are greater then the third side remaining. Ra. l. 6. p. 7.
30 If a right line in a tryangle be parallell to the base, it cutteth the féete proportionally, and contrariwise. Eu. l. 6. p. 2. and being parallell the angles be equall.

31 The thrée angles in a tryangle are equall vnto two right angles. Eu. l. 1. p. 32. Therefore
1 Any two angles in a tryangle are lesser then two right angles.
2 The side of a tryangle being continued forth infinitly, the outward angle is equall to the two inward angles opposite, and greater by the same consequence then any inward angle opposite.

32 If a tryangle haue equall féete, the angles at the base are equall and contrary. Eu. l. 1. p. 5. & 6. Consequently
1 An equiangle triangle is also equilater, and contrary.
2 An angle of an equilater tryangle is as great as ⅔ of a right angle. Ra. l. 6. p. 10. Cons. 3.
33 The greatest side of a tryangle subtendeth the greatest angle, and contrary. Eu. l. 1. p. 19. & 18.
34 Tryangles of equall height are in proportion as their bases. Eu. l. 6. p. 1.
35 All Circles in Trygonometria are deuided into 360 equall parts, and so into minutes, &c. accordingly. So that the quadrant of a circle containes 90 degrées.
36 The giuen arke in the lesser quadrant is the complement to the distance thereof from 90 as 40, the giuen arke is the complement to 50, the distance thereof from 90.
37 The arke in the greater quadrant is an excesse aboue 90, as 140 is an arke in the greater quadrant excéeding 90, 50 degrées.
38 All lines drawne from the center to the circumference be of equall length.

div.head: CHAP. II.

Hauing giuen you some necessary Geometricall instructions, for the better opening of your vnderstanding, now shall follow the Axiomes of Trigonometria it selfe, which chiefely is effected by the rule of proportion: the first Axiome shall teach what proportions shall be in the tryangles or parts thereof; afterward shall be declared, how those Axiomes may be applied to vse.

p.hi: Axioma 1. In plaine rectangled tryangles, any one of the three sides may be put for the radius,

div.p: FIrst, if you put the side subtending the right angle for the radius, the sides including the right angle are the sines of the acute opposite angles, As in the plaine tryangle A B C, if you put the side A B, subtending the right angle for the Radius, then B C, the lesse side including the right angle is the sine of the lesser acute angle opposite therto, as A B C; and the greater side A C including the right angle, is the sine of the greater angle opposite as A B C.

2 If you put the greater side including the right angle for the Radius, then the lesser side including the right angle is the Tangent, and the side subtending the right angle is the secant of the lesser acute angle.

As if you put the greatter side including the right angle A C for the Radius, then is the lesser including side B C the Tangent of B A C, the lesser angle opposite thereto, and A B, the line subtending the right angle, the secant of the said acute angle.

3 If to conclude, you put the lesse side including the right
angle for the Radius, the greater side including the right angle is the Tangent, and the side subtending the right angle is the secant of the greater acute angle.

As if you put the lesse side B C for the Radius, then the greater side A C including the right angle, is the Tangent of ye greater acute angle opposite there to A B C, and the subtending side A B is the secant of the said acute angle.

p.hi: Consectary 1. Therefore in plaine right angled tryangles

div.p: The angles being giuen, the proportions of the side are had thrée manner of waies.
One side together with the angles being giuen, the rest of the sides are had after a thréefold proportion, according to the side that you put for the Radius.

As in the plaine right angled tryangle proposed A B C, the giuen angle A, is 30 degrées 20 min. and thereby B 59 degrées, 40 min. (for ye one acute angle is the complement to ye other, as you may gather Chapter 1, def. 30, therefore in plaine right angled tryangles, one of the acute angles being giuen, the rest are likewise had) so as I say the angle at A is 30 degrées, 20 min. and at B 59, 40 whereby the proportion of the sides stand thus.

row.cell: B C the sine of the acute angle B A C
A C the sine of the acute angle A B C
B C, the Tangent of the acute angle B A C
A B, the secant of the said acute angle
A C, the Tangent of the acute angle A B C
A B, the secant of the said acute angle

list.item: 1 As A B / 100000 the radius is to B C / 50502 the fine of the acute angle B A C.
2 Or, as A B / 115861 the secant is to B C / 58513 the tangent of the acute angle B A C.
3 Or to conclude, as A B / 198008 the secant of the acute angle A B C is to B C / 100000 the radius, and so of the rest.

div.p: 1 Besides the angles giuen there is also giuen the side A B 4 féete, and the side B C is required how many féete it conaines: Therefore say
1 As A B / 100000 the radius, is to B C / 505029 the right sine, so is A B / 24 feete the side, to A C 12 12671/100000 féete.
2 As A B / 115861 the secant, is to B C / 58513 the tangent, so is A B / 24 feet to B C 12 17986/115861 féete.
3 As A B / 198008 the complement of the secant, is to B C / 100000 the radius, so is A B / 24 feet the side to B C 12 23902/198008 féete.
2 Likewise if the same side A B 24 féete were giuen, and the side A C required, Say
1 As A B / 100000 the radius, is to A C / 86310 the right sine, so is A B / 24 feet the side, to A C 20 71444/100000 feete.
2 As A B / 115861 the secant, is to A C / 100000 the radius, so is A B / 24 feete the side, to A C 20 82776/115861 feete.
3 As A B / 198008 the complement of the secant, is to A C / 170901 the tangent, so is A B 24 feete to A C 141465/198008 feete.
3 In like manner, if the side A C 20 71444/100000 féete be giuen, and the side B C required: Say
1 As A C / 86310 the right sine is to B C / 505027 so is A C 20 71444/100000 féete, to B C 12 16418/86 • 10 féete.
2 As A C / 100000 the radius, is to B C / 58523 the tangent, so is A C 20 71444/100000 feete, to B C 12 12071/100000 féete.
3 As A C / 170901 the tangent of the complement, is to B C / 100000 the radius, so is A C 20 71444/100000 feete, to B C 12 26636/170901 feete.

But the witty Artist skilfull in the vse of this treatise of Trigonometria, will proportion his numbers in such order that the Radius shall alwaies haue the first place, thereby to auoide the great labour in deuiding such great numbers.

p.hi: Consectarie 2. By the giuing of two sides which soeuer they be, both the acure angles are obtained by a double proportion, according to the side that you appoint for the radius.

div.p: 1 AS in the plaine right angled tryangle A B C, if two sides including the right angle be giuen, as A B and B C, the one being 5 féete, the other 3 féete, and the acute angles at A and B are required; Say

1 As A B / 5 Feet is to B C / 3 feete, so is A B / 100000 the radius, to B C / 59995 the sine of the angle B A C, answering to which sine in the Table vpon the left side the page is 36 degrees, 52 minutes, and the last row in the Table vpon the right hand is 53 degrées, 8 minuts, the complement of A B C.

2 As B C / 3 Feet is to A B / 5 Feet, so is B C / 100000 the radius to A B / 166679 the secant of the angle A B C, to which secant vpon the right hand in the right Table answeres 53 degrees, 8 minutes, and in the left margent in the lefte Table answering thereunto is the complement of the Angle 36 degrées, 52 minutes.
Likewise in the tryangle A B C, if there be giuen two sides containing the right angle, as A C 4 féete, and B C 3 feete, and the acute angles B and A, be required, you may say

1 As A C / 4 feete is to B C / 3 feet so is B C / 100000 the radius to B C / 74991 the tangent of the angle B A C, the arke answering in the Table is 36 degrées,The second figure in the first Axiome serueth here. 52 minutes, and the complement of that angle is 53 degrées, 8 minutes.

2 As B C / 3 feete is to A C / 4 feete so is B C / 100000 the radius to A C / 133549 the tangent of the angle A B C, the arke answering to which tangent in the right table is 53 degrées,The third figure in the first Axiome serueth here also. 8 minutes, and the complement of the sayd arke in the last row leftwards in the left Table is 36 degrées 52 min.

p.hi: Axioma 2. In all kind of plaine tryangles

div.p: The sides haue like proportion vnto the other, as the signes of the opposite angles haue, respecting the said sides.

The signes be equall with the halfe of the subtensions, and the sides of tryangles haue like proportion vnto the other as the lines haue subtending the said angles: the like therefore hath the halfe subtension; for what proportion the whole hath to the whole, the same hath the halfe to the halfe; for the same proportion as 16 hath to 6, the like hath 8 to 3.

Demonstration: if about the plaine tryangle A B C. there be circumscribed a circle, the side A B is made a line subtending the angle A B C, that is the arke A B, which méeteth with the angle A C B; the side B C is made the subtension of the angle B A C, because it méeteth with the angle A C B: to conclude, the side A C is made to subtend the angle A B C, that is the arke A C, because it méeteth with the angle A B C.
Therefore the side A B beares it selfe in such proportion to the side B C, as the subtention of the angle A C B, doth to the subtension of the angle B A C, &c. which was required to be demonstrated.

p.hi: Therefore the angles being giuen, the proportion of the side • be also found.

div.p: Besides, the angles hauing also one side, both the other sides are easily obtained.

As in the plaine obliqueangled tryangle A B C, the angle at A 20 degrées, 10 minutes, at C 60 degrées, 23 min. is giuen, and therefore B 99 deg. 27 mini is also giuen, then the proportion of the sides be found thus.
A B 86935 the sine of the angle A C B, 60 degrées, 23 min.
B C 34475 the sine of the angle B A C, 20 degr. 10 min.
A C 98642 the sine of the angle A B C, 99 deg 27 min.

Therefore if further there be giuen one side, as A B 34
féete, the other sides B C and A C, are also to be had: For

1 As A B / 869 • 5 is to B C / 34475 •
so is A B / 34 feete to B C 13 42660/ • 6935 feete.

2 As A B / 869 • 5 is to A C / 98642 •
so is A B / 34 feet to A C 38 • 9324/89985 feete.

2 As A C B / 8663 •
is to A B / 34 feete, so is B A C / • 4475 to B C 13 42/8 •
féete.

2 As A C B / 8693 •
is to A B / 34 et so is A B C / 98642 to A C 38 50/ ••
féete.

p.hi: Consectarie 2. Two sides of a tryangle being giuen, with an angle opposite to one of the said sides, to find the other side, and the other two angles opposite to the two sides.

div.p: AS in the oblique angled tryangle A B C, two sides being giuen A B 34 féete, and B C 13 42660/86935 féete, with the angle A C B opposite to A B containing 60 degrées 23 min. You shall also be brought to the knowledge of the angle A B C opposite to any other of the giuen sids, to wit A C, for by the giuing of the angle A C B 60 degrées 23 min, the fine of that angle 86935, is also had: Therefore I say, as A B the side 34 féete is to B C the side 13 41669/86935 féete, so is A B the sine of the angle A C B 86935 to B C the sine of the angle B A C 34475.

As AB / 34 feete is to A C B / 86 • 35 so is B C, 13 42000/86935 féete to B A C / 34475 To which sine 34475 in the Table vpon the lette hand in
the left margent 20 gr. and 10 min. doth answere, therefore the angle B A C is 20 gr. 10 min.

Note, in the vse of the former consectary certaine doubts may arise, to wit: if there be giuen two sides, wherof the one is the greater side, together with the angle opposite to the lesse of the giuen sides, and there is required the angle opposite to the greater of the giuen sides, and for because this angle may be acute or obtuse, and so the same sine serue to which you please, hauing obtained the sine, it is a doubt to which angle it answea • eth.

As in the oblique tryangle A B, if two sides be giuen A C • 0 féet, and B C 10 féete together with the angle B A C 29 degrées and 59 min. and the angle A B C is demanded opposite to the greatest side, if I should say:

As the side B C 10 féete is to the side A C 20 féete; so is B C y• sine of the angle B A C 49974 to A C to the sine of ye angle A B C, for the sine of A C is easily found 99947, but because this sine is as well the sine of the acute angle A D C 88 degrées 8 min. as of the obtuse angle A B C 91 degrées 52 min. it is doubtfull whether the obtuse angle of 91 degrees 52 min. or the acute angle of 88 deg. and 8 min, be found by that sine.
Neither can this doubt otherwise be resolued, then by the doctrine before to find out the quantify of the said vnknowen angle.

p.hi: Axioma III. In all kind of plaine tryangles.

div.p: AS the whole of two sides is to the difference of the same, so is the Tangent of the whole halfe of the two opposite angles, to the Tangent of the difference, that is, more or lesse then the halfe.

Declaration: in the plaine obliquangled tryangle A B C, I say, that the tangent of the whole halfe of the two angles at A and B, is to the Tangent of the difference of the angle B more, and of the angle A lesse then the halfe, as the whole of the two sides B C, and A C opposite to those angles, is to the difference of the same.

Demonstration: describe a quadrant A B C, and therein appoint the angles D A E and E A C equal to the halfe angles in the former scheme A B C, and B A C, and therein let be the whole halfe of those two angles, which is héere contained in the angle D A C; let the halfe of that whole be D A F, or F A C, the difference of the angle D A E more then the halfe of D A F, or of the angle E A C, lesse then the halfe of F A C, is the angle F A E. The subtension of the whole of those two angles
is the right line D C, the sine of the angle D A E is D G, the sine of the lesser angle E A C is the right lins C H; the Tangent of the whole halfe of the two tryangles is F N or F K, the Tangent of the difference lesse, or more then the halfe is F E: now the tryangles G D P, and C P H, are equall by the Chapter 1, def. 26, so that we may inferre proportional termes thus; as P D is to G D, so is P C to C H, as is proued 4. P. 6. Eucl. And so in the first figure.

As A C is to A B C, iso is B C to B A C, by the third Axioma, therefore the sides D P and P C, haue in like manner the same proportion in this figure, as the sides A C and B, haue in the first scheme.

Wherefore we may boldly take the right line D C for the whole of the two giuen • ids A C and B C, and the partes D P and P C, for those two sides A C and B C: the which so being, N P is the difference of y• two sides, but the sides A C and B C in the first, and D P and P C in the second scheme are giuen, therefore the difference of the same side N P is also giuen together with the halfe of the difference thereof, as O P.

Furthermore, because the tryangles composed of A K L F E M and A D N O P C, are together equiangled by reason of the parallels D C and K M, therefore both the sides and the segment of the sides be proportionall:—so that,
As D C the whole of the two sides, is to N P the difference of the same:
So is K M the double Tangent of halfe of the twe angles to L E the double Tangent of the difference more or lesse then the halfe.
As O C the halfe of the whole of the two sides, is to O P the halfe of the difference thereof:
So is F M, the Tangent of the whole halfe of the two opposit angles, to F E the tangent of the difference more, or lesse then the halfe,

As the whole of the two sides is to N P, the difference of the same, so is F M, the Tangent of the halfe of the two opposite angles, to F E the Tangent of the difference, more or lesse then the halfe. For as the whole is to the whole, so is the parte to the parte: therefore as the whole K M is to the part L E, so is the halfe F M, to the halfe F E.

p.hi: Consectarium. Therefore in plaine oblique angled tryangles, two sides being giuen with the angle comprehended by the same, the other two angles are also found.

div.p: As in the plaine obliquangled try angle A B C, by the giuing of the two sides A C 5, and B C 3 féete together with the angle A C B 40 degrées, the other two angles A B C and B A C are found, thus.
The whole of the two giuen sides is eight, the difference two.
The whole of the angles at A and B is 140 degrées by the Chap. 1. def. 30
The halfe of that whole is 70 grad. whose Tangent is 274747

As the two giuen sides 8, is to 2 the difference of the same, so is the Tangent of the halfe of the opposite angles 274747 to 68685 the Tangent of the arke, 34 degrées, 29 min, the difference of the angle A lesse, and of B more then the halfe.
So that it is thus.

p.hi: Axioma V. In all kind of plaine tryangles,

div.p: As the greatest side is to the other two sids, so is the difference of the rest of the sides, to the segment of the greatest side, which being taken away, the perpendicular falleth in the midst of that which remaineth.

Declaration, let the obliquangle be A B C, whose lest side is A C, ye greatest B C, the radius of the lefe side A C, the center A, whereon describe a circle C D E F, cut in the other two sides in points at F and E, making A C the radius or semidiameter: furthermore the side A B is produced to D, and B D is the whole of the two sides, A B and A C, for A C and A D be equall. now E B is the difference of the sides A B and A C, for A E and A C againe be equall by the Chapter 1. P. 37—so that I say: As C B, is to B D, so is E B to B F.
Next the right line F G, is cut into two parte by the perpendicular A G falling in the midst thereof.
Consectarie. Therefore in plaine obliquangled tryangles, the thrée sides being giuen, to find either of the segments in the greatest side whereon the perpendicular falleth from the greatest angle.
As in the plaine obliquangled tryangle A B C, there be the 3 sides giuen, to wit.

list.item: A B, 20 féete.
B C, 22 féete.
A C, 13 féete.

div.p: And there is required the segment of the greatest side B C, in the concourse whereof, to wit, of B G and B C, the perpendicular falleth.
The greatest side is 21 féete the whole of the other two sides viz. of A B 20 féete, and A C 13 féete; is 33 féete, the difference 7 féete.

As BC / 21 Feet the greatest side is to BD / 3 • Feet the whole of the other two sides, so is BE / 7 Feet the difference of the other two fids to BF / 11 Feet, the which segment being taken from B C 21 féete, there remaines F C, 10 féete, whose one halfe F G, or G C is 5 feete; therefore G C is 5 féete, and G B 16 féete.

p.hi: A Manuduction or the vse of the former Axiomes.

div.p:
IN all tryangles there be 3 sides and thrée angles, of which any thrée being giuen, the other thrée are found, & that after diuers waies as you may gather in the precedent: Axiomes,
onely excepting that you haue not onely thrée angles, and no side, for no side being giuen, no side is found; for because the thrée angles of one tryangle may be equall vnto the thrée angles of another tryangle, although'all the sides be vnquall', as thrée angles in the tryangles A B C, and D A E, are equall, because their bases B C and B E be equal, as in Chap. 1 P. 29, & yet the sides of the tryangle A B C are far greater then the sides of the tryangle D A E: and this axception is onely in Trigonometria; in all other take any of the thrée, and you may haue ye other thrée, howsoeuer the question be propounded, the differences whereof follow.
Aplaine triangle, is either a right angle or an obliquangle.

list.item: 1 In plaine right angled tryangles, either all the angles are giuen (to wit by the giuing of one of the acute angles) with one side, and the other two sides be sought.
2 Or there is giuen two sides with one angle, to wit, the right angle, and the other two angles, and the third side is required.

div.p: Both the which are resolued in the first Axiome.

1 Either all the angles be giuen (which is as often as two be giuen, for the third is alwaies the complement vnto two right angles by the 30 P. Chap. 1) with one side, and there is sought the other two sides.
2 Or two sides is giuen with the angle opposite vnto one of the giuen sides, and there is required the angle opposite to the other of the giuen sides, together with the third sides.
3 Or there is giuen two sides with the angle comprehended by the same, and there is required the other two angles with the third side.
4 Or to conclude all the thrée sides be giuen, and th angles he all required.
The two first of these differences is resolued by the second Axioma.
In the third difference the two vnknowne angles are found by third Axioma, and afterwards the third side by the second Axioma.

In the fourth difference there is made a dislocation of the plaine obliquangle tryangle, into two right angles, letting a perpendicular fall from the greatest angle vpon the greatest side, by the fourth Axioma, and so by these right angled tryangles euery angle is found by the first Axioma.

¶ But the three former differences may be resolued by the first Axioma, if so that from any vnknowne angle vpon the fide opposite thereto, a perpendicular be let fall, happening within or without the tryangle, according as the case shall require, & thereby the obliquangled tryangle is conuerted into two tryangles; whether the perpendicular fall within or without the tryangles
1 As if there be giuen this proportion; as A B the sine of the angle A C B, is to B C, the sine of the angle B A C, so is A B the side to B C the side by the second Axioma.

p.hi: To the same effect you may say by the first Axioma:

div.p: 1 As A B the radius is to B D, the sine of the angle B A D, so is A B the side to B D E the side.
Secondly as B D the radius, is to B C the secant of the angle D B C (which is the complement of the angle B C D) so is B D the side to B C the side.
2 If this proportion be giuen, as A B the side is to C B the side, so is A B the sine of the angle A C B, to B C the sine of the angle B A C by the second Axioma.

p.hi: After the same manner may you say.

div.p: First, as B C the radius is to B D the sine of the angle B C D, so is B C the side to B D the side.

Secondly, as B D the side, is to A B the side: so is B D the radius to A B the secant of the angle A B D, whose complement is the angle B A D, which angle B A D added to the angle D B C, maketh the angle A B C:

3 Lastly, if there be such a proportion as this giuen: As the whole of the sides A B and A C, is to the difference of the same, so is the Tangent of the halfe of the angle A B C, and A C B to the Tangent of the difference, being more or lesse then the halfe, as by the third Axioma.

p.hi: To the same effect may you say by the first Axioma:

div.p: First, as A B the radius, is to B D the sine of the angle B A D, so A B the side to D B the side.
Secondly, as A B the radius is to A D the sine of the angle, A B D, so is A B, the side to A D the side; which being taken from the side A C, the side D C remaineth.

Thirdly, as D C the side, is to the side B D: so is D C, the radius to B D the Tangent of
the angle D C B, which added to the angle B A C, and the whole taken from two right angles, there remaines the angle A B C.
And if furthermore you would know the side B C, by the 1. Axiom. say, as the radius D C is to the secant of the angle D C B, so is the side D C, to the side B C.

¶ Thus farre of the dimension of tryangles by sines, tangents, and secants, which I haue for the most part drawne from the doctrine of Bartholo. Pitiscus Grunbergens. a forraine moderne writer, hoping you will take pleasure in the application thereof to the singular vse of the Geodeticall staffe.

p.hi: By this Sinicall doctrine may you find the sides, diagonals and perpendiculars in any figure, and so thereby measure fields, woods, countries, &c. as in the sixt booke.

div.trailer: The end of the first part of Trigonometria.

div.head: TRIGONOMETRIA THE SECOND PART.
Containing Altimetria and Longimetria, by Sines, Tangents and Secants.

p.hi: Problema 1. The distance of any Turret, &c. being giuen, to finde the altitude.

div.p:
LEt the Turret be B G, and let the giuen distance be A C, or E G 200 féete, and you desire to know the altitude of the battlement of the sayd Turret B, aboue the eye of the obseruer A, or C: You shall therefore by your staffe, as in the second booke, Chapter 4, or by your Topographicall Glasse, or some such Instrument, obserue the
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
angle of altitude C A B 29 degrées, 40 min. and thereby get the angle A B C 60 deg. 20 min. by the second booke Chap. 15. Then say.

As AC / 86892 the sine of the angle A B C 60/200 deg 20 m. feete is to B C / 4949 •
the sine of the angle B A C 29 deg. 40 min, so is A C / 200 feete to B C 113 80204/86892, which is well néere 114 féete.
Or As A C / 199000 the radius, is to B C / 56 • 62 the tangent of ye angle B A C 29 degrées, 40 min. so is A C / 200 feete to B C 113 922/2000 feete: that is néere 114 féete.
Or to conclude. As A C / 175556 the tangent of A B C 60 degrées, 20 min. is to B C / 109000 the radius, so is A C / 209 feete to B C 113 162172/175556 feete.
All these be referred vnto the first Axioma:

Multiply the tangent B C 56961 by 200 feete, the distance of A C, and the product is 113 (92200, which part by the totall sine 100000 (as in the end of this treatise you be easily taught to do) so haue you 113 9 • 2/1000 féete, the height of B C.

p.hi: Probleme 2; The distance of any towre being giuen, to find the hypotenusall.

div.p: A Castle is appointed, the distance of the same assigned, and you be required to deliuer the length of a scaling ladder answering to the same distance.
The giuen distance is A C 200 féete, and the hipotenusall or scaling ladder A B is required.
Obserue therefore as before the angle C A B, &c. then say,
As A B C / 86892 60 deg. 20 m. is to A C / 200 feete the distance, so is A C B / 1 •• 000 90 degrées to A B the hipotenusall 230 14340/86892 féete.

The figure of the first probleme serueth here. As A C / 100000 the radius, is to A B / 11508 •
the secant of the angle B A C, 29 deg. 40 min. so is A C / 200 feete the distance to A B the hipotenusall 230 17/100 feete.
Multiply A B, 115085 the secant, by A C, 200 feete the distance, and the product is 23017000, which part by 200 féete, so haue you 230 17000/100000 feete, or 230 17/100 feete; the hypotenusall A B.

p.hi: Probleme 3. Any part of the distance of a tower being giuen, to find the rest.

div.p: Let a part of the distance A C be giuen, as A D, or E F 90 feete, and let the rest of the distance be required, to which you cannot come to meate by reason of waters, ditches, &c. therefore at the first station A, obserue the angle B A C 29 degrées, 40 min. and at the second station F, the angle B D C, and so by substraction from 90 by the 30 Prop. Chap. 1. you haue the angle A B C, 60 deg. 20 min. and the angle D B C 44 degrées.
First then substract the tangent of the angle D B C 96568, from the tangent of the angle A B C 175556, and there rests 78988 the line A D, then say

As A D / 789 ••
the difference of the Tangents is to D C / 96568 the lesser tangent, so is A D / 90 feete the difference of the stations to D C / • 2 •• feete the distance of the néere station, viz. of D from C.

Multiply D C 96568 the lesser tangent, by A D 90 feete, the difference of the stations, so haue you 8691120, which denide by A D, 78988 the difference of the stations, and the offcome is 100 féete your desire.

p.hi: Probleme IIII. Any parte of a distance being giuen, to find out the altitude.

div.p: As AD / 78988 the difference of the Tangents is to BC / 100000 the radius, so is AD / 90 feete the difference of the stations to BC / 114 feete ferè the altitude.
Multiply the totall sine 100000 by the difference of the stations 90 féete, so haue you 9000000, which parte by difference of the Tangents, and you haue 114 féete the altitude.

p.hi: Any parte of a distance being giuen, to find the hypothenufall.

div.p: The figure of the first probleme serueth here. As AD / 28122 the sine of the angle A B D 16 deg. 20 min. is to A B the sine of the angle A D B 134 deg./71933, so is AD / 90 feete. to A B, 230 491/28122 féete.

As A B D / 28122 the sine of 16 degrées, 20 min. is to A D / 90 feete, part of the distance, so is
• D B / 71933 the sine of 134 degrées, to 234 401/28122 feete the hinothenufall.

p.hi: Or if you seeke the Hypothenufall D B; say

div.p: As A D / 28122 is to B D 29 deg. 40 m./49495 so is A D / 90 feet to D B 154 11274/28122 feete.

As A B D / 28122 is to A D / 90 feete, so is
• A D 29 deg 40 m./49495 to D B 158 11274/28122 feete.

p.hi: Probleme 6. To seeke any kind of distance at one station.

div.p:
LEt the distance be proposed and your station assigned, from which you may not depart, where plant your hollow
staffe, as you sée cause, which done, you are to consider thrée things.

list.item: 1 If the marke whose distance is required, lye leuell with your foote or no.
2 If not leuell, whether aboue the leuell.
3 Or below the leuell of your foote.

div.p: 1 If the distance desired lys leuell with your foote, as F E, you shall first obserue the angle F A E 75 deg. 58 min. Now for the more ease, it is best that your staffe A E stand perpendicular, so shall A E F be a right angle; the angle A being had, you may conclude.
As A E / 100000 the total sine, is to F A E 75 deg. 58 m./400086, the tangent, so is A E / 4 feete the length of my staffe to E F / 16 feete the distance.
Multiply the secant 400086 by 4, so haue you 16 (00344, which deuide by the totall sine 100000, the quotient yéeldeth your desire: 16 344/109000 feete, the distance of F E.
2 If the distance required lye aboue the leuell of the lower end of your staffe, worke thus.
Q H is your staffe, & B a distance required, which lieth higher then H my feete.

Therefore I séeke the angle B Q H 101 deg. then I go to H the foote of my staffe, and there obserue the angle B H Q 67 degr. by adding these two angles together, and taking the totall from 180, I haue the angle Q B H 12 deg. then I conclude by the 2 Axioma, Confect. 1.
As Q B H 12 deg./20791 the right sine is to Q H • 67 deg./92939 the fine of the sayd angle, so is Q H / 4 feete the length of my staffe to Q B 17 1579/20791 feete, the distance.

By the same Axiome may you find the line H B: for As H B Q 12 deg./20791 is to ye sine of the angle H Q B 102 deg./98162 (or the sine
of 79 degrées, the complement of 101 deg) so is Q H / 4 feete the length of the staffe to H B 18 18410/20791 féete.
As 20791 is to, 4, so is 98162 to the distance H B, your desire.
Multiply 98162 by 4, the product whereof is 392648, which parte by 20791, and the quotient is 18 18410/20791 féete.
Thus of any such like question, the second Axioma will direct you plainely.

Thirdly, before you were placed vpon the top of some cliff or rocke, where you could not stirre to méete an ordinary stationary line, and yet were required to expresse the distance of the toppe of a Turret lying farre aboue your féete.

Now here also are you placed vpon the like rocke where you haue no liberty to stirre any way from the place you be in, neither to séeke the déepenesse of the said rocke with a plumbs line to make a stationary line of, (as in such cases the order is) nor to goe any way at all, and yet are required to deliuer the true distance of the base of a Turret that lyeth farre below the leuel of your féete, which to doe.

Erect your staffe and obserue the angle H Q C, and there the angle Q H C, which adding together as before, get the angle H C Q, hauing the angles séeke their sines, and so worke as before, according to the foresaid second Axiome, cons. 1.

And here obserue the singularity of this probleme, wherby you are taught to séeke the distance of any thing, within sight at one station howsoeuer situate, as from the toppe of a castle or rocke or such like to descry the distance of ships vpon ye seas, of armies of men or such like, and contrary being in a low valey, to discouer the distance of forts, camps, bulwarkes or any other obiect situate vpon the toppe of any high hill, and that directly, spéedily and readily at one station, with most approued truth after the same order may you stand in the midst of any medow, and spéedily plat the same &c.

p.hi: Probleme VII. To seeke the distance betwixt any two townes, any two ships vpon the seas, or any other inaccessible obiects whatsoeuer.

div.p: THis probleme is performed after this manner, first get the distance of each towne from you by the 6 probleme, and then obserue the angle at your station, so haue you an angle, & his two containing sides, then may you find the third side, & the other two angles diuers waies by my doctrine of tryangles.

And so referring all other kind of Altitude, Longitude, Latitude or profundities to the discréete carriage of the reader, since they be but relatiues to what is said before. Indéed we might inuent and draw diuerse kinds, according to the situation of the obiect, & so increase the booke, & confound the memory, but the whole ground of all that can be deuised or inuented is already set downe, and therefore I presume that no right lined tryangle howsoeuer situate, shall happen, whose sides you shall be ignorant of, if you doe but well obserue my doctrine in Trygonometria.

¶ And here let it be noted that when the totall sine is the first number in proportion, you may audide deuision, and if it be not, you may so order the proposition, that it shall be in all right angled tryangles, as in the first Axiome; for if the radius be not in the first place, then either the right sine, the Tangent,
or the secant is, all which the first Axioma resolueth, so that you may make which side you please the radius; therefore when I say, but compendiously, as in the end of the first probleme, hauing multiplied the second number by the last, as 56961 in 200, the product is 113, (92200: and where you should deuide this number by the totall sine, you néede but cut off so many figures from the product vpon your right hand, as there be cyphers in the totall sine as you sée before, so is the thrée figures vpon your left hand the quotient, and the fiue figures vpon your right hand the remainder; and so must you deale in al such kind of works where the total sine is deuisor.

Example
The numbers to be multiplied.
56961
200
The product after multiplication 113 (92200
The totall sine 100000
The quotient 113
The remainder. 92200
And here note further, when I say, as such a number is to such a one, &c. so is such a one to such a one &c. you must worke by the rule of thrée, to find out the numbers required.

As A D / 2 is to A C / 3 so is
• D / 4 to D F / 6, therefore

Multiply A C, the second number in proportion by C D, the third number, to wit thrée in foure, so haue you twelue, which parte by A B 2, the first number in proportion; so is the quotient D F; or the fourth in proportion viz, 6 the remainder: and thus of any other, and this in briefe is the golden rule or rule of thrée.

p.hi: The description and vse of the Canon or Table for the dimension of tryangles, by sines, Tangents, and secants, according as I haue newly calculated the same.

div.p:
TO audid tediousnesse in fractions, as also for that few fractions are precisely true, Authors haue deuised to deuide the semidiameter of a circle into a certaine number of equal parts, wherby they expresse ye true quantity of any arch; & the more partes the semediameter is deuided into, the truer
is your worke. Regiomtonanus vsed 6,000,000, equall parts, and Radium particularum 60,000,000,000. Rheticus made the semidiameter to containe 10,000,000,000, and Radium particularum, 1,000,000,000,000,000, but with vs 100,000, equall partes shall suffice, according vnto which there be tables of sines calculated by Wittikineus for dials, but not after this method.
2 In this doctrine crooked or circular lines be reduced to right lines.
3 Curued lines are reduced vnto right lines by the definition of quantity, which they haue, being applied to a circle in respect of the radius.
4 Any right lines being applied to a circle is called a subtention, which may be Sines, Tangents, or Secants.
5 A subtention is a right line inscribed in a circle deuiding the whole circle into two segments, and in like manner subtending both those segments.
9 A subtention is great or not great.
7 The great subtention is a line, which deuides the whole circle into two equal parts, and therefore doth subtend both the semicircles, as the right line G C, which is also the diameter.

8 A subtention not great, is, which deuides the circle into two vnequall segments, subtending them both, as the right lines I B doth, both subtend the lesser arke in the semicircle I F B, and also the greater arke in the semicircle, as I H B.
9 A sine is right or versed.

10 A right sine is the halfe subtention of a double arke, as the right sine of the arke B C, or B G is the line D E, the halfe subtention of the double arke B C D or B G D, which the line B E D doth subtend.
1 Therefore the right sine of the arke in the lesser or greater quadrant euen to the semicircle be all on.
As the right sine of the arke B C and B G, be all one to the right line B E, because it is the halfe of the right line B E D, which doth as wel subtend the arke B G D, as the arke B C D
2 So that when we say the complement of the right sine, there is onely meant the complement of the right sine in the lesser quadrant.
As the complement of the right sine B C, to wit B F is the right line B K.
Thirdly, euery right sine falleth perpendicular vpon the diameter from the terme of the giuen arke, as B E.

Fourthly, the right sine of the complement is equal ye to radius or segment of the diameter intercepted betwixt the right sine of the arke and the center, as the right sine of the complement B F viz. B K is equall to E A.
11 Sinus versus a versed sine is the segment of the diameter intercepted betwixt the right sine and the circumference.
As the versed sine of the arke B C is the segment of the diameter E C, and sinus versus of the arke B G, is the segment of the diameter G F,
12 Therefore of versed fines some be great, others lesse.
13 Sinus versus maior is the versed sine of the arke in ye greater quadrant as G E, is the versed sine of the arke G F B in the greater quadrant.
14 Sinus versus minor, is the versed sine of the arke in the lesser quadrant, as E C of the arke B C.
15 A Tangent is a right line méeting with the secant of the one terme of an arke falling perpendicular vpon the diameter, by the other terme of the arke.

Or a Tangent is a right line standing perpendicular vpon the extreme of a diameter at the one terme of a giuen arke, and produced infinitely, vntill it intersect with the secant of the said arke, as L C is the Tangent of the arke B C.
16 A secant is a right line produced from the center by the terme of a giuen arke vntil it touch the Tangent, as A L is the secant of the arke B C:
17 A Tangent is so called, for that it toucheth the circumference. A secant is so called for that it cuts the same circumference.
18 Cordus a chord is a circle cutting the totall sine at right angles extended from the one terme of an arch vnto the other, as B D is the chord of the arch B C D.
19 Euery cord is a double sine.
20 the greatest chord that may be in any circles is the diameter, and the greatest sine the semidiameter.

21 The Tables of Sines, Tangents, and secants extend not beyond 90 degrées, for the right sines of the greater and lesser quadrant be all one by the 10 def. as for Tangents and secants they neuer excéed the quadrant of a circle by the 15 and 16 def.

list.item: 1 To come vnto the tables themselues, first know, that vpon the sides of euery page there be placed foure tables: it would be but vaine to make ample relation, since that the superscriptions be plaine, onely the difficultnesse is in the degrées and minutes.

2 Therfore you must note, that we in this calculation, haue two kind of quadrants, and thereby two kind of arkes, as the arke of the lesser quadrant, which cannot excéed 90 degrées, and the arke in the greater quadrant which may be 180 degrées.

3 The degrées of any arke in the lesser quadrant to 45, are placed vpon the right hand in the toppe of euery fable in great figures, so that euery table hath one of these deg. the min. answering to these deg. as in the first colum or row, vnder these deg. procéeding by 5, as 0. 5. 10. 15. &c.

4 The minutes are set by 5, because vpon our instruments (notwithstanding my exact deuiding of the circle by helpe of I sosceles tryangles) we cannot put a sensible difference in lesse diuisions, and therefore we were content to draw our tables according vnto a deg. deuided into 12 equall parts, euery parte containing 5 min. for it is vaine to deliuer quantities more precise in figures then we can, finding it by obseruation, for what would the sine or secant of thrée min. auaile, vs when instrumentally we can hardly obserue 5 minuts: therefore be
our tables be drawne to answere to our instrumentall obsernations.

5 If the arke of the lesser quadrant excéed 45 degrées, you shall find the same in the table vpon the right side the page, at the lower end of the said table, the minutes answering wherevnto, doe ascend in the last columne vpon the right hand.
6 So that if the giuen arke be vnder 45, find the deg. and min. in the table vpon the left hand, if aboue 45, in the table vpon the right hand.

7 The complement of any arke in the lesser quadrant, stands directly against the ark giuen, but not in the same table; as the arke giuen is 3 deg. 45 min. those deg. and min. are found in the table vpon the left hand, answering to which in the table vpon the right hand, in the last row, is 86 degrées, 15 minutes, the complement of 3 deg. 45 min. or if 86 & 85 min. had bene the giuen arke, 3 deg. and 45 min. in the other table was the complement to the same.

8 Briefly, this table extends but to the halfe arke of the lesser quadrant, yet doth serue to the whole arke in the greater or lesser quadrant, as in the 10 def. consect.
• . so that you may find any arke or angle giuen, together with the sines, Tangents and secants answering therunto; also the complements of the arkes or of the sines &c. or the sine, Tangent or secant being giuen, you may find the arke answering thereunto.

div.p:
The giuen arke is 3 degrées 35 minutes,
Sine 6250
Tangent. 6262
Secant 100195

The complement of the arke 86 deg. 25 min. whose.
Sine 99804
Tangent (is) 1596867
Secant 1599995

list.item: 9 If the sine &c. be giuen, and the arke required, séeke in the body of the tables for the sine, and then remembring the precedent rules, the arke answereth thereunto.

10 Touching arkes in the greater quadrant, they and the complements thereof stand in the tables vpon the right hand with the minutes answering: they begin at 90 deg. in the first row at the toppe of the right tables, and so procéed to 135, and then goe forward in the foote of the table, being the lowermost of the two numbers placed there; but if you séeke the complement of those numbers in the other table on the left hand, in
the foote of the tables, they be in the table on the left hand, as if you séeke the complement of 176 deg. 25 min. the degrées of complement is in the table vpon the left hand, and in the row vnder it is the minute also, as 3 deg. 35 min. which makes 176 deg. 25 min. iust 180 deg.
11 There is no Tangent or Secant in the greater quadrant by the 15 and 16 Def.

12 So that if you séeke the complement of any arke in the greater quadrant, if the degrées and minutes stand in the first row in the right table vpon the left hand, then the complement thereof is the vppermost of the numbers in the foote of the sayd table vpon the right margent, and the minutes stand in the vttermost columbe rightwards ascending.
13 But if you séeke the complement of any of the numbers that stand lowermost in the foote of the right table, then must the degrées of complement be sought in the left table.
14 Subtract the arch giuen from 90, the remainder is Sinus Complementi of the lesser quadrant.

15 Substract Sinus Complementi of the arch giuen from the totall sine, the remainder is Sinus versus, as Sinus Complementi is 35027, which take from 100000, and there remaines 64973. Sinus versus is in stead of the right sine of any arke of the greater quadrant, the complement thereof is vsed: therefore the arke it selfe doth serue in these tables, because the true arke stands against the complement, as well in the great quadrant as in the lesser, as is sayd.
16 Deduct the arke giuen from 280, the remainder is Sinus Complementi of the greater quadrant.

table.head: A Canon or Table for the dimension of Triangles compendiously calculated. 1609.
Belonging to the 7 booke of the Geodedical staffe called Trigonometria.

div.p: I might here take occasion to teach you to worke matters Astronomicall, but it was not my intent so to do in this volume, such that desire the same, may finde some satisfaction therein, wrote by Master Blundeuil, & who so desireth it more ample, most also in such matters haue more ample tables, for these tables be onely drawne to be applied to instrumentall obseruation as I haue said before, wherein we may find the iust minute, as precisely as can be obserued instrumentally, and what needeth more?

div.head: THE EIGHTH BOOKE Of the Geodeticall Staffe:

Whereby is performed most conclusions that may be wrought by the Globe or any Astrolabe, with the art of Horomancie, wherein you be taught to make Horizontall, Vertical, and East and West Dials, with diuerse others only by the Staffe, without any kind of Arithmeticke; to draw a Map of the world, according to the Longitude and Latitude of the places; to find how one place doth beare from another, by the poynts of the Mariners Compasse and such like: in all which you shall craue but the onely helpe of your staffe.
CHAP. I.
Principall notes and definitions for the better vnderstanding of this booke.
div.p: FIRST, this kind of worke consisteth in proiecting ye celestial circles into parallell and Ellipsicall lines.
2 According vnto perspectiue demonstrations, there can but the halfe of any spheare be layd downe in plano.
3 Def. All parallel lines be circles of latitude, declination, and circles of altitude and depression.
4 Def. Lines Ellipsicall be meridians, Azimuths and circles of longitude.
5 Def. All circles of latitude be parallell to the Eclipticke in all Astronomicall operations, and are measured by Chords vpon the lymbe.
6 Def. All circles of declination lye parallell vnto the Equinoctiall, and are expressed by chords.
7 Def. Circles of altitude and depression lye parallell to the horizon, and are expressed as other parallels be.
8 Def. Circles of declination be counted vpon the limbe from the equinoctiall towards the poles.
9 Def. Circles of latitude are counted from the Zodiacke vpon the limbe.
10 Def. Circles of altitude and depression are counted from the Horizon on the limbe.
11 Def. Take it generall that all parallell lines are counted on the limbe from that great circle they lye parallell vnto towards the pole thereof.
Lines Ellipsicall.
12 Def. You must first vnderstand that all kind of ellipticall lines by a certaine reducement are measured by chords vpon the limbe, like to parallels.

13 Def. Ameridian is a great circle passing by the poles of the world, and cutting the equinoctial at right angles expressed by chords, and reduced to the limbe by lines paralell to the 6 of clocke meridian.

14 Def. All Azimuths be great circles passing by the verticall point, and crossing the horizon at right angles, expressed by chords on the limbe, and transferred thereunto by lines parallell to the east and west Azimuth.

15 All circles of longitude be great circles passing by the poles of the Zodiack, cutting the eclipticke at right angles, measured vpon the limbe and transferred thereunts by lines parallell vnto the axtrée of the eclipticke.
16 Def. All great circles be meridians, circles of longitude, verticall circles, Coluers, the equinoctiall, ecliptake, &c.
17 Def. All lesse circles be parallels.
18 Def. Generally all great circles crosse one the other vpon the center, and all other lesse circles neuer crosse ouer the center.
19 The center in this proiectment doth represent the equinoctiall points of ♈ &c ♎, the circumference, the meridian, or 12 of clocke line, but in some conclusions, the Solstitiall Colure.

20 Def. All times are reckoned from 12 of the clocke at noone, to 12 at night, and are measured in the parallell of the sunne (and so do Astronomers count it in their. Ephemerides) and counted from the axes of the Equinoctiall.
21 Def. One degrée of the Equinoctiall containes foure minutes of time, and 15 degrées one houre, for which purpose behold the insuing table.

table.head: A Table of reduction of the parts of time, into the parts of the Equinoctiall arke.

row.cell: the arke of the ecquino, circle.

table.head: A Table of reduction of the parts of the Equator circle into parts of the like time.

row.cell: the arke of the equator circle.

div.head: CHAP. II.
To expresse any chord in the limbe of a circle, and to protract any angle.
div.p: THis Chapter, and the other fire ensuing, well vnderstood, the rest of the booke is but easy.

To measure any thing in a circumference is no other thing but either hauing a chord giuē to expresse the quantity therof, or hauing an angle giuen to protract the like: for which purpose the 2 Chapter of the 6 booke shall very fully instruct you in all points, therefore I will referre you thereunto for breuities sake.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Any parte of a diameter being giuen or required, to expresse the same in degrees.
div.p: TO measure a diameter, is either for to expresse the parts giuen, or to giue the part expressed.
Any diameter in this worke is a great circle, by the 17 def. because he crosseth the center; then to expresse the part giuen, worke thus.

Let A B C D E be an hemisphere, and let the proposition be to expresse A F part of the diameter B D, by the 2 def. this must be transserred to the circumference, thus: draw a line G H, to passe by the pointe F parallel to C E, then by the first Chap. measure G C or H E, so haue you your desire.
2 To giue the part expressed is, when there is any number of degrées expressed, to find the pointe whereon they fall, performed thus.
I haue a number of degrées giuen as 30, and am required to shew in what part of the diameter A D, they end.

By the first Chapter, I protract a chord G C of 30 degrées, from whence I draw a line G H parallel to C D, & where that point cuts the diameter A B as at F, there is your desire; I conclude that A F containes 30 degrées

And you must note that this worke is generall for the transserring of al kind of ellipsical lines, be they Meridians, circles of longitude &c. remembring that the parallel line G H, must alwaies in Meridians be drawn parallel to the axtrée line, as in the 13 Def. in azimuths to the east and west azimuth, as in the 14 def. and so of circles of Longitude, as in the 15 Def.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
Any part of a parallel being giuen or required, to expresse the same.
div.p: TO measure a parallel, is either to find what Ellipsscall line passeth by some point in any parallel, or some ellipsicall line being giuen, to find where he should cut the parallel: and to do either, you must first make the parallel the diameter of a circle, whereupon describe a semicircle, then worke thus.

First, let the parallel be G L, and let the prop. be to find what Ellipsicall line passeth by the pointe M, make G L the diameter of a circle, then on the point N describe the semicircle, G I L, next from that point M draw a parallel to F A as I M, then the portion of the circumference I O, is your desire, 30 degrées, by the 1 Chapter, and so of the parallel H P or any other.

2 But if you haue the number of the ellipsical line giuen,
and be required to find what pointe of the parallel he should passe by, worke thus.
Let the parallel be H P, and let the proposition be to find where the 30 Ellipsicall line shall passe by?

Make H P the diameter of a circle, and then vpon O the center describe H F P the demicircle, then by the first Chap. protract a chord F K 30 degrées, whence draw a line parallel to F A as K R, which shall cut the parallel H P in R: I conclude that R is the point where as ye 30 ellipsicall line should passe by, and so of G L, or any other parallel.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Any point being giuen in the hemisphere, to find what Ellipsicall line passeth by the same:
div.p: THe premisses well vnderstood, this Chapter is easy. The point being assigned, you shal consider whether your question be to know what Meridian, what circle of longitude or Azimuth passeth there by, and then calling to minde the end of the third Chapter, worke thus.

Let the point taken in the hemispere A B C D E be R, The figure in the 4 Chapter serueth here. and let the question be to find what Meridian passeth thereby, B D is the Equinoctiall, E C the axtrée, draw therefore by the point R a line parallel to B D; then by the 4 Chapter, first difference, find what Ellipsicall line passeth by R, which you shall find 30. I conclude, the 30 Meridian doth passe by the point P, and so of any other.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
To draw a paralell by any number of degrees assigned, or a parallel being drawne, to find what number of degrees he containes.
div.p: VVHat parallel circles be, is shewed in the first Chap. which considered, worke thus.
1 Let the proposition be to draw a parallel of declination 23 degrées, 28 minutes distant North from the Equinoctiall, which let be the Tropick of Cancer.

Let A B C D E be the hemispers, B D the Equinoctiall, F C the axtrée, then by the first Chapter I protract a chorde B G, and L D 23 degrées, 28 minutes, from the equinoctiall: I then conclude that G L is the parallel representing the Tropick of Cancer, and so of any other.
2 But if a parallel be drawne, and you would find what number of degrées it containes, doe thus.
Let the parallell be H P, then by the first Chapter, find the chord B H 50 degrées, your demand by the 10 def.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
To lay downe a right oblique spheare.
div.p: AN oblique spheare is such an one, whose North or South pole is eleuated any thing at all aboue the Horizon, and is thus laide downe.

Let A B C D E be the hemispheare, then draw the diameter B D which call the Equinoctiall, then crosse B D with a right line vpon the center A at right angles as C E, which call the axtrée of the world, C the North pole, E the South; then draw a parallel to B D the Equinoctiall 23 degrées, 28 toward the North pole A, by the last Chap. which let be F K, call that the Tropick of Cancer; doe so vpon the other side the Equinoctiall as L M, call that the Tropick of Capricorne; next draw N
O, 23 degrées, 28 minutes, from C, and parallel to B D, which call the circle articke, doe so to B Q, so haue you the circle antactick: then the line L K is the Zodratke, so now haue you a right spheare; but of right spheares I note two kindes, that is a polar and an Equinoctiall, if you will make this an Equinoctiall, make C E the Horizon, and B D the Equinoctiall passing by the zenith; but if you will make it a polar, then make B D the Equinoctial the Horizon, and so you haue either of the right spheares, but to make the oblique spheare, consider if the North or South pole be eleuated, and how much, let C the North pole be eleuated 52 degrées and minutes, therefore by the first Chap. protract the chord R C 52 degrées min. whence draw aline by the center A, to the circumference, so haue you the line R S the Horizon C, being eleuated 52 degrée min & this rule is generall: well then the poles of the Horizon viz. the Zenith and Nadit be T W; and the poles of the Ecliptick L K be N Q, for the poles of the Ecliptick be alwaies found in the circles, Articke and Antartick; well then the Meridian or 12 of clocke line is the Peripher.
Now shall follow some counclustion Astrononicall, which will be very easy if you vnderstand what is said before, for all the worke doth consist thereupon.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
To take the altitude of the Sunne.
div.p: I haue taught you how to performe this prope already in my second booke, howbeit I shall not bring it out of season here to deliuer an other way no lesse easy, and fa •• e betted for seamen: cause therefore the left legge to hang perpendicular, the center vpwards (which you may dos diners wires, as by hanging a plumbe at the lower end) turne the • nds of the legges fromwards the Sun, beauing vp or putting down ye right leg vntil the Sunne beames that pearceth through the slitte in the center-sight agrée with the fidutiall edge of the right leg; note then the quantity of that angle by the second booke Chapter 5, for that is the distance of the Sunne from the Zenith, therefore take that from 90 and the remainder is your desire.

The 20 day of September 1607, making obseruation at London as before, I found the angle vpon the leggs to containe 64 42/60 degrées, which argued that the Sun was then 64 deg. 40 min. distant from our Zenith; take that therefore from 90, so haue you 25 11/62 deg. the true altitude of the Sunne at London vpon the to day of September, at 10 of the clocke before noone.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
To find the Sunnes declination for euery day in the yeare, and the declination of any parte of the Eclipticke.
div.p: AS the latitudes in the heauen be counted from the Ecliptick, so the declinations be numbred from the equator, therefore the declination is the arke of a great circle intercepted betwixt the Equator and the place of Eclinticke or star, thus had.

By the 10, find the place of the Sunne in the Eclinticke, by which point draw a line parallel to the Equinoctiall, then the thord on the peripher betwixt that panalel & the Equinoctial is your desire.
