B C D E is the hemispheare, B D the Equinoctial, F K the Ecliptick 〈◊〉 the place of the Sun, viz. in the 20 degrée of ♉ draw therefore by the point 〈◊〉 a line Y V, parallel to B D, the Equinoctiall; I conclude the arke V D, is the declination of the 20 degrée of which by the 2, is 17 degrées 45 min. 40 sec.

div.head: CHAP. X.
To find any place of the Sunne in the Ecliptick, or any point proposed.
div.p: TO find the place of the Sun in the Eclipticke, worke thus. Let A B C D E be the hemispheare, F K the Tropick of ♋, K L the Ecliptick, and let the prop. be to find where the 20 degrée of ♉ falleth.

In this worke you be to consider, how many degrées the Sunne is distant from the néerest Equinoctial point of ♈ or ♎ which can neuer excéed 90 degrées, and thereby whether the question be for North or South sines, as héere it falleth out:
for by the 20 degrée if ♉ a North signe, whose distance from the beginning of ♈ is 50 degrées, draw therefore by the 6 Chap,The figure in the third Chapter serueth here. a line parallel to N Q the artrées of the Eclpticke 50 degrées distant, as O M, which shall intersect the North part of the Eclipticke A K at X the very place of the 20 degrée of ♉, and so of any other North signe, pointe or starre.
But for South signes, you must worke vpon the other side the axtrée of the Ecliptick N Q, and then the worke is all one with the former.

Let the question be to find the first min. of Scorpio, of the two Equinoctiall points M is nearest to ♎, being 30 degrées, distant, therefore by the prescript, I draw R Z parallel to N Q the axtrée of the Eclipticke, 30 degrées distant, whose intersection with A L, the South moety of the Zodiack is the beginning of M, as is plaine in the figure.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
To find the altitude of the pole for any country whatsoeuer.
div.p: THe altitude or eleuation of the pole is a portion of a Maridian included betwixt the Horizon, & the pole eleuated, had thus.

Lay downe a right spheare as if his poles were in the Zenith by the 7, then by the 6. draw a parallel according to the Sunnes declination, Next hauing the Meridian altitude of the Sunne draw a line by the 6, distant from the parallel of the Sunne, according to the Meridians altitude, by the end of which numbers draw a line crossing the center, whose distance on the peripher from the pole, is your desire.

Let the hemispheare be A B C D E, then I draw a parallel according to the declination of the Sunne, the 10 of Aprill, 11 40/60 degrées, then I count the Meridian Altitude of the Sunne 50 degrées, from F towards E, as to H; then did I draw a line
from H to A, and so to I: I conclude the thord B I is the elenation 51 40/50 by the 2 Chap.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
To know what howre of the day it is, the Sunne shinng in any Region.
div.p: To know what of the clocke it is, is to find how many 15 degrées the Sunne is distant on his parallel from the Meridian, and so many howers, is the time of the day lacking or past the common 12 of clocke, according as the question, fell before or after noone.

Lay therefore downe a spheare according to the eleuation of your pole, and draw a parallel by the 6 according vnto the declination of the Sunne then take the altitude of the Sun, and by the 7 and 10 def. of the first Chapter, draw an almicanter according to the altitude taken. Lastly, the Meridian by the 4 Chapter, passing by the intersection of the almicanter and parallel of declination, is your desire.

Upon the 10 of April I made obseruation as followeth;
First I laid downe the hemispheare A B C D Eas before, then I draw F G a parallel by the 6, according vnto the Suns declination 11 40/60 degrées, next by the 8, I obserued the altitude of the Sunne 40 12/60 degrées, and by the 6 according to the 7 and 10 def. Chap. 1, I draw an almicanter I K according to the Sunnes altitude taken, which intersects with F G the parallel of declination at L. Lastly I found by the 5. that the 30 Meridian passed by L, reckoned from F, then for that my obseruation was before noone, I may safely conclude that it was precisely 10 of the clocke, for that 30 degrées containes two houres, as is plaine in the table in the first chap. If my obsernation had bene after noone, it had bene iust two of the clocke, then the Azimuth cutin there, sheweth the coast: and if you know not whether your obseruation were before or after noone after your first taking the Sunnes altitude, anon after obserue it againe if then the altitude be greater then it was before, then were your obsernations before noone, if lesse, afternoone.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
To find the right asention of any portion of the Eclipticke, together with the dogrees of the Equinoctial, that doe ascend with cou • ry degree of the Eclipticke in a right spheare.
div.p: THe right ascention, is a point or arke of the Equator that doth ascend with any g • uen arke of the Ecliptick, or any point or starre in a right spheare, and found thus.
Lay downe a right spheare, so that the parts may be in the horizon, thense what Meridian passeth by that point to the Equinoctiall, so haue you your desire.

The figure in the third Chapter serueth here. Let A B C D E be ye h ••• spheare, B D ye Equinoctiall, L K ye Eclipticke, & let the proposition be for to find the right ascention of the ☉ degrée ♉, by the 10 Chapter find the place of the ☉ deg. of ♉ in the Ecliptick A L, which is marked with his character, and by that point in the Ecliptick, draw therefore a line paras • el to O E as O LL. I conclude the chord O C is your demand, viz. 27 54/60 deg. the right ascention of the ☉ degrée of Taurus, and this rule is generall for all degrées or points not about 90 deg. distant-from 〈◊〉 , which is three signes iust.

But you must note that ye point giuen, may either containe iust 90 degrées, which is three signes, or be more then 90, and yet lesse then 180, or more then 180, and yet lesse then 270 or more then 270, and •••• e then 360.
If the who • e iust 90 deg. containing 3 signes as the ☉ degrée of • dollar;, then is 90 the right ascention.

2 If the arke be more then 90 as the ☉ degrée of ☊ 120, and lesse then 180, then substract the arke giuen from 180 viz. 120 from 180, so haue you 60 remaining, then séeke the right ascention of the remainder (as of 60) as before: 60 containes 2 signes, therefore I séeke the right ascention of ☉ deg. ♎, which is 2 signes from ♈, which I find 57 49/6 •
deg, which take from 180, the remainder is the right ascention of the giuen arke, viz. • 7 degr. 48 min. 48 see, from 180, so haue you 122 21/60 degr. and bette • , you desire.

3. But if • he arke comprehended betwixt ♈ and the point giuen, be more then 180, and yet lesse then 270, that is, if the arke be more then 6 signes and lesse then 9, as the ☉ deg. of ♏ 210 degrées or 7 signes, subtract 180 degrees from that arke
the right ascension of the remainder taken from the beginning of ♎ and adde to 180, so haue you your desire; as for the purpose 180 taken from 210 leaueth 30, which c • ntaineth one signe, whose right ascention by the former is 27 deg. 54 min. 20 sec. which added to 180, maketh 207 deg. 54 min. 20 sec. the right ascention of the 0 deg. of ♏.

4. Lastly, if the arke giuen, comprehended betwi • t Aries and the point assigned be greater then 270 or 9 signes, as • he 0 deg. of •
300 deg. or 10 signes, then substrast that arke from 360, then the right ascention of the remainder taken from 360 leaueth your desire, as 300 taken from 360 leaueth 60, or two signes, whose right ascention 57 deg. 48 min 48 sec. taken from 360 leaueth 302 deg. 11 min. 12 sec. the right ascention of 0 deg. of Aquariust so that you sée by finding the right ascention of any arke vnder 90 deg. as you be taught to doe, you haue the right ascention of any other arke.

And I would haue you note, that opposite signes, and signes alike distant from the Equinoctiall point, doe ascend in a right spheare in equall time, as ♈ ♓ ♎ and ♍ so doth also ♉ ♌ ♏ ♒ and in like manner Gem. Can. Cap. Sagit.

And for as much as euery Meridian is a right Horizon to some one place or other, therefore the degrée of the Ecliptick coascending with any deg. of the Equinoctiall, in a right spheare must of necessity passe by the Meridian of any place together, and this is called the culminating of a starre, &c. or celimeditation, so that you may gather hereby that the culminating of any point in the heauens is all one in substance with his right ascention.

div.head: CHAP. XIIII.
Of the difference of ascentions.
div.p: THe difference of ascention is an arke of the Equator whereby the oblique ascention or descention of the Ecliptick doth differ from the right.

Now to find the difference of ascentions, haning laid down a spheare according vnto your Latitude, set in the Eclipticke line, the deg. whose ascentionall difference you séeks, by which point draw a line parallell to the Equinoctiall; then note the intersection of that parallel with the Horizon, for the Meridian passing by that point is your desire, being reckoned from
the axtrée line.

Let A B C D E be an hemispheare, let the proposition be to find the ascentionall difference of the 29 degrée of ♉, let M be the 26 of ♉, by which draw F G parallel to C D the Equinoctiall, let the Horizon be I H B, the pole eleuated 52 degrées 2 • /60 then I note the intersection of F G with I H, as at N. Lastly by the fourth I séeke what Meridian passeth by N reckoned from B E, which I find 13 46/60 Meridian and better. I then conclude that the ascentionall difference of the 26 degrée of ♉ in the 52 20/60 degrée of latitude, is 13 degrées, 16 min. 26 sec. so that Taurus, because he is a signe oblique ascending, I affirme that he riseth so much sooner in this oblique spheare, then in a right spheare, as 13 deg. &c. cometh vnto.
And note further that the ascentionall difference from one quarter goeth for all the rest in the same latitude.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Of the oblique ascensions
div.p: THe oblique ascentions, be an arke or point of the Equator, which doe coascend with any giuen arke of the Eclipticke or with any starre aboue the Horizon, and found thus. Consider if the signes be North or South, if South, adde to their right ascention the difference of ascention; if North, take the difference of ascension from the right ascension, and the totall of the one, or remainder of the other, is your desire.

The right ascension of the 4 deg. of ♊ is 62 degrées, by the 13 Chapter, the difference by the 14, is 29 47/60 deg. Gemini is a North signe, therefore I substract the difference viz 29 47/60 from 62, so haue you 32 13/60 deg. the oblique ascension.

Then for the South signe we will take the opposite deg. to the former as 4 of ♐, whose right ascension by the 13 is 242, to which I adde 29 47/60 deg. the difference of ascensions by the 14, so haue you the oblique ascension of the 4 deg. of Taurus, viz. 271 47/60 deg.
These propositions be most excellent in all Astronomicall operations.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Of descensions both right and oblique.
div.p: VNto the oblique ascension of the opposite degrée to the degrée proposed, adde 180, and so haue you your desire.

I would find the oblique descension of the 20 deg. of $, therefore I adde 180 vnto 323 deg. 9 min. 34 sec. the oblique ascension of the 20 deg. of Capt. so haue you 503 de. 9 mi. 34 sec. your desire, were it not that it doth excéed the whole circle 360, which for because it so falleth out, I must alwaies in such a case substract 360, as 360 deg. from 503 deg. 9 min. 34 sec. there remaineth 143 deg. 9 min 34 sec. your desire.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
The longitude and latitude of any starre proposed, to find his right and oblique ascention together with his declination from the Equinoctiall, and to place any starre in the hemispheare.
div.p: THis matter is easily performed by your staffe, vnderstanding but what is said before, but to the matter.

Here we shall haue occasion to vse the circles of longitude remembred in the first Chap. def. 15, and circles of latitude as in the 9 def. first therefore by some tables find the true longitude and latitude of the starre proposed, then in the hemispheare draw a line parallel to the Ecliptick by the 6 according vnto the latitude giuen: then by the 4 find where the circle of longitude 〈◊〉 the said parallel, for that is the stars place in the hemis ••• , the • worke according vnto the 12 def. & by the 4 Chapter, what Meridian passeth by that point, for that is the starres right ascention by the 13, and the parallel of declination cutting there also, is the declination by the 9, and according to the 6 and 8 def.

There is a faire starre of the first magnitude placed in the North, whose name is Capella, Hircus, or Alhaoith, in English the goate: I find the longitude of this star to extend it selfe into the 1637 deg. of Gemini, or to be distant from the vernall intersection of ♈ 76 37/69 deg. and that his latitude from the Eclipticke is 22 2/4 deg. into the North. I draw therefore as I am wont my hemispheare A B C D E, wherein F G is the Equinoctiall
M I the Ecliptick, H Q the artrée of the Eclipticke; thē 1 I draw a line F P, parallel to the Eclipticke M I, according to the latitude, v • z 22 deg. 30 min, then by the 4 I find where the 76 • 7/60 Elipticall line or circle of longitude •• tteth the said parallel, as at P, which point I affirme is the true place of the starre; then the distance of the parallel B F from F G, the Equinoctiall by the 6, is the declination viz. B F or P G, 45 • /60 deg. and the denomination is North.

Then the Meridian passing by that place of the starre is his right astention, which by the 4 is. 72 • 1/ ••
Meridian.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
The difference of ascensions or the oblique ascension of any point in the Ecliptick proposed, or of any starre, to find the latitude of the country.
div.p:
DRaw a parallel according to the declination of the point proposed, then by the 14 number the difference of ascensions proposed vpon the said parallel, fromwards the axtrée of the world, by which point in the parallel draw a line to
passe by the center touching the peripher, the chord then included betwixt the pole and the intersection of that line with the peripher is your desire.

Hauing laid downe a right spheare as A B C D E, making F G the Equinoctiall, L I the Tropick of Cancer, The figure in the 17 Chapter serueth here. let then the question be of the 0 deg, of $, whose difference of ascentions let be 34 13/60 deg, which I counte by the 4 def. on, L I the Tropick fromwards S towards L, which falleth at R. I conclude aline drawne from the circumference by R to A, and so to the peripher againe, is the Semihorizon, as B R A C, then E being the pole eleuated I affirme by the 2, that the chord B E limites the eleuation, viz. 52 20/60 deg.
But if the oblique ascension be proposed you must subtract that from the right ascension, and so get the difference of ascensions.
The oblique ascension of the 0 deg. of $ is proposed to be 55 47/60 deg. which take from the right ascension, which by the 13 is 90: so haue you 34 1 • /60 deg. then worke as before.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
Of the amplitude of the rising and setting of the Sunne or any starre or point in the heauens.
div.p: THe amplitude of rising is an arke of the Horizon intercepted betwixt the rising of the Equinoctial & the true rising of the Ellipticke, or the Sunne or any star or point in the heauens

For where as the Sunne and other starres, as most of them be without the Equator, and by their diuers sites doe obtaine diuers declination, and doe describe diuers parallels, by the first mouer, which do cut the Horizon in diuers places, then who doth not consider that there is also great variety of the amplitude of rising, which doth much vary in the starres and points of the Ecliptick, by reason of the diuerse inclination of the Equinoctiall to the Horizon, and the diuers places vpon the earth? but to the matter.

You shal therefore lay down an oblique sphere by the 7 according to ye eleuation, thē draw a parallel according to the declinatiō of the star or point whose amplitude you séeke; note thē ye
intersection of the parallel with the Horizon, for the Azimuth or distance of that point from the center is your desire.

The Sunne being in 0 deg of $ I doe desire his amplitude in the 52 20/60 latitude, first I lay downe a spheare according to my latitude, as A B C D E, F G being the Equinoctiall, O P the Tropical parallel, B the North pole, H I the Horison, and I the chord of eleuation: so then I note where O P the Tropick, and H I the Horizon intersect, as at Q. I conclude Q A is the amplitude then by the 3 Cha. and Chap. 1 def. 14. And for that the 40 40/60 Azimuth passeth by Q which is the true distance of Q from A, I conclude that the amplitude of ☉ being in the 0 deg of Cancer, was iust 40 40/60 deg.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
The amplitude of rising of any starre knowne, or of the Sunne with his place in the Zodiack: to find the Latitude of the country.
div.p: IMagine the amplitude of ☉ being in 0 deg of $ were giuen to be 40 40/60 deg.

Let A B C D, be the hemispheare, O P a parallell drawne, according vnto the declination of the 0 deg. of $ then doe I protract a chord from R towards B according vnto the amplitude as R B 40 40/60 deg,The figure last before serueth here. then from B I draw a line B Q parallel to R A, which shal entersect with O P the Tropick at G, I conclude a line drawne from A by Q to the circumference, as H A Q I, is the Horizon, so is B I the chord of eleuation, which by the 2 is 52 20/60 deg.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
To know the rising and setting of the Sunne, the length of the day and night, with the continuance of twilight.
div.p: THe day, after vulgar capacity, is taken two-fold, ciuill and naturall: the day ciuill is the space of time wherein one renolution of the equator with the adding of the motion of the Sunne, is full compleate, and is alwaies 24 howers.
The natural day is a space of time, wherein the Sun is caried from the East, by the midst of heanen to the West, and is altered in euery seuerall latitude.
Now the night is the space of time wherein the center of the Sunne is caried from the West by the Imum Coeli to the East, thus sound.

Hauing laide downe your hemispheare, as you be accustomed according vnto your eleuation, draw a parallel according vnto the declination of the Sunne for the day proposed, note then the intersection of that parallel with the Horizon, for the Meridian circle passing by is your desire, viz. the hower of Sunne rising, and the Azimuth passing by that point sheweth the coast.

I would know the rising of the Sunne, &c. in the 52 deg. 20 min. of latitude, the ☉ being in no degrée $, lay downe an oblique spheare B D C E, according to ye eleuation: let B C be the Horizon, E ye North pole, L I the Tropicke of $, the entersection of ye Tropick and the Horizon R: by the 4 I find ye the 39 Meridian counted from S passeth by R, R is the 6 of clocke Meridian, and 39 deg. by the first is 2 houres, 4 deg. therefore the Sunne rose 4 deg. before 4 in the morning, which is 16 mi. before 4: if you had sought a setting you must haue counted those deg. forwards from 6, so had the setting bin 8 deg. after 8
at night.

Then if you adde the howre of Sunne rising and setting together, they make alwaies 12, & if you double the howre of Sunne setting you haue the length of the day, that taken from 24 leaueth the length of the night, as double 8 and 4 min. so haue you 16, 8 min. the length of the day, which taken from 24, there remaineth 7 56/60 howers, the length of night.

By the 14, learne the difference of ascensions, which by the first reduce into time, which take from 6, if the Sunne haue declination toward the pole eleuated, or adde to 6, if the Sun haue declination from the pole eleuated, the remainder of the one, or totall of the other is your howre of ☉ rising.
Then the howre of Sunne rising taken from 12 sheweth the howre of Sun setting, which doubled, sheweth the length of the day as before.

Now for the continuance of twilight, draw a parallel 18 deg. vnder the Horizon, then the portion of the parallel of the Sun included betwixt that line of depression last drawne, and the Horizon is your desire, whereby you may gather that in summer we haue no ending of twilight, but all day; for that the circle of depression L T drawne 8 deg. vnder B C, the Horizon doth not reach L I the Tropick of Cancer, whereas otherwise when the Sunne is in the Equinoctiall F G we haue a great twilight, for that the portion of the Sunnes parallell A V is great, containing by the thrée aboue 30 deg. which is more then two houres; and so long is it then that twilight doth beginne before Suune rising called commonly the breake of day, and so long likewise doth it endure after Sunne set.

So that you sée in summer for a certaine space we haue all day, and in other times a kind of twilight, which is nothing else but dis • unction of day and might, or lightnes and darknes made by reason of ye refulgent beames of the, Sun which cannot quite be obscured vntill he be 18 degrées below the Horizon.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
To know the Semidurnall arch of the Sunne or starres with the length of day and night, &c.
div.p:
LEt the question be to know the semidurnal arch of the 25 deg. of ♈, in the 52 deg. of latitude, lay downe your oblique
hemispheare according to your latitude as you wont, which let be A B C E D, let C D be Equinoctiall, and let F G be a parallel drawne according to the declination of the 25 deg. of ♈, which let intersect with H I the Horizon at N: I then conclude that I N is the semidurnall arch of ☉ being in the 25 deg. of ♈, which by the 4 I find to be 102 deg. or 6 howers, 48 min. which doubled, so haue you 204 deg. or 13 howeres, 36 mi. the whole diurnall arch, which taken from 360 or 24 howers, so haue you 156 deg. or 10 howers, 24 min. the length of the night: then if you take the length of the night from 24, you leaue the length of the day, and so get Sunne rising and setting, as in the last Chapter.

Then for the semidiurnall arke of the starres, worke in all respects with their parallell of declination as you did with the Sunnes, and you haue your desire; and so shall you find the informed starre vnder the belly of Leo, to agrée very néere with the former.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
The quantity of the longest day of any country giuen, to find the eleuation of the pole, and to distinguish the climats.
div.p:
THe Cosinographicall tables shew that the Ilande called Insula Zirisaea, containeth in latitude,
• r deg. and therfore by the 27, the longest day is 16 2/4 howers, but now imagine that you had but onely the length of the longest day giuen, and were thereby required to deliuer the latitude.

Draw therefore an hemispheare which let be A F D K E, then draw L I the Tropick of Cancer, now the longest day is 16 2/4 howers, halfe that is 8 ¼ howers, the semidiurnall arch, which by the first containes 123 deg. and 3 min. therefore by the 4, I find where the 123 Meridian counted from I curteth the Tropical parallel as at R, or take 90 from 123, so haue you 33; then by the foresaid 4 Chap. find where the 33 Meridian counted from E passeth, by the said Tropick of $, which wil also fall out at R: I conclude by either of the waies, that a right line drawne from A by R to the circumference as to B, is the halfe semihorizon, and C B the whole semihorizon, and that the chord B E is the eleuation of the pole viz. 52 deg.
Now saith Gemma Frifius, if out of the longest day you take 12, and reduce the remainder into quarters of howers, to which adding one, the number or order of the parallell desixed is knowne.

In the Iland before, the longest day was 16 • 0/60 howres, from which take 12, so haue you 4 30/60 howres remaining; which containeth 18 quarters of an howre, to which I adde one, so haue I 19 I then affirme that Insula Zirisaea lyeth vnder the 19 parallell.

Now hauing found the parallel, take thence 3 and halfe the remainder acquaints you the order of climate, as for the purpose, 3 from 19 there remaineth 16, halfe which is 8, which sheweth that they doe inhabite in or vnder the 8 climate.

div.head: CHAP. XXIIII.
To know the Meridian altitude of the Sunne or any starre.
div.p: THe Meridian altitude of the Sun or any star, is the greatest altitude that either of them can haue, & is found thus.

Lay downe an hemispheare according vnto the latitude, and then draw a parallel according to the declination of the Sunne or starre proposed, the chord then that is intercepted betwixt the Horizon and the parallell counted vpon the limbe, is your desire.
The Sunne being in the 0 degré, of $, I would know his Meridian altiude here at London.

Let A B C E D, be your hemisphere, C D the Equinoctiall, O P a parallell drawne according to the declination of the 0 degree of s, H I the Horizon, then do I conclude that the chord O H is your desire, which by the second is found 62 deg.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
To finde the degree of Medium Coeli, or Culmination at any time proposed.

p.hi: The degrees of the Eclipticke any time being in the Meridian, is called Gradus Medii Coeli, with some, Cor Coeli, but most generall, Culmem Coeli, thus had.

div.p:
YOu must séeke the right ascension of the degrée proposed, & then get this distance from the Meridian line in degrées:
then for the forenoone howres, take the distance from the right ascension, adding 360, if othere wise substraction cannot be made, and then make substraction: but for afternoone howres, adde the ascension to the distance, casting away 360. if the whole summe excéede 360; so haue you the right ascension of the culminating, then the deg. of the Zodiack is found by the 13.

I would know the degrée of culmination, the ☉ being in the 0 degrée of $ at thrée a clocke before noone, the right ascension by the 13 is 90 degrées; then I take 45 deg. out of 90, so haue I 45 degrées remaining, the right ascension of the degrée of culmination: then by the 13 may you find the deg. of the Zodiack answering thereunto, forit is but vsing that Chap. Vice versa, so will it be néere the 13 deg. of ♉.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
To know the heigth of the Sunne, euery howre in the yeare aboue the Horizon without the sight thereof, as also to find the Azimuth in any region of the world.
div.p: HAuing laid downe your hemispheare according vnto your latitude, draw then a parallel according vnto L the declination, and find a Meridian cutting the same according to the howre assigned; by which point of intersection, draw an almicanter parallell tothe Horizon, whose distance on the peripher from the Horizon is your desire, then the Azimuth passing by that point also,The figure in the 11 Chapter serueth here. is the verticall circle.
Upon the 10 day of Aprill 1607, I desired the altitude of the Sunne at London, iust at ten of the clocke before noone.

First, I laid downe the hemispheare A B C E D, according to the latitude, C D being the Equinoctiall, B E the North and South pole, H I the Horizon, R the Zenith, then is F G a parallell drawne according vnto the Sunnes declination 11 40/60; deg. next is L a point by the 4, where the 10 of clocke howrely, or 60 Meridian counted from B, passeth by: then is I K an almicanter, drawne by the point L according to the 7 def. the arke of whose distance from the Horizon as I H, is the altitude of the Sunne, 46 12/90; deg, then the Azimuth by the 14 def. passing by L, shew the Azimuth or vetical circle that the
Sunne was in, reckoned from R. which by the 4. I found 47 or there abouts: whereby I might conclude that the Sun was 47 deg. distant from the East into the South.

And by this meanes may you find the points of the compasse, thus, the pointes of the compasse be 32, which deuide by 306, the quotientis 11 8/60; deg. which is one point; then deuide 47 the Azimuth by 11 8/60; deg. the quotient doth yéeld the number of points from the East to be 4, which is Southeast.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
To find the Meridian and foure quarters of the world by the Geodeticall staffe.
div.p: By the last Chap. you shall get the Azimuth of the Sunne, or by the 28; then shall you draw a line to point direct towardes the Sunne, and then protract an angle according vnto to the Azimuth, and that line represents the true Meridian.
And you must note if you worke according to the finding of the Azimuth in the last Chap. you must remember to note this Azimuth counted from the South.

By the last Chap. I found the Sunne was 47 deg. distant from the East, and therefore 43 deg. distant from the Merididian, I draw therefore a line A B to point iust towards the
Sunne, then I protract an angle of 4 • . deg. B A C: I conclude the line A C lieth iust vnder the Meridian.
In like manner may you doe with the legs whithout proing any angle.
And you must note, if the Sunne were East from the Meridian, you must protract the foresaid angle on the right hand: if west on the left.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII.
To find the Azimuth of the Sunne.
div.p: COnsider if the Sunne be on the East or West side the Meridian, if on the East, aply a néedle to the right legge: if on the West, to the left leg, in such forte that the Meridian line in the card vnder the néedle may lye parallell to the legge he is applied vnto: then cause the néedle to stand iust ouer the Meridian in the carde, & open the other leg, vntill the shadow of the sight placed therein agrée with the fidutiall edge of the leg: then note the quantity of the angle, for the distance of the Sunne from the South, or Azimuth of the Sun?

div.head: CHAP. XXIX.
To know what howre the Sunne cometh to any Azimuth proposed.
div.p: DRaw an hemispheare according vnto your latitude, then note what howre line cutteth the proposed Azimuth on the Parallell of declination, and that is your desire,

Let A B C E D, The figure in the 11 Chapter serueth here. be an hemispheare, H I the Horizon, &c. F P a parallel drawne according to the declination 11 deg. 40 mi and let the question be to know when the Sunne cometh vnto the 47 Azimuth: by the 4 find where the 47 Azimuth cutteth F G the parallell of declination, as at L: then by the said 4 sée what Meridian circle passeth by L, reckoned from B E the 6 of clocke Meridian, so shall you find the 60 Meridian; therefore by the first I conclude that the Sunne cometh to the 47 Azimuth according as is said, at the precise howre of 10 of the clocke before noone: for 1 •
the number of degrées in our Horizon is in 60, 4 times; which is 4 howres, & that added to 6, howres maketh 10, as before.

div.head: CHAP. XXX.
Another way most easy and true to know the howre of the day.
div.p: YOu shall obserue by the 28 Chap. or some other way the Azimuth of the Sunne, and then lay downe a •• he are according to the latitude, and draw a parallell according vnto ye declination of the Sunne: note then where the Azimuth and the parallell of the Sunne intersect, for the Meridian passing by sheweth the howre desired.

Lay downe your hemisphe are A B C E D, let H I be the Horizon, F G a parallell drawne according vnto the declination 11 40/60; deg. let the Azimuth by the 28 Chap. be 43 deger. distant from the South which let cut F G at L: The figure in the 11 Chapter serueth here. then by the 4 see what Meridian passeth by that point as by L, which you shall find the 60, reckoned from the 6 of clocke line E; therfore it is 10 before noone, or 2 after noone, but because my obseruation was before noone, it is 10.

I could inlarge this Booke greatly in matters. Astro •• uncall, as to teach you how to erect a figure to find the beginning quantity and duration of Eclipses, to obserue the motion of the star • es, &c. would my occasions affoord me so much time but since I am called away, I will onely teach you how to make some kind of dials, very easy and spéedily, and so then conclude the Booke, with certaine pleasant Cosmo graphicall propositions.

div.trailer: Here ends the first part of the eighth Booke, called Planisphera.

div.head: HOROMANCI, OR THE ART OF DIALLING By the Geodeticall staffe, Containing the making of many, or rather, most Dials, without other helpe.
CHAP. XXXI.
To make an horizontall horoscope or Diall in any oblique Horizon, with the theoricall ground thereof.
div.p:
TO make an Horizontall Diall is no other thing then to find how many be, of the Horizon is contained betwixt euery 15 Meridian, so that euery howre in the Diall doth comprehend 15 Meridians, therefore if the Meridians in the heauen were visible to the eye, if you did but stand on the South part of the Diall, and behold the North, you should sée that the 12 of clocke would iust point to the North part of our common Meridian, & that 11 or one of the clocke would di 〈7 letters〉 your sight to the is Meridian into the East or West, and so 10 or 2 of clocke to the 30, &c. whereupon you may gather, that the lesse the pose is eleuated, the lesse the howres be towards noone, and the greater towards euening, because the Meridians answering to the middest of the day be néerer together, because their distance is taken néere the pole, as concurring at a conunon center: and further distant in the euening, because they point or answere to the Meridians in the middest of the spheare, which are so much the greater by how much the pole is lesse eleuated, by reason of the oblique section of the Horizon. And as I distinguish the howres in any Horizontall Sunne Diall by the number of the Horizontal.
degrées included betwixt enery 15 Meridian, so likewise it shall come all to one passe, if you take the number of Meridians included betwixt the section of euery 15 degrée of the Horizon: the onely difference is, that the axtrée line or 6 of clocke Meridian in this worke, must be the 12 of clocke line.
Let A E C D be an hemisphear • , and let the proposition be to make an Horizontall Diall to the 53 degrée of latitude, which may aptly enough be applied to the latitude of the towne of Shrowsebury.
Let C be the North pole, B the South, F G the Horizon, drawne according to the eleuation 53 degas F C: let H be the • enith, C B the 12 of clocke Meridian,

The first thing then that we be to doe, is to find the distance
betwixt euery 15 deg. vpon the Horizon A F, counting from wards A, which by the 14 def. of the first, is performed by Azimuths, then it is easy by the 3 Chapter at 2 to find, where euery 15 Azimuth cutteth, so shall you find A I to be 15, and there the 15 Azimuth cutteth A K to 30, A L 45, A M 60, A N 75, and A F 90: then are you to counte what number of Meridians counted from A passe by éach of those points, which the 4 Chapter will easily performe, which limits the distance of one howre from another in deg. so shall you find the 12 5/60 Meridian to passe by I, the 24 43/60 by K, the 38 37/60 by L: the 54 3/60 by M, the 71 28/60 by N, and the 90 by F, as is plaine by the pricked lines and the foresaid 4 Chapter: so then haue you found the one quarter of your Diall, by which all the rest is made.

The distance of each howre thus found, the labour then is no more but to describe a blind circle vpon your platte, and then protract each howre by the first Chapter, according to the degrée found, and then to put figures thereunto to signify 1, 2, 3, &c. of the clocke, and solder a gnome according to the eleuation, as hereafter.

Let A B C D be the platte of brasse for your Diall, E the center, whereupon describe a blind circle F G H, and crosse the same with two diameters at right augles, as F G H E: make E H the 12 of clocke marke, and F G the 6 of clocke markes: then protract the one quarter of the Diall, as H F, thus: count the number of Meridians included betwixt F A, in the 1 figure or F S: viz. 12 5/60 deg. from H towards F in the insuing figure, as H K, then draw ye line E K for the 1 of clocke line: next take ye number of Meridians included betwixt A and K, or K R in the first figurs, as 24 43/60 deg. and then protract the angle L E H 24 43/60 deg. so haue you E L the 2 of clocke markernext note the number of Meridians included betwixt A and L in the first figure, or L and Q, viz. 38 • 7/60 degrées, and then from I protract H E M an angle of 38 37/60 degrées, so haue you E M the 3 of clocke marke: do so with M A and N A, as with 54 3/60, and 71 28/60 degrées, so haue you E N and E O, the 4 and 5 of clocke marke, the 6 of clocke is F E.

Now for the howre beyond 6 to 8, F P, and F O be equal, so is F N and F Q, then for the forenoone part of the Diall, make it in all respects like vnto the other, and the howre a like
distant from 12 of clocke, as 1 and 11, 2 and 10, 3 and 9, 4 and 8, &c. and by this meanes I hold you may make a diall as precisely as by any instrument whatsoeuer.

Now for the gnome note the eleuation as 53 degrées, according to which protract an angle of 53 degrées, as I E H: I conclude the tryangle shadowed with lines as I E H, is the true patterne of the cocke or gnome H E, being souldered fast on the Meridian at right angles with the platte.

I could here you teach another way to describe this kind of Dial, but by this instrumet more troublesome, tho haply more agréeing to the ground of Dials, as by the section of euery 15 Meridian with the Horizon, as is remembred in the beginning of the Chap. notwithstanding any man of reasonable capacity
may easily conceiūe the making thereof; but I hold it lesse certaine then this, which is most precise: but howsouer, 〈◊〉 entend not here to aggregate multiplicities.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII.
To make an horoscope Diall to any wall, directly beholding the South, and standing perpendicular.
div.p: SUch a South wal in any country is such an one, whose pole Zenith lieth or pointeth directly to the intersection of the Meridian with the Horizon, or we may terme it to be an Horizon, but all is one: for the making thereof doth not much differ from the former.

Hauing therefore drawne your Horizon F G according to the elenation as in the last Chapter, crosse the same with another line at right angles iust ouer the center, as H I, then make I H the Horizon, and worke in all respects as in the last Chap. for the finding out of the howres.

Hauing made I H the Horizon, working as you were instructed in the last Chapter, you shall find that the 9 10/60 Meridian passeth by H, and so many deg. must the 11, or 1 of clocke marks stand from 12: then procéeding you shall find the 19 • /60 Meridian passe by K K, and so much must the 10 or 2 of clocke line stand from 12: then by LL passeth the 31 2/60 Meridian, by 4 the 46 33/60 Meridian, by 5, 66 Meridian: & so the 6 of clocke H endeth at 90, whereby you may also perce • ue, that in a direct South Diall there can be placed but 12 howres, as 6 before noone, and 6 after noone: therefore hauing found the distance of your howre lines, fall to protract thus.

Let A B C D be a boord, or such like, to make your Diall vpon; vpon the midst of A B, as E, erect a perpendieular E F, & then on L as a center, describe the semicircle A F B: make E F the 12 of clocke line, then in the quadrant A F, protract by the first Chap. an angle of 9 10/60 deg. as F E G, so shall E G be the 〈◊〉 of clocke line: do so to all ye other howres found according as
in the last Chap. so shall F H containe 19 • /60, D F I 31 2/60 deg. F K 46 12/60 deg. F L 60 deg. and F A 90 deg. this side of your Diall made, the other for the after noone is made in the same manner, then put figures thereunto according as in the demonstration.

Now to make a gnomon or still for this Diall, you must take 53 degrées the eleuation of your pole out of 90, so haue you 37 degrées, and then from F protract an angle of 37 deg. as F E M, which is the height of the gonion; and the line E F must alwaies be placed very perpendicularly vpon the wall, and so haue you finished your South Diall: and note that in the former of the 2 figures, the chord C H, is alwaies equall to the height of the cocke in a South Diall.

Now the differences of placing this Dial from the former, is that the ende of the cocke, which pointed into the South in an Horizontall, must lie in the Zenith here in this verticall or South Diall, and hang perpendicular, as is said already.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII.
To make a direct North Diall or horoscope.
div.p: I will not stand vpon circumstances in this place, for this Diall is all one with the last, onely you must turne the side C D which was downewards in the South, to stand vpward, E being the nadir and, F the Zenith: so then shall the cocke behold the North pole, and M E lie parallell to the axtrée line, which of necessity must be in al kind of Dials whatsoeuer: for ye side E M doth alwaies represent the axtrées line about which the Sun is caried, & you may omit ye houre of 11, 10 & 9 before noon, and so likewise of 12 and 3 after noone, because the Sunne cometh into the direct North wall, but onely before 6 in the morning, and after fixe at euening.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIIII.
To make a Diall to a direct East wall, called a verticall horoscope.
div.p:
LEt A B C D be an East wall, whereon draw a perpendicular, then note ye eleuation of your pole for ye country where you make the Diall viz. 53 degrées, which take from 90, so haue you 37 degrées the height of the Equinoctiall: then from
the perpendicular E F draw an arch on the South side the same, and in any place of the perpendicular as G H: next from G protract an angle of 37 degrées as G I, & then draw the line E F which represents the axtrée of the world, and doth lie parallel there with: so is also F E G the true patten of the cock for the South Diall: but to the purpose, from any pointe in the line E F draw a perpendicular as K L: then sée what breadth you will haue your Diall, and accordingly draw another line parallell thereunto as M N, so is your Diall prepared to reeiue declination.

In any place of your diall towards the South end draw a line ouerthwarte the Diall perpendicular to K L, and extend that line beyond the Dial as O P, thē on the point P making P Q ye diameter of a circle, describe a demicircle according as you sée C Q R, then from Q, towards R protract an angle of 15 degrées as Q S, then draw a line from Q by S to cut the line K L, as at S; doe so to euery 15 degrée, in the quadrant Q R extending the lines vntill they make section with K L, so shall Q F be 30 degrées, Q R 45 degrées, &c. and so shall the lines drawne by those number make section with the line K L at S F V W and L, then from S draw a line parallel to O Q for ye 7 of clocke
line, do so from F for the 8 of clocke line, and so likewise from V W and L, for the 9, 10, and 11 of clocke lines: then for 4 and 5 before 6, make those howers equall to 8, and 7 after 6; then putting figures to howres as in the demonstration, the howr • lines be finished.

Now for the cocke of this Diall, he must not be made like to a tryangle, but as a parallellogram like to Q O Y Z, containing the iust height of the semidiameter P Q, he must be placed in the 6 of clocke line at right angles with the wall.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV.
Of an West Diall.
div.p: VVOrke in all respects, according vnto the last Chap. onely this difference there is, that where you placed the 11, 10, 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, of clocke houres before noone, here must you set in their places 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. 7. 8. of clocke houres for the afternoone, because the Sun cometh not into the West vntil after 12.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI.
To make a Diall vnto any right Horizon.
div.p: VVHat a right Horizon is, I haue already shewed in the 7 Chap. and that there be two kinds thereof, viz. Polar and Equinoctial: and in that Chapter I something disagrée from other writers, in calling that an Equinoctiall spheare which is vsed for a spheare Polar, my reason is, because I hold this nomination more proper: not for that it cometh from the most worthiest part as that which is highest, which the Equinoctial is, for that he passeth by the Zenith, but for because the daies & nights there be alwaies equall through the yeare, what declination soeuer the Sun haue: & this circle is called the Equinoctial for no other cause but for that ye Sun being there doth make equall daies and nights through the world, onely that Horizon excepted which they terme the Equinoctiall Horizon: for the Sunne being there in that circle, he beginneth either two depart out of sight, or remaine in sight for halfe the yeare, so that in that Horizon, there is neither equall day or night at any time; and therefore the denomination of ye spheare should séeme vnproper, but howsoeuer.

For a right Horizon where the pole is in the Zenith, which I call a polar Horizon, the making of a Diall thereunto is easy: for if you deuide a circle by your staffe into 24 equall partes, and put a stile perpendicular therein, the labour is finished, onely adding figures to the howres, as the common order is.
But for a Diall where the Equinoctiall is in the Zenith, worke thus.

Let the péece of platte whereon you would make this Diall be A B C D, then make choice of what breadth he shal be as D E, then draw the line E F parallell to D C, and in the middest thereof draw a line squire wise to E F, as G H; make H I the diameter of a circle, and on H as a center describe a demicircle K I L, then take one of the quadrants as I L, and first protract an angle of 15 degrées a I H O, then of 30 as I H P, then of 45 deg. as I H Q, then of 60 degrées as I H R, lastly of 75 as I H S; so haue you denided I L into 6 equal parts: then kéeping arule vpon H, draw a line by S, noting where it cuts the line E F as A F, then draw a line from H by R noting where it cutteth E F as be ore, as at M, do so to Q P O, and the line E F shall be cut at N Z O; then from F to the line B D C draw a line parallell to I G, and that is the 7 of clocke in the morning: doe so from M N Z O, so haue you the 8. 9. 10. and 11. of clocke as in the figure, then the howres afternoone as 1. 2. 3. &c. be all one with the forenoone howres, as is plaine.

Now for the cocke of this Diall, he must stand ouer I G the 12 of clocke line, containing the iust heigth of the semidiameter
I H, as you may well perceiue by the cocke in the Diall, which is shadowed with lines: for your better vnderstanding he must stand perpendicular vpon the platte; and thus farrs of direct Dials.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII.
To take the declination of any wall.
div.p: A Declining wall is such a sur face that doth notdicectly behold the South or North, but bendeth either into the East or West, and is thus found.

Draw a line perpendicular vpon the wall, and in that line stick a stile to make right angles with the said wall, note when the shadow that ye stile yéeldeth is in one line with the perpendicular, and at that instance take the height of the Sunne, and so get by the 26 or 28 Chapter his Azimuth, reckoned from the South, for that is the true declination of the wall.

You shall first by some of the forenamed Chapters get the true Azimuth of the Sunne reckoned from the South, and consider whether it be East or West, then whether the wall be East or West declining from the South: first therefore in East declining walles open the legges vnto a right angle, and apply the right legge (the equall diuisious vpward) vnto the saide wall; then if the shadow of the left sight, agrée with the fidutiall edge of the left legge, the Azimuth of the Sunne is the declination of the wall; but if the shadow doe not agrée, then open or close the left legge vntill the said shadow do agrée, and note the quantity of the angle vpon the legs, and then worke thus.

list.item: 1 If ye angle excéed 90, sustract 90, and note the remainder.

2 If the angle be lesse then 90, take the said angle 〈◊〉 of 90, and note the remainder.
1 If the angle excéed 90, and the Sunne be East from the Meridian, then take the foresaid remainder out of the Suns Azimuth, the remainder is the declination.
2 If the angle be lesse then 60, and the Sunne West from the Meridian, then take the Azimuth out of the foresaid remainder, and that which remaineth is your desire.
3 If the angle be lesse then 90, and the Sunne East, then adde the said remainder to the Azimuth, so haue you the declination:
and these rules be generall for any South wall declining into the East.

p.hi: For walles declining into the West.

div.p: For West walles apply the left legge to the wall, and vse the right as before the left.
First then, if the angle be more then 90, and the Azimuth West, take the foresaid remainder out of the Azimuth.
If the angle belesse then 90, and the Sunne East from the Meridian, take the Azimuth out of the remainder.
But if the Azimuth be West, and the angle lesse then 90, adde the said remainder to the Azimuth of the Sunne: so in all these waies haue you the declination of any South wall declining into the West.
Note for East declining walles betimes in the morning, is good for West late néere Sunne set.

I was to obserue the declination of a wall, bending into the East, I therefore tooke the Azimuth of the Sunne, and found it East from the Meridian 16 deg. then did I apply the right legge vnto the wall as before, and found the angle 110 deg. I take therefore 90 from 110, so is the remainder 20, which I take from 30, and that which remaineth is 10, the declination from the wall, by the first def. of East walles.
Consider if the Sunne decline into the East or West.

If East, apply an néedle vnto the left leg as in the 28 Chap. then apply the right legge vnto the wall, opening the left vntill the néedle stand iust ouer the line in the bottome of the card: then note the quantity of the angle vpon the legges for the declination.

But if the wall decline West, apply the néedle as before vnto the right legge, then apply the left vnto the wall, opening the right vntill the néedle stand ouer his due place, the angle then vpon the legges is the true declination.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII.
To learne the Elenation and Angle of deflection, of any declining wall, by the declination.
div.p:
DRaw asemicircle A B C, then on the center D erect a perpendicular D B, then note the dcelination of the wall,
which by the last Chapter was 10, therfore from B protract a chord B E of 10 deg. & from E to D draw a line E D: then note your latitude which taken from 90, the latitude is 53, which taken from 90 leaueth 37: therefore by the 6 draw a parallell to A C 37 degrées distant as F G, next draw a line so farre from C as E is from B, as I D: now I say, the Ellipsicall line passing by H, counted from E D, is the angle of deflection, which by the 5 is aboute 9 degrées. I could not iudge precisely for wante of an instrment, when I wrote this Chap. then by the 3 Chap. the distance of H from D I is the elenation of the wall, as I K, which by the 6 you shall find néere 36 deg. or thereabouts. I cannot speake precisely, because as I haue said I wante my instrument.

If you desire the ground of this worke, you may reade M. Blagraues 6 Booke, Chap. 16 of his worthy Iewell: for A C is the Equinoctial, B D halfe the axtrée line, E D the Zenith line, D I part of the Horizon.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX.
To take the reclination or inclination of any wall.
div.p: IF the wall recline, apply the left legge to lie parallell with the superficies of the reclining platte, then heaue vp the right leg, vntill he stand perpendicular, which you may eastly try by helpe of a plumbe: note the angle then vpon the legs, for the quantity of the reclination.
The like must you obserue for inclining walles, onely the right legge must hang right downeward towards the ground, which before did stand perpendicular pointing to the Zenith.

div.head: CHAP. XL.
To make a Diall to a South or North inclining or reclining flatte.
div.p: YOu must consider, whether the flatte doe recline or incline, and thereby whether it be North or South: if the flatte incline or recline North, take the reclination from the eleuation: but if it be Southwards, adde the reclination to the eleuation, so haue you the height of the pole aboue that flatte: but it the addition excéed 90, subtract 90: the remainder taken from 90, leaueth the poles eleuation, which had, by the 31 Chapter make a Diall according to the eleuation, which shall serue your flatte.

At this time I will speake no more of Dials, because I haue drawne them into a faire volume by them selues, kéeping it for one of my Mathematicall Flowers, where they be performed diuers waies, as well instrumentally and Arithmetically, as by an easy kind of Mechanicall working: for here my intent was not to enter into the whole Art of Dialling, but onely to shew you some such few propositions, that the staffe easily performed of himselfe.

div.head: CHAP. XLI.
Certaine Cosmographicall notes.
div.p: I mind not here to make ample relation of Cosmography, but onely teach you one or two conclusions: for the better vnderstanding whereof, it were fit that these notes were precisely considered,

1 All places according as they be situate vpon ye earth, haue both longitude and latitude, as the starres haue in heauen, I speake Cosmographically: and so is the earth distinguished into like circles as the heauen is.
2 Latitude on ye earth is no other thing then declination in the heauens, therefore by the 1. def. 6, all circles of latitude lie parallell to the Equinoctiall.
3 Latitude is denominated by the arke of the Meridian or circle of longitude included betwixt the Equinoctiall and the place proposed, so that there is both North & South latitude.
4 Def. North latitude is reckoned from the Equinoctiall towards the North pole, and South towards the South pole.

5 Longitude on the earth, is not taken as Longitude in the heauens, according to the 15 def. of the 1. but longitude of the earth is the distance of any place East from the Ilands called Insulae Fortunatae, which are certaine Ilands situated West from vs at London.
6 The Meridian passing by those Islands is the first deg. of longitude reckoned vpon the Equinoctiall into the East, so that there is both East and West longitude.
7 East longitude continues vntill 180 deg. and West longitude, from 180 vnto 360 compleate.
8 The number of Meridians included betwixt any two places reckoned on the Equinoctiall, is called the difference of longitude.

9 Our late Cosmographers make the first degrée of longitude to take beginning at the Islands of Azores, which is 5 demore West then the fortunate Islands, because then the compasse is found to haue no variation.
10 All townes either haue one longitude, and onely differ in latitude, or one latitude differing in longitude, or else differing both in longitude and latitude.
11 The earth is also deuided by the waters after 4 manners, either it is deuided into an Island, or a Peninsula, or an Isthmus, or a Continent.
12 An Iland is a part of the earth that is inclosed round with waters, as Britannia, Rhodus, Scilia, America, &c.

13 Peninsula called Chersonesus, is neither an absolute Iland nor yet a Continent, and is such a one that is included round with waters, onely some narrow or streight place remaining, such is Cymbrica Chersonesus, or England and Scotland.

14 Isthmus, is a narrow péece of land included betwixt 2 seas, stretching it selfe so out, that you may passe thereby into the Peninsula, as an appendix, knitting the 2 Peninsulaes together, as Northumberland doth England and Scotland; so may you passe from Dania to Cymbrus.
15 A Continent is called all the fixed or solide earth, which is neither Iland, Peninsula, Isthmus, but doth onely cohere and consist of it selfe, such is Bohemia, Saxonia &c.

So thē the men inhabiting in these diuers parts the of earth, haue diuers names according to their shadows, as Amphiscij, Heteroscij, Periscij, and according to the situation, as Antaeci,
Periaeci and Antipodes.
16. Amphiscij, be those thata remaine vnder the Equinoctiall, to whom the Sunne yéeldeth 4 shadows.
17 Heteroscij, be those that dwell vnder either of the temperate Zones, casting their shadowes but one way at noonetide alwaies
18 Periscij, be those that cast their shadowes round about, and such inhabit vnder the poles, according to situation.

19 Antaeci or Anticolae, be such that inhabite vnder one Metidian, and be a like distance from the Equinoctiall, that is, hauing equall latitude but on different sides the Equinoctiall, as if ours be North, theirs is South, and they haue paria tempora, but not pariter.

20 Periaeci or Circumcolae, be they that remaine all vnder 1 Meridian & in 1 latitude, with whom there is all things alike to vs, as times, seasons, &c. onely this difference, when we haue noone, they haue midnight, when we haue night they haue day, our Sunne set is there Sunne rising &c.
21 Antipodes be those that dwell féete to féete with vs diametrically, so that if there be a plumbe let fall through the center of the earth from vs, it should passe to them.

div.head: CHAP. XLII.
To make a mappe of the would, and therein to describe any towne according vnto his t •• e longitude and latitude.
div.p: THis matter is very easily performed by your staffe, first you must repaire to the tables of Apian, or some more late writer, and therein séeke the true longitude and latitude of the towne or city whose place you require, then draw a parallell vnto the Equinoctiall according vnto the latitude, and find where the Meridian or circle of longitude cutteth the said parallel for that is the place of the towne or citty.

I would place London in the hemispheare according to true longitude and latitude, by A • ians Tables I find the latitude of London to containe 52 ½ degrées, which is more then we allow, and the longitude to containe 13 1/3 degr. (wich is lesse then we allow) I make A B C D an hemisphe are, B D the Equinoctiall, C the North pole: then I protract by the 6, a parallel E F 52 ½ degrées distant from A D: now I make the circumference
to be the first Meridian according to the old writers, then doe I find by the 4. where the 13 1/3 Meridian doth cut E F counted from the circumference, which falleth at E the true place of London, as you may perceiue in the figure.
In like manner may you sée Edenburgh, Venice, and Toletum, &c. placed.
Now if you desire hereafter by your staffe to séeke the longitude of any place, the 5 Chapter will teach you, and for latitudes the 6 may suffice.
By this instrument may you most easily find out the distance of places by a demicircle, according as Maister Blundiuell hath set it downe, without the deuiding of the same into 180 degr.

div.head: CHAP. XLIII.
How to know, how one place beareth from another, by the Geodeticall staffe.
div.p:
THe places being giuen which you desire, to know how yt one beareth from the other, you shall first take the place of your abode, which is the place you desire to know how the other beareth from it: then in your mappe finde the next Meridian passing by the same, which had, let fall a perpendicular from the said place of your abode vpon the said néerest Meridian: then crosse the perpendicular with a liue at right angles, in the very place of your abode, which shall represent the Meridian of the saide place, and the perpendicular the latitude: so the one end of the Meridian representeth the North, the other
the South, and the perpendicular on the East side the Meridian the East, and the part on the other side the West: now you are to consider on which side this new found Meridian the other place standeth either East or West, and towards the same draw a demicircle, the one foote of your compasse placed in the very intersection of the lines vpon ye place of your aboad; then vpon the center of this demicircle and the place desired lay a ruler, or extend a thred, which shall cut the demicircle in some point, the chord whereof included betwixt that point and the Meridian, doth shew the number of degrées; and so by allowing 11 ¼ deg. to a rombe, you may easily find what wind ye section made in the demicircle, ye opposite wind therunto is the wind that driueth you vnto the desired place.

And here you haue to note, whether the demicircle were made vpon the East or West side the new found Meridian, if on the East the partes of the compasse be either S E or Northeast, and the contrary for the West: if you desire to worke this proposition by this staffe, you may haue the wind distinguished vpon the legges among the chord diuisions.

G H, is the Meridian in the Map, C the place of your abode, C I the line falling perpendicular vpon the Meridan, F ye place sought how it beareth from C lying Westwards from ye Meridian, N S, S W N, ye semicircle drawne on the West side, F C a line drawn from the one place to ye other A, a place wher ye line cutteth the semicircle A N, the chord measured 45 deg. distant from N the North, to ye West: now A N, 45 deg. reduced into winds, containes 4 windes from the North, which is Northwest, and so doth F beare from C; now the oppositewind to N
W, is SE, which is the wind must driue you from C to F.

I might here adioyne many pleasant & easy waies by this instrument to get the eleuation, as by the declination, almicanter, and Azimuth, or by the declination howre, and almicanter, or by the declination and amplitude, or by the starres that neuer set, or by the starres that set, &c. but since I haue shewed some few waies to that purpose before, I wil here leaue to confound ye reader with varieties, presuming that what is said before, may giue light sufficient to the performing of these and many other waies.

div.trailer: Here ends the eight Bookes of Geodetia.

div.head: A briefe Table of all the Chapters, in these eight bookes of the Geodeticall staffe.

list.head: The first Booke.
list.item: Chap. 1 OF the framing, composing, and quantity of timber required to make the Geodeticall staffe. Fol. 1
Chap. 2 Of the deffinition and vocation of the staffe and his principall partes. 3
Chap. 3 Of the deuision of the vpside of both the legges, together with the one side of the graduator. 5
Chap. 4 To proiect the degree of a circle to 90 vpon the graduator, and vnto 180, vpon the legges. 6
Chap. 5 The order of proiecting the Geometrical quadrant and hypsometricall scale vpon the graduator. 8
Chap. 6 Of the staffe his parts and application. 9
Chap. 7 A needfull proposition to be vnderstood for the performing of the fourth proposition. 13
Chap. 8 The order of proiecting the chord of a circle vpon the lower side of the legs of the Geodetical staffe. 14

list.head: The Chapters contained in the second Booke.
list.item: Chap. 1 THe manner of vsing the Geodeticall Staffe, with the things therein to be considered. 17
Chap. 2 Of English measures, both old and such as be allowed by statute, with the comparing of them together &c. 19

list.head: The Chapters contained in the seauenth Booke.
list.item: 1 Geometricall deffinitions, propositions, and consequences, of lines, angles, and tryangles, &c. 269

2 Hauing giuen you some necessary Geometricall instructions, for the better opening of your vnderstanding, now shal follow Axiomes of Trygonometria it selfe, which chiefly is effected by the rule of
proportion. The first Axiome shall teach what protions shall be in the tryangles or parts thereof, afterwards shall be declared, how those Axiomes may be applied to vse. 272
